children.prevalue: Yes quite livid with brassy edges to the clouds and here and there a white gleam more ghastly than the lurid tinge which as you looked at it you momentarily expected would kindle into blinding lightning

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Did it thunder?
children.prevalue: Did it thunder

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: It muttered distant peals, but the storm did not break till evening, after we had reached our inn    that inn being an isolated house at the foot of a range of mountains.
children.prevalue: It muttered distant peals but the storm did not break till evening after we had reached our inn that inn being an isolated house at the foot of a range of mountains

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Did you watch the clouds come down over the mountains?
children.prevalue: Did you watch the clouds come down over the mountains

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I did. I stood at the window an hour watching them. The hills seemed rolled in a sullen mist, and when the rain fell in whitening sheets, suddenly they were blotted from the prospect; they were washed from the world.
children.prevalue: I did I stood at the window an hour watching them The hills seemed rolled in a sullen mist and when the rain fell in whitening sheets suddenly they were blotted from the prospect they were washed from the world

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I have seen such storms in hilly districts in Yorkshire; and at their riotous climax, while the sky was all cataract, the earth all flood, I have remembered the Deluge.
children.prevalue: I have seen such storms in hilly districts in Yorkshire and at their riotous climax while the sky was all cataract the earth all flood I have remembered the Deluge

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It is singularly reviving after such hurricanes to feel calm return, and from the opening clouds to receive a consolatory gleam, softly testifying that the sun is not quenched.
children.prevalue: It is singularly reviving after such hurricanes to feel calm return and from the opening clouds to receive a consolatory gleam softly testifying that the sun is not quenched

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Miss Keeldar, just stand still now, and look down at Nunnely dale and wood.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar just stand still now and look down at Nunnely dale and wood

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: They both halted on the green brow of the common. They looked down on the deep valley robed in May raiment; on varied meads, some pearled with daisies, and some golden with king  cups. To  day all this young verdure smiled clear in sunlight; transparent emerald and amber gleams played over it. On Nunnwood    the sole remnant of antique British forest in a region whose lowlands were once all silvan chase, as its highlands were breast  deep heather    slept the shadow of a cloud; the distant hills were dappled, the horizon was shaded and tinted like mother  of  pearl; silvery blues, soft purples, evanescent greens and rose  shades, all melting into fleeces of white cloud, pure as azury snow, allured the eye as with a remote glimpse of heaven's foundations. The air blowing on the brow was fresh, and sweet, and bracing.
children.prevalue: They both halted on the green brow of the common They looked down on the deep valley robed in May raiment on varied meads some pearled with daisies and some golden with king cups To day all this young verdure smiled clear in sunlight transparent emerald and amber gleams played over it On Nunnwood the sole remnant of antique British forest in a region whose lowlands were once all silvan chase as its highlands were breast deep heather slept the shadow of a cloud the distant hills were dappled the horizon was shaded and tinted like mother of pearl silvery blues soft purples evanescent greens and rose shades all melting into fleeces of white cloud pure as azury snow allured the eye as with a remote glimpse of heaven s foundations The air blowing on the brow was fresh and sweet and bracing

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Our England is a bonny island, said Shirley, and Yorkshire is one of her bonniest nooks.
children.prevalue: Our England is a bonny island said Shirley and Yorkshire is one of her bonniest nooks

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You are a Yorkshire girl too?
children.prevalue: You are a Yorkshire girl too

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I am    Yorkshire in blood and birth. Five generations of my race sleep under the aisles of Briarfield Church. I drew my first breath in the old black hall behind us.
children.prevalue: I am Yorkshire in blood and birth Five generations of my race sleep under the aisles of Briarfield Church I drew my first breath in the old black hall behind us

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Hereupon Caroline presented her hand, which was accordingly taken and shaken. We are compatriots, said she.
children.prevalue: Hereupon Caroline presented her hand which was accordingly taken and shaken We are compatriots said she

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, agreed Shirley, with a grave nod.
children.prevalue: Yes agreed Shirley with a grave nod

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And that, asked Miss Keeldar, pointing to the forest    that is Nunnwood?
children.prevalue: And that asked Miss Keeldar pointing to the forest that is Nunnwood

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It is.
children.prevalue: It is

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Were you ever there?
children.prevalue: Were you ever there

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Many a time.
children.prevalue: Many a time

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: In the heart of it?
children.prevalue: In the heart of it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What is it like?
children.prevalue: What is it like

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: It is like an encampment of forest sons of Anak. The trees are huge and old. When you stand at their roots, the summits seem in another region. The trunks remain still and firm as pillars, while the boughs sway to every breeze. In the deepest calm their leaves are never quite hushed, and in high wind a flood rushes, a sea thunders above you.
children.prevalue: It is like an encampment of forest sons of Anak The trees are huge and old When you stand at their roots the summits seem in another region The trunks remain still and firm as pillars while the boughs sway to every breeze In the deepest calm their leaves are never quite hushed and in high wind a flood rushes a sea thunders above you

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Was it not one of Robin Hood's haunts?
children.prevalue: Was it not one of Robin Hood s haunts

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, and there are mementos of him still existing. To penetrate into Nunnwood, Miss Keeldar, is to go far back into the dim days of old. Can you see a break in the forest, about the centre?
children.prevalue: Yes and there are mementos of him still existing To penetrate into Nunnwood Miss Keeldar is to go far back into the dim days of old Can you see a break in the forest about the centre

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Yes, distinctly.
children.prevalue: Yes distinctly

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: That break is a dell    a deep, hollow cup, lined with turf as green and short as the sod of this common. The very oldest of the trees, gnarled mighty oaks, crowd about the brink of this dell. In the bottom lie the ruins of a nunnery.
children.prevalue: That break is a dell a deep hollow cup lined with turf as green and short as the sod of this common The very oldest of the trees gnarled mighty oaks crowd about the brink of this dell In the bottom lie the ruins of a nunnery

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: We will go    you and I alone, Caroline    to that wood, early some fine summer morning, and spend a long day there. We can take pencils and sketch  books, and any interesting reading book we like; and of course we shall take something to eat. I have two little baskets, in which Mrs. Gill, my housekeeper, might pack our provisions, and we could each carry our own. It would not tire you too much to walk so far?
children.prevalue: We will go you and I alone Caroline to that wood early some fine summer morning and spend a long day there We can take pencils and sketch books and any interesting reading book we like and of course we shall take something to eat I have two little baskets in which Mrs Gill my housekeeper might pack our provisions and we could each carry our own It would not tire you too much to walk so far

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh no; especially if we rested the whole day in the wood. And I know all the pleasantest spots. I know where we could get nuts in nutting time; I know where wild strawberries abound; I know certain lonely, quite untrodden glades, carpeted with strange mosses, some yellow as if gilded, some a sober gray, some gem  green. I know groups of trees that ravish the eye with their perfect, picture  like effects    rude oak, delicate birch, glossy beech, clustered in contrast; and ash trees stately as Saul, standing isolated; and superannuated wood  giants clad in bright shrouds of ivy. Miss Keeldar, I could guide you.
children.prevalue: Oh no especially if we rested the whole day in the wood And I know all the pleasantest spots I know where we could get nuts in nutting time I know where wild strawberries abound I know certain lonely quite untrodden glades carpeted with strange mosses some yellow as if gilded some a sober gray some gem green I know groups of trees that ravish the eye with their perfect picture like effects rude oak delicate birch glossy beech clustered in contrast and ash trees stately as Saul standing isolated and superannuated wood giants clad in bright shrouds of ivy Miss Keeldar I could guide you

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You would be dull with me alone?
children.prevalue: You would be dull with me alone

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: I should not. I think we should suit; and what third person is there whose presence would not spoil our pleasure?
children.prevalue: I should not I think we should suit and what third person is there whose presence would not spoil our pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Indeed, I know of none about our own ages    no lady at least; and as to gentlemen
children.prevalue: Indeed I know of none about our own ages no lady at least and as to gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: An excursion becomes quite a different thing when there are gentlemen of the party, interrupted Caroline.
children.prevalue: An excursion becomes quite a different thing when there are gentlemen of the party interrupted Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I agree with you    quite a different thing to what we were proposing.
children.prevalue: I agree with you quite a different thing to what we were proposing

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: We were going simply to see the old trees, the old ruins; to pass a day in old times, surrounded by olden silence, and above all by quietude.
children.prevalue: We were going simply to see the old trees the old ruins to pass a day in old times surrounded by olden silence and above all by quietude

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You are right; and the presence of gentlemen dispels the last charm, I think. If they are of the wrong sort, like your Malones, and your young Sykes, and Wynnes, irritation takes the place of serenity. If they are of the right sort, there is still a change; I can hardly tell what change    one easy to feel, difficult to describe.
children.prevalue: You are right and the presence of gentlemen dispels the last charm I think If they are of the wrong sort like your Malones and your young Sykes and Wynnes irritation takes the place of serenity If they are of the right sort there is still a change I can hardly tell what change one easy to feel difficult to describe

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: We forget Nature,   imprimis  .
children.prevalue: We forget Nature imprimis

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And then Nature forgets us, covers her vast calm brow with a dim veil, conceals her face, and withdraws the peaceful joy with which, if we had been content to worship her only, she would have filled our hearts.
children.prevalue: And then Nature forgets us covers her vast calm brow with a dim veil conceals her face and withdraws the peaceful joy with which if we had been content to worship her only she would have filled our hearts

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What does she give us instead?
children.prevalue: What does she give us instead

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: More elation and more anxiety; an excitement that steals the hours away fast, and a trouble that ruffles their course.
children.prevalue: More elation and more anxiety an excitement that steals the hours away fast and a trouble that ruffles their course

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Our power of being happy lies a good deal in ourselves, I believe, remarked Caroline sagely. I have gone to Nunnwood with a large party    all the curates and some other gentry of these parts, together with sundry ladies    and I found the affair insufferably tedious and absurd; and I have gone quite alone, or accompanied but by Fanny, who sat in the woodman's hut and sewed, or talked to the goodwife, while I roamed about and made sketches, or read; and I have enjoyed much happiness of a quiet kind all day long. But that was when I was young    two years ago.
children.prevalue: Our power of being happy lies a good deal in ourselves I believe remarked Caroline sagely I have gone to Nunnwood with a large party all the curates and some other gentry of these parts together with sundry ladies and I found the affair insufferably tedious and absurd and I have gone quite alone or accompanied but by Fanny who sat in the woodman s hut and sewed or talked to the goodwife while I roamed about and made sketches or read and I have enjoyed much happiness of a quiet kind all day long But that was when I was young two years ago

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Did you ever go with your cousin, Robert Moore?
children.prevalue: Did you ever go with your cousin Robert Moore

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Yes; once.
children.prevalue: Yes once

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What sort of a companion is he on these occasions?
children.prevalue: What sort of a companion is he on these occasions

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: A cousin, you know, is different to a stranger.
children.prevalue: A cousin you know is different to a stranger

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I am aware of that; but cousins, if they are stupid, are still more insupportable than strangers, because you cannot so easily keep them at a distance. But your cousin is not stupid?
children.prevalue: I am aware of that but cousins if they are stupid are still more insupportable than strangers because you cannot so easily keep them at a distance But your cousin is not stupid

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: No; but
children.prevalue: No but

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: If the company of fools irritates, as you say, the society of clever men leaves its own peculiar pain also. Where the goodness or talent of your friend is beyond and above all doubt, your own worthiness to be his associate often becomes a matter of question.
children.prevalue: If the company of fools irritates as you say the society of clever men leaves its own peculiar pain also Where the goodness or talent of your friend is beyond and above all doubt your own worthiness to be his associate often becomes a matter of question

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Oh! there I cannot follow you. That crotchet is not one I should choose to entertain for an instant. I consider myself not unworthy to be the associate of the best of them    of gentlemen, I mean    though that is saying a great deal. Where they are good, they are very good, I believe. Your uncle, by  the  bye, is not a bad specimen of the elderly gentleman. I am always glad to see his brown, keen, sensible old face, either in my own house or any other. Are you fond of him? Is he kind to you? Now, speak the truth.
children.prevalue: Oh there I cannot follow you That crotchet is not one I should choose to entertain for an instant I consider myself not unworthy to be the associate of the best of them of gentlemen I mean though that is saying a great deal Where they are good they are very good I believe Your uncle by the bye is not a bad specimen of the elderly gentleman I am always glad to see his brown keen sensible old face either in my own house or any other Are you fond of him Is he kind to you Now speak the truth

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: He has brought me up from childhood, I doubt not, precisely as he would have brought up his own daughter, if he had had one; and that is kindness. But I am not fond of him. I would rather be out of his presence than in it.
children.prevalue: He has brought me up from childhood I doubt not precisely as he would have brought up his own daughter if he had had one and that is kindness But I am not fond of him I would rather be out of his presence than in it

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Strange, when he has the art of making himself so agreeable.
children.prevalue: Strange when he has the art of making himself so agreeable

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes, in company; but he is stern and silent at home. As he puts away his cane and shovel  hat in the rectory hall, so he locks his liveliness in his book  case and study  desk: the knitted brow and brief word for the fireside; the smile, the jest, the witty sally for society.
children.prevalue: Yes in company but he is stern and silent at home As he puts away his cane and shovel hat in the rectory hall so he locks his liveliness in his book case and study desk the knitted brow and brief word for the fireside the smile the jest the witty sally for society

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Is he tyrannical?
children.prevalue: Is he tyrannical

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Not in the least. He is neither tyrannical nor hypocritical. He is simply a man who is rather liberal than good  natured, rather brilliant than genial, rather scrupulously equitable than truly just    if you can understand such superfine distinctions.
children.prevalue: Not in the least He is neither tyrannical nor hypocritical He is simply a man who is rather liberal than good natured rather brilliant than genial rather scrupulously equitable than truly just if you can understand such superfine distinctions

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh yes! Good  nature implies indulgence, which he has not; geniality, warmth of heart, which he does not own; and genuine justice is the offspring of sympathy and considerateness, of which, I can well conceive, my bronzed old friend is quite innocent.
children.prevalue: Oh yes Good nature implies indulgence which he has not geniality warmth of heart which he does not own and genuine justice is the offspring of sympathy and considerateness of which I can well conceive my bronzed old friend is quite innocent

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: I often wonder, Shirley, whether most men resemble my uncle in their domestic relations; whether it is necessary to be new and unfamiliar to them in order to seem agreeable or estimable in their eyes; and whether it is impossible to their natures to retain a constant interest and affection for those they see every day.
children.prevalue: I often wonder Shirley whether most men resemble my uncle in their domestic relations whether it is necessary to be new and unfamiliar to them in order to seem agreeable or estimable in their eyes and whether it is impossible to their natures to retain a constant interest and affection for those they see every day

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I don't know. I can't clear up your doubts. I ponder over similar ones myself sometimes. But, to tell you a secret, if I were convinced that they are necessarily and universally different from us    fickle, soon petrifying, unsympathizing    I would never marry. I should not like to find out that what I loved did not love me, that it was weary of me, and that whatever effort I might make to please would hereafter be worse than useless, since it was inevitably in its nature to change and become indifferent. That discovery once made, what should I long for? To go away, to remove from a presence where my society gave no pleasure.
children.prevalue: I don t know I can t clear up your doubts I ponder over similar ones myself sometimes But to tell you a secret if I were convinced that they are necessarily and universally different from us fickle soon petrifying unsympathizing I would never marry I should not like to find out that what I loved did not love me that it was weary of me and that whatever effort I might make to please would hereafter be worse than useless since it was inevitably in its nature to change and become indifferent That discovery once made what should I long for To go away to remove from a presence where my society gave no pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: But you could not if you were married.
children.prevalue: But you could not if you were married

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: No, I could not. There it is. I could never be my own mistress more. A terrible thought! It suffocates me! Nothing irks me like the idea of being a burden and a bore    an inevitable burden, a ceaseless bore! Now, when I feel my company superfluous, I can comfortably fold my independence round me like a mantle, and drop my pride like a veil, and withdraw to solitude. If married, that could not be.
children.prevalue: No I could not There it is I could never be my own mistress more A terrible thought It suffocates me Nothing irks me like the idea of being a burden and a bore an inevitable burden a ceaseless bore Now when I feel my company superfluous I can comfortably fold my independence round me like a mantle and drop my pride like a veil and withdraw to solitude If married that could not be

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I wonder we don't all make up our minds to remain single, said Caroline. We should if we listened to the wisdom of experience. My uncle always speaks of marriage as a burden; and I believe whenever he hears of a man being married he invariably regards him as a fool, or, at any rate, as doing a foolish thing.
children.prevalue: I wonder we don t all make up our minds to remain single said Caroline We should if we listened to the wisdom of experience My uncle always speaks of marriage as a burden and I believe whenever he hears of a man being married he invariably regards him as a fool or at any rate as doing a foolish thing

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: But, Caroline, men are not all like your uncle. Surely not. I hope not.
children.prevalue: But Caroline men are not all like your uncle Surely not I hope not

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: She paused and mused.
children.prevalue: She paused and mused

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I suppose we each find an exception in the one we love, till we   are   married, suggested Caroline.
children.prevalue: I suppose we each find an exception in the one we love till we are married suggested Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I suppose so. And this exception we believe to be of sterling materials. We fancy it like ourselves; we imagine a sense of harmony. We think his voice gives the softest, truest promise of a heart that will never harden against us; we read in his eyes that faithful feeling    affection. I don't think we should trust to what they call passion at all, Caroline. I believe it is a mere fire of dry sticks, blazing up and vanishing. But we watch him, and see him kind to animals, to little children, to poor people. He is kind to us likewise, good, considerate. He does not flatter women, but he is patient with them, and he seems to be easy in their presence, and to find their company genial. He likes them not only for vain and selfish reasons, but as   we   like him    because we like him. Then we observe that he is just, that he always speaks the truth, that he is conscientious. We feel joy and peace when he comes into a room; we feel sadness and trouble when he leaves it. We know that this man has been a kind son, that he is a kind brother. Will any one dare to tell me that he will not be a kind husband?
children.prevalue: I suppose so And this exception we believe to be of sterling materials We fancy it like ourselves we imagine a sense of harmony We think his voice gives the softest truest promise of a heart that will never harden against us we read in his eyes that faithful feeling affection I don t think we should trust to what they call passion at all Caroline I believe it is a mere fire of dry sticks blazing up and vanishing But we watch him and see him kind to animals to little children to poor people He is kind to us likewise good considerate He does not flatter women but he is patient with them and he seems to be easy in their presence and to find their company genial He likes them not only for vain and selfish reasons but as we like him because we like him Then we observe that he is just that he always speaks the truth that he is conscientious We feel joy and peace when he comes into a room we feel sadness and trouble when he leaves it We know that this man has been a kind son that he is a kind brother Will any one dare to tell me that he will not be a kind husband

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: My uncle would affirm it unhesitatingly. 'He will be sick of you in a month,' he would say.
children.prevalue: My uncle would affirm it unhesitatingly He will be sick of you in a month he would say

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Mrs. Pryor would seriously intimate the same.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor would seriously intimate the same

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Mrs. Yorke and Miss Mann would darkly suggest ditto.
children.prevalue: Mrs Yorke and Miss Mann would darkly suggest ditto

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: If they are true oracles, it is good never to fall in love.
children.prevalue: If they are true oracles it is good never to fall in love

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Very good, if you can avoid it.
children.prevalue: Very good if you can avoid it

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: I choose to doubt their truth.
children.prevalue: I choose to doubt their truth

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: I am afraid that proves you are already caught.
children.prevalue: I am afraid that proves you are already caught

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Not I. But if I were, do you know what soothsayers I would consult?
children.prevalue: Not I But if I were do you know what soothsayers I would consult

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Let me hear.
children.prevalue: Let me hear

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Neither man nor woman, elderly nor young: the little Irish beggar that comes barefoot to my door; the mouse that steals out of the cranny in the wainscot; the bird that in frost and snow pecks at my window for a crumb; the dog that licks my hand and sits beside my knee.
children.prevalue: Neither man nor woman elderly nor young the little Irish beggar that comes barefoot to my door the mouse that steals out of the cranny in the wainscot the bird that in frost and snow pecks at my window for a crumb the dog that licks my hand and sits beside my knee

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Did you ever see any one who was kind to such things?
children.prevalue: Did you ever see any one who was kind to such things

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Did you ever see any one whom such things seemed instinctively to follow, like, rely on?
children.prevalue: Did you ever see any one whom such things seemed instinctively to follow like rely on

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: We have a black cat and an old dog at the rectory. I know somebody to whose knee that black cat loves to climb, against whose shoulder and cheek it likes to purr. The old dog always comes out of his kennel and wags his tail, and whines affectionately when somebody passes.
children.prevalue: We have a black cat and an old dog at the rectory I know somebody to whose knee that black cat loves to climb against whose shoulder and cheek it likes to purr The old dog always comes out of his kennel and wags his tail and whines affectionately when somebody passes

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And what does that somebody do?
children.prevalue: And what does that somebody do

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: He quietly strokes the cat, and lets her sit while he conveniently can; and when he must disturb her by rising, he puts her softly down, and never flings her from him roughly. He always whistles to the dog and gives him a caress.
children.prevalue: He quietly strokes the cat and lets her sit while he conveniently can and when he must disturb her by rising he puts her softly down and never flings her from him roughly He always whistles to the dog and gives him a caress

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Does he? It is not Robert?
children.prevalue: Does he It is not Robert

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: But it is Robert.
children.prevalue: But it is Robert

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Handsome fellow! said Shirley, with enthusiasm. Her eyes sparkled.
children.prevalue: Handsome fellow said Shirley with enthusiasm Her eyes sparkled

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Is he not handsome? Has he not fine eyes and well  cut features, and a clear, princely forehead?
children.prevalue: Is he not handsome Has he not fine eyes and well cut features and a clear princely forehead

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: He has all that, Caroline. Bless him! he is both graceful and good.
children.prevalue: He has all that Caroline Bless him he is both graceful and good

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I was sure you would see that he was. When I first looked at your face I knew you would.
children.prevalue: I was sure you would see that he was When I first looked at your face I knew you would

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I was well inclined to him before I saw him. I liked him when I did see him. I admire him now. There is charm in beauty for itself, Caroline; when it is blent with goodness, there is a powerful charm.
children.prevalue: I was well inclined to him before I saw him I liked him when I did see him I admire him now There is charm in beauty for itself Caroline when it is blent with goodness there is a powerful charm

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: When mind is added, Shirley?
children.prevalue: When mind is added Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Who can resist it?
children.prevalue: Who can resist it

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Remember my uncle, Mesdames Pryor, Yorke, and Mann.
children.prevalue: Remember my uncle Mesdames Pryor Yorke and Mann

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Remember the croaking of the frogs of Egypt. He is a noble being. I tell you when they   are   good they are the lords of the creation    they are the sons of God. Moulded in their Maker's image, the minutest spark of His spirit lifts them almost above mortality. Indisputably, a great, good, handsome man is the first of created things.
children.prevalue: Remember the croaking of the frogs of Egypt He is a noble being I tell you when they are good they are the lords of the creation they are the sons of God Moulded in their Maker s image the minutest spark of His spirit lifts them almost above mortality Indisputably a great good handsome man is the first of created things

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Above us?
children.prevalue: Above us

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: I would scorn to contend for empire with him    I would scorn it. Shall my left hand dispute for precedence with my right? Shall my heart quarrel with my pulse? Shall my veins be jealous of the blood which fills them?
children.prevalue: I would scorn to contend for empire with him I would scorn it Shall my left hand dispute for precedence with my right Shall my heart quarrel with my pulse Shall my veins be jealous of the blood which fills them

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Men and women, husbands and wives, quarrel horribly, Shirley.
children.prevalue: Men and women husbands and wives quarrel horribly Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Poor things! Poor, fallen, degenerate things! God made them for another lot, for other feelings.
children.prevalue: Poor things Poor fallen degenerate things God made them for another lot for other feelings

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: But are we men's equals, or are we not?
children.prevalue: But are we men s equals or are we not

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Nothing ever charms me more than when I meet my superior    one who makes me sincerely feel that he is my superior.
children.prevalue: Nothing ever charms me more than when I meet my superior one who makes me sincerely feel that he is my superior

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Did you ever meet him?
children.prevalue: Did you ever meet him

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I should be glad to see him any day. The higher above me, so much the better. It degrades to stoop; it is glorious to look up. What frets me is, that when I try to esteem, I am baffled; when religiously inclined, there are but false gods to adore. I disdain to be a pagan.
children.prevalue: I should be glad to see him any day The higher above me so much the better It degrades to stoop it is glorious to look up What frets me is that when I try to esteem I am baffled when religiously inclined there are but false gods to adore I disdain to be a pagan

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Miss Keeldar, will you come in? We are here at the rectory gates.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar will you come in We are here at the rectory gates

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Not to  day, but to  morrow I shall fetch you to spend the evening with me. Caroline Helstone, if you really are what at present to me you seem, you and I will suit. I have never in my whole life been able to talk to a young lady as I have talked to you this morning. Kiss me    and good  bye.
children.prevalue: Not to day but to morrow I shall fetch you to spend the evening with me Caroline Helstone if you really are what at present to me you seem you and I will suit I have never in my whole life been able to talk to a young lady as I have talked to you this morning Kiss me and good bye

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Mrs. Pryor seemed as well disposed to cultivate Caroline's acquaintance as Shirley. She, who went nowhere else, called on an early day at the rectory. She came in the afternoon, when the rector happened to be out. It was rather a close day; the heat of the weather had flushed her, and she seemed fluttered too by the circumstance of entering a strange house, for it appeared her habits were most retiring and secluded. When Miss Helstone went to her in the dining  room she found her seated on the sofa, trembling, fanning herself with her handkerchief, and seeming to contend with a nervous discomposure that threatened to become hysterical.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor seemed as well disposed to cultivate Caroline s acquaintance as Shirley She who went nowhere else called on an early day at the rectory She came in the afternoon when the rector happened to be out It was rather a close day the heat of the weather had flushed her and she seemed fluttered too by the circumstance of entering a strange house for it appeared her habits were most retiring and secluded When Miss Helstone went to her in the dining room she found her seated on the sofa trembling fanning herself with her handkerchief and seeming to contend with a nervous discomposure that threatened to become hysterical

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Caroline marvelled somewhat at this unusual want of self  command in a lady of her years, and also at the lack of real strength in one who appeared almost robust    for Mrs. Pryor hastened to allege the fatigue of her walk, the heat of the sun, etc., as reasons for her temporary indisposition; and still as, with more hurry than coherence, she again and again enumerated these causes of exhaustion, Caroline gently sought to relieve her by opening her shawl and removing her bonnet. Attentions of this sort Mrs. Pryor would not have accepted from every one. In general she recoiled from touch or close approach with a mixture of embarrassment and coldness far from flattering to those who offered her aid. To Miss Helstone's little light hand, however, she yielded tractably, and seemed soothed by its contact. In a few minutes she ceased to tremble, and grew quiet and tranquil.
children.prevalue: Caroline marvelled somewhat at this unusual want of self command in a lady of her years and also at the lack of real strength in one who appeared almost robust for Mrs Pryor hastened to allege the fatigue of her walk the heat of the sun etc as reasons for her temporary indisposition and still as with more hurry than coherence she again and again enumerated these causes of exhaustion Caroline gently sought to relieve her by opening her shawl and removing her bonnet Attentions of this sort Mrs Pryor would not have accepted from every one In general she recoiled from touch or close approach with a mixture of embarrassment and coldness far from flattering to those who offered her aid To Miss Helstone s little light hand however she yielded tractably and seemed soothed by its contact In a few minutes she ceased to tremble and grew quiet and tranquil

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Her usual manner being resumed, she proceeded to talk of ordinary topics. In a miscellaneous company Mrs. Pryor rarely opened her lips, or, if obliged to speak, she spoke under restraint, and consequently not well; in dialogue she was a good converser. Her language, always a little formal, was well chosen; her sentiments were just; her information was varied and correct. Caroline felt it pleasant to listen to her, more pleasant than she could have anticipated.
children.prevalue: Her usual manner being resumed she proceeded to talk of ordinary topics In a miscellaneous company Mrs Pryor rarely opened her lips or if obliged to speak she spoke under restraint and consequently not well in dialogue she was a good converser Her language always a little formal was well chosen her sentiments were just her information was varied and correct Caroline felt it pleasant to listen to her more pleasant than she could have anticipated

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: On the wall opposite the sofa where they sat hung three pictures    the centre one, above the mantelpiece, that of a lady; the two others, male portraits.
children.prevalue: On the wall opposite the sofa where they sat hung three pictures the centre one above the mantelpiece that of a lady the two others male portraits

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: That is a beautiful face, said Mrs. Pryor, interrupting a brief pause which had followed half an hour's animated conversation. The features may be termed perfect; no statuary's chisel could improve them. It is a portrait from the life, I presume?
children.prevalue: That is a beautiful face said Mrs Pryor interrupting a brief pause which had followed half an hour s animated conversation The features may be termed perfect no statuary s chisel could improve them It is a portrait from the life I presume

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: It is a portrait of Mrs. Helstone.
children.prevalue: It is a portrait of Mrs Helstone

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Of Mrs. Matthewson Helstone? Of your uncle's wife?
children.prevalue: Of Mrs Matthewson Helstone Of your uncle s wife

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: It is, and is said to be a good likeness. Before her marriage she was accounted the beauty of the district.
children.prevalue: It is and is said to be a good likeness Before her marriage she was accounted the beauty of the district

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: I should say she merited the distinction. What accuracy in all the lineaments! It is, however, a passive face. The original could not have been what is generally termed 'a woman of spirit.'
children.prevalue: I should say she merited the distinction What accuracy in all the lineaments It is however a passive face The original could not have been what is generally termed a woman of spirit

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: I believe she was a remarkably still, silent person.
children.prevalue: I believe she was a remarkably still silent person

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: One would scarcely have expected, my dear, that your uncle's choice should have fallen on a partner of that description. Is he not fond of being amused by lively chat?
children.prevalue: One would scarcely have expected my dear that your uncle s choice should have fallen on a partner of that description Is he not fond of being amused by lively chat

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: In company he is. But he always says he could never do with a talking wife. He must have quiet at home. You go out to gossip, he affirms; you come home to read and reflect.
children.prevalue: In company he is But he always says he could never do with a talking wife He must have quiet at home You go out to gossip he affirms you come home to read and reflect

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Mrs. Matthewson lived but a few years after her marriage, I think I have heard?
children.prevalue: Mrs Matthewson lived but a few years after her marriage I think I have heard

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: About five years.
children.prevalue: About five years

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Well, my dear, pursued Mrs. Pryor, rising to go, I trust it is understood that you will frequently come to Fieldhead. I hope you will. You must feel lonely here, having no female relative in the house; you must necessarily pass much of your time in solitude.
children.prevalue: Well my dear pursued Mrs Pryor rising to go I trust it is understood that you will frequently come to Fieldhead I hope you will You must feel lonely here having no female relative in the house you must necessarily pass much of your time in solitude

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: I am inured to it. I have grown up by myself. May I arrange your shawl for you?
children.prevalue: I am inured to it I have grown up by myself May I arrange your shawl for you

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Mrs. Pryor submitted to be assisted.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor submitted to be assisted

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Should you chance to require help in your studies, she said, you may command me.
children.prevalue: Should you chance to require help in your studies she said you may command me

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Caroline expressed her sense of such kindness.
children.prevalue: Caroline expressed her sense of such kindness

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: I hope to have frequent conversations with you. I should wish to be of use to you.
children.prevalue: I hope to have frequent conversations with you I should wish to be of use to you

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Again Miss Helstone returned thanks. She thought what a kind heart was hidden under her visitor's seeming chilliness. Observing that Mrs. Pryor again glanced with an air of interest towards the portraits, as she walked down the room, Caroline casually explained: The likeness that hangs near the window, you will see, is my uncle, taken twenty years ago; the other, to the left of the mantelpiece, is his brother James, my father.
children.prevalue: Again Miss Helstone returned thanks She thought what a kind heart was hidden under her visitor s seeming chilliness Observing that Mrs Pryor again glanced with an air of interest towards the portraits as she walked down the room Caroline casually explained The likeness that hangs near the window you will see is my uncle taken twenty years ago the other to the left of the mantelpiece is his brother James my father

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: They resemble each other in some measure, said Mrs. Pryor; yet a difference of character may be traced in the different mould of the brow and mouth.
children.prevalue: They resemble each other in some measure said Mrs Pryor yet a difference of character may be traced in the different mould of the brow and mouth

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: What difference? inquired Caroline, accompanying her to the door. James Helstone    that is, my father    is generally considered the best  looking of the two. Strangers, I remark, always exclaim, 'What a handsome man!' Do you think his picture handsome, Mrs. Pryor?
children.prevalue: What difference inquired Caroline accompanying her to the door James Helstone that is my father is generally considered the best looking of the two Strangers I remark always exclaim What a handsome man Do you think his picture handsome Mrs Pryor

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: It is much softer or finer featured than that of your uncle.
children.prevalue: It is much softer or finer featured than that of your uncle

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: But where or what is the difference of character to which you alluded? Tell me. I wish to see if you guess right.
children.prevalue: But where or what is the difference of character to which you alluded Tell me I wish to see if you guess right

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: My dear, your uncle is a man of principle. His forehead and his lips are firm, and his eye is steady.
children.prevalue: My dear your uncle is a man of principle His forehead and his lips are firm and his eye is steady

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Well, and the other? Do not be afraid of offending me. I always like the truth.
children.prevalue: Well and the other Do not be afraid of offending me I always like the truth

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Do you like the truth? It is well for you. Adhere to that preference    never swerve thence. The other, my dear, if he had been living now, would probably have furnished little support to his daughter. It is, however, a graceful head    taken in youth, I should think. My dear (turning abruptly), you acknowledge an inestimable value in principle?
children.prevalue: Do you like the truth It is well for you Adhere to that preference never swerve thence The other my dear if he had been living now would probably have furnished little support to his daughter It is however a graceful head taken in youth I should think My dear turning abruptly you acknowledge an inestimable value in principle

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: I am sure no character can have true worth without it.
children.prevalue: I am sure no character can have true worth without it

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: You feel what you say? You have considered the subject?
children.prevalue: You feel what you say You have considered the subject

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: Often. Circumstances early forced it upon my attention.
children.prevalue: Often Circumstances early forced it upon my attention

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: The lesson was not lost, then, though it came so prematurely. I suppose the soil is not light nor stony, otherwise seed falling in that season never would have borne fruit. My dear, do not stand in the air of the door; you will take cold. Good  afternoon.
children.prevalue: The lesson was not lost then though it came so prematurely I suppose the soil is not light nor stony otherwise seed falling in that season never would have borne fruit My dear do not stand in the air of the door you will take cold Good afternoon

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: Miss Helstone's new acquaintance soon became of value to her: their society was acknowledged a privilege. She found she would have been in error indeed to have let slip this chance of relief, to have neglected to avail herself of this happy change. A turn was thereby given to her thoughts; a new channel was opened for them, which, diverting a few of them at least from the one direction in which all had hitherto tended, abated the impetuosity of their rush, and lessened the force of their pressure on one worn  down point.
children.prevalue: Miss Helstone s new acquaintance soon became of value to her their society was acknowledged a privilege She found she would have been in error indeed to have let slip this chance of relief to have neglected to avail herself of this happy change A turn was thereby given to her thoughts a new channel was opened for them which diverting a few of them at least from the one direction in which all had hitherto tended abated the impetuosity of their rush and lessened the force of their pressure on one worn down point

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: Soon she was content to spend whole days at Fieldhead, doing by turns whatever Shirley or Mrs. Pryor wished her to do; and now one would claim her, now the other. Nothing could be less demonstrative than the friendship of the elder lady, but also nothing could be more vigilant, assiduous, untiring. I have intimated that she was a peculiar personage, and in nothing was her peculiarity more shown than in the nature of the interest she evinced for Caroline. She watched all her movements; she seemed as if she would have guarded all her steps. It gave her pleasure to be applied to by Miss Helstone for advice and assistance. She yielded her aid, when asked, with such quiet yet obvious enjoyment that Caroline ere long took delight in depending on her.
children.prevalue: Soon she was content to spend whole days at Fieldhead doing by turns whatever Shirley or Mrs Pryor wished her to do and now one would claim her now the other Nothing could be less demonstrative than the friendship of the elder lady but also nothing could be more vigilant assiduous untiring I have intimated that she was a peculiar personage and in nothing was her peculiarity more shown than in the nature of the interest she evinced for Caroline She watched all her movements she seemed as if she would have guarded all her steps It gave her pleasure to be applied to by Miss Helstone for advice and assistance She yielded her aid when asked with such quiet yet obvious enjoyment that Caroline ere long took delight in depending on her

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Shirley Keeldar's complete docility with Mrs. Pryor had at first surprised Miss Helstone, and not less the fact of the reserved ex  governess being so much at home and at ease in the residence of her young pupil, where she filled with such quiet independency a very dependent post; but she soon found that it needed but to know both ladies to comprehend fully the enigma. Every one, it seemed to her, must like, must love, must prize Mrs. Pryor when they knew her. No matter that she perseveringly wore old  fashioned gowns; that her speech was formal and her manner cool; that she had twenty little ways such as nobody else had: she was still such a stay, such a counsellor, so truthful, so kind in her way, that, in Caroline's idea, none once accustomed to her presence could easily afford to dispense with it.
children.prevalue: Shirley Keeldar s complete docility with Mrs Pryor had at first surprised Miss Helstone and not less the fact of the reserved ex governess being so much at home and at ease in the residence of her young pupil where she filled with such quiet independency a very dependent post but she soon found that it needed but to know both ladies to comprehend fully the enigma Every one it seemed to her must like must love must prize Mrs Pryor when they knew her No matter that she perseveringly wore old fashioned gowns that her speech was formal and her manner cool that she had twenty little ways such as nobody else had she was still such a stay such a counsellor so truthful so kind in her way that in Caroline s idea none once accustomed to her presence could easily afford to dispense with it

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: As to dependency or humiliation, Caroline did not feel it in her intercourse with Shirley, and why should Mrs. Pryor? The heiress was rich    very rich    compared with her new friend: one possessed a clear thousand a year, the other not a penny; and yet there was a safe sense of equality experienced in her society, never known in that of the ordinary Briarfield and Whinbury gentry.
children.prevalue: As to dependency or humiliation Caroline did not feel it in her intercourse with Shirley and why should Mrs Pryor The heiress was rich very rich compared with her new friend one possessed a clear thousand a year the other not a penny and yet there was a safe sense of equality experienced in her society never known in that of the ordinary Briarfield and Whinbury gentry

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: The reason was, Shirley's head ran on other things than money and position. She was glad to be independent as to property; by fits she was even elated at the notion of being lady of the manor, and having tenants and an estate. She was especially tickled with an agreeable complacency when reminded of all that property down in the Hollow, comprising an excellent cloth  mill, dyehouse, warehouse, together with the messuage, gardens, and outbuildings, termed Hollow's Cottage; but her exultation being quite undisguised was singularly inoffensive; and, for her serious thoughts, they tended elsewhere. To admire the great, reverence the good, and be joyous with the genial, was very much the bent of Shirley's soul: she mused, therefore, on the means of following this bent far oftener than she pondered on her social superiority.
children.prevalue: The reason was Shirley s head ran on other things than money and position She was glad to be independent as to property by fits she was even elated at the notion of being lady of the manor and having tenants and an estate She was especially tickled with an agreeable complacency when reminded of all that property down in the Hollow comprising an excellent cloth mill dyehouse warehouse together with the messuage gardens and outbuildings termed Hollow s Cottage but her exultation being quite undisguised was singularly inoffensive and for her serious thoughts they tended elsewhere To admire the great reverence the good and be joyous with the genial was very much the bent of Shirley s soul she mused therefore on the means of following this bent far oftener than she pondered on her social superiority

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: In Caroline Miss Keeldar had first taken an interest because she was quiet, retiring, looked delicate, and seemed as if she needed some one to take care of her. Her predilection increased greatly when she discovered that her own way of thinking and talking was understood and responded to by this new acquaintance. She had hardly expected it. Miss Helstone, she fancied, had too pretty a face, manners and voice too soft, to be anything out of the common way in mind and attainments; and she very much wondered to see the gentle features light up archly to the reveille of a dry sally or two risked by herself; and more did she wonder to discover the self  won knowledge treasured, and the untaught speculations working in that girlish, curl  veiled head. Caroline's instinct of taste, too, was like her own. Such books as Miss Keeldar had read with the most pleasure were Miss Helstone's delight also. They held many aversions too in common, and could have the comfort of laughing together over works of false sentimentality and pompous pretension.
children.prevalue: In Caroline Miss Keeldar had first taken an interest because she was quiet retiring looked delicate and seemed as if she needed some one to take care of her Her predilection increased greatly when she discovered that her own way of thinking and talking was understood and responded to by this new acquaintance She had hardly expected it Miss Helstone she fancied had too pretty a face manners and voice too soft to be anything out of the common way in mind and attainments and she very much wondered to see the gentle features light up archly to the reveille of a dry sally or two risked by herself and more did she wonder to discover the self won knowledge treasured and the untaught speculations working in that girlish curl veiled head Caroline s instinct of taste too was like her own Such books as Miss Keeldar had read with the most pleasure were Miss Helstone s delight also They held many aversions too in common and could have the comfort of laughing together over works of false sentimentality and pompous pretension

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: Few, Shirley conceived, men or women have the right taste in poetry, the right sense for discriminating between what is real and what is false. She had again and again heard very clever people pronounce this or that passage, in this or that versifier, altogether admirable, which, when she read, her soul refused to acknowledge as anything but cant, flourish, and tinsel, or at the best elaborate wordiness, curious, clever, learned, perhaps, haply even tinged with the fascinating hues of fancy, but, God knows, as different from real poetry as the gorgeous and massy vase of mosaic is from the little cup of pure metal; or, to give the reader a choice of similes, as the milliner's artificial wreath is from the fresh  gathered lily of the field.
children.prevalue: Few Shirley conceived men or women have the right taste in poetry the right sense for discriminating between what is real and what is false She had again and again heard very clever people pronounce this or that passage in this or that versifier altogether admirable which when she read her soul refused to acknowledge as anything but cant flourish and tinsel or at the best elaborate wordiness curious clever learned perhaps haply even tinged with the fascinating hues of fancy but God knows as different from real poetry as the gorgeous and massy vase of mosaic is from the little cup of pure metal or to give the reader a choice of similes as the milliner s artificial wreath is from the fresh gathered lily of the field

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: Caroline, she found, felt the value of the true ore, and knew the deception of the flashy dross. The minds of the two girls being toned in harmony often chimed very sweetly together.
children.prevalue: Caroline she found felt the value of the true ore and knew the deception of the flashy dross The minds of the two girls being toned in harmony often chimed very sweetly together

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: One evening they chanced to be alone in the oak  parlour. They had passed a long wet day together without   ennui  . It was now on the edge of dark; candles were not yet brought in; both, as twilight deepened, grew meditative and silent. A western wind roared high round the hall, driving wild clouds and stormy rain up from the far  remote ocean; all was tempest outside the antique lattices, all deep peace within. Shirley sat at the window, watching the rack in heaven, the mist on earth, listening to certain notes of the gale that plained like restless spirits    notes which, had she not been so young, gay, and healthy, would have swept her trembling nerves like some omen, some anticipatory dirge. In this her prime of existence and bloom of beauty they but subdued vivacity to pensiveness. Snatches of sweet ballads haunted her ear; now and then she sang a stanza. Her accents obeyed the fitful impulse of the wind; they swelled as its gusts rushed on, and died as they wandered away. Caroline, withdrawn to the farthest and darkest end of the room, her figure just discernible by the ruby shine of the flameless fire, was pacing to and fro, muttering to herself fragments of well  remembered poetry. She spoke very low, but Shirley heard her; and while singing softly, she listened. This was the strain:

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Obscurest night involved the sky,        The Atlantic billows roared,      When such a destined wretch as I,        Washed headlong from on board,      Of friends, of hope, of all bereft,      His floating home for ever left.
children.prevalue: Obscurest night involved the sky The Atlantic billows roared When such a destined wretch as I Washed headlong from on board Of friends of hope of all bereft His floating home for ever left

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: Here the fragment stopped, because Shirley's song, erewhile somewhat full and thrilling, had become delicately faint.
children.prevalue: Here the fragment stopped because Shirley s song erewhile somewhat full and thrilling had become delicately faint

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: Go on, said she.
children.prevalue: Go on said she

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: Then you go on too. I was only repeating 'The Castaway.'
children.prevalue: Then you go on too I was only repeating The Castaway

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: I know. If you can remember it all, say it all.
children.prevalue: I know If you can remember it all say it all

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: And as it was nearly dark, and, after all, Miss Keeldar was no formidable auditor, Caroline went through it. She went through it as she should have gone through it. The wild sea, the drowning mariner, the reluctant ship swept on in the storm, you heard were realized by her; and more vividly was realized the heart of the poet, who did not weep for The Castaway, but who, in an hour of tearless anguish, traced a semblance to his own God  abandoned misery in the fate of that man  forsaken sailor, and cried from the depths where he struggled,
children.prevalue: And as it was nearly dark and after all Miss Keeldar was no formidable auditor Caroline went through it She went through it as she should have gone through it The wild sea the drowning mariner the reluctant ship swept on in the storm you heard were realized by her and more vividly was realized the heart of the poet who did not weep for The Castaway but who in an hour of tearless anguish traced a semblance to his own God abandoned misery in the fate of that man forsaken sailor and cried from the depths where he struggled

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: No voice divine the storm allayed,        No light propitious shone,      When, snatched from all effectual aid,        We perished    each alone!      But I beneath a rougher sea,      And whelmed in deeper gulfs than he.
children.prevalue: No voice divine the storm allayed No light propitious shone When snatched from all effectual aid We perished each alone But I beneath a rougher sea And whelmed in deeper gulfs than he

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: I hope William Cowper is safe and calm in heaven now, said Caroline.
children.prevalue: I hope William Cowper is safe and calm in heaven now said Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: Do you pity what he suffered on earth? asked Miss Keeldar.
children.prevalue: Do you pity what he suffered on earth asked Miss Keeldar

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: Pity him, Shirley? What can I do else? He was nearly broken  hearted when he wrote that poem, and it almost breaks one's heart to read it. But he found relief in writing it    I know he did; and that gift of poetry    the most divine bestowed on man    was, I believe, granted to allay emotions when their strength threatens harm. It seems to me, Shirley, that nobody should write poetry to exhibit intellect or attainment. Who cares for that sort of poetry? Who cares for learning    who cares for fine words in poetry? And who does not care for feeling    real feeling    however simply, even rudely expressed?
children.prevalue: Pity him Shirley What can I do else He was nearly broken hearted when he wrote that poem and it almost breaks one s heart to read it But he found relief in writing it I know he did and that gift of poetry the most divine bestowed on man was I believe granted to allay emotions when their strength threatens harm It seems to me Shirley that nobody should write poetry to exhibit intellect or attainment Who cares for that sort of poetry Who cares for learning who cares for fine words in poetry And who does not care for feeling real feeling however simply even rudely expressed

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: It seems you care for it, at all events; and certainly, in hearing that poem, one discovers that Cowper was under an impulse strong as that of the wind which drove the ship    an impulse which, while it would not suffer him to stop to add ornament to a single stanza, filled him with force to achieve the whole with consummate perfection. You managed to recite it with a steady voice, Caroline. I wonder thereat.
children.prevalue: It seems you care for it at all events and certainly in hearing that poem one discovers that Cowper was under an impulse strong as that of the wind which drove the ship an impulse which while it would not suffer him to stop to add ornament to a single stanza filled him with force to achieve the whole with consummate perfection You managed to recite it with a steady voice Caroline I wonder thereat

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: Cowper's hand did not tremble in writing the lines. Why should my voice falter in repeating them? Depend on it, Shirley, no tear blistered the manuscript of 'The Castaway.' I hear in it no sob of sorrow, only the cry of despair; but, that cry uttered, I believe the deadly spasm passed from his heart, that he wept abundantly, and was comforted.
children.prevalue: Cowper s hand did not tremble in writing the lines Why should my voice falter in repeating them Depend on it Shirley no tear blistered the manuscript of The Castaway I hear in it no sob of sorrow only the cry of despair but that cry uttered I believe the deadly spasm passed from his heart that he wept abundantly and was comforted

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Shirley resumed her ballad minstrelsy. Stopping short, she remarked ere long, One could have loved Cowper, if it were only for the sake of having the privilege of comforting him.
children.prevalue: Shirley resumed her ballad minstrelsy Stopping short she remarked ere long One could have loved Cowper if it were only for the sake of having the privilege of comforting him

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: You never would have loved Cowper, rejoined Caroline promptly. He was not made to be loved by woman.
children.prevalue: You never would have loved Cowper rejoined Caroline promptly He was not made to be loved by woman

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: What I say. I know there is a kind of natures in the world    and very noble, elevated natures too    whom love never comes near. You might have sought Cowper with the intention of loving him, and you would have looked at him, pitied him, and left him, forced away by a sense of the impossible, the incongruous, as the crew were borne from their drowning comrade by 'the furious blast.'
children.prevalue: What I say I know there is a kind of natures in the world and very noble elevated natures too whom love never comes near You might have sought Cowper with the intention of loving him and you would have looked at him pitied him and left him forced away by a sense of the impossible the incongruous as the crew were borne from their drowning comrade by the furious blast

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: You may be right. Who told you this?
children.prevalue: You may be right Who told you this

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: And what I say of Cowper, I should say of Rousseau. Was Rousseau ever loved? He loved passionately; but was his passion ever returned? I am certain, never. And if there were any female Cowpers and Rousseaus, I should assert the same of them.
children.prevalue: And what I say of Cowper I should say of Rousseau Was Rousseau ever loved He loved passionately but was his passion ever returned I am certain never And if there were any female Cowpers and Rousseaus I should assert the same of them

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: Who told you this, I ask? Did Moore?
children.prevalue: Who told you this I ask Did Moore

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: Why should anybody have told me? Have I not an instinct? Can I not divine by analogy? Moore never talked to me either about Cowper, or Rousseau, or love. The voice we hear in solitude told me all I know on these subjects.
children.prevalue: Why should anybody have told me Have I not an instinct Can I not divine by analogy Moore never talked to me either about Cowper or Rousseau or love The voice we hear in solitude told me all I know on these subjects

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: Do you like characters of the Rousseau order, Caroline?
children.prevalue: Do you like characters of the Rousseau order Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: Not at all, as a whole. I sympathize intensely with certain qualities they possess. Certain divine sparks in their nature dazzle my eyes, and make my soul glow. Then, again, I scorn them. They are made of clay and gold. The refuse and the ore make a mass of weakness: taken altogether, I feel them unnatural, unhealthy, repulsive.
children.prevalue: Not at all as a whole I sympathize intensely with certain qualities they possess Certain divine sparks in their nature dazzle my eyes and make my soul glow Then again I scorn them They are made of clay and gold The refuse and the ore make a mass of weakness taken altogether I feel them unnatural unhealthy repulsive

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: I dare say I should be more tolerant of a Rousseau than you would, Cary. Submissive and contemplative yourself, you like the stern and the practical. By the way, you must miss that Cousin Robert of yours very much, now that you and he never meet.
children.prevalue: I dare say I should be more tolerant of a Rousseau than you would Cary Submissive and contemplative yourself you like the stern and the practical By the way you must miss that Cousin Robert of yours very much now that you and he never meet

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: I do.
children.prevalue: I do

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: And he must miss you?
children.prevalue: And he must miss you

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: That he does not.
children.prevalue: That he does not

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: I cannot imagine, pursued Shirley, who had lately got a habit of introducing Moore's name into the conversation, even when it seemed to have no business there    I cannot imagine but that he was fond of you, since he took so much notice of you, talked to you, and taught you so much.
children.prevalue: I cannot imagine pursued Shirley who had lately got a habit of introducing Moore s name into the conversation even when it seemed to have no business there I cannot imagine but that he was fond of you since he took so much notice of you talked to you and taught you so much

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: He never was fond of me; he never professed to be fond of me. He took pains to prove that he only just tolerated me.
children.prevalue: He never was fond of me he never professed to be fond of me He took pains to prove that he only just tolerated me

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Caroline, determined not to err on the flattering side in estimating her cousin's regard for her, always now habitually thought of it and mentioned it in the most scanty measure. She had her own reasons for being less sanguine than ever in hopeful views of the future, less indulgent to pleasurable retrospections of the past.
children.prevalue: Caroline determined not to err on the flattering side in estimating her cousin s regard for her always now habitually thought of it and mentioned it in the most scanty measure She had her own reasons for being less sanguine than ever in hopeful views of the future less indulgent to pleasurable retrospections of the past

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: Of course, then, observed Miss Keeldar, you only just tolerated him in return?
children.prevalue: Of course then observed Miss Keeldar you only just tolerated him in return

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: Shirley, men and women are so different; they are in such a different position. Women have so few things to think about, men so many. You may have a friendship for a man, while he is almost indifferent to you. Much of what cheers your life may be dependent on him, while not a feeling or interest of moment in his eyes may have reference to you. Robert used to be in the habit of going to London, sometimes for a week or a fortnight together. Well, while he was away, I found his absence a void. There was something wanting; Briarfield was duller. Of course, I had my usual occupations; still I missed him. As I sat by myself in the evenings, I used to feel a strange certainty of conviction I cannot describe, that if a magician or a genius had, at that moment, offered me Prince Ali's tube (you remember it in the 'Arabian Nights'?), and if, with its aid, I had been enabled to take a view of Robert    to see where he was, how occupied    I should have learned, in a startling manner, the width of the chasm which gaped between such as he and such as I. I knew that, however my thoughts might adhere to him, his were effectually sundered from me.
children.prevalue: Shirley men and women are so different they are in such a different position Women have so few things to think about men so many You may have a friendship for a man while he is almost indifferent to you Much of what cheers your life may be dependent on him while not a feeling or interest of moment in his eyes may have reference to you Robert used to be in the habit of going to London sometimes for a week or a fortnight together Well while he was away I found his absence a void There was something wanting Briarfield was duller Of course I had my usual occupations still I missed him As I sat by myself in the evenings I used to feel a strange certainty of conviction I cannot describe that if a magician or a genius had at that moment offered me Prince Ali s tube you remember it in the Arabian Nights and if with its aid I had been enabled to take a view of Robert to see where he was how occupied I should have learned in a startling manner the width of the chasm which gaped between such as he and such as I I knew that however my thoughts might adhere to him his were effectually sundered from me

children.name: Paragraph_196
children.value: Caroline, demanded Miss Keeldar abruptly, don't you wish you had a profession    a trade?
children.prevalue: Caroline demanded Miss Keeldar abruptly don t you wish you had a profession a trade

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: I wish it fifty times a day. As it is, I often wonder what I came into the world for. I long to have something absorbing and compulsory to fill my head and hands and to occupy my thoughts.
children.prevalue: I wish it fifty times a day As it is I often wonder what I came into the world for I long to have something absorbing and compulsory to fill my head and hands and to occupy my thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: Can labour alone make a human being happy?
children.prevalue: Can labour alone make a human being happy

children.name: Paragraph_199
children.value: No; but it can give varieties of pain, and prevent us from breaking our hearts with a single tyrant master  torture. Besides, successful labour has its recompense; a vacant, weary, lonely, hopeless life has none.
children.prevalue: No but it can give varieties of pain and prevent us from breaking our hearts with a single tyrant master torture Besides successful labour has its recompense a vacant weary lonely hopeless life has none

children.name: Paragraph_200
children.value: But hard labour and learned professions, they say, make women masculine, coarse, unwomanly.
children.prevalue: But hard labour and learned professions they say make women masculine coarse unwomanly

children.name: Paragraph_201
children.value: And what does it signify whether unmarried and never  to  be  married women are unattractive and inelegant or not? Provided only they are decent, decorous, and neat, it is enough. The utmost which ought to be required of old maids, in the way of appearance, is that they should not absolutely offend men's eyes as they pass them in the street; for the rest, they should be allowed, without too much scorn, to be as absorbed, grave, plain  looking, and plain  dressed as they please.
children.prevalue: And what does it signify whether unmarried and never to be married women are unattractive and inelegant or not Provided only they are decent decorous and neat it is enough The utmost which ought to be required of old maids in the way of appearance is that they should not absolutely offend men s eyes as they pass them in the street for the rest they should be allowed without too much scorn to be as absorbed grave plain looking and plain dressed as they please

children.name: Paragraph_202
children.value: You might be an old maid yourself, Caroline, you speak so earnestly.
children.prevalue: You might be an old maid yourself Caroline you speak so earnestly

children.name: Paragraph_203
children.value: I shall be one. It is my destiny. I will never marry a Malone or a Sykes; and no one else will ever marry me.
children.prevalue: I shall be one It is my destiny I will never marry a Malone or a Sykes and no one else will ever marry me

children.name: Paragraph_204
children.value: Here fell a long pause. Shirley broke it. Again the name by which she seemed bewitched was almost the first on her lips.
children.prevalue: Here fell a long pause Shirley broke it Again the name by which she seemed bewitched was almost the first on her lips

children.name: Paragraph_205
children.value: Lina    did not Moore call you Lina sometimes?
children.prevalue: Lina did not Moore call you Lina sometimes

children.name: Paragraph_206
