children.value: I will bear the brunt of his wrath; he will not devour me. I shall be sorry to miss his pungent speech. I know it will be all sense for the church, and all causticity for schism. He'll not forget the battle of Royd Lane. I shall be sorry also to deprive you of Mr. Hall's sincere friendly homily, with all its racy Yorkshireisms; but here I must stay. The gray church and grayer tombs look divine with this crimson gleam on them. Nature is now at her evening prayers; she is kneeling before those red hills. I see her prostrate on the great steps of her altar, praying for a fair night for mariners at sea, for travellers in deserts, for lambs on moors, and unfledged birds in woods. Caroline, I see her, and I will tell you what she is like. She is like what Eve was when she and Adam stood alone on earth.
children.prevalue: I will bear the brunt of his wrath he will not devour me I shall be sorry to miss his pungent speech I know it will be all sense for the church and all causticity for schism He ll not forget the battle of Royd Lane I shall be sorry also to deprive you of Mr Hall s sincere friendly homily with all its racy Yorkshireisms but here I must stay The gray church and grayer tombs look divine with this crimson gleam on them Nature is now at her evening prayers she is kneeling before those red hills I see her prostrate on the great steps of her altar praying for a fair night for mariners at sea for travellers in deserts for lambs on moors and unfledged birds in woods Caroline I see her and I will tell you what she is like She is like what Eve was when she and Adam stood alone on earth

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And that is not Milton's Eve, Shirley.
children.prevalue: And that is not Milton s Eve Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Milton's Eve! Milton's Eve! I repeat. No, by the pure Mother of God, she is not! Cary, we are alone; we may speak what we think. Milton was great; but was he good? His brain was right; how was his heart? He saw heaven; he looked down on hell. He saw Satan, and Sin his daughter, and Death their horrible offspring. Angels serried before him their battalions; the long lines of adamantine shields flashed back on his blind eyeballs the unutterable splendour of heaven. Devils gathered their legions in his sight; their dim, discrowned, and tarnished armies passed rank and file before him. Milton tried to see the first woman; but, Cary, he saw her not.
children.prevalue: Milton s Eve Milton s Eve I repeat No by the pure Mother of God she is not Cary we are alone we may speak what we think Milton was great but was he good His brain was right how was his heart He saw heaven he looked down on hell He saw Satan and Sin his daughter and Death their horrible offspring Angels serried before him their battalions the long lines of adamantine shields flashed back on his blind eyeballs the unutterable splendour of heaven Devils gathered their legions in his sight their dim discrowned and tarnished armies passed rank and file before him Milton tried to see the first woman but Cary he saw her not

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You are bold to say so, Shirley.
children.prevalue: You are bold to say so Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Not more bold than faithful. It was his cook that he saw; or it was Mrs. Gill, as I have seen her, making custards, in the heat of summer, in the cool dairy, with rose  trees and nasturtiums about the latticed window, preparing a cold collation for the rectors    preserves and 'dulcet creams;' puzzled 'what choice to choose for delicacy best; what order so contrived as not to mix tastes, not well  joined, inelegant, but bring taste after taste, upheld with kindliest change.'
children.prevalue: Not more bold than faithful It was his cook that he saw or it was Mrs Gill as I have seen her making custards in the heat of summer in the cool dairy with rose trees and nasturtiums about the latticed window preparing a cold collation for the rectors preserves and dulcet creams puzzled what choice to choose for delicacy best what order so contrived as not to mix tastes not well joined inelegant but bring taste after taste upheld with kindliest change

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: All very well too, Shirley.
children.prevalue: All very well too Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I would beg to remind him that the first men of the earth were Titans, and that Eve was their mother; from her sprang Saturn, Hyperion, Oceanus; she bore Prometheus
children.prevalue: I would beg to remind him that the first men of the earth were Titans and that Eve was their mother from her sprang Saturn Hyperion Oceanus she bore Prometheus

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Pagan that you are! what does that signify?
children.prevalue: Pagan that you are what does that signify

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I say, there were giants on the earth in those days    giants that strove to scale heaven. The first woman's breast that heaved with life on this world yielded the daring which could contend with Omnipotence, the strength which could bear a thousand years of bondage, the vitality which could feed that vulture death through uncounted ages, the unexhausted life and uncorrupted excellence, sisters to immortality, which, after millenniums of crimes, struggles, and woes, could conceive and bring forth a Messiah. The first woman was heaven  born. Vast was the heart whence gushed the well  spring of the blood of nations, and grand the undegenerate head where rested the consort  crown of creation.
children.prevalue: I say there were giants on the earth in those days giants that strove to scale heaven The first woman s breast that heaved with life on this world yielded the daring which could contend with Omnipotence the strength which could bear a thousand years of bondage the vitality which could feed that vulture death through uncounted ages the unexhausted life and uncorrupted excellence sisters to immortality which after millenniums of crimes struggles and woes could conceive and bring forth a Messiah The first woman was heaven born Vast was the heart whence gushed the well spring of the blood of nations and grand the undegenerate head where rested the consort crown of creation

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: She coveted an apple, and was cheated by a snake; but you have got such a hash of Scripture and mythology into your head that there is no making any sense of you. You have not yet told me what you saw kneeling on those hills.
children.prevalue: She coveted an apple and was cheated by a snake but you have got such a hash of Scripture and mythology into your head that there is no making any sense of you You have not yet told me what you saw kneeling on those hills

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I saw    I now see    a woman  Titan. Her robe of blue air spreads to the outskirts of the heath, where yonder flock is grazing; a veil white as an avalanche sweeps from her head to her feet, and arabesques of lightning flame on its borders. Under her breast I see her zone, purple like that horizon; through its blush shines the star of evening. Her steady eyes I cannot picture. They are clear, they are deep as lakes, they are lifted and full of worship, they tremble with the softness of love and the lustre of prayer. Her forehead has the expanse of a cloud, and is paler than the early moon, risen long before dark gathers. She reclines her bosom on the ridge of Stilbro' Moor; her mighty hands are joined beneath it. So kneeling, face to face she speaks with God. That Eve is Jehovah's daughter, as Adam was His son.
children.prevalue: I saw I now see a woman Titan Her robe of blue air spreads to the outskirts of the heath where yonder flock is grazing a veil white as an avalanche sweeps from her head to her feet and arabesques of lightning flame on its borders Under her breast I see her zone purple like that horizon through its blush shines the star of evening Her steady eyes I cannot picture They are clear they are deep as lakes they are lifted and full of worship they tremble with the softness of love and the lustre of prayer Her forehead has the expanse of a cloud and is paler than the early moon risen long before dark gathers She reclines her bosom on the ridge of Stilbro Moor her mighty hands are joined beneath it So kneeling face to face she speaks with God That Eve is Jehovah s daughter as Adam was His son

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: She is very vague and visionary. Come, Shirley, we ought to go into church.
children.prevalue: She is very vague and visionary Come Shirley we ought to go into church

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Caroline, I will not; I will stay out here with my mother Eve, in these days called Nature. I love her    undying, mighty being! Heaven may have faded from her brow when she fell in paradise, but all that is glorious on earth shines there still. She is taking me to her bosom, and showing me her heart. Hush, Caroline! You will see her and feel as I do, if we are both silent.
children.prevalue: Caroline I will not I will stay out here with my mother Eve in these days called Nature I love her undying mighty being Heaven may have faded from her brow when she fell in paradise but all that is glorious on earth shines there still She is taking me to her bosom and showing me her heart Hush Caroline You will see her and feel as I do if we are both silent

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I will humour your whim; but you will begin talking again ere ten minutes are over.
children.prevalue: I will humour your whim but you will begin talking again ere ten minutes are over

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Miss Keeldar, on whom the soft excitement of the warm summer evening seemed working with unwonted power, leaned against an upright headstone; she fixed her eyes on the deep  burning west, and sank into a pleasurable trance. Caroline, going a little apart, paced to and fro beneath the rectory garden wall, dreaming too in her way. Shirley had mentioned the word mother. That word suggested to Caroline's imagination not the mighty and mystical parent of Shirley's visions, but a gentle human form    the form she ascribed to her own mother, unknown, unloved, but not unlonged for.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar on whom the soft excitement of the warm summer evening seemed working with unwonted power leaned against an upright headstone she fixed her eyes on the deep burning west and sank into a pleasurable trance Caroline going a little apart paced to and fro beneath the rectory garden wall dreaming too in her way Shirley had mentioned the word mother That word suggested to Caroline s imagination not the mighty and mystical parent of Shirley s visions but a gentle human form the form she ascribed to her own mother unknown unloved but not unlonged for

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh that the day would come when she would remember her child! Oh that I might know her, and knowing, love her!
children.prevalue: Oh that the day would come when she would remember her child Oh that I might know her and knowing love her

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Such was her aspiration.
children.prevalue: Such was her aspiration

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The longing of her childhood filled her soul again. The desire which many a night had kept her awake in her crib, and which fear of its fallacy had of late years almost extinguished, relit suddenly, and glowed warm in her heart, that her mother might come some happy day, and send for her to her presence, look upon her fondly with loving eyes, and say to her tenderly, in a sweet voice, Caroline, my child, I have a home for you; you shall live with me. All the love you have needed, and not tasted, from infancy, I have saved for you carefully. Come; it shall cherish you now.
children.prevalue: The longing of her childhood filled her soul again The desire which many a night had kept her awake in her crib and which fear of its fallacy had of late years almost extinguished relit suddenly and glowed warm in her heart that her mother might come some happy day and send for her to her presence look upon her fondly with loving eyes and say to her tenderly in a sweet voice Caroline my child I have a home for you you shall live with me All the love you have needed and not tasted from infancy I have saved for you carefully Come it shall cherish you now

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: A noise on the road roused Caroline from her filial hopes, and Shirley from her Titan visions. They listened, and heard the tramp of horses. They looked, and saw a glitter through the trees. They caught through the foliage glimpses of martial scarlet; helm shone, plume waved. Silent and orderly, six soldiers rode softly by.
children.prevalue: A noise on the road roused Caroline from her filial hopes and Shirley from her Titan visions They listened and heard the tramp of horses They looked and saw a glitter through the trees They caught through the foliage glimpses of martial scarlet helm shone plume waved Silent and orderly six soldiers rode softly by

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The same we saw this afternoon, whispered Shirley. They have been halting somewhere till now. They wish to be as little noticed as possible, and are seeking their rendezvous at this quiet hour, while the people are at church. Did I not say we should see unusual things ere long?
children.prevalue: The same we saw this afternoon whispered Shirley They have been halting somewhere till now They wish to be as little noticed as possible and are seeking their rendezvous at this quiet hour while the people are at church Did I not say we should see unusual things ere long

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Scarcely were sight and sound of the soldiers lost, when another and somewhat different disturbance broke the night  hush    a child's impatient scream. They looked. A man issued from the church, carrying in his arms an infant    a robust, ruddy little boy of some two years old    roaring with all the power of his lungs. He had probably just awaked from a church  sleep. Two little girls, of nine and ten, followed. The influence of the fresh air, and the attraction of some flowers gathered from a grave, soon quieted the child. The man sat down with him, dandling him on his knee as tenderly as any woman; the two little girls took their places one on each side.
children.prevalue: Scarcely were sight and sound of the soldiers lost when another and somewhat different disturbance broke the night hush a child s impatient scream They looked A man issued from the church carrying in his arms an infant a robust ruddy little boy of some two years old roaring with all the power of his lungs He had probably just awaked from a church sleep Two little girls of nine and ten followed The influence of the fresh air and the attraction of some flowers gathered from a grave soon quieted the child The man sat down with him dandling him on his knee as tenderly as any woman the two little girls took their places one on each side

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Good  evening, William, said Shirley, after due scrutiny of the man. He had seen her before, and apparently was waiting to be recognized. He now took off his hat, and grinned a smile of pleasure. He was a rough  headed, hard  featured personage, not old, but very weather  beaten. His attire was decent and clean; that of his children singularly neat. It was our old friend Farren. The young ladies approached him.
children.prevalue: Good evening William said Shirley after due scrutiny of the man He had seen her before and apparently was waiting to be recognized He now took off his hat and grinned a smile of pleasure He was a rough headed hard featured personage not old but very weather beaten His attire was decent and clean that of his children singularly neat It was our old friend Farren The young ladies approached him

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You are not going into the church? he inquired, gazing at them complacently, yet with a mixture of bashfulness in his look    a sentiment not by any means the result of awe of their station, but only of appreciation of their elegance and youth. Before gentlemen    such as Moore or Helstone, for instance    William was often a little dogged; with proud or insolent ladies, too, he was quite unmanageable, sometimes very resentful; but he was most sensible of, most tractable to, good  humour and civility. His nature    a stubborn one    was repelled by inflexibility in other natures; for which reason he had never been able to like his former master, Moore; and unconscious of that gentleman's good opinion of himself, and of the service he had secretly rendered him in recommending him as gardener to Mr. Yorke, and by this means to other families in the neighbourhood, he continued to harbour a grudge against his austerity. Latterly he had often worked at Fieldhead. Miss Keeldar's frank, hospitable manners were perfectly charming to him. Caroline he had known from her childhood; unconsciously she was his ideal of a lady. Her gentle mien, step, gestures, her grace of person and attire, moved some artist  fibres about his peasant heart. He had a pleasure in looking at her, as he had in examining rare flowers or in seeing pleasant landscapes. Both the ladies liked William; it was their delight to lend him books, to give him plants; and they preferred his conversation far before that of many coarse, hard, pretentious people immeasurably higher in station.
children.prevalue: You are not going into the church he inquired gazing at them complacently yet with a mixture of bashfulness in his look a sentiment not by any means the result of awe of their station but only of appreciation of their elegance and youth Before gentlemen such as Moore or Helstone for instance William was often a little dogged with proud or insolent ladies too he was quite unmanageable sometimes very resentful but he was most sensible of most tractable to good humour and civility His nature a stubborn one was repelled by inflexibility in other natures for which reason he had never been able to like his former master Moore and unconscious of that gentleman s good opinion of himself and of the service he had secretly rendered him in recommending him as gardener to Mr Yorke and by this means to other families in the neighbourhood he continued to harbour a grudge against his austerity Latterly he had often worked at Fieldhead Miss Keeldar s frank hospitable manners were perfectly charming to him Caroline he had known from her childhood unconsciously she was his ideal of a lady Her gentle mien step gestures her grace of person and attire moved some artist fibres about his peasant heart He had a pleasure in looking at her as he had in examining rare flowers or in seeing pleasant landscapes Both the ladies liked William it was their delight to lend him books to give him plants and they preferred his conversation far before that of many coarse hard pretentious people immeasurably higher in station

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Who was speaking, William, when you came out? asked Shirley.
children.prevalue: Who was speaking William when you came out asked Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: A gentleman ye set a deal of store on, Miss Shirley    Mr. Donne.
children.prevalue: A gentleman ye set a deal of store on Miss Shirley Mr Donne

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You look knowing, William. How did you find out my regard for Mr. Donne?
children.prevalue: You look knowing William How did you find out my regard for Mr Donne

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Ay, Miss Shirley, there's a gleg light i' your een sometimes which betrays you. You look raight down scornful sometimes when Mr. Donne is by.
children.prevalue: Ay Miss Shirley there s a gleg light i your een sometimes which betrays you You look raight down scornful sometimes when Mr Donne is by

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Do you like him yourself, William?
children.prevalue: Do you like him yourself William

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Me? I'm stalled o' t' curates, and so is t' wife. They've no manners. They talk to poor folk fair as if they thought they were beneath them. They're allus magnifying their office. It is a pity but their office could magnify them; but it does nought o' t' soart. I fair hate pride.
children.prevalue: Me I m stalled o t curates and so is t wife They ve no manners They talk to poor folk fair as if they thought they were beneath them They re allus magnifying their office It is a pity but their office could magnify them but it does nought o t soart I fair hate pride

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: But you are proud in your own way yourself, interposed Caroline. You are what you call house  proud: you like to have everything handsome about you. Sometimes you look as if you were almost too proud to take your wages. When you were out of work, you were too proud to get anything on credit. But for your children, I believe you would rather have starved than gone to the shops without money; and when I wanted to give you something, what a difficulty I had in making you take it!
children.prevalue: But you are proud in your own way yourself interposed Caroline You are what you call house proud you like to have everything handsome about you Sometimes you look as if you were almost too proud to take your wages When you were out of work you were too proud to get anything on credit But for your children I believe you would rather have starved than gone to the shops without money and when I wanted to give you something what a difficulty I had in making you take it

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It is partly true, Miss Caroline. Ony day I'd rather give than take, especially from sich as ye. Look at t' difference between us. Ye're a little, young, slender lass, and I'm a great strong man; I'm rather more nor twice your age. It is not   my   part, then, I think, to tak fro'   ye      to be under obligations (as they say) to   ye  . And that day ye came to our house, and called me to t' door, and offered me five shillings, which I doubt ye could ill spare    for ye've no fortin', I know    that day I war fair a rebel, a radical, an insurrectionist; and   ye   made me so. I thought it shameful that, willing and able as I was to work, I suld be i' such a condition that a young cratur about the age o' my own eldest lass suld think it needful to come and offer me her bit o' brass.
children.prevalue: It is partly true Miss Caroline Ony day I d rather give than take especially from sich as ye Look at t difference between us Ye re a little young slender lass and I m a great strong man I m rather more nor twice your age It is not my part then I think to tak fro ye to be under obligations as they say to ye And that day ye came to our house and called me to t door and offered me five shillings which I doubt ye could ill spare for ye ve no fortin I know that day I war fair a rebel a radical an insurrectionist and ye made me so I thought it shameful that willing and able as I was to work I suld be i such a condition that a young cratur about the age o my own eldest lass suld think it needful to come and offer me her bit o brass

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I suppose you were angry with me, William?
children.prevalue: I suppose you were angry with me William

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I almost was, in a way. But I forgave ye varry soon. Ye meant well. Ay,   I am   proud, and so are   ye  ; but your pride and mine is t' raight mak    what we call i' Yorkshire clean pride    such as Mr. Malone and Mr. Donne knows nought about. Theirs is mucky pride. Now, I shall teach my lasses to be as proud as Miss Shirley there, and my lads to be as proud as myseln; but I dare ony o' 'em to be like t' curates. I'd lick little Michael if I seed him show any signs o' that feeling.
children.prevalue: I almost was in a way But I forgave ye varry soon Ye meant well Ay I am proud and so are ye but your pride and mine is t raight mak what we call i Yorkshire clean pride such as Mr Malone and Mr Donne knows nought about Theirs is mucky pride Now I shall teach my lasses to be as proud as Miss Shirley there and my lads to be as proud as myseln but I dare ony o em to be like t curates I d lick little Michael if I seed him show any signs o that feeling

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What is the difference, William?
children.prevalue: What is the difference William

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Ye know t' difference weel enow, but ye want me to get a gate o' talking. Mr. Malone and Mr. Donne is almost too proud to do aught for theirseln;   we   are almost too proud to let anybody do aught for us. T' curates can hardly bide to speak a civil word to them they think beneath them;   we   can hardly bide to tak an uncivil word fro' them that thinks themseln aboon us.
children.prevalue: Ye know t difference weel enow but ye want me to get a gate o talking Mr Malone and Mr Donne is almost too proud to do aught for theirseln we are almost too proud to let anybody do aught for us T curates can hardly bide to speak a civil word to them they think beneath them we can hardly bide to tak an uncivil word fro them that thinks themseln aboon us

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Now, William, be humble enough to tell me truly how you are getting on in the world. Are you well off?
children.prevalue: Now William be humble enough to tell me truly how you are getting on in the world Are you well off

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Miss Shirley, I am varry well off. Since I got into t' gardening line, wi' Mr. Yorke's help, and since Mr. Hall (another o' t' raight sort) helped my wife to set up a bit of a shop, I've nought to complain of. My family has plenty to eat and plenty to wear. My pride makes me find means to have an odd pound now and then against rainy days; for I think I'd die afore I'd come to t' parish; and me and mine is content. But t' neighbours is poor yet. I see a great deal of distress.
children.prevalue: Miss Shirley I am varry well off Since I got into t gardening line wi Mr Yorke s help and since Mr Hall another o t raight sort helped my wife to set up a bit of a shop I ve nought to complain of My family has plenty to eat and plenty to wear My pride makes me find means to have an odd pound now and then against rainy days for I think I d die afore I d come to t parish and me and mine is content But t neighbours is poor yet I see a great deal of distress

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And, consequently, there is still discontent, I suppose? inquired Miss Keeldar.
children.prevalue: And consequently there is still discontent I suppose inquired Miss Keeldar

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Consequently      ye say right      consequently  . In course, starving folk cannot be satisfied or settled folk. The country's not in a safe condition    I'll say so mich!
children.prevalue: Consequently ye say right consequently In course starving folk cannot be satisfied or settled folk The country s not in a safe condition I ll say so mich

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But what can be done? What more can I do, for instance?
children.prevalue: But what can be done What more can I do for instance

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Do? Ye can do not mich, poor young lass! Ye've gi'en your brass; ye've done well. If ye could transport your tenant, Mr. Moore, to Botany Bay, ye'd happen do better. Folks hate him.
children.prevalue: Do Ye can do not mich poor young lass Ye ve gi en your brass ye ve done well If ye could transport your tenant Mr Moore to Botany Bay ye d happen do better Folks hate him

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: William, for shame! exclaimed Caroline warmly. If folks   do   hate him, it is to their disgrace, not his. Mr. Moore himself hates nobody. He only wants to do his duty, and maintain his rights. You are wrong to talk so.
children.prevalue: William for shame exclaimed Caroline warmly If folks do hate him it is to their disgrace not his Mr Moore himself hates nobody He only wants to do his duty and maintain his rights You are wrong to talk so

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I talk as I think. He has a cold, unfeeling heart, yond' Moore.
children.prevalue: I talk as I think He has a cold unfeeling heart yond Moore

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But, interposed Shirley, supposing Moore was driven from the country, and his mill razed to the ground, would people have more work?
children.prevalue: But interposed Shirley supposing Moore was driven from the country and his mill razed to the ground would people have more work

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: They'd have less. I know that, and they know that; and there is many an honest lad driven desperate by the certainty that whichever way he turns he cannot better himself; and there is dishonest men plenty to guide them to the devil, scoundrels that reckons to be the 'people's friends,' and that knows nought about the people, and is as insincere as Lucifer. I've lived aboon forty year in the world, and I believe that 'the people' will never have any true friends but theirseln and them two or three good folk i' different stations that is friends to all the world. Human natur', taking it i' th' lump, is nought but selfishness. It is but excessive few, it is but just an exception here and there, now and then, sich as ye two young uns and me, that, being in a different sphere, can understand t' one t' other, and be friends wi'out slavishness o' one hand or pride o' t' other. Them that reckons to be friends to a lower class than their own fro' political motives is never to be trusted; they always try to make their inferiors tools. For my own part, I will neither be patronized nor misled for no man's pleasure. I've had overtures made to me lately that I saw were treacherous, and I flung 'em back i' the faces o' them that offered 'em.
children.prevalue: They d have less I know that and they know that and there is many an honest lad driven desperate by the certainty that whichever way he turns he cannot better himself and there is dishonest men plenty to guide them to the devil scoundrels that reckons to be the people s friends and that knows nought about the people and is as insincere as Lucifer I ve lived aboon forty year in the world and I believe that the people will never have any true friends but theirseln and them two or three good folk i different stations that is friends to all the world Human natur taking it i th lump is nought but selfishness It is but excessive few it is but just an exception here and there now and then sich as ye two young uns and me that being in a different sphere can understand t one t other and be friends wi out slavishness o one hand or pride o t other Them that reckons to be friends to a lower class than their own fro political motives is never to be trusted they always try to make their inferiors tools For my own part I will neither be patronized nor misled for no man s pleasure I ve had overtures made to me lately that I saw were treacherous and I flung em back i the faces o them that offered em

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You won't tell us what overtures?
children.prevalue: You won t tell us what overtures

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I will not. It would do no good. It would mak no difference. Them they concerned can look after theirseln.
children.prevalue: I will not It would do no good It would mak no difference Them they concerned can look after theirseln

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Ay, we'se look after werseln, said another voice. Joe Scott had sauntered forth from the church to get a breath of fresh air, and there he stood.
children.prevalue: Ay we se look after werseln said another voice Joe Scott had sauntered forth from the church to get a breath of fresh air and there he stood

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I'll warrant   ye  , Joe, observed William, smiling.
children.prevalue: I ll warrant ye Joe observed William smiling

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And I'll warrant my maister, was the answer.    Young ladies, continued Joe, assuming a lordly air, ye'd better go into th' house.
children.prevalue: And I ll warrant my maister was the answer Young ladies continued Joe assuming a lordly air ye d better go into th house

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I wonder what for? inquired Shirley, to whom the overlooker's somewhat pragmatical manners were familiar, and who was often at war with him; for Joe, holding supercilious theories about women in general, resented greatly, in his secret soul, the fact of his master and his master's mill being, in a manner, under petticoat government, and had felt as wormwood and gall certain business visits of the heiress to the Hollow's counting  house.
children.prevalue: I wonder what for inquired Shirley to whom the overlooker s somewhat pragmatical manners were familiar and who was often at war with him for Joe holding supercilious theories about women in general resented greatly in his secret soul the fact of his master and his master s mill being in a manner under petticoat government and had felt as wormwood and gall certain business visits of the heiress to the Hollow s counting house

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Because there is nought agate that fits women to be consarned in.
children.prevalue: Because there is nought agate that fits women to be consarned in

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Indeed! There is prayer and preaching agate in that church. Are we not concerned in that?
children.prevalue: Indeed There is prayer and preaching agate in that church Are we not concerned in that

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ye have been present neither at the prayer nor preaching, ma'am, if I have observed aright. What I alluded to was politics. William Farren here was touching on that subject, if I'm not mista'en.
children.prevalue: Ye have been present neither at the prayer nor preaching ma am if I have observed aright What I alluded to was politics William Farren here was touching on that subject if I m not mista en

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Well, what then? Politics are our habitual study, Joe. Do you know I see a newspaper every day, and two of a Sunday?
children.prevalue: Well what then Politics are our habitual study Joe Do you know I see a newspaper every day and two of a Sunday

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I should think you'll read the marriages, probably, miss, and the murders, and the accidents, and sich like?
children.prevalue: I should think you ll read the marriages probably miss and the murders and the accidents and sich like

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I read the leading articles, Joe, and the foreign intelligence, and I look over the market prices. In short, I read just what gentlemen read.
children.prevalue: I read the leading articles Joe and the foreign intelligence and I look over the market prices In short I read just what gentlemen read

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Joe looked as if he thought this talk was like the chattering of a pie. He replied to it by a disdainful silence.
children.prevalue: Joe looked as if he thought this talk was like the chattering of a pie He replied to it by a disdainful silence

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Joe, continued Miss Keeldar, I never yet could ascertain properly whether you are a Whig or a Tory. Pray, which party has the honour of your alliance?
children.prevalue: Joe continued Miss Keeldar I never yet could ascertain properly whether you are a Whig or a Tory Pray which party has the honour of your alliance

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It is rayther difficult to explain where you are sure not to be understood, was Joe's haughty response; but as to being a Tory, I'd as soon be an old woman, or a young one, which is a more flimsier article still. It is the Tories that carries on the war and ruins trade; and if I be of any party    though political parties is all nonsense    I'm of that which is most favourable to peace, and, by consequence, to the mercantile interests of this here land.
children.prevalue: It is rayther difficult to explain where you are sure not to be understood was Joe s haughty response but as to being a Tory I d as soon be an old woman or a young one which is a more flimsier article still It is the Tories that carries on the war and ruins trade and if I be of any party though political parties is all nonsense I m of that which is most favourable to peace and by consequence to the mercantile interests of this here land

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: So am I, Joe, replied Shirley, who had rather a pleasure in teasing the overlooker, by persisting in talking on subjects with which he opined she, as a woman, had no right to meddle    partly, at least. I have rather a leaning to the agricultural interest, too; as good reason is, seeing that I don't desire England to be under the feet of France, and that if a share of my income comes from Hollow's Mill, a larger share comes from the landed estate around it. It would not do to take any measures injurious to the farmers, Joe, I think?
children.prevalue: So am I Joe replied Shirley who had rather a pleasure in teasing the overlooker by persisting in talking on subjects with which he opined she as a woman had no right to meddle partly at least I have rather a leaning to the agricultural interest too as good reason is seeing that I don t desire England to be under the feet of France and that if a share of my income comes from Hollow s Mill a larger share comes from the landed estate around it It would not do to take any measures injurious to the farmers Joe I think

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The dews at this hour is unwholesome for females, observed Joe.
children.prevalue: The dews at this hour is unwholesome for females observed Joe

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: If you make that remark out of interest in me, I have merely to assure you that I am impervious to cold. I should not mind taking my turn to watch the mill one of these summer nights, armed with your musket, Joe.
children.prevalue: If you make that remark out of interest in me I have merely to assure you that I am impervious to cold I should not mind taking my turn to watch the mill one of these summer nights armed with your musket Joe

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Joe Scott's chin was always rather prominent. He poked it out, at this speech, some inches farther than usual.
children.prevalue: Joe Scott s chin was always rather prominent He poked it out at this speech some inches farther than usual

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But    to go back to my sheep, she proceeded    clothier and mill  owner as I am, besides farmer, I cannot get out of my head a certain idea that we manufacturers and persons of business are sometimes a little    a   very little      selfish and short  sighted in our views, and rather   too   regardless of human suffering, rather heartless in our pursuit of gain. Don't you agree with me, Joe?
children.prevalue: But to go back to my sheep she proceeded clothier and mill owner as I am besides farmer I cannot get out of my head a certain idea that we manufacturers and persons of business are sometimes a little a very little selfish and short sighted in our views and rather too regardless of human suffering rather heartless in our pursuit of gain Don t you agree with me Joe

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I cannot argue where I cannot be comprehended, was again the answer.
children.prevalue: I cannot argue where I cannot be comprehended was again the answer

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Man of mystery! Your master will argue with me sometimes, Joe. He is not so stiff as you are.
children.prevalue: Man of mystery Your master will argue with me sometimes Joe He is not so stiff as you are

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Maybe not. We've all our own ways.
children.prevalue: Maybe not We ve all our own ways

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Joe, do you seriously think all the wisdom in the world is lodged in male skulls?
children.prevalue: Joe do you seriously think all the wisdom in the world is lodged in male skulls

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I think that women are a kittle and a froward generation; and I've a great respect for the doctrines delivered in the second chapter of St. Paul's first Epistle to Timothy.
children.prevalue: I think that women are a kittle and a froward generation and I ve a great respect for the doctrines delivered in the second chapter of St Paul s first Epistle to Timothy

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: What doctrines, Joe?
children.prevalue: What doctrines Joe

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'Let the woman learn in silence, with all subjection. I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence. For Adam was first formed, then Eve.'
children.prevalue: Let the woman learn in silence with all subjection I suffer not a woman to teach nor to usurp authority over the man but to be in silence For Adam was first formed then Eve

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: What has that to do with the business? interjected Shirley. That smacks of rights of primogeniture. I'll bring it up to Mr. Yorke the first time he inveighs against those rights.
children.prevalue: What has that to do with the business interjected Shirley That smacks of rights of primogeniture I ll bring it up to Mr Yorke the first time he inveighs against those rights

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And, continued Joe Scott, Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression.
children.prevalue: And continued Joe Scott Adam was not deceived but the woman being deceived was in the transgression

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: More shame to Adam to sin with his eyes open! cried Miss Keeldar. To confess the honest truth, Joe, I never was easy in my mind concerning that chapter. It puzzles me.
children.prevalue: More shame to Adam to sin with his eyes open cried Miss Keeldar To confess the honest truth Joe I never was easy in my mind concerning that chapter It puzzles me

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: It is very plain, miss. He that runs may read.
children.prevalue: It is very plain miss He that runs may read

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: He may read it in his own fashion, remarked Caroline, now joining in the dialogue for the first time. You allow the right of private judgment, I suppose, Joe?
children.prevalue: He may read it in his own fashion remarked Caroline now joining in the dialogue for the first time You allow the right of private judgment I suppose Joe

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: My certy, that I do! I allow and claim it for every line of the holy Book.
children.prevalue: My certy that I do I allow and claim it for every line of the holy Book

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Women may exercise it as well as men?
children.prevalue: Women may exercise it as well as men

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Nay. Women is to take their husbands' opinion, both in politics and religion. It's wholesomest for them.
children.prevalue: Nay Women is to take their husbands opinion both in politics and religion It s wholesomest for them

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Oh! oh! exclaimed both Shirley and Caroline.
children.prevalue: Oh oh exclaimed both Shirley and Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: To be sure; no doubt on't, persisted the stubborn overlooker.
children.prevalue: To be sure no doubt on t persisted the stubborn overlooker

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Consider yourself groaned down, and cried shame over, for such a stupid observation, said Miss Keeldar. You might as well say men are to take the opinions of their priests without examination. Of what value would a religion so adopted be? It would be mere blind, besotted superstition.
children.prevalue: Consider yourself groaned down and cried shame over for such a stupid observation said Miss Keeldar You might as well say men are to take the opinions of their priests without examination Of what value would a religion so adopted be It would be mere blind besotted superstition

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And what is   your   reading, Miss Helstone, o' these words o' St. Paul's?
children.prevalue: And what is your reading Miss Helstone o these words o St Paul s

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Hem! I    I account for them in this way. He wrote that chapter for a particular congregation of Christians, under peculiar circumstances; and besides, I dare say, if I could read the original Greek, I should find that many of the words have been wrongly translated, perhaps misapprehended altogether. It would be possible, I doubt not, with a little ingenuity, to give the passage quite a contrary turn    to make it say, 'Let the woman speak out whenever she sees fit to make an objection.' 'It is permitted to a woman to teach and to exercise authority as much as may be. Man, meantime, cannot do better than hold his peace;' and so on.
children.prevalue: Hem I I account for them in this way He wrote that chapter for a particular congregation of Christians under peculiar circumstances and besides I dare say if I could read the original Greek I should find that many of the words have been wrongly translated perhaps misapprehended altogether It would be possible I doubt not with a little ingenuity to give the passage quite a contrary turn to make it say Let the woman speak out whenever she sees fit to make an objection It is permitted to a woman to teach and to exercise authority as much as may be Man meantime cannot do better than hold his peace and so on

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: That willn't wash, miss.
children.prevalue: That willn t wash miss

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I dare say it will. My notions are dyed in faster colours than yours, Joe. Mr. Scott, you are a thoroughly dogmatical person, and always were. I like William better than you.
children.prevalue: I dare say it will My notions are dyed in faster colours than yours Joe Mr Scott you are a thoroughly dogmatical person and always were I like William better than you

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Joe is well enough in his own house, said Shirley. I have seen him as quiet as a lamb at home. There is not a better nor a kinder husband in Briarfield. He does not dogmatize to his wife.
children.prevalue: Joe is well enough in his own house said Shirley I have seen him as quiet as a lamb at home There is not a better nor a kinder husband in Briarfield He does not dogmatize to his wife

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: My wife is a hard  working, plain woman; time and trouble has ta'en all the conceit out of her. But that is not the case with you, young misses. And then you reckon to have so much knowledge; and i' my thoughts it's only superficial sort o' vanities you're acquainted with. I can tell    happen a year sin'    one day Miss Caroline coming into our counting  house when I war packing up summat behind t' great desk, and she didn't see me, and she brought a slate wi' a sum on it to t' maister. It war only a bit of a sum in practice, that our Harry would have settled i' two minutes. She couldn't do it. Mr. Moore had to show her how. And when he did show her, she couldn't understand him.
children.prevalue: My wife is a hard working plain woman time and trouble has ta en all the conceit out of her But that is not the case with you young misses And then you reckon to have so much knowledge and i my thoughts it s only superficial sort o vanities you re acquainted with I can tell happen a year sin one day Miss Caroline coming into our counting house when I war packing up summat behind t great desk and she didn t see me and she brought a slate wi a sum on it to t maister It war only a bit of a sum in practice that our Harry would have settled i two minutes She couldn t do it Mr Moore had to show her how And when he did show her she couldn t understand him

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Nonsense, Joe!
children.prevalue: Nonsense Joe

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Nay, it's no nonsense. And Miss Shirley there reckons to hearken to t' maister when he's talking ower trade, so attentive like, as if she followed him word for word, and all war as clear as a lady's looking  glass to her een; and all t' while she's peeping and peeping out o' t' window to see if t' mare stands quiet; and then looking at a bit of a splash on her riding  skirt; and then glancing glegly round at wer counting  house cobwebs and dust, and thinking what mucky folk we are, and what a grand ride she'll have just i' now ower Nunnely Common. She hears no more o' Mr. Moore's talk nor if he spake Hebrew.
children.prevalue: Nay it s no nonsense And Miss Shirley there reckons to hearken to t maister when he s talking ower trade so attentive like as if she followed him word for word and all war as clear as a lady s looking glass to her een and all t while she s peeping and peeping out o t window to see if t mare stands quiet and then looking at a bit of a splash on her riding skirt and then glancing glegly round at wer counting house cobwebs and dust and thinking what mucky folk we are and what a grand ride she ll have just i now ower Nunnely Common She hears no more o Mr Moore s talk nor if he spake Hebrew

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Joe, you are a real slanderer. I would give you your answer, only the people are coming out of church. We must leave you. Man of prejudice, good  bye.    William, good  bye.    Children, come up to Fieldhead to  morrow, and you shall choose what you like best out of Mrs. Gill's store  room.
children.prevalue: Joe you are a real slanderer I would give you your answer only the people are coming out of church We must leave you Man of prejudice good bye William good bye Children come up to Fieldhead to morrow and you shall choose what you like best out of Mrs Gill s store room

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The hour was now that of dusk. A clear air favoured the kindling of the stars.
children.prevalue: The hour was now that of dusk A clear air favoured the kindling of the stars

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There will be just light enough to show me the way home, said Miss Keeldar, as she prepared to take leave of Caroline at the rectory garden door.
children.prevalue: There will be just light enough to show me the way home said Miss Keeldar as she prepared to take leave of Caroline at the rectory garden door

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: You must not go alone, Shirley; Fanny shall accompany you.
children.prevalue: You must not go alone Shirley Fanny shall accompany you

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: That she shall not. Of what need I be afraid in my own parish? I would walk from Fieldhead to the church any fine midsummer night, three hours later than this, for the mere pleasure of seeing the stars and the chance of meeting a fairy.
children.prevalue: That she shall not Of what need I be afraid in my own parish I would walk from Fieldhead to the church any fine midsummer night three hours later than this for the mere pleasure of seeing the stars and the chance of meeting a fairy

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But just wait till the crowd is cleared away.
children.prevalue: But just wait till the crowd is cleared away

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Agreed. There are the five Misses Armitage streaming by. Here comes Mrs. Sykes's phaeton, Mr. Wynne's close carriage, Mrs. Birtwhistle's car. I don't wish to go through the ceremony of bidding them all good  bye, so we will step into the garden and take shelter amongst the laburnums for an instant.
children.prevalue: Agreed There are the five Misses Armitage streaming by Here comes Mrs Sykes s phaeton Mr Wynne s close carriage Mrs Birtwhistle s car I don t wish to go through the ceremony of bidding them all good bye so we will step into the garden and take shelter amongst the laburnums for an instant

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The rectors, their curates, and their churchwardens now issued from the church porch. There was a great confabulation, shaking of hands, congratulation on speeches, recommendation to be careful of the night air, etc. By degrees the throng dispersed, the carriages drove off. Miss Keeldar was just emerging from her flowery refuge when Mr. Helstone entered the garden and met her.
children.prevalue: The rectors their curates and their churchwardens now issued from the church porch There was a great confabulation shaking of hands congratulation on speeches recommendation to be careful of the night air etc By degrees the throng dispersed the carriages drove off Miss Keeldar was just emerging from her flowery refuge when Mr Helstone entered the garden and met her

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh, I want you! he said. I was afraid you were already gone.    Caroline, come here.
children.prevalue: Oh I want you he said I was afraid you were already gone Caroline come here

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Caroline came, expecting, as Shirley did, a lecture on not having been visible at church. Other subjects, however, occupied the rector's mind.
children.prevalue: Caroline came expecting as Shirley did a lecture on not having been visible at church Other subjects however occupied the rector s mind

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I shall not sleep at home to  night, he continued. I have just met with an old friend, and promised to accompany him. I shall return probably about noon to  morrow. Thomas, the clerk, is engaged, and I cannot get him to sleep in the house, as I usually do when I am absent for a night. Now
children.prevalue: I shall not sleep at home to night he continued I have just met with an old friend and promised to accompany him I shall return probably about noon to morrow Thomas the clerk is engaged and I cannot get him to sleep in the house as I usually do when I am absent for a night Now

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now, interrupted Shirley, you want me as a gentleman    the first gentleman in Briarfield, in short    to supply your place, be master of the rectory and guardian of your niece and maids while you are away?
children.prevalue: Now interrupted Shirley you want me as a gentleman the first gentleman in Briarfield in short to supply your place be master of the rectory and guardian of your niece and maids while you are away

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Exactly, captain. I thought the post would suit you. Will you favour Caroline so far as to be her guest for one night? Will you stay here instead of going back to Fieldhead?
children.prevalue: Exactly captain I thought the post would suit you Will you favour Caroline so far as to be her guest for one night Will you stay here instead of going back to Fieldhead

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And what will Mrs. Pryor do? she expects me home.
children.prevalue: And what will Mrs Pryor do she expects me home

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I will send her word. Come, make up your mind to stay. It grows late; the dew falls heavily. You and Caroline will enjoy each other's society, I doubt not.
children.prevalue: I will send her word Come make up your mind to stay It grows late the dew falls heavily You and Caroline will enjoy each other s society I doubt not

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I promise you, then, to stay with Caroline, replied Shirley. As you say, we shall enjoy each other's society. We will not be separated to  night. Now, rejoin your old friend, and fear nothing for us.
children.prevalue: I promise you then to stay with Caroline replied Shirley As you say we shall enjoy each other s society We will not be separated to night Now rejoin your old friend and fear nothing for us

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If there should chance to be any disturbance in the night, captain; if you should hear the picking of a lock, the cutting out of a pane of glass, a stealthy tread of steps about the house (and I need not fear to tell   you  , who bear a well  tempered, mettlesome heart under your girl's ribbon sash, that such little incidents are very possible in the present time), what would you do?
children.prevalue: If there should chance to be any disturbance in the night captain if you should hear the picking of a lock the cutting out of a pane of glass a stealthy tread of steps about the house and I need not fear to tell you who bear a well tempered mettlesome heart under your girl s ribbon sash that such little incidents are very possible in the present time what would you do

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Don't know; faint, perhaps    fall down, and have to be picked up again. But, doctor, if you assign me the post of honour, you must give me arms. What weapons are there in your stronghold?
children.prevalue: Don t know faint perhaps fall down and have to be picked up again But doctor if you assign me the post of honour you must give me arms What weapons are there in your stronghold

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You could not wield a sword?
children.prevalue: You could not wield a sword

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No; I could manage the carving  knife better.
children.prevalue: No I could manage the carving knife better

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You will find a good one in the dining  room sideboard    a lady's knife, light to handle, and as sharp  pointed as a poniard.
children.prevalue: You will find a good one in the dining room sideboard a lady s knife light to handle and as sharp pointed as a poniard

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It will suit Caroline. But you must give me a brace of pistols. I know you have pistols.
children.prevalue: It will suit Caroline But you must give me a brace of pistols I know you have pistols

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I have two pairs. One pair I can place at your disposal. You will find them suspended over the mantelpiece of my study in cloth cases.
children.prevalue: I have two pairs One pair I can place at your disposal You will find them suspended over the mantelpiece of my study in cloth cases

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Loaded?
children.prevalue: Loaded

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yes, but not on the cock. Cock them before you go to bed. It is paying you a great compliment, captain, to lend you these. Were you one of the awkward squad you should not have them.
children.prevalue: Yes but not on the cock Cock them before you go to bed It is paying you a great compliment captain to lend you these Were you one of the awkward squad you should not have them

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I will take care. You need delay no longer, Mr. Helstone. You may go now.    He is gracious to me to lend me his pistols, she remarked, as the rector passed out at the garden gate. But come, Lina, she continued, let us go in and have some supper. I was too much vexed at tea with the vicinage of Mr. Sam Wynne to be able to eat, and now I am really hungry.
children.prevalue: I will take care You need delay no longer Mr Helstone You may go now He is gracious to me to lend me his pistols she remarked as the rector passed out at the garden gate But come Lina she continued let us go in and have some supper I was too much vexed at tea with the vicinage of Mr Sam Wynne to be able to eat and now I am really hungry

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Entering the house, they repaired to the darkened dining  room, through the open windows of which apartment stole the evening air, bearing the perfume of flowers from the garden, the very distant sound of far  retreating steps from the road, and a soft, vague murmur whose origin Caroline explained by the remark, uttered as she stood listening at the casement, Shirley, I hear the beck in the Hollow.
children.prevalue: Entering the house they repaired to the darkened dining room through the open windows of which apartment stole the evening air bearing the perfume of flowers from the garden the very distant sound of far retreating steps from the road and a soft vague murmur whose origin Caroline explained by the remark uttered as she stood listening at the casement Shirley I hear the beck in the Hollow

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Then she rang the bell, asked for a candle and some bread and milk    Miss Keeldar's usual supper and her own. Fanny, when she brought in the tray, would have closed the windows and the shutters, but was requested to desist for the present. The twilight was too calm, its breath too balmy to be yet excluded. They took their meal in silence. Caroline rose once to remove to the window  sill a glass of flowers which stood on the sideboard, the exhalation from the blossoms being somewhat too powerful for the sultry room. In returning she half opened a drawer, and took from it something that glittered clear and keen in her hand.
children.prevalue: Then she rang the bell asked for a candle and some bread and milk Miss Keeldar s usual supper and her own Fanny when she brought in the tray would have closed the windows and the shutters but was requested to desist for the present The twilight was too calm its breath too balmy to be yet excluded They took their meal in silence Caroline rose once to remove to the window sill a glass of flowers which stood on the sideboard the exhalation from the blossoms being somewhat too powerful for the sultry room In returning she half opened a drawer and took from it something that glittered clear and keen in her hand

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You assigned this to me, then, Shirley, did you? It is bright, keen  edged, finely tapered; it is dangerous  looking. I never yet felt the impulse which could move me to direct this against a fellow  creature. It is difficult to fancy that circumstances could nerve my arm to strike home with this long knife.
children.prevalue: You assigned this to me then Shirley did you It is bright keen edged finely tapered it is dangerous looking I never yet felt the impulse which could move me to direct this against a fellow creature It is difficult to fancy that circumstances could nerve my arm to strike home with this long knife

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I should hate to do it, replied Shirley, but I think I could do it, if goaded by certain exigencies which I can imagine. And Miss Keeldar quietly sipped her glass of new milk, looking somewhat thoughtful and a little pale; though, indeed, when did she not look pale? She was never florid.
children.prevalue: I should hate to do it replied Shirley but I think I could do it if goaded by certain exigencies which I can imagine And Miss Keeldar quietly sipped her glass of new milk looking somewhat thoughtful and a little pale though indeed when did she not look pale She was never florid

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The milk sipped and the bread eaten, Fanny was again summoned. She and Eliza were recommended to go to bed, which they were quite willing to do, being weary of the day's exertions, of much cutting of currant  buns, and filling of urns and teapots, and running backwards and forwards with trays. Ere long the maids' chamber door was heard to close. Caroline took a candle and went quietly all over the house, seeing that every window was fast and every door barred. She did not even evade the haunted back kitchen nor the vault  like cellars. These visited, she returned.
children.prevalue: The milk sipped and the bread eaten Fanny was again summoned She and Eliza were recommended to go to bed which they were quite willing to do being weary of the day s exertions of much cutting of currant buns and filling of urns and teapots and running backwards and forwards with trays Ere long the maids chamber door was heard to close Caroline took a candle and went quietly all over the house seeing that every window was fast and every door barred She did not even evade the haunted back kitchen nor the vault like cellars These visited she returned

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: There is neither spirit nor flesh in the house at present, she said, which should not be there. It is now near eleven o'clock, fully bedtime; yet I would rather sit up a little longer, if you do not object, Shirley. Here, she continued, I have brought the brace of pistols from my uncle's study. You may examine them at your leisure.
children.prevalue: There is neither spirit nor flesh in the house at present she said which should not be there It is now near eleven o clock fully bedtime yet I would rather sit up a little longer if you do not object Shirley Here she continued I have brought the brace of pistols from my uncle s study You may examine them at your leisure

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: She placed them on the table before her friend.
children.prevalue: She placed them on the table before her friend

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Why would you rather sit up longer? asked Miss Keeldar, taking up the firearms, examining them, and again laying them down.
children.prevalue: Why would you rather sit up longer asked Miss Keeldar taking up the firearms examining them and again laying them down

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Because I have a strange, excited feeling in my heart.
children.prevalue: Because I have a strange excited feeling in my heart

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: So have I.
children.prevalue: So have I

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Is this state of sleeplessness and restlessness caused by something electrical in the air, I wonder?
children.prevalue: Is this state of sleeplessness and restlessness caused by something electrical in the air I wonder

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No; the sky is clear, the stars numberless. It is a fine night.
children.prevalue: No the sky is clear the stars numberless It is a fine night

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But very still. I hear the water fret over its stony bed in Hollow's Copse as distinctly as if it ran below the churchyard wall.
children.prevalue: But very still I hear the water fret over its stony bed in Hollow s Copse as distinctly as if it ran below the churchyard wall

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I am glad it is so still a night. A moaning wind or rushing rain would vex me to fever just now.
children.prevalue: I am glad it is so still a night A moaning wind or rushing rain would vex me to fever just now

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Why, Shirley?
children.prevalue: Why Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Because it would baffle my efforts to listen.
children.prevalue: Because it would baffle my efforts to listen

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Do you listen towards the Hollow?
children.prevalue: Do you listen towards the Hollow

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes; it is the only quarter whence we can hear a sound just now.
children.prevalue: Yes it is the only quarter whence we can hear a sound just now

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The only one, Shirley.
children.prevalue: The only one Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: They both sat near the window, and both leaned their arms on the sill, and both inclined their heads towards the open lattice. They saw each other's young faces by the starlight and that dim June twilight which does not wholly fade from the west till dawn begins to break in the east.
children.prevalue: They both sat near the window and both leaned their arms on the sill and both inclined their heads towards the open lattice They saw each other s young faces by the starlight and that dim June twilight which does not wholly fade from the west till dawn begins to break in the east

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Mr. Helstone thinks we have no idea which way he is gone, murmured Miss Keeldar, nor on what errand, nor with what expectations, nor how prepared. But I guess much; do not you?
children.prevalue: Mr Helstone thinks we have no idea which way he is gone murmured Miss Keeldar nor on what errand nor with what expectations nor how prepared But I guess much do not you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I guess something.
children.prevalue: I guess something

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: All those gentlemen    your cousin Moore included    think that you and I are now asleep in our beds, unconscious.
children.prevalue: All those gentlemen your cousin Moore included think that you and I are now asleep in our beds unconscious

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Caring nothing about them    hoping and fearing nothing for them, added Caroline.
children.prevalue: Caring nothing about them hoping and fearing nothing for them added Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Both kept silent for full half an hour. The night was silent too; only the church clock measured its course by quarters. Some words were interchanged about the chill of the air. They wrapped their scarves closer round them, resumed their bonnets, which they had removed, and again watched.
children.prevalue: Both kept silent for full half an hour The night was silent too only the church clock measured its course by quarters Some words were interchanged about the chill of the air They wrapped their scarves closer round them resumed their bonnets which they had removed and again watched

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Towards midnight the teasing, monotonous bark of the house  dog disturbed the quietude of their vigil. Caroline rose, and made her way noiselessly through the dark passages to the kitchen, intending to appease him with a piece of bread. She succeeded. On returning to the dining  room she found it all dark, Miss Keeldar having extinguished the candle. The outline of her shape was visible near the still open window, leaning out. Miss Helstone asked no questions; she stole to her side. The dog recommenced barking furiously. Suddenly he stopped, and seemed to listen. The occupants of the dining  room listened too, and not merely now to the flow of the mill  stream. There was a nearer, though a muffled, sound on the road below the churchyard    a measured, beating, approaching sound    a dull tramp of marching feet.
children.prevalue: Towards midnight the teasing monotonous bark of the house dog disturbed the quietude of their vigil Caroline rose and made her way noiselessly through the dark passages to the kitchen intending to appease him with a piece of bread She succeeded On returning to the dining room she found it all dark Miss Keeldar having extinguished the candle The outline of her shape was visible near the still open window leaning out Miss Helstone asked no questions she stole to her side The dog recommenced barking furiously Suddenly he stopped and seemed to listen The occupants of the dining room listened too and not merely now to the flow of the mill stream There was a nearer though a muffled sound on the road below the churchyard a measured beating approaching sound a dull tramp of marching feet

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It drew near. Those who listened by degrees comprehended its extent. It was not the tread of two, nor of a dozen, nor of a score of men; it was the tread of hundreds. They could see nothing; the high shrubs of the garden formed a leafy screen between them and the road. To hear, however, was not enough, and this they felt as the troop trod forwards, and seemed actually passing the rectory. They felt it more when a human voice    though that voice spoke but one word    broke the hush of the night.
children.prevalue: It drew near Those who listened by degrees comprehended its extent It was not the tread of two nor of a dozen nor of a score of men it was the tread of hundreds They could see nothing the high shrubs of the garden formed a leafy screen between them and the road To hear however was not enough and this they felt as the troop trod forwards and seemed actually passing the rectory They felt it more when a human voice though that voice spoke but one word broke the hush of the night

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Halt!
children.prevalue: Halt

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: A halt followed. The march was arrested. Then came a low conference, of which no word was distinguishable from the dining  room.
children.prevalue: A halt followed The march was arrested Then came a low conference of which no word was distinguishable from the dining room

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: We   must   hear this, said Shirley.
children.prevalue: We must hear this said Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: She turned, took her pistols from the table, silently passed out through the middle window of the dining  room, which was, in fact, a glass door, stole down the walk to the garden wall, and stood listening under the lilacs. Caroline would not have quitted the house had she been alone, but where Shirley went she would go. She glanced at the weapon on the sideboard, but left it behind her, and presently stood at her friend's side. They dared not look over the wall, for fear of being seen; they were obliged to crouch behind it. They heard these words,
children.prevalue: She turned took her pistols from the table silently passed out through the middle window of the dining room which was in fact a glass door stole down the walk to the garden wall and stood listening under the lilacs Caroline would not have quitted the house had she been alone but where Shirley went she would go She glanced at the weapon on the sideboard but left it behind her and presently stood at her friend s side They dared not look over the wall for fear of being seen they were obliged to crouch behind it They heard these words

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It looks a rambling old building. Who lives in it besides the damned parson?
children.prevalue: It looks a rambling old building Who lives in it besides the damned parson

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Only three women    his niece and two servants.
children.prevalue: Only three women his niece and two servants

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Do you know where they sleep?
children.prevalue: Do you know where they sleep

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The lasses behind; the niece in a front room.
children.prevalue: The lasses behind the niece in a front room

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And Helstone?
children.prevalue: And Helstone

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yonder is his chamber. He was burning a light, but I see none now.
children.prevalue: Yonder is his chamber He was burning a light but I see none now

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Where would you get in?
children.prevalue: Where would you get in

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: If I were ordered to do his job    and he desarves it    I'd try yond' long window; it opens to the dining  room. I could grope my way upstairs, and I know his chamber.
children.prevalue: If I were ordered to do his job and he desarves it I d try yond long window it opens to the dining room I could grope my way upstairs and I know his chamber

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: How would you manage about the women folk?
children.prevalue: How would you manage about the women folk

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Let 'em alone except they shrieked, and then I'd soon quieten 'em. I could wish to find the old chap asleep. If he waked, he'd be dangerous.
children.prevalue: Let em alone except they shrieked and then I d soon quieten em I could wish to find the old chap asleep If he waked he d be dangerous

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Has he arms?
children.prevalue: Has he arms

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Firearms, allus    and allus loadened.
children.prevalue: Firearms allus and allus loadened

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then you're a fool to stop us here. A shot would give the alarm. Moore would be on us before we could turn round. We should miss our main object.
children.prevalue: Then you re a fool to stop us here A shot would give the alarm Moore would be on us before we could turn round We should miss our main object

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You might go on, I tell you. I'd engage Helstone alone.
children.prevalue: You might go on I tell you I d engage Helstone alone

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: A pause. One of the party dropped some weapon, which rang on the stone causeway. At this sound the rectory dog barked again furiously    fiercely.
children.prevalue: A pause One of the party dropped some weapon which rang on the stone causeway At this sound the rectory dog barked again furiously fiercely

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: That spoils all! said the voice. He'll awake. A noise like that might rouse the dead. You did not say there was a dog. Damn you! Forward!
children.prevalue: That spoils all said the voice He ll awake A noise like that might rouse the dead You did not say there was a dog Damn you Forward

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Forward they went    tramp, tramp    with mustering, manifold, slow  filing tread. They were gone.
children.prevalue: Forward they went tramp tramp with mustering manifold slow filing tread They were gone

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Shirley stood erect, looked over the wall, along the road.
children.prevalue: Shirley stood erect looked over the wall along the road

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Not a soul remains, she said.
children.prevalue: Not a soul remains she said

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: She stood and mused. Thank God! was the next observation.
children.prevalue: She stood and mused Thank God was the next observation

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Caroline repeated the ejaculation    not in so steady a tone. She was trembling much. Her heart was beating fast and thick; her face was cold, her forehead damp.
children.prevalue: Caroline repeated the ejaculation not in so steady a tone She was trembling much Her heart was beating fast and thick her face was cold her forehead damp

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Thank God for us! she reiterated. But what will happen elsewhere? They have passed us by that they may make sure of others.
children.prevalue: Thank God for us she reiterated But what will happen elsewhere They have passed us by that they may make sure of others

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: They have done well, returned Shirley, with composure. The others will defend themselves. They can do it. They are prepared for them. With us it is otherwise.
