children.value: She fell back on her pillow. Mrs. Pryor found means to steal quietly from the room. She re  entered it soon after, apparently as composed as if she had really not overheard this strange soliloquy.
children.prevalue: She fell back on her pillow Mrs Pryor found means to steal quietly from the room She re entered it soon after apparently as composed as if she had really not overheard this strange soliloquy

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The next day several callers came. It had become known that Miss Helstone was worse. Mr. Hall and his sister Margaret arrived. Both, after they had been in the sickroom, quitted it in tears; they had found the patient more altered than they expected. Hortense Moore came. Caroline seemed stimulated by her presence. She assured her, smiling, she was not dangerously ill; she talked to her in a low voice, but cheerfully. During her stay, excitement kept up the flush of her complexion; she looked better.
children.prevalue: The next day several callers came It had become known that Miss Helstone was worse Mr Hall and his sister Margaret arrived Both after they had been in the sickroom quitted it in tears they had found the patient more altered than they expected Hortense Moore came Caroline seemed stimulated by her presence She assured her smiling she was not dangerously ill she talked to her in a low voice but cheerfully During her stay excitement kept up the flush of her complexion she looked better

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: How is Mr. Robert? asked Mrs. Pryor, as Hortense was preparing to take leave.
children.prevalue: How is Mr Robert asked Mrs Pryor as Hortense was preparing to take leave

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: He was very well when he left.
children.prevalue: He was very well when he left

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Left! Is he gone from home?
children.prevalue: Left Is he gone from home

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was then explained that some police intelligence about the rioters of whom he was in pursuit had, that morning, called him away to Birmingham, and probably a fortnight might elapse ere he returned.
children.prevalue: It was then explained that some police intelligence about the rioters of whom he was in pursuit had that morning called him away to Birmingham and probably a fortnight might elapse ere he returned

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He is not aware that Miss Helstone is very ill?
children.prevalue: He is not aware that Miss Helstone is very ill

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh no! He thought, like me, that she had only a bad cold.
children.prevalue: Oh no He thought like me that she had only a bad cold

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: After this visit, Mrs. Pryor took care not to approach Caroline's couch for above an hour. She heard her weep, and dared not look on her tears.
children.prevalue: After this visit Mrs Pryor took care not to approach Caroline s couch for above an hour She heard her weep and dared not look on her tears

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: As evening closed in, she brought her some tea. Caroline, opening her eyes from a moment's slumber, viewed her nurse with an unrecognizing glance.
children.prevalue: As evening closed in she brought her some tea Caroline opening her eyes from a moment s slumber viewed her nurse with an unrecognizing glance

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I smelt the honeysuckles in the glen this summer morning, she said, as I stood at the counting  house window.
children.prevalue: I smelt the honeysuckles in the glen this summer morning she said as I stood at the counting house window

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Strange words like these from pallid lips pierce a loving listener's heart more poignantly than steel. They sound romantic, perhaps, in books; in real life they are harrowing.
children.prevalue: Strange words like these from pallid lips pierce a loving listener s heart more poignantly than steel They sound romantic perhaps in books in real life they are harrowing

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: My darling, do you know me? said Mrs. Pryor.
children.prevalue: My darling do you know me said Mrs Pryor

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I went in to call Robert to breakfast. I have been with him in the garden. He asked me to go. A heavy dew has refreshed the flowers. The peaches are ripening.
children.prevalue: I went in to call Robert to breakfast I have been with him in the garden He asked me to go A heavy dew has refreshed the flowers The peaches are ripening

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: My darling! my darling! again and again repeated the nurse.
children.prevalue: My darling my darling again and again repeated the nurse

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I thought it was daylight    long after sunrise. It looks dark. Is the moon now set?
children.prevalue: I thought it was daylight long after sunrise It looks dark Is the moon now set

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That moon, lately risen, was gazing full and mild upon her. Floating in deep blue space, it watched her unclouded.
children.prevalue: That moon lately risen was gazing full and mild upon her Floating in deep blue space it watched her unclouded

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Then it is not morning? I am not at the cottage? Who is this? I see a shape at my bedside.
children.prevalue: Then it is not morning I am not at the cottage Who is this I see a shape at my bedside

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: It is myself    it is your friend    your nurse    your         Lean your head on my shoulder. Collect yourself. In a lower tone    O God, take pity! Give   her   life, and   me   strength! Send me courage! Teach me words!
children.prevalue: It is myself it is your friend your nurse your Lean your head on my shoulder Collect yourself In a lower tone O God take pity Give her life and me strength Send me courage Teach me words

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Some minutes passed in silence. The patient lay mute and passive in the trembling arms, on the throbbing bosom of the nurse.
children.prevalue: Some minutes passed in silence The patient lay mute and passive in the trembling arms on the throbbing bosom of the nurse

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I am better now, whispered Caroline at last, much better. I feel where I am. This is Mrs. Pryor near me. I was dreaming. I talk when I wake up from dreams; people often do in illness. How fast your heart beats, ma'am! Do not be afraid.
children.prevalue: I am better now whispered Caroline at last much better I feel where I am This is Mrs Pryor near me I was dreaming I talk when I wake up from dreams people often do in illness How fast your heart beats ma am Do not be afraid

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It is not fear, child    only a little anxiety, which will pass. I have brought you some tea, Cary. Your uncle made it himself. You know he says he can make a better cup of tea than any housewife can. Taste it. He is concerned to hear that you eat so little; he would be glad if you had a better appetite.
children.prevalue: It is not fear child only a little anxiety which will pass I have brought you some tea Cary Your uncle made it himself You know he says he can make a better cup of tea than any housewife can Taste it He is concerned to hear that you eat so little he would be glad if you had a better appetite

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I am thirsty. Let me drink.
children.prevalue: I am thirsty Let me drink

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: She drank eagerly.
children.prevalue: She drank eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: What o'clock is it, ma'am? she asked.
children.prevalue: What o clock is it ma am she asked

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Past nine.
children.prevalue: Past nine

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Not later? Oh! I have yet a long night before me. But the tea has made me strong. I will sit up.
children.prevalue: Not later Oh I have yet a long night before me But the tea has made me strong I will sit up

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Mrs. Pryor raised her, and arranged her pillows.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor raised her and arranged her pillows

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Thank Heaven! I am not always equally miserable, and ill, and hopeless. The afternoon has been bad since Hortense went; perhaps the evening may be better. It is a fine night, I think? The moon shines clear.
children.prevalue: Thank Heaven I am not always equally miserable and ill and hopeless The afternoon has been bad since Hortense went perhaps the evening may be better It is a fine night I think The moon shines clear

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Very fine    a perfect summer night. The old church  tower gleams white almost as silver.
children.prevalue: Very fine a perfect summer night The old church tower gleams white almost as silver

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And does the churchyard look peaceful?
children.prevalue: And does the churchyard look peaceful

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes, and the garden also. Dew glistens on the foliage.
children.prevalue: Yes and the garden also Dew glistens on the foliage

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Can you see many long weeds and nettles amongst the graves? or do they look turfy and flowery?
children.prevalue: Can you see many long weeds and nettles amongst the graves or do they look turfy and flowery

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I see closed daisy  heads gleaming like pearls on some mounds. Thomas has mown down the dock  leaves and rank grass, and cleared all away.
children.prevalue: I see closed daisy heads gleaming like pearls on some mounds Thomas has mown down the dock leaves and rank grass and cleared all away

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I always like that to be done; it soothes one's mind to see the place in order. And, I dare say, within the church just now that moonlight shines as softly as in my room. It will fall through the east window full on the Helstone monument. When I close my eyes I seem to see poor papa's epitaph in black letters on the white marble. There is plenty of room for other inscriptions underneath.
children.prevalue: I always like that to be done it soothes one s mind to see the place in order And I dare say within the church just now that moonlight shines as softly as in my room It will fall through the east window full on the Helstone monument When I close my eyes I seem to see poor papa s epitaph in black letters on the white marble There is plenty of room for other inscriptions underneath

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: William Farren came to look after your flowers this morning. He was afraid, now you cannot tend them yourself, they would be neglected. He has taken two of your favourite plants home to nurse for you.
children.prevalue: William Farren came to look after your flowers this morning He was afraid now you cannot tend them yourself they would be neglected He has taken two of your favourite plants home to nurse for you

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: If I were to make a will, I would leave William all my plants; Shirley my trinkets    except one, which must not be taken off my neck; and you, ma'am, my books. After a pause    Mrs. Pryor, I feel a longing wish for something.
children.prevalue: If I were to make a will I would leave William all my plants Shirley my trinkets except one which must not be taken off my neck and you ma am my books After a pause Mrs Pryor I feel a longing wish for something

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: For what, Caroline?
children.prevalue: For what Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You know I always delight to hear you sing. Sing me a hymn just now. Sing that hymn which begins,
children.prevalue: You know I always delight to hear you sing Sing me a hymn just now Sing that hymn which begins

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: 'Our God, our help in ages past,        Our hope for years to come,      Our shelter from the stormy blast,        Our refuge, haven, home!'
children.prevalue: Our God our help in ages past Our hope for years to come Our shelter from the stormy blast Our refuge haven home

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Mrs. Pryor at once complied.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor at once complied

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: No wonder Caroline liked to hear her sing. Her voice, even in speaking, was sweet and silver clear; in song it was almost divine. Neither flute nor dulcimer has tones so pure. But the tone was secondary, compared to the expression which trembled through    a tender vibration from a feeling heart.
children.prevalue: No wonder Caroline liked to hear her sing Her voice even in speaking was sweet and silver clear in song it was almost divine Neither flute nor dulcimer has tones so pure But the tone was secondary compared to the expression which trembled through a tender vibration from a feeling heart

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The servants in the kitchen, hearing the strain, stole to the stair  foot to listen. Even old Helstone, as he walked in the garden, pondering over the unaccountable and feeble nature of women, stood still amongst his borders to catch the mournful melody more distinctly. Why it reminded him of his forgotten dead wife, he could not tell; nor why it made him more concerned than he had hitherto been for Caroline's fading girlhood. He was glad to recollect that he had promised to pay Wynne, the magistrate, a visit that evening. Low spirits and gloomy thoughts were very much his aversion. When they attacked him he usually found means to make them march in double  quick time. The hymn followed him faintly as he crossed the fields. He hastened his customary sharp pace, that he might get beyond its reach.
children.prevalue: The servants in the kitchen hearing the strain stole to the stair foot to listen Even old Helstone as he walked in the garden pondering over the unaccountable and feeble nature of women stood still amongst his borders to catch the mournful melody more distinctly Why it reminded him of his forgotten dead wife he could not tell nor why it made him more concerned than he had hitherto been for Caroline s fading girlhood He was glad to recollect that he had promised to pay Wynne the magistrate a visit that evening Low spirits and gloomy thoughts were very much his aversion When they attacked him he usually found means to make them march in double quick time The hymn followed him faintly as he crossed the fields He hastened his customary sharp pace that he might get beyond its reach

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Thy word commands our flesh to dust,            'Return, ye sons of men;'      All nations rose from earth at first,        And turn to earth again.
children.prevalue: Thy word commands our flesh to dust Return ye sons of men All nations rose from earth at first And turn to earth again

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: A thousand ages in Thy sight        Are like an evening gone          Short as the watch that ends the night        Before the rising sun.
children.prevalue: A thousand ages in Thy sight Are like an evening gone Short as the watch that ends the night Before the rising sun

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Time, like an ever  rolling stream,        Bears all its sons away;      They fly, forgotten, as a dream        Dies at the opening day.
children.prevalue: Time like an ever rolling stream Bears all its sons away They fly forgotten as a dream Dies at the opening day

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Like flowery fields, the nations stand,        Fresh in the morning light;      The flowers beneath the mower's hand        Lie withering ere 'tis night.
children.prevalue: Like flowery fields the nations stand Fresh in the morning light The flowers beneath the mower s hand Lie withering ere tis night

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Our God, our help in ages past,        Our hope for years to come,      Be Thou our guard while troubles last            O Father, be our home!
children.prevalue: Our God our help in ages past Our hope for years to come Be Thou our guard while troubles last O Father be our home

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Now sing a song    a Scottish song, suggested Caroline, when the hymn was over    'Ye banks and braes o' bonnie Doon.'
children.prevalue: Now sing a song a Scottish song suggested Caroline when the hymn was over Ye banks and braes o bonnie Doon

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Again Mrs. Pryor obeyed, or essayed to obey. At the close of the first stanza she stopped. She could get no further. Her full heart flowed over.
children.prevalue: Again Mrs Pryor obeyed or essayed to obey At the close of the first stanza she stopped She could get no further Her full heart flowed over

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You are weeping at the pathos of the air. Come here, and I will comfort you, said Caroline, in a pitying accent. Mrs. Pryor came. She sat down on the edge of her patient's bed, and allowed the wasted arms to encircle her.
children.prevalue: You are weeping at the pathos of the air Come here and I will comfort you said Caroline in a pitying accent Mrs Pryor came She sat down on the edge of her patient s bed and allowed the wasted arms to encircle her

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: You often soothe me; let me soothe you, murmured the young girl, kissing her cheek. I hope, she added, it is not for me you weep?
children.prevalue: You often soothe me let me soothe you murmured the young girl kissing her cheek I hope she added it is not for me you weep

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: No answer followed.
children.prevalue: No answer followed

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Do you think I shall not get better? I do not feel   very   ill    only weak.
children.prevalue: Do you think I shall not get better I do not feel very ill only weak

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: But your mind, Caroline    your mind is crushed. Your heart is almost broken; you have been so neglected, so repulsed, left so desolate.
children.prevalue: But your mind Caroline your mind is crushed Your heart is almost broken you have been so neglected so repulsed left so desolate

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: I believe grief is, and always has been, my worst ailment. I sometimes think if an abundant gush of happiness came on me I could revive yet.
children.prevalue: I believe grief is and always has been my worst ailment I sometimes think if an abundant gush of happiness came on me I could revive yet

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Do you wish to live?
children.prevalue: Do you wish to live

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I have no object in life.
children.prevalue: I have no object in life

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: You love me, Caroline?
children.prevalue: You love me Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Very much    very truly    inexpressibly sometimes. Just now I feel as if I could almost grow to your heart.
children.prevalue: Very much very truly inexpressibly sometimes Just now I feel as if I could almost grow to your heart

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I will return directly, dear, remarked Mrs. Pryor, as she laid Caroline down.
children.prevalue: I will return directly dear remarked Mrs Pryor as she laid Caroline down

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Quitting her, she glided to the door, softly turned the key in the lock, ascertained that it was fast, and came back. She bent over her. She threw back the curtain to admit the moonlight more freely. She gazed intently on her face.
children.prevalue: Quitting her she glided to the door softly turned the key in the lock ascertained that it was fast and came back She bent over her She threw back the curtain to admit the moonlight more freely She gazed intently on her face

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Then, if you love me, said she, speaking quickly, with an altered voice; if you feel as if, to use your own words, you could 'grow to my heart,' it will be neither shock nor pain for you to know that   that   heart is the source whence yours was filled; that from   my   veins issued the tide which flows in   yours  ; that you are   mine      my daughter    my own child.
children.prevalue: Then if you love me said she speaking quickly with an altered voice if you feel as if to use your own words you could grow to my heart it will be neither shock nor pain for you to know that that heart is the source whence yours was filled that from my veins issued the tide which flows in yours that you are mine my daughter my own child

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Mrs. Pryor
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: My own child!
children.prevalue: My own child

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: That is    that means    you have adopted me?
children.prevalue: That is that means you have adopted me

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: It means that, if I have given you nothing else, I at least gave you life; that I bore you, nursed you; that I am your true mother. No other woman can claim the title; it is   mine  .
children.prevalue: It means that if I have given you nothing else I at least gave you life that I bore you nursed you that I am your true mother No other woman can claim the title it is mine

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: But Mrs. James Helstone    but my father's wife, whom I do not remember ever to have seen, she is my mother?
children.prevalue: But Mrs James Helstone but my father s wife whom I do not remember ever to have seen she is my mother

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: She   is   your mother. James Helstone was   my   husband. I say you are   mine  . I have proved it. I thought perhaps you were all his, which would have been a cruel dispensation for me. I find it is   not   so. God permitted me to be the parent of my child's mind. It belongs to me; it is my property    my   right  . These features are James's own. He had a fine face when he was young, and not altered by error. Papa, my darling, gave you your blue eyes and soft brown hair; he gave you the oval of your face and the regularity of your lineaments    the outside   he   conferred; but the heart and the brain are   mine  . The germs are from   me  , and they are improved, they are developed to excellence. I esteem and approve my child as highly as I do most fondly love her.
children.prevalue: She is your mother James Helstone was my husband I say you are mine I have proved it I thought perhaps you were all his which would have been a cruel dispensation for me I find it is not so God permitted me to be the parent of my child s mind It belongs to me it is my property my right These features are James s own He had a fine face when he was young and not altered by error Papa my darling gave you your blue eyes and soft brown hair he gave you the oval of your face and the regularity of your lineaments the outside he conferred but the heart and the brain are mine The germs are from me and they are improved they are developed to excellence I esteem and approve my child as highly as I do most fondly love her

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Is what I hear true? Is it no dream?
children.prevalue: Is what I hear true Is it no dream

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: I wish it were as true that the substance and colour of health were restored to your cheek.
children.prevalue: I wish it were as true that the substance and colour of health were restored to your cheek

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: My own mother! is she one I can be so fond of as I can of you? People generally did not like her    so I have been given to understand.
children.prevalue: My own mother is she one I can be so fond of as I can of you People generally did not like her so I have been given to understand

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: They told you that? Well, your mother now tells you that, not having the gift to please people generally, for their approbation she does not care. Her thoughts are centred in her child. Does that child welcome or reject her?
children.prevalue: They told you that Well your mother now tells you that not having the gift to please people generally for their approbation she does not care Her thoughts are centred in her child Does that child welcome or reject her

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: But if you   are   my mother, the world is all changed to me. Surely I can live. I should like to recover
children.prevalue: But if you are my mother the world is all changed to me Surely I can live I should like to recover

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: You   must   recover. You drew life and strength from my breast when you were a tiny, fair infant, over whose blue eyes I used to weep, fearing I beheld in your very beauty the sign of qualities that had entered my heart like iron, and pierced through my soul like a sword. Daughter! we have been long parted; I return now to cherish you again.
children.prevalue: You must recover You drew life and strength from my breast when you were a tiny fair infant over whose blue eyes I used to weep fearing I beheld in your very beauty the sign of qualities that had entered my heart like iron and pierced through my soul like a sword Daughter we have been long parted I return now to cherish you again

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: She held her to her bosom; she cradled her in her arms; she rocked her softly, as if lulling a young child to sleep.
children.prevalue: She held her to her bosom she cradled her in her arms she rocked her softly as if lulling a young child to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: My mother    my own mother!
children.prevalue: My mother my own mother

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: The offspring nestled to the parent; that parent, feeling the endearment and hearing the appeal, gathered her closer still. She covered her with noiseless kisses; she murmured love over her, like a cushat fostering its young.
children.prevalue: The offspring nestled to the parent that parent feeling the endearment and hearing the appeal gathered her closer still She covered her with noiseless kisses she murmured love over her like a cushat fostering its young

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: There was silence in the room for a long while.
children.prevalue: There was silence in the room for a long while

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Does my uncle know?
children.prevalue: Does my uncle know

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Your uncle knows. I told him when I first came to stay with you here.
children.prevalue: Your uncle knows I told him when I first came to stay with you here

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Did you recognize me when we first met at Fieldhead?
children.prevalue: Did you recognize me when we first met at Fieldhead

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: How could it be otherwise? Mr. and Miss Helstone being announced, I was prepared to see my child.
children.prevalue: How could it be otherwise Mr and Miss Helstone being announced I was prepared to see my child

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: It was that, then, which moved you. I saw you disturbed.
children.prevalue: It was that then which moved you I saw you disturbed

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: You saw nothing, Caroline; I can cover my feelings. You can never tell what an age of strange sensation I lived, during the two minutes that elapsed between the report of your name and your entrance. You can never tell how your look, mien, carriage, shook me.
children.prevalue: You saw nothing Caroline I can cover my feelings You can never tell what an age of strange sensation I lived during the two minutes that elapsed between the report of your name and your entrance You can never tell how your look mien carriage shook me

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Why? Were you disappointed?
children.prevalue: Why Were you disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: What will she be like? I had asked myself; and when I saw what you were like, I could have dropped.
children.prevalue: What will she be like I had asked myself and when I saw what you were like I could have dropped

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Mamma, why?
children.prevalue: Mamma why

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: I trembled in your presence. I said, I will never own her; she shall never know me.
children.prevalue: I trembled in your presence I said I will never own her she shall never know me

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: But I said and did nothing remarkable. I felt a little diffident at the thought of an introduction to strangers    that was all.
children.prevalue: But I said and did nothing remarkable I felt a little diffident at the thought of an introduction to strangers that was all

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: I soon saw you were diffident. That was the first thing which reassured me. Had you been rustic, clownish, awkward, I should have been content.
children.prevalue: I soon saw you were diffident That was the first thing which reassured me Had you been rustic clownish awkward I should have been content

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: You puzzle me.
children.prevalue: You puzzle me

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: I had reason to dread a fair outside, to mistrust a popular bearing, to shudder before distinction, grace, and courtesy. Beauty and affability had come in my way when I was recluse, desolate, young, and ignorant    a toil  worn governess perishing of uncheered labour, breaking down before her time. These, Caroline, when they smiled on me, I mistook for angels. I followed them home; and when into their hands I had given without reserve my whole chance of future happiness, it was my lot to witness a transfiguration on the domestic hearth    to see the white mask lifted, the bright disguise put away, and opposite me sat down         O God, I   have   suffered!
children.prevalue: I had reason to dread a fair outside to mistrust a popular bearing to shudder before distinction grace and courtesy Beauty and affability had come in my way when I was recluse desolate young and ignorant a toil worn governess perishing of uncheered labour breaking down before her time These Caroline when they smiled on me I mistook for angels I followed them home and when into their hands I had given without reserve my whole chance of future happiness it was my lot to witness a transfiguration on the domestic hearth to see the white mask lifted the bright disguise put away and opposite me sat down O God I have suffered

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: She sank on the pillow.
children.prevalue: She sank on the pillow

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: I   have   suffered! None saw    none knew. There was no sympathy, no redemption, no redress!
children.prevalue: I have suffered None saw none knew There was no sympathy no redemption no redress

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Take comfort, mother. It is over now.
children.prevalue: Take comfort mother It is over now

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: It is over, and not fruitlessly. I tried to keep the word of His patience. He kept me in the days of my anguish. I was afraid with terror    I was troubled. Through great tribulation He brought me through to a salvation revealed in this last time. My fear had torment; He has cast it out. He has given me in its stead perfect love. But, Caroline
children.prevalue: It is over and not fruitlessly I tried to keep the word of His patience He kept me in the days of my anguish I was afraid with terror I was troubled Through great tribulation He brought me through to a salvation revealed in this last time My fear had torment He has cast it out He has given me in its stead perfect love But Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Thus she invoked her daughter after a pause.
children.prevalue: Thus she invoked her daughter after a pause

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Mother!
children.prevalue: Mother

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: I charge you, when you next look on your father's monument, to respect the name chiselled there. To you he did only good. On you he conferred his whole treasure of beauties, nor added to them one dark defect. All   you   derived from him is excellent. You owe him gratitude. Leave, between him and me, the settlement of our mutual account. Meddle not. God is the arbiter. This world's laws never came near us    never! They were powerless as a rotten bulrush to protect me    impotent as idiot babblings to restrain him! As you said, it is all over now; the grave lies between us. There he sleeps, in that church. To his dust I say this night, what I have never said before, 'James, slumber peacefully! See! your terrible debt is cancelled! Look! I wipe out the long, black account with my own hand! James, your child atones. This living likeness of you    this thing with your perfect features    this one good gift you gave me has nestled affectionately to my heart, and tenderly called me mother. Husband, rest forgiven!'
children.prevalue: I charge you when you next look on your father s monument to respect the name chiselled there To you he did only good On you he conferred his whole treasure of beauties nor added to them one dark defect All you derived from him is excellent You owe him gratitude Leave between him and me the settlement of our mutual account Meddle not God is the arbiter This world s laws never came near us never They were powerless as a rotten bulrush to protect me impotent as idiot babblings to restrain him As you said it is all over now the grave lies between us There he sleeps in that church To his dust I say this night what I have never said before James slumber peacefully See your terrible debt is cancelled Look I wipe out the long black account with my own hand James your child atones This living likeness of you this thing with your perfect features this one good gift you gave me has nestled affectionately to my heart and tenderly called me mother Husband rest forgiven

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Dearest mother, that is right! Can papa's spirit hear us? Is he comforted to know that we still love him?
children.prevalue: Dearest mother that is right Can papa s spirit hear us Is he comforted to know that we still love him

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: I said nothing of love. I spoke of forgiveness. Mind the truth, child; I said nothing of love! On the threshold of eternity, should he be there to see me enter, will I maintain that.
children.prevalue: I said nothing of love I spoke of forgiveness Mind the truth child I said nothing of love On the threshold of eternity should he be there to see me enter will I maintain that

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: O mother, you must have suffered!
children.prevalue: O mother you must have suffered

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: O child, the human heart   can   suffer! It can hold more tears than the ocean holds waters. We never know how deep, how wide it is, till misery begins to unbind her clouds, and fill it with rushing blackness.
children.prevalue: O child the human heart can suffer It can hold more tears than the ocean holds waters We never know how deep how wide it is till misery begins to unbind her clouds and fill it with rushing blackness

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Mother, forget.
children.prevalue: Mother forget

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Forget! she said, with the strangest spectre of a laugh. The north pole will rush to the south, and the headlands of Europe be locked into the bays of Australia ere I forget.
children.prevalue: Forget she said with the strangest spectre of a laugh The north pole will rush to the south and the headlands of Europe be locked into the bays of Australia ere I forget

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Hush, mother! Rest! Be at peace!
children.prevalue: Hush mother Rest Be at peace

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: And the child lulled the parent, as the parent had erst lulled the child. At last Mrs. Pryor wept. She then grew calmer. She resumed those tender cares agitation had for a moment suspended. Replacing her daughter on the couch, she smoothed the pillow and spread the sheet. The soft hair whose locks were loosened she rearranged, the damp brow she refreshed with a cool, fragrant essence.
children.prevalue: And the child lulled the parent as the parent had erst lulled the child At last Mrs Pryor wept She then grew calmer She resumed those tender cares agitation had for a moment suspended Replacing her daughter on the couch she smoothed the pillow and spread the sheet The soft hair whose locks were loosened she rearranged the damp brow she refreshed with a cool fragrant essence

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Mamma, let them bring a candle, that I may see you; and tell my uncle to come into this room by  and  by. I want to hear him say that I am your daughter. And, mamma, take your supper here. Don't leave me for one minute to  night.
children.prevalue: Mamma let them bring a candle that I may see you and tell my uncle to come into this room by and by I want to hear him say that I am your daughter And mamma take your supper here Don t leave me for one minute to night

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: O Caroline, it is well you are gentle! You will say to me, Go, and I shall go; Come, and I shall come; Do this, and I shall do it. You inherit a certain manner as well as certain features. It will always be 'mamma' prefacing a mandate    softly spoken, though, from you, thank God! Well, she added, under her breath, he spoke softly too, once, like a flute breathing tenderness; and then, when the world was not by to listen, discords that split the nerves and curdled the blood    sounds to inspire insanity.
children.prevalue: O Caroline it is well you are gentle You will say to me Go and I shall go Come and I shall come Do this and I shall do it You inherit a certain manner as well as certain features It will always be mamma prefacing a mandate softly spoken though from you thank God Well she added under her breath he spoke softly too once like a flute breathing tenderness and then when the world was not by to listen discords that split the nerves and curdled the blood sounds to inspire insanity

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: It seems so natural, mamma, to ask you for this and that. I shall want nobody but you to be near me, or to do anything for me. But do not let me be troublesome. Check me if I encroach.
children.prevalue: It seems so natural mamma to ask you for this and that I shall want nobody but you to be near me or to do anything for me But do not let me be troublesome Check me if I encroach

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: You must not depend on me to check you; you must keep guard over yourself. I have little moral courage; the want of it is my bane. It is that which has made me an unnatural parent    which has kept me apart from my child during the ten years which have elapsed since my husband's death left me at liberty to claim her. It was that which first unnerved my arms and permitted the infant I might have retained a while longer to be snatched prematurely from their embrace.
children.prevalue: You must not depend on me to check you you must keep guard over yourself I have little moral courage the want of it is my bane It is that which has made me an unnatural parent which has kept me apart from my child during the ten years which have elapsed since my husband s death left me at liberty to claim her It was that which first unnerved my arms and permitted the infant I might have retained a while longer to be snatched prematurely from their embrace

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: How, mamma?
children.prevalue: How mamma

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: I let you go as a babe, because you were pretty, and I feared your loveliness, deeming it the stamp of perversity. They sent me your portrait, taken at eight years old; that portrait confirmed my fears. Had it shown me a sunburnt little rustic    a heavy, blunt  featured, commonplace child    I should have hastened to claim you; but there, under the silver paper, I saw blooming the delicacy of an aristocratic flower    'little lady' was written on every trait. I had too recently crawled from under the yoke of the fine gentleman    escaped galled, crushed, paralyzed, dying    to dare to encounter his still finer and most fairy  like representative. My sweet little lady overwhelmed me with dismay; her air of native elegance froze my very marrow. In my experience I had not met with truth, modesty, good principle as the concomitants of beauty. A form so straight and fine, I argued, must conceal a mind warped and cruel. I had little faith in the power of education to rectify such a mind; or rather, I entirely misdoubted my own ability to influence it. Caroline, I dared not undertake to rear you. I resolved to leave you in your uncle's hands. Matthewson Helstone I knew, if an austere, was an upright man. He and all the world thought hardly of me for my strange, unmotherly resolve, and I deserved to be misjudged.
children.prevalue: I let you go as a babe because you were pretty and I feared your loveliness deeming it the stamp of perversity They sent me your portrait taken at eight years old that portrait confirmed my fears Had it shown me a sunburnt little rustic a heavy blunt featured commonplace child I should have hastened to claim you but there under the silver paper I saw blooming the delicacy of an aristocratic flower little lady was written on every trait I had too recently crawled from under the yoke of the fine gentleman escaped galled crushed paralyzed dying to dare to encounter his still finer and most fairy like representative My sweet little lady overwhelmed me with dismay her air of native elegance froze my very marrow In my experience I had not met with truth modesty good principle as the concomitants of beauty A form so straight and fine I argued must conceal a mind warped and cruel I had little faith in the power of education to rectify such a mind or rather I entirely misdoubted my own ability to influence it Caroline I dared not undertake to rear you I resolved to leave you in your uncle s hands Matthewson Helstone I knew if an austere was an upright man He and all the world thought hardly of me for my strange unmotherly resolve and I deserved to be misjudged

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Mamma, why did you call yourself Mrs. Pryor?
children.prevalue: Mamma why did you call yourself Mrs Pryor

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: It was a name in my mother's family. I adopted it that I might live unmolested. My married name recalled too vividly my married life; I could not bear it. Besides, threats were uttered of forcing me to return to bondage. It could not be. Rather a bier for a bed, the grave for a home. My new name sheltered me. I resumed under its screen my old occupation of teaching. At first it scarcely procured me the means of sustaining life; but how savoury was hunger when I fasted in peace! How safe seemed the darkness and chill of an unkindled hearth when no lurid reflection from terror crimsoned its desolation! How serene was solitude, when I feared not the irruption of violence and vice!
children.prevalue: It was a name in my mother s family I adopted it that I might live unmolested My married name recalled too vividly my married life I could not bear it Besides threats were uttered of forcing me to return to bondage It could not be Rather a bier for a bed the grave for a home My new name sheltered me I resumed under its screen my old occupation of teaching At first it scarcely procured me the means of sustaining life but how savoury was hunger when I fasted in peace How safe seemed the darkness and chill of an unkindled hearth when no lurid reflection from terror crimsoned its desolation How serene was solitude when I feared not the irruption of violence and vice

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: But, mamma, you have been in this neighbourhood before. How did it happen that when you reappeared here with Miss Keeldar you were not recognized?
children.prevalue: But mamma you have been in this neighbourhood before How did it happen that when you reappeared here with Miss Keeldar you were not recognized

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: I only paid a short visit, as a bride, twenty years ago, and then I was very different to what I am now    slender, almost as slender as my daughter is at this day. My complexion, my very features are changed; my hair, my style of dress    everything is altered. You cannot fancy me a slim young person, attired in scanty drapery of white muslin, with bare arms, bracelets and necklace of beads, and hair disposed in round Grecian curls above my forehead?
children.prevalue: I only paid a short visit as a bride twenty years ago and then I was very different to what I am now slender almost as slender as my daughter is at this day My complexion my very features are changed my hair my style of dress everything is altered You cannot fancy me a slim young person attired in scanty drapery of white muslin with bare arms bracelets and necklace of beads and hair disposed in round Grecian curls above my forehead

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: You must, indeed, have been different. Mamma, I heard the front door open. If it is my uncle coming in, just ask him to step upstairs, and let me hear his assurance that I am truly awake and collected, and not dreaming or delirious.
children.prevalue: You must indeed have been different Mamma I heard the front door open If it is my uncle coming in just ask him to step upstairs and let me hear his assurance that I am truly awake and collected and not dreaming or delirious

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: The rector, of his own accord, was mounting the stairs, and Mrs. Pryor summoned him to his niece's apartment.
children.prevalue: The rector of his own accord was mounting the stairs and Mrs Pryor summoned him to his niece s apartment

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: She's not worse, I hope? he inquired hastily.
children.prevalue: She s not worse I hope he inquired hastily

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: I think her better. She is disposed to converse; she seems stronger.
children.prevalue: I think her better She is disposed to converse she seems stronger

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: Good! said he, brushing quickly into the room.    Ha, Cary! how do? Did you drink my cup of tea? I made it for you just as I like it myself.
children.prevalue: Good said he brushing quickly into the room Ha Cary how do Did you drink my cup of tea I made it for you just as I like it myself

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: I drank it every drop, uncle. It did me good; it has made me quite alive. I have a wish for company, so I begged Mrs. Pryor to call you in.
children.prevalue: I drank it every drop uncle It did me good it has made me quite alive I have a wish for company so I begged Mrs Pryor to call you in

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: The respected ecclesiastic looked pleased, and yet embarrassed. He was willing enough to bestow his company on his sick niece for ten minutes, since it was her whim to wish it; but what means to employ for her entertainment he knew not. He hemmed    he fidgeted.
children.prevalue: The respected ecclesiastic looked pleased and yet embarrassed He was willing enough to bestow his company on his sick niece for ten minutes since it was her whim to wish it but what means to employ for her entertainment he knew not He hemmed he fidgeted

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: You'll be up in a trice, he observed, by way of saying something. The little weakness will soon pass off; and then you must drink port wine    a pipe, if you can    and eat game and oysters. I'll get them for you, if they are to be had anywhere. Bless me! we'll make you as strong as Samson before we're done with you.
children.prevalue: You ll be up in a trice he observed by way of saying something The little weakness will soon pass off and then you must drink port wine a pipe if you can and eat game and oysters I ll get them for you if they are to be had anywhere Bless me we ll make you as strong as Samson before we re done with you

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: Who is that lady, uncle, standing beside you at the bed  foot?
children.prevalue: Who is that lady uncle standing beside you at the bed foot

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: Good God! he ejaculated. She's not wandering, is she, ma'am?
children.prevalue: Good God he ejaculated She s not wandering is she ma am

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: Mrs. Pryor smiled.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor smiled

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: I am wandering in a pleasant world, said Caroline, in a soft, happy voice, and I want you to tell me whether it is real or visionary. What lady is that? Give her a name, uncle.
children.prevalue: I am wandering in a pleasant world said Caroline in a soft happy voice and I want you to tell me whether it is real or visionary What lady is that Give her a name uncle

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: We must have Dr. Rile again, ma'am; or better still, MacTurk. He's less of a humbug. Thomas must saddle the pony and go for him.
children.prevalue: We must have Dr Rile again ma am or better still MacTurk He s less of a humbug Thomas must saddle the pony and go for him

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: No; I don't want a doctor. Mamma shall be my only physician. Now, do you understand, uncle?
children.prevalue: No I don t want a doctor Mamma shall be my only physician Now do you understand uncle

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: Mr. Helstone pushed up his spectacles from his nose to his forehead, handled his snuff  box, and administered to himself a portion of the contents. Thus fortified, he answered briefly, I see daylight. You've told her then, ma'am?
children.prevalue: Mr Helstone pushed up his spectacles from his nose to his forehead handled his snuff box and administered to himself a portion of the contents Thus fortified he answered briefly I see daylight You ve told her then ma am

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: And is it   true  ? demanded Caroline, rising on her pillow. Is she   really   my mother?
children.prevalue: And is it true demanded Caroline rising on her pillow Is she really my mother

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: You won't cry, or make any scene, or turn hysterical, if I answer Yes?
children.prevalue: You won t cry or make any scene or turn hysterical if I answer Yes

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Cry! I'd cry if you said   No  . It would be terrible to be disappointed now. But give her a name. How do you call her?
children.prevalue: Cry I d cry if you said No It would be terrible to be disappointed now But give her a name How do you call her

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: I call this stout lady in a quaint black dress, who looks young enough to wear much smarter raiment, if she would    I call her Agnes Helstone. She married my brother James, and is his widow.
children.prevalue: I call this stout lady in a quaint black dress who looks young enough to wear much smarter raiment if she would I call her Agnes Helstone She married my brother James and is his widow

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: And my mother?
children.prevalue: And my mother

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: What a little sceptic it is! Look at her small face, Mrs. Pryor, scarcely larger than the palm of my hand, alive with acuteness and eagerness. To Caroline    She had the trouble of bringing you into the world at any rate. Mind you show your duty to her by quickly getting well, and repairing the waste of these cheeks.    Heigh  ho! she used to be plump. What she has done with it all I can't, for the life of me, divine.
children.prevalue: What a little sceptic it is Look at her small face Mrs Pryor scarcely larger than the palm of my hand alive with acuteness and eagerness To Caroline She had the trouble of bringing you into the world at any rate Mind you show your duty to her by quickly getting well and repairing the waste of these cheeks Heigh ho she used to be plump What she has done with it all I can t for the life of me divine

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: If   wishing   to get well will help me, I shall not be long sick. This morning I had no reason and no strength to wish it.
children.prevalue: If wishing to get well will help me I shall not be long sick This morning I had no reason and no strength to wish it

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: Fanny here tapped at the door, and said that supper was ready.
children.prevalue: Fanny here tapped at the door and said that supper was ready

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: Uncle, if you please, you may send me a little bit of supper    anything you like, from your own plate. That is wiser than going into hysterics, is it not?
children.prevalue: Uncle if you please you may send me a little bit of supper anything you like from your own plate That is wiser than going into hysterics is it not

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: It is spoken like a sage, Cary. See if I don't cater for you judiciously. When women are sensible, and, above all, intelligible, I can get on with them. It is only the vague, superfine sensations, and extremely wire  drawn notions, that put me about. Let a woman ask me to give her an edible or a wearable    be the same a roc's egg or the breastplate of Aaron, a share of St. John's locusts and honey or the leathern girdle about his loins    I can, at least, understand the demand; but when they pine for they know not what    sympathy, sentiment, some of these indefinite abstractions    I can't do it; I don't know it; I haven't got it.    Madam, accept my arm.
children.prevalue: It is spoken like a sage Cary See if I don t cater for you judiciously When women are sensible and above all intelligible I can get on with them It is only the vague superfine sensations and extremely wire drawn notions that put me about Let a woman ask me to give her an edible or a wearable be the same a roc s egg or the breastplate of Aaron a share of St John s locusts and honey or the leathern girdle about his loins I can at least understand the demand but when they pine for they know not what sympathy sentiment some of these indefinite abstractions I can t do it I don t know it I haven t got it Madam accept my arm

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: Mrs. Pryor signified that she should stay with her daughter that evening. Helstone, accordingly, left them together. He soon returned, bringing a plate in his own consecrated hand.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor signified that she should stay with her daughter that evening Helstone accordingly left them together He soon returned bringing a plate in his own consecrated hand

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: This is chicken, he said, but we'll have partridge to  morrow.    Lift her up, and put a shawl over her. On my word, I understand nursing.    Now, here is the very same little silver fork you used when you first came to the rectory. That strikes me as being what you may call a happy thought    a delicate attention. Take it, Cary, and munch away cleverly.
children.prevalue: This is chicken he said but we ll have partridge to morrow Lift her up and put a shawl over her On my word I understand nursing Now here is the very same little silver fork you used when you first came to the rectory That strikes me as being what you may call a happy thought a delicate attention Take it Cary and munch away cleverly

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: Caroline did her best. Her uncle frowned to see that her powers were so limited. He prophesied, however, great things for the future; and as she praised the morsel he had brought, and smiled gratefully in his face, he stooped over her pillow, kissed her, and said, with a broken, rugged accent, Good  night, bairnie! God bless thee!
children.prevalue: Caroline did her best Her uncle frowned to see that her powers were so limited He prophesied however great things for the future and as she praised the morsel he had brought and smiled gratefully in his face he stooped over her pillow kissed her and said with a broken rugged accent Good night bairnie God bless thee

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: Caroline enjoyed such peaceful rest that night, circled by her mother's arms, and pillowed on her breast, that she forgot to wish for any other stay; and though more than one feverish dream came to her in slumber, yet, when she woke up panting, so happy and contented a feeling returned with returning consciousness that her agitation was soothed almost as soon as felt.
children.prevalue: Caroline enjoyed such peaceful rest that night circled by her mother s arms and pillowed on her breast that she forgot to wish for any other stay and though more than one feverish dream came to her in slumber yet when she woke up panting so happy and contented a feeling returned with returning consciousness that her agitation was soothed almost as soon as felt

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: As to the mother, she spent the night like Jacob at Peniel. Till break of day she wrestled with God in earnest prayer.
children.prevalue: As to the mother she spent the night like Jacob at Peniel Till break of day she wrestled with God in earnest prayer

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Not always do those who dare such divine conflict prevail. Night after night the sweat of agony may burst dark on the forehead; the supplicant may cry for mercy with that soundless voice the soul utters when its appeal is to the Invisible. Spare my beloved, it may implore. Heal my life's life. Rend not from me what long affection entwines with my whole nature. God of heaven, bend, hear, be clement! And after this cry and strife the sun may rise and see him worsted. That opening morn, which used to salute him with the whisper of zephyrs, the carol of skylarks, may breathe, as its first accents, from the dear lips which colour and heat have quitted, Oh! I have had a suffering night. This morning I am worse. I have tried to rise. I cannot. Dreams I am unused to have troubled me.
children.prevalue: Not always do those who dare such divine conflict prevail Night after night the sweat of agony may burst dark on the forehead the supplicant may cry for mercy with that soundless voice the soul utters when its appeal is to the Invisible Spare my beloved it may implore Heal my life s life Rend not from me what long affection entwines with my whole nature God of heaven bend hear be clement And after this cry and strife the sun may rise and see him worsted That opening morn which used to salute him with the whisper of zephyrs the carol of skylarks may breathe as its first accents from the dear lips which colour and heat have quitted Oh I have had a suffering night This morning I am worse I have tried to rise I cannot Dreams I am unused to have troubled me

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Then the watcher approaches the patient's pillow, and sees a new and strange moulding of the familiar features, feels at once that the insufferable moment draws nigh, knows that it is God's will his idol shall be broken, and bends his head, and subdues his soul to the sentence he cannot avert and scarce can bear.
children.prevalue: Then the watcher approaches the patient s pillow and sees a new and strange moulding of the familiar features feels at once that the insufferable moment draws nigh knows that it is God s will his idol shall be broken and bends his head and subdues his soul to the sentence he cannot avert and scarce can bear

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Happy Mrs. Pryor! She was still praying, unconscious that the summer sun hung above the hills, when her child softly woke in her arms. No piteous, unconscious moaning    sound which so wastes our strength that, even if we have sworn to be firm, a rush of unconquerable tears sweeps away the oath    preceded her waking. No space of deaf apathy followed. The first words spoken were not those of one becoming estranged from this world, and already permitted to stray at times into realms foreign to the living. Caroline evidently remembered with clearness what had happened.
children.prevalue: Happy Mrs Pryor She was still praying unconscious that the summer sun hung above the hills when her child softly woke in her arms No piteous unconscious moaning sound which so wastes our strength that even if we have sworn to be firm a rush of unconquerable tears sweeps away the oath preceded her waking No space of deaf apathy followed The first words spoken were not those of one becoming estranged from this world and already permitted to stray at times into realms foreign to the living Caroline evidently remembered with clearness what had happened

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Mamma, I have slept   so   well. I only dreamed and woke twice.
children.prevalue: Mamma I have slept so well I only dreamed and woke twice

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Mrs. Pryor rose with a start, that her daughter might not see the joyful tears called into her eyes by that affectionate word mamma, and the welcome assurance that followed it.
children.prevalue: Mrs Pryor rose with a start that her daughter might not see the joyful tears called into her eyes by that affectionate word mamma and the welcome assurance that followed it

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: For many days the mother dared rejoice only with trembling. That first revival seemed like the flicker of a dying lamp. If the flame streamed up bright one moment, the next it sank dim in the socket. Exhaustion followed close on excitement.
children.prevalue: For many days the mother dared rejoice only with trembling That first revival seemed like the flicker of a dying lamp If the flame streamed up bright one moment the next it sank dim in the socket Exhaustion followed close on excitement

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: There was always a touching endeavour to   appear   better, but too often ability refused to second will; too often the attempt to bear up failed. The effort to eat, to talk, to look cheerful, was unsuccessful. Many an hour passed during which Mrs. Pryor feared that the chords of life could never more be strengthened, though the time of their breaking might be deferred.
children.prevalue: There was always a touching endeavour to appear better but too often ability refused to second will too often the attempt to bear up failed The effort to eat to talk to look cheerful was unsuccessful Many an hour passed during which Mrs Pryor feared that the chords of life could never more be strengthened though the time of their breaking might be deferred

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: During this space the mother and daughter seemed left almost alone in the neighbourhood. It was the close of August; the weather was fine    that is to say, it was very dry and very dusty, for an arid wind had been blowing from the east this month past; very cloudless, too, though a pale haze, stationary in the atmosphere, seemed to rob of all depth of tone the blue of heaven, of all freshness the verdure of earth, and of all glow the light of day. Almost every family in Briarfield was absent on an excursion. Miss Keeldar and her friends were at the seaside; so were Mrs. Yorke's household. Mr. Hall and Louis Moore, between whom a spontaneous intimacy seemed to have arisen    the result, probably, of harmony of views and temperament    were gone up north on a pedestrian excursion to the Lakes. Even Hortense, who would fain have stayed at home and aided Mrs. Pryor in nursing Caroline, had been so earnestly entreated by Miss Mann to accompany her once more to Wormwood Wells, in the hope of alleviating sufferings greatly aggravated by the insalubrious weather, that she felt obliged to comply; indeed, it was not in her nature to refuse a request that at once appealed to her goodness of heart, and, by a confession of dependency, flattered her   amour propre  . As for Robert, from Birmingham he had gone on to London, where he still sojourned.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So long as the breath of Asiatic deserts parched Caroline's lips and fevered her veins, her physical convalescence could not keep pace with her returning mental tranquillity; but there came a day when the wind ceased to sob at the eastern gable of the rectory, and at the oriel window of the church. A little cloud like a man's hand arose in the west; gusts from the same quarter drove it on and spread it wide; wet and tempest prevailed a while. When that was over the sun broke out genially, heaven regained its azure, and earth its green; the livid cholera  tint had vanished from the face of nature; the hills rose clear round the horizon, absolved from that pale malaria  haze.
children.prevalue: So long as the breath of Asiatic deserts parched Caroline s lips and fevered her veins her physical convalescence could not keep pace with her returning mental tranquillity but there came a day when the wind ceased to sob at the eastern gable of the rectory and at the oriel window of the church A little cloud like a man s hand arose in the west gusts from the same quarter drove it on and spread it wide wet and tempest prevailed a while When that was over the sun broke out genially heaven regained its azure and earth its green the livid cholera tint had vanished from the face of nature the hills rose clear round the horizon absolved from that pale malaria haze

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Caroline's youth could now be of some avail to her, and so could her mother's nurture. Both, crowned by God's blessing, sent in the pure west wind blowing soft as fresh through the ever  open chamber lattice, rekindled her long  languishing energies. At last Mrs. Pryor saw that it was permitted to hope: a genuine, material convalescence had commenced. It was not merely Caroline's smile which was brighter, or her spirits which were cheered, but a certain look had passed from her face and eye    a look dread and indescribable, but which will easily be recalled by those who have watched the couch of dangerous disease. Long before the emaciated outlines of her aspect began to fill, or its departed colour to return, a more subtle change took place; all grew softer and warmer. Instead of a marble mask and glassy eye, Mrs. Pryor saw laid on the pillow a face pale and wasted enough, perhaps more haggard than the other appearance, but less awful; for it was a sick, living girl, not a mere white mould or rigid piece of statuary.
children.prevalue: Caroline s youth could now be of some avail to her and so could her mother s nurture Both crowned by God s blessing sent in the pure west wind blowing soft as fresh through the ever open chamber lattice rekindled her long languishing energies At last Mrs Pryor saw that it was permitted to hope a genuine material convalescence had commenced It was not merely Caroline s smile which was brighter or her spirits which were cheered but a certain look had passed from her face and eye a look dread and indescribable but which will easily be recalled by those who have watched the couch of dangerous disease Long before the emaciated outlines of her aspect began to fill or its departed colour to return a more subtle change took place all grew softer and warmer Instead of a marble mask and glassy eye Mrs Pryor saw laid on the pillow a face pale and wasted enough perhaps more haggard than the other appearance but less awful for it was a sick living girl not a mere white mould or rigid piece of statuary

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now, too, she was not always petitioning to drink. The words, I am   so   thirsty, ceased to be her plaint. Sometimes, when she had swallowed a morsel, she would say it had revived her. All descriptions of food were no longer equally distasteful; she could be induced, sometimes, to indicate a preference. With what trembling pleasure and anxious care did not her nurse prepare what was selected! How she watched her as she partook of it!
children.prevalue: Now too she was not always petitioning to drink The words I am so thirsty ceased to be her plaint Sometimes when she had swallowed a morsel she would say it had revived her All descriptions of food were no longer equally distasteful she could be induced sometimes to indicate a preference With what trembling pleasure and anxious care did not her nurse prepare what was selected How she watched her as she partook of it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Nourishment brought strength. She could sit up. Then she longed to breathe the fresh air, to revisit her flowers, to see how the fruit had ripened. Her uncle, always liberal, had bought a garden  chair for her express use. He carried her down in his own arms, and placed her in it himself, and William Farren was there to wheel her round the walks, to show her what he had done amongst her plants, to take her directions for further work.
children.prevalue: Nourishment brought strength She could sit up Then she longed to breathe the fresh air to revisit her flowers to see how the fruit had ripened Her uncle always liberal had bought a garden chair for her express use He carried her down in his own arms and placed her in it himself and William Farren was there to wheel her round the walks to show her what he had done amongst her plants to take her directions for further work

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: William and she found plenty to talk about. They had a dozen topics in common    interesting to them, unimportant to the rest of the world. They took a similar interest in animals, birds, insects, and plants; they held similar doctrines about humanity to the lower creation, and had a similar turn for minute observation on points of natural history. The nest and proceedings of some ground  bees, which had burrowed in the turf under an old cherry  tree, was one subject of interest; the haunts of certain hedge  sparrows, and the welfare of certain pearly eggs and callow fledglings, another.
children.prevalue: William and she found plenty to talk about They had a dozen topics in common interesting to them unimportant to the rest of the world They took a similar interest in animals birds insects and plants they held similar doctrines about humanity to the lower creation and had a similar turn for minute observation on points of natural history The nest and proceedings of some ground bees which had burrowed in the turf under an old cherry tree was one subject of interest the haunts of certain hedge sparrows and the welfare of certain pearly eggs and callow fledglings another

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Had   Chambers's Journal   existed in those days, it would certainly have formed Miss Helstone's and Farren's favourite periodical. She would have subscribed for it, and to him each number would duly have been lent; both would have put implicit faith and found great savour in its marvellous anecdotes of animal sagacity.
children.prevalue: Had Chambers s Journal existed in those days it would certainly have formed Miss Helstone s and Farren s favourite periodical She would have subscribed for it and to him each number would duly have been lent both would have put implicit faith and found great savour in its marvellous anecdotes of animal sagacity

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: This is a digression, but it suffices to explain why Caroline would have no other hand than William's to guide her chair, and why his society and conversation sufficed to give interest to her garden  airings.
children.prevalue: This is a digression but it suffices to explain why Caroline would have no other hand than William s to guide her chair and why his society and conversation sufficed to give interest to her garden airings

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Mrs. Pryor, walking near, wondered how her daughter could be so much at ease with a man of the people.   She   found it impossible to speak to him otherwise than stiffly. She felt as if a great gulf lay between her caste and his, and that to cross it or meet him half  way would be to degrade herself. She gently asked Caroline, Are you not afraid, my dear, to converse with that person so unreservedly? He may presume, and become troublesomely garrulous.
