children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: William presume, mamma? You don't know him. He never presumes. He is altogether too proud and sensitive to do so. William has very fine feelings.
children.prevalue: William presume mamma You don t know him He never presumes He is altogether too proud and sensitive to do so William has very fine feelings

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And Mrs. Pryor smiled sceptically at the nave notion of that rough  handed, rough  headed, fustian  clad clown having fine feelings.
children.prevalue: And Mrs Pryor smiled sceptically at the nave notion of that rough handed rough headed fustian clad clown having fine feelings

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Farren, for his part, showed Mrs. Pryor only a very sulky brow. He knew when he was misjudged, and was apt to turn unmanageable with such as failed to give him his due.
children.prevalue: Farren for his part showed Mrs Pryor only a very sulky brow He knew when he was misjudged and was apt to turn unmanageable with such as failed to give him his due

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The evening restored Caroline entirely to her mother, and Mrs. Pryor liked the evening; for then, alone with her daughter, no human shadow came between her and what she loved. During the day she would have her stiff demeanour and cool moments, as was her wont. Between her and Mr. Helstone a very respectful but most rigidly ceremonious intercourse was kept up. Anything like familiarity would have bred contempt at once in one or both these personages; but by dint of strict civility and well  maintained distance they got on very smoothly.
children.prevalue: The evening restored Caroline entirely to her mother and Mrs Pryor liked the evening for then alone with her daughter no human shadow came between her and what she loved During the day she would have her stiff demeanour and cool moments as was her wont Between her and Mr Helstone a very respectful but most rigidly ceremonious intercourse was kept up Anything like familiarity would have bred contempt at once in one or both these personages but by dint of strict civility and well maintained distance they got on very smoothly

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Towards the servants Mrs. Pryor's bearing was not uncourteous, but shy, freezing, ungenial. Perhaps it was diffidence rather than pride which made her appear so haughty; but, as was to be expected, Fanny and Eliza failed to make the distinction, and she was unpopular with them accordingly. She felt the effect produced; it rendered her at times dissatisfied with herself for faults she could not help, and with all else dejected, chill, and taciturn.
children.prevalue: Towards the servants Mrs Pryor s bearing was not uncourteous but shy freezing ungenial Perhaps it was diffidence rather than pride which made her appear so haughty but as was to be expected Fanny and Eliza failed to make the distinction and she was unpopular with them accordingly She felt the effect produced it rendered her at times dissatisfied with herself for faults she could not help and with all else dejected chill and taciturn

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: This mood changed to Caroline's influence, and to that influence alone. The dependent fondness of her nursling, the natural affection of her child, came over her suavely. Her frost fell away, her rigidity unbent; she grew smiling and pliant. Not that Caroline made any wordy profession of love    that would ill have suited Mrs. Pryor; she would have read therein the proof of insincerity    but she hung on her with easy dependence; she confided in her with fearless reliance. These things contented the mother's heart.
children.prevalue: This mood changed to Caroline s influence and to that influence alone The dependent fondness of her nursling the natural affection of her child came over her suavely Her frost fell away her rigidity unbent she grew smiling and pliant Not that Caroline made any wordy profession of love that would ill have suited Mrs Pryor she would have read therein the proof of insincerity but she hung on her with easy dependence she confided in her with fearless reliance These things contented the mother s heart

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: She liked to hear her daughter say, Mamma, do this; Please, mamma, fetch me that; Mamma, read to me; Sing a little, mamma.
children.prevalue: She liked to hear her daughter say Mamma do this Please mamma fetch me that Mamma read to me Sing a little mamma

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Nobody else    not one living thing    had ever so claimed her services, so looked for help at her hand. Other people were always more or less reserved and stiff with her, as she was reserved and stiff with them; other people betrayed consciousness of and annoyance at her weak points. Caroline no more showed such wounding sagacity or reproachful sensitiveness now than she had done when a suckling of three months old.
children.prevalue: Nobody else not one living thing had ever so claimed her services so looked for help at her hand Other people were always more or less reserved and stiff with her as she was reserved and stiff with them other people betrayed consciousness of and annoyance at her weak points Caroline no more showed such wounding sagacity or reproachful sensitiveness now than she had done when a suckling of three months old

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yet Caroline could find fault. Blind to the constitutional defects that were incurable, she had her eyes wide open to the acquired habits that were susceptible of remedy. On certain points she would quite artlessly lecture her parent; and that parent, instead of being hurt, felt a sensation of pleasure in discovering that the girl   dared   lecture her, that she was so much at home with her.
children.prevalue: Yet Caroline could find fault Blind to the constitutional defects that were incurable she had her eyes wide open to the acquired habits that were susceptible of remedy On certain points she would quite artlessly lecture her parent and that parent instead of being hurt felt a sensation of pleasure in discovering that the girl dared lecture her that she was so much at home with her

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Mamma, I am determined you shall not wear that old gown any more. Its fashion is not becoming; it is too strait in the skirt. You shall put on your black silk every afternoon. In that you look nice; it suits you. And you shall have a black satin dress for Sundays    a real satin, not a satinet or any of the shams. And, mamma, when you get the new one, mind you must wear it.
children.prevalue: Mamma I am determined you shall not wear that old gown any more Its fashion is not becoming it is too strait in the skirt You shall put on your black silk every afternoon In that you look nice it suits you And you shall have a black satin dress for Sundays a real satin not a satinet or any of the shams And mamma when you get the new one mind you must wear it

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: My dear, I thought of the black silk serving me as a best dress for many years yet, and I wished to buy you several things.
children.prevalue: My dear I thought of the black silk serving me as a best dress for many years yet and I wished to buy you several things

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Nonsense, mamma. My uncle gives me cash to get what I want. You know he is generous enough; and I have set my heart on seeing you in a black satin. Get it soon, and let it be made by a dressmaker of my recommending. Let me choose the pattern. You always want to disguise yourself like a grandmother. You would persuade one that you are old and ugly. Not at all! On the contrary, when well dressed and cheerful you are very comely indeed; your smile is so pleasant, your teeth are so white, your hair is still such a pretty light colour. And then you speak like a young lady, with such a clear, fine tone, and you sing better than any young lady I ever heard. Why do you wear such dresses and bonnets, mamma, such as nobody else ever wears?

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Does it annoy you, Caroline?
children.prevalue: Does it annoy you Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Very much; it vexes me even. People say you are miserly; and yet you are not, for you give liberally to the poor and to religious societies    though your gifts are conveyed so secretly and quietly that they are known to few except the receivers. But I will be your lady's  maid myself. When I get a little stronger I will set to work, and you must be good, mamma, and do as I bid you.

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And Caroline, sitting near her mother, rearranged her muslin handkerchief and resmoothed her hair.
children.prevalue: And Caroline sitting near her mother rearranged her muslin handkerchief and resmoothed her hair

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: My own mamma, then she went on, as if pleasing herself with the thought of their relationship, who belongs to me, and to whom I belong! I am a rich girl now. I have something I can love well, and not be afraid of loving. Mamma, who gave you this little brooch? Let me unpin it and look at it.

children.value: Mrs. Pryor, who usually shrank from meddling fingers and near approach, allowed the license complacently.

children.prevalue: That you prize

children.prevalue: Valuable and pretty

children.value: Whose features still give me such a strange thrill sometimes. I half fear your fair looks yet, child.

children.value: You don't; you can't. Mamma, I am sorry papa was not good. I do so wish he had been. Wickedness spoils and poisons all pleasant things. It kills love. If you and I thought each other wicked, we could not love each other, could we?

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And if we could not trust each other, Cary?
children.prevalue: And if we could not trust each other Cary

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: How miserable we should be! Mother, before I knew you I had an apprehension that you were not good    that I could not esteem you. That dread damped my wish to see you. And now my heart is elate because I find you perfect    almost; kind, clever, nice. Your sole fault is that you are old  fashioned, and of that I shall cure you. Mamma, put your work down; read to me. I like your southern accent; it is so pure, so soft. It has no rugged burr, no nasal twang, such as almost every one's voice here in the north has. My uncle and Mr. Hall say that you are a fine reader, mamma. Mr. Hall said he never heard any lady read with such propriety of expression or purity of accent.

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I wish I could reciprocate the compliment, Cary; but, really, the first time I heard your truly excellent friend read and preach I could not understand his broad northern tongue.

children.prevalue: Could you understand me mamma Did I seem to speak roughly

children.value: No. I almost wished you had, as I wished you had looked unpolished. Your father, Caroline, naturally spoke well, quite otherwise than your worthy uncle    correctly, gently, smoothly. You inherit the gift.

children.value: Mamma, you will keep stitching, stitching away. Put down the sewing; I am an enemy to it. It cumbers your lap, and I want it for my head; it engages your eyes, and I want them for a book. Here is your favourite    Cowper.

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: These importunities were the mother's pleasure. If ever she delayed compliance, it was only to hear them repeated, and to enjoy her child's soft, half  playful, half  petulant urgency. And then, when she yielded, Caroline would say archly, You will spoil me, mamma. I always thought I should like to be spoiled, and I find it very sweet. So did Mrs. Pryor.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: By the time the Fieldhead party returned to Briarfield Caroline was nearly well. Miss Keeldar, who had received news by post of her friend's convalescence, hardly suffered an hour to elapse between her arrival at home and her first call at the rectory.
children.prevalue: By the time the Fieldhead party returned to Briarfield Caroline was nearly well Miss Keeldar who had received news by post of her friend s convalescence hardly suffered an hour to elapse between her arrival at home and her first call at the rectory

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: A shower of rain was falling gently, yet fast, on the late flowers and russet autumn shrubs, when the garden wicket was heard to swing open, and Shirley's well  known form passed the window. On her entrance her feelings were evinced in her own peculiar fashion. When deeply moved by serious fears or joys she was not garrulous. The strong emotion was rarely suffered to influence her tongue, and even her eye refused it more than a furtive and fitful conquest. She took Caroline in her arms, gave her one look, one kiss, then said, You are better.
children.prevalue: A shower of rain was falling gently yet fast on the late flowers and russet autumn shrubs when the garden wicket was heard to swing open and Shirley s well known form passed the window On her entrance her feelings were evinced in her own peculiar fashion When deeply moved by serious fears or joys she was not garrulous The strong emotion was rarely suffered to influence her tongue and even her eye refused it more than a furtive and fitful conquest She took Caroline in her arms gave her one look one kiss then said You are better

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: And a minute after, I see you are safe now; but take care. God grant your health may be called on to sustain no more shocks!
children.prevalue: And a minute after I see you are safe now but take care God grant your health may be called on to sustain no more shocks

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: She proceeded to talk fluently about the journey. In the midst of vivacious discourse her eye still wandered to Caroline. There spoke in its light a deep solicitude, some trouble, and some amaze.
children.prevalue: She proceeded to talk fluently about the journey In the midst of vivacious discourse her eye still wandered to Caroline There spoke in its light a deep solicitude some trouble and some amaze

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: She may be better, it said, but how weak she still is! What peril she has come through!
children.prevalue: She may be better it said but how weak she still is What peril she has come through

children.prevalue: Suddenly her glance reverted to Mrs Pryor It pierced her through

children.prevalue: When will my governess return to me she asked

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I guessed long since the whole business. I have heard somewhat of Mrs. Pryor's history    not from herself, but from others. With every detail of Mr. James Helstone's career and character I was acquainted. An afternoon's sitting and conversation with Miss Mann had rendered me familiar therewith; also he is one of Mrs. Yorke's warning examples    one of the blood  red lights she hangs out to scare young ladies from matrimony. I believe I should have been sceptical about the truth of the portrait traced by such fingers    both these ladies take a dark pleasure in offering to view the dark side of life    but I questioned Mr. Yorke on the subject, and he said, 'Shirley, my woman, if you want to know aught about yond' James Helstone, I can only say he was a man  tiger. He was handsome, dissolute, soft, treacherous, courteous, cruel        ' Don't cry, Cary; we'll say no more about it.

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I am not crying, Shirley; or if I am, it is nothing. Go on; you are no friend if you withhold from me the truth. I hate that false plan of disguising, mutilating the truth.
children.prevalue: I am not crying Shirley or if I am it is nothing Go on you are no friend if you withhold from me the truth I hate that false plan of disguising mutilating the truth

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Fortunately I have said pretty nearly all that I have to say, except that your uncle himself confirmed Mr. Yorke's words; for he too scorns a lie, and deals in none of those conventional subterfuges that are shabbier than lies.
children.prevalue: Fortunately I have said pretty nearly all that I have to say except that your uncle himself confirmed Mr Yorke s words for he too scorns a lie and deals in none of those conventional subterfuges that are shabbier than lies

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But papa is dead; they should let him alone now.
children.prevalue: But papa is dead they should let him alone now

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: They should; and we   will   let him alone. Cry away, Cary; it will do you good. It is wrong to check natural tears. Besides, I choose to please myself by sharing an idea that at this moment beams in your mother's eye while she looks at you. Every drop blots out a sin. Weep! your tears have the virtue which the rivers of Damascus lacked. Like Jordan, they can cleanse a leprous memory.
children.prevalue: They should and we will let him alone Cry away Cary it will do you good It is wrong to check natural tears Besides I choose to please myself by sharing an idea that at this moment beams in your mother s eye while she looks at you Every drop blots out a sin Weep your tears have the virtue which the rivers of Damascus lacked Like Jordan they can cleanse a leprous memory

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Madam, she continued, addressing Mrs. Pryor, did you think I could be daily in the habit of seeing you and your daughter together    marking your marvellous similarity in many points, observing (pardon me) your irrepressible emotions in the presence and still more in the absence of your child    and not form my own conjectures? I formed them, and they are literally correct. I shall begin to think myself shrewd.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And you said nothing? observed Caroline, who soon regained the quiet control of her feelings.
children.prevalue: And you said nothing observed Caroline who soon regained the quiet control of her feelings

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Nothing. I had no warrant to breathe a word on the subject.   My   business it was not; I abstained from making it such.
children.prevalue: Nothing I had no warrant to breathe a word on the subject My business it was not I abstained from making it such

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You guessed so deep a secret, and did not hint that you guessed it?
children.prevalue: You guessed so deep a secret and did not hint that you guessed it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Is that so difficult?
children.prevalue: Is that so difficult

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It is not like you.
children.prevalue: It is not like you

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: How do you know?
children.prevalue: How do you know

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You are not reserved; you are frankly communicative.
children.prevalue: You are not reserved you are frankly communicative

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I may be communicative, yet know where to stop. In showing my treasure I may withhold a gem or two    a curious, unbought graven stone    an amulet of whose mystic glitter I rarely permit even myself a glimpse. Good  day.
children.prevalue: I may be communicative yet know where to stop In showing my treasure I may withhold a gem or two a curious unbought graven stone an amulet of whose mystic glitter I rarely permit even myself a glimpse Good day

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Caroline thus seemed to get a view of Shirley's character under a novel aspect. Ere long the prospect was renewed; it opened upon her.
children.prevalue: Caroline thus seemed to get a view of Shirley s character under a novel aspect Ere long the prospect was renewed it opened upon her

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No sooner had she regained sufficient strength to bear a change of scene    the excitement of a little society    than Miss Keeldar sued daily for her presence at Fieldhead. Whether Shirley had become wearied of her honoured relatives is not known. She did not say she was; but she claimed and retained Caroline with an eagerness which proved that an addition to that worshipful company was not unwelcome.
children.prevalue: No sooner had she regained sufficient strength to bear a change of scene the excitement of a little society than Miss Keeldar sued daily for her presence at Fieldhead Whether Shirley had become wearied of her honoured relatives is not known She did not say she was but she claimed and retained Caroline with an eagerness which proved that an addition to that worshipful company was not unwelcome

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The Sympsons were church people. Of course the rector's niece was received by them with courtesy. Mr. Sympson proved to be a man of spotless respectability, worrying temper, pious principles, and worldly views; his lady was a very good woman    patient, kind, well  bred. She had been brought up on a narrow system of views, starved on a few prejudices    a mere handful of bitter herbs; a few preferences, soaked till their natural flavour was extracted, and with no seasoning added in the cooking; some excellent principles, made up in a stiff raised crust of bigotry difficult to digest. Far too submissive was she to complain of this diet or to ask for a crumb beyond it.
children.prevalue: The Sympsons were church people Of course the rector s niece was received by them with courtesy Mr Sympson proved to be a man of spotless respectability worrying temper pious principles and worldly views his lady was a very good woman patient kind well bred She had been brought up on a narrow system of views starved on a few prejudices a mere handful of bitter herbs a few preferences soaked till their natural flavour was extracted and with no seasoning added in the cooking some excellent principles made up in a stiff raised crust of bigotry difficult to digest Far too submissive was she to complain of this diet or to ask for a crumb beyond it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The daughters were an example to their sex. They were tall, with a Roman nose apiece. They had been educated faultlessly. All they did was well done. History and the most solid books had cultivated their minds. Principles and opinions they possessed which could not be mended. More exactly  regulated lives, feelings, manners, habits, it would have been difficult to find anywhere. They knew by heart a certain young  ladies'  schoolroom code of laws on language, demeanour, etc.; themselves never deviated from its curious little pragmatical provisions, and they regarded with secret whispered horror all deviations in others. The Abomination of Desolation was no mystery to them; they had discovered that unutterable Thing in the characteristic others call Originality. Quick were they to recognize the signs of this evil; and wherever they saw its trace    whether in look, word, or deed; whether they read it in the fresh, vigorous style of a book, or listened to it in interesting, unhackneyed, pure, expressive language    they shuddered, they recoiled. Danger was above their heads, peril about their steps. What was this strange thing? Being unintelligible it must be bad. Let it be denounced and chained up.
children.prevalue: The daughters were an example to their sex They were tall with a Roman nose apiece They had been educated faultlessly All they did was well done History and the most solid books had cultivated their minds Principles and opinions they possessed which could not be mended More exactly regulated lives feelings manners habits it would have been difficult to find anywhere They knew by heart a certain young ladies schoolroom code of laws on language demeanour etc themselves never deviated from its curious little pragmatical provisions and they regarded with secret whispered horror all deviations in others The Abomination of Desolation was no mystery to them they had discovered that unutterable Thing in the characteristic others call Originality Quick were they to recognize the signs of this evil and wherever they saw its trace whether in look word or deed whether they read it in the fresh vigorous style of a book or listened to it in interesting unhackneyed pure expressive language they shuddered they recoiled Danger was above their heads peril about their steps What was this strange thing Being unintelligible it must be bad Let it be denounced and chained up

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Henry Sympson, the only son and youngest child of the family, was a boy of fifteen. He generally kept with his tutor. When he left him, he sought his cousin Shirley. This boy differed from his sisters. He was little, lame, and pale; his large eyes shone somewhat languidly in a wan orbit. They were, indeed, usually rather dim, but they were capable of illumination. At times they could not only shine, but blaze. Inward emotion could likewise give colour to his cheek and decision to his crippled movements. Henry's mother loved him; she thought his peculiarities were a mark of election. He was not like other children, she allowed. She believed him regenerate    a new Samuel    called of God from his birth. He was to be a clergyman. Mr. and the Misses Sympson, not understanding the youth, let him much alone. Shirley made him her pet, and he made Shirley his playmate.
children.prevalue: Henry Sympson the only son and youngest child of the family was a boy of fifteen He generally kept with his tutor When he left him he sought his cousin Shirley This boy differed from his sisters He was little lame and pale his large eyes shone somewhat languidly in a wan orbit They were indeed usually rather dim but they were capable of illumination At times they could not only shine but blaze Inward emotion could likewise give colour to his cheek and decision to his crippled movements Henry s mother loved him she thought his peculiarities were a mark of election He was not like other children she allowed She believed him regenerate a new Samuel called of God from his birth He was to be a clergyman Mr and the Misses Sympson not understanding the youth let him much alone Shirley made him her pet and he made Shirley his playmate

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: In the midst of this family circle, or rather outside it, moved the tutor    the satellite.
children.prevalue: In the midst of this family circle or rather outside it moved the tutor the satellite

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, Louis Moore was a satellite of the house of Sympson    connected, yet apart; ever attendant, ever distant. Each member of that correct family treated him with proper dignity. The father was austerely civil, sometimes irritable; the mother, being a kind woman, was attentive, but formal; the daughters saw in him an abstraction, not a man. It seemed, by their manner, that their brother's tutor did not live for them. They were learned; so was he    but not for them. They were accomplished; he had talents too, imperceptible to their senses. The most spirited sketch from his fingers was a blank to their eyes; the most original observation from his lips fell unheard on their ears. Nothing could exceed the propriety of their behaviour.
children.prevalue: Yes Louis Moore was a satellite of the house of Sympson connected yet apart ever attendant ever distant Each member of that correct family treated him with proper dignity The father was austerely civil sometimes irritable the mother being a kind woman was attentive but formal the daughters saw in him an abstraction not a man It seemed by their manner that their brother s tutor did not live for them They were learned so was he but not for them They were accomplished he had talents too imperceptible to their senses The most spirited sketch from his fingers was a blank to their eyes the most original observation from his lips fell unheard on their ears Nothing could exceed the propriety of their behaviour

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I should have said nothing could have equalled it; but I remember a fact which strangely astonished Caroline Helstone. It was    to discover that her cousin had absolutely   no   sympathizing friend at Fieldhead; that to Miss Keeldar he was as much a mere teacher, as little a gentleman, as little a man, as to the estimable Misses Sympson.
children.prevalue: I should have said nothing could have equalled it but I remember a fact which strangely astonished Caroline Helstone It was to discover that her cousin had absolutely no sympathizing friend at Fieldhead that to Miss Keeldar he was as much a mere teacher as little a gentleman as little a man as to the estimable Misses Sympson

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: What had befallen the kind  hearted Shirley that she should be so indifferent to the dreary position of a fellow  creature thus isolated under her roof? She was not, perhaps, haughty to him, but she never noticed him    she let him alone. He came and went, spoke or was silent, and she rarely recognized his existence.
children.prevalue: What had befallen the kind hearted Shirley that she should be so indifferent to the dreary position of a fellow creature thus isolated under her roof She was not perhaps haughty to him but she never noticed him she let him alone He came and went spoke or was silent and she rarely recognized his existence

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: As to Louis Moore himself, he had the air of a man used to this life, and who had made up his mind to bear it for a time. His faculties seemed walled up in him, and were unmurmuring in their captivity. He never laughed; he seldom smiled; he was uncomplaining. He fulfilled the round of his duties scrupulously. His pupil loved him; he asked nothing more than civility from the rest of the world. It even appeared that he would accept nothing more    in that abode at least; for when his cousin Caroline made gentle overtures of friendship, he did not encourage them    he rather avoided than sought her. One living thing alone, besides his pale, crippled scholar, he fondled in the house, and that was the ruffianly Tartar, who, sullen and impracticable to others, acquired a singular partiality for him    a partiality so marked that sometimes, when Moore, summoned to a meal, entered the room and sat down unwelcomed, Tartar would rise from his lair at Shirley's feet and betake himself to the taciturn tutor. Once    but once    she noticed the desertion, and holding out her white hand, and speaking softly, tried to coax him back. Tartar looked, slavered, and sighed, as his manner was, but yet disregarded the invitation, and coolly settled himself on his haunches at Louis Moore's side. That gentleman drew the dog's big, black  muzzled head on to his knee, patted him, and smiled one little smile to himself.

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: An acute observer might have remarked, in the course of the same evening, that after Tartar had resumed his allegiance to Shirley, and was once more couched near her footstool, the audacious tutor by one word and gesture fascinated him again. He pricked up his ears at the word; he started erect at the gesture, and came, with head lovingly depressed, to receive the expected caress. As it was given, the significant smile again rippled across Moore's quiet face.
children.prevalue: An acute observer might have remarked in the course of the same evening that after Tartar had resumed his allegiance to Shirley and was once more couched near her footstool the audacious tutor by one word and gesture fascinated him again He pricked up his ears at the word he started erect at the gesture and came with head lovingly depressed to receive the expected caress As it was given the significant smile again rippled across Moore s quiet face

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Shirley, said Caroline one day, as they two were sitting alone in the summer  house, did you know that my cousin Louis was tutor in your uncle's family before the Sympsons came down here?
children.prevalue: Shirley said Caroline one day as they two were sitting alone in the summer house did you know that my cousin Louis was tutor in your uncle s family before the Sympsons came down here

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Shirley's reply was not so prompt as her responses usually were, but at last she answered, Yes    of course; I knew it well.
children.prevalue: Shirley s reply was not so prompt as her responses usually were but at last she answered Yes of course I knew it well

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I thought you must have been aware of the circumstance.
children.prevalue: I thought you must have been aware of the circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well! what then?
children.prevalue: Well what then

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: It puzzles me to guess how it chanced that you never mentioned it to me.
children.prevalue: It puzzles me to guess how it chanced that you never mentioned it to me

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Why should it puzzle you?
children.prevalue: Why should it puzzle you

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It seems odd. I cannot account for it. You talk a great deal    you talk freely. How was that circumstance never touched on?
children.prevalue: It seems odd I cannot account for it You talk a great deal you talk freely How was that circumstance never touched on

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Because it never was, and Shirley laughed.
children.prevalue: Because it never was and Shirley laughed

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: You are a singular being! observed her friend. I thought I knew you quite well; I begin to find myself mistaken. You were silent as the grave about Mrs. Pryor, and now again here is another secret. But why you made it a secret is the mystery to me.

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I never made it a secret; I had no reason for so doing. If you had asked me who Henry's tutor was, I would have told you. Besides, I thought you knew.
children.prevalue: I never made it a secret I had no reason for so doing If you had asked me who Henry s tutor was I would have told you Besides I thought you knew

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I am puzzled about more things than one in this matter. You don't like poor Louis. Why? Are you impatient at what you perhaps consider his   servile   position? Do you wish that Robert's brother were more highly placed?
children.prevalue: I am puzzled about more things than one in this matter You don t like poor Louis Why Are you impatient at what you perhaps consider his servile position Do you wish that Robert s brother were more highly placed

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Robert's brother, indeed! was the exclamation, uttered in a tone like the accents of scorn; and with a movement of proud impatience Shirley snatched a rose from a branch peeping through the open lattice.
children.prevalue: Robert s brother indeed was the exclamation uttered in a tone like the accents of scorn and with a movement of proud impatience Shirley snatched a rose from a branch peeping through the open lattice

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, repeated Caroline, with mild firmness, Robert's brother. He   is   thus closely related to Grard Moore of the Hollow, though nature has not given him features so handsome or an air so noble as his kinsman; but his blood is as good, and he is as much a gentleman were he free.
children.prevalue: Yes repeated Caroline with mild firmness Robert s brother He is thus closely related to Grard Moore of the Hollow though nature has not given him features so handsome or an air so noble as his kinsman but his blood is as good and he is as much a gentleman were he free

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Wise, humble, pious Caroline! exclaimed Shirley ironically. Men and angels, hear her! We should not despise plain features, nor a laborious yet honest occupation, should we? Look at the subject of your panegyric. He is there in the garden, she continued, pointing through an aperture in the clustering creepers; and by that aperture Louis Moore was visible, coming slowly down the walk.

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He is not ugly, Shirley, pleaded Caroline; he is not ignoble. He is sad; silence seals his mind. But I believe him to be intelligent; and be certain, if he had not something very commendable in his disposition, Mr. Hall would never seek his society as he does.
children.prevalue: He is not ugly Shirley pleaded Caroline he is not ignoble He is sad silence seals his mind But I believe him to be intelligent and be certain if he had not something very commendable in his disposition Mr Hall would never seek his society as he does

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Shirley laughed; she laughed again, each time with a slightly sarcastic sound. Well, well, was her comment. On the plea of the man being Cyril Hall's friend and Robert Moore's brother, we'll just tolerate his existence; won't we, Cary? You believe him to be intelligent, do you? Not quite an idiot    eh? Something commendable in his disposition!      id est  , not an absolute ruffian. Good! Your representations have weight with me; and to prove that they have, should he come this way I will speak to him.

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: He approached the summer  house. Unconscious that it was tenanted, he sat down on the step. Tartar, now his customary companion, had followed him, and he couched across his feet.
children.prevalue: He approached the summer house Unconscious that it was tenanted he sat down on the step Tartar now his customary companion had followed him and he couched across his feet

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Old boy! said Louis, pulling his tawny ear, or rather the mutilated remains of that organ, torn and chewed in a hundred battles, the autumn sun shines as pleasantly on us as on the fairest and richest. This garden is none of ours, but we enjoy its greenness and perfume, don't we?

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He sat silent, still caressing Tartar, who slobbered with exceeding affection. A faint twittering commenced among the trees round. Something fluttered down as light as leaves. They were little birds, which, lighting on the sward at shy distance, hopped as if expectant.

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The small brown elves actually remember that I fed them the other day, again soliloquized Louis. They want some more biscuit. To  day I forgot to save a fragment. Eager little sprites, I have not a crumb for you.
children.prevalue: The small brown elves actually remember that I fed them the other day again soliloquized Louis They want some more biscuit To day I forgot to save a fragment Eager little sprites I have not a crumb for you

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: He put his hand in his pocket and drew it out empty.
children.prevalue: He put his hand in his pocket and drew it out empty

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: A want easily supplied, whispered the listening Miss Keeldar.
children.prevalue: A want easily supplied whispered the listening Miss Keeldar

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: She took from her reticule a morsel of sweet  cake; for that repository was never destitute of something available to throw to the chickens, young ducks, or sparrows. She crumbled it, and bending over his shoulder, put the crumbs into his hand.

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: There, said she    there is a providence for the improvident.
children.prevalue: There said she there is a providence for the improvident

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: This September afternoon is pleasant, observed Louis Moore, as, not at all discomposed, he calmly cast the crumbs on to the grass.
children.prevalue: This September afternoon is pleasant observed Louis Moore as not at all discomposed he calmly cast the crumbs on to the grass

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Even for you?
children.prevalue: Even for you

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: As pleasant for me as for any monarch.
children.prevalue: As pleasant for me as for any monarch

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You take a sort of harsh, solitary triumph in drawing pleasure out of the elements and the inanimate and lower animate creation.
children.prevalue: You take a sort of harsh solitary triumph in drawing pleasure out of the elements and the inanimate and lower animate creation

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Solitary, but not harsh. With animals I feel I am Adam's son, the heir of him to whom dominion was given over 'every living thing that moveth upon the earth.' Your dog likes and follows me. When I go into that yard, the pigeons from your dovecot flutter at my feet. Your mare in the stable knows me as well as it knows you, and obeys me better.

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And my roses smell sweet to you, and my trees give you shade.
children.prevalue: And my roses smell sweet to you and my trees give you shade

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: And, continued Louis, no caprice can withdraw these pleasures from me; they are   mine  .
children.prevalue: And continued Louis no caprice can withdraw these pleasures from me they are mine

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: He walked off. Tartar followed him, as if in duty and affection bound, and Shirley remained standing on the summer  house step. Caroline saw her face as she looked after the rude tutor. It was pale, as if her pride bled inwardly.
children.prevalue: He walked off Tartar followed him as if in duty and affection bound and Shirley remained standing on the summer house step Caroline saw her face as she looked after the rude tutor It was pale as if her pride bled inwardly

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You see, remarked Caroline apologetically, his feelings are so often hurt it makes him morose.
children.prevalue: You see remarked Caroline apologetically his feelings are so often hurt it makes him morose

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You see, retorted Shirley, with ire, he is a topic on which you and I shall quarrel if we discuss it often; so drop it henceforward and for ever.
children.prevalue: You see retorted Shirley with ire he is a topic on which you and I shall quarrel if we discuss it often so drop it henceforward and for ever

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I suppose he has more than once behaved in this way, thought Caroline to herself, and that renders Shirley so distant to him. Yet I wonder she cannot make allowance for character and circumstances. I wonder the general modesty, manliness, sincerity of his nature do not plead with her in his behalf. She is not often so inconsiderate, so irritable.
children.prevalue: I suppose he has more than once behaved in this way thought Caroline to herself and that renders Shirley so distant to him Yet I wonder she cannot make allowance for character and circumstances I wonder the general modesty manliness sincerity of his nature do not plead with her in his behalf She is not often so inconsiderate so irritable

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The verbal testimony of two friends of Caroline's to her cousin's character augmented her favourable opinion of him. William Farren, whose cottage he had visited in company with Mr. Hall, pronounced him a real gentleman; there was not such another in Briarfield. He    William    could do aught for that man. And then to see how t' bairns liked him, and how t' wife took to him first minute she saw him. He never went into a house but t' childer wor about him directly. Them little things wor like as if they'd a keener sense nor grown  up folks i' finding our folk's natures.
children.prevalue: The verbal testimony of two friends of Caroline s to her cousin s character augmented her favourable opinion of him William Farren whose cottage he had visited in company with Mr Hall pronounced him a real gentleman there was not such another in Briarfield He William could do aught for that man And then to see how t bairns liked him and how t wife took to him first minute she saw him He never went into a house but t childer wor about him directly Them little things wor like as if they d a keener sense nor grown up folks i finding our folk s natures

children.value: Well, I suppose she doesn't know him, mused Caroline to herself, and by this hypothesis she endeavoured to account for what seemed else unaccountable. children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: One day she chanced to be in the schoolroom with Henry Sympson, whose amiable and affectionate disposition had quickly recommended him to her regard. The boy was busied about some mechanical contrivance; his lameness made him fond of sedentary occupation. He began to ransack his tutor's desk for a piece of wax or twine necessary to his work. Moore happened to be absent. Mr. Hall, indeed, had called for him to take a long walk. Henry could not immediately find the object of his search. He rummaged compartment after compartment; and at last, opening an inner drawer, he came upon    not a ball of cord or a lump of beeswax, but a little bundle of small marble  coloured cahiers, tied with tape. Henry looked at them. What rubbish Mr. Moore stores up in his desk! he said. I hope he won't keep my old exercises so carefully.

Yet that name astonished her    Shirley Keeldar, Sympson Grove,         shire (a southern county), and a date four years back.

I'm afraid I am a poor unfortunate, Miss Caroline Helstone. I am a cripple, you know.

children.value: Listen, Henry. Generally, I don't like schoolboys. I have a great horror of them. They seem to me little ruffians, who take an unnatural delight in killing and tormenting birds, and insects, and kittens, and whatever is weaker than themselves. But you are so different I am quite fond of you. You have almost as much sense as a man (far more, God wot, she muttered to herself, than many men); you are fond of reading, and you can talk sensibly about what you read.

children.value: Harry, it is your mind, which is stronger and older than your frame, that troubles you. It is a captive; it lies in physical bondage. But it will work its own redemption yet. Study carefully not only books but the world. You love nature; love her without fear. Be patient    wait the course of time. You will not be a soldier or a sailor, Henry; but if you live you will be    listen to my prophecy    you will be an author, perhaps a poet.

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: The hostess rang the bell and gave her frugal orders, which were presently executed. She herself measured out the milk, and distributed the bread round the cosy circle now enclosing the bright little schoolroom fire. She then took the post of toaster  general; and kneeling on the rug, fork in hand, fulfilled her office with dexterity. Mr. Hall, who relished any homely innovation on ordinary usages, and to whom the husky oatcake was from custom suave as manna, seemed in his best spirits. He talked and laughed gleefully    now with Caroline, whom he had fixed by his side, now with Shirley, and again with Louis Moore. And Louis met him in congenial spirit. He did not laugh much, but he uttered in the quietest tone the wittiest things. Gravely spoken sentences, marked by unexpected turns and a quite fresh flavour and poignancy, fell easily from his lips. He proved himself to be    what Mr. Hall had said he was    excellent company. Caroline marvelled at his humour, but still more at his entire self  possession. Nobody there present seemed to impose on him a sensation of unpleasant restraint. Nobody seemed a bore    a check    a chill to him; and yet there was the cool and lofty Miss Keeldar kneeling before the fire, almost at his feet.
children.prevalue: The hostess rang the bell and gave her frugal orders which were presently executed She herself measured out the milk and distributed the bread round the cosy circle now enclosing the bright little schoolroom fire She then took the post of toaster general and kneeling on the rug fork in hand fulfilled her office with dexterity Mr Hall who relished any homely innovation on ordinary usages and to whom the husky oatcake was from custom suave as manna seemed in his best spirits He talked and laughed gleefully now with Caroline whom he had fixed by his side now with Shirley and again with Louis Moore And Louis met him in congenial spirit He did not laugh much but he uttered in the quietest tone the wittiest things Gravely spoken sentences marked by unexpected turns and a quite fresh flavour and poignancy fell easily from his lips He proved himself to be what Mr Hall had said he was excellent company Caroline marvelled at his humour but still more at his entire self possession Nobody there present seemed to impose on him a sensation of unpleasant restraint Nobody seemed a bore a check a chill to him and yet there was the cool and lofty Miss Keeldar kneeling before the fire almost at his feet

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: But Shirley was cool and lofty no longer, at least not at this moment. She appeared unconscious of the humility of her present position; or if conscious, it was only to taste a charm in its lowliness. It did not revolt her pride that the group to whom she voluntarily officiated as handmaid should include her cousin's tutor. It did not scare her that while she handed the bread and milk to the rest, she had to offer it to him also; and Moore took his portion from her hand as calmly as if he had been her equal.
children.prevalue: But Shirley was cool and lofty no longer at least not at this moment She appeared unconscious of the humility of her present position or if conscious it was only to taste a charm in its lowliness It did not revolt her pride that the group to whom she voluntarily officiated as handmaid should include her cousin s tutor It did not scare her that while she handed the bread and milk to the rest she had to offer it to him also and Moore took his portion from her hand as calmly as if he had been her equal

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: You are overheated now, he said, when she had retained the fork for some time; let me relieve you.
children.prevalue: You are overheated now he said when she had retained the fork for some time let me relieve you

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: And he took it from her with a sort of quiet authority, to which she submitted passively, neither resisting him nor thanking him.
children.prevalue: And he took it from her with a sort of quiet authority to which she submitted passively neither resisting him nor thanking him

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: I should like to see your pictures, Louis, said Caroline, when the sumptuous luncheon was discussed.    Would not you, Mr. Hall?
children.prevalue: I should like to see your pictures Louis said Caroline when the sumptuous luncheon was discussed Would not you Mr Hall

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: To please you, I should; but, for my own part, I have cut him as an artist. I had enough of him in that capacity in Cumberland and Westmoreland. Many a wetting we got amongst the mountains because he would persist in sitting on a camp  stool, catching effects of rain  clouds, gathering mists, fitful sunbeams, and what not.

children.value: Louis took it, but he still sat as if he wanted another to speak. It seemed as if he would not open it unless the proud Shirley deigned to show herself interested in the exhibition.
children.prevalue: Louis took it but he still sat as if he wanted another to speak It seemed as if he would not open it unless the proud Shirley deigned to show herself interested in the exhibition

children.value: He held it. She opened it, and, monopolizing the contents, had the first view of every sketch herself. She enjoyed the treat    if treat it were    in silence, without a single comment. Moore stood behind her chair and looked over her shoulder, and when she had done and the others were still gazing, he left his post and paced through the room.

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: There are callers, she said, and I shall be summoned to the room. A pretty figure    as they say    I am to receive company. I and Henry have been in the garden gathering fruit half the morning. Oh for rest under my own vine and my own fig  tree! Happy is the slave  wife of the Indian chief, in that she has no drawing  room duty to perform, but can sit at ease weaving mats, and stringing beads, and peacefully flattening her pickaninny's head in an unmolested corner of her wigwam. I'll emigrate to the western woods.

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: To marry a White Cloud or a Big Buffalo, and after wedlock to devote yourself to the tender task of digging your lord's maize  field while he smokes his pipe or drinks fire  water.
children.prevalue: To marry a White Cloud or a Big Buffalo and after wedlock to devote yourself to the tender task of digging your lord s maize field while he smokes his pipe or drinks fire water

children.value: The family from De Walden Hall! Couldn't be a worse set, murmured Shirley.
children.prevalue: The family from De Walden Hall Couldn t be a worse set murmured Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: She sat still, looking a little contumacious, and very much indisposed to stir. She was flushed with the fire. Her dark hair had been more than once dishevelled by the morning wind that day. Her attire was a light, neatly fitting, but amply flowing dress of muslin; the shawl she had worn in the garden was still draped in a careless fold round her. Indolent, wilful, picturesque, and singularly pretty was her aspect    prettier than usual, as if some soft inward emotion, stirred who knows how, had given new bloom and expression to her features.

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: Shirley, Shirley, you ought to go, whispered Caroline.
children.prevalue: Shirley Shirley you ought to go whispered Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: I wonder why?
children.prevalue: I wonder why

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: She lifted her eyes, and saw in the glass over the fireplace both Mr. Hall and Louis Moore gazing at her gravely.
children.prevalue: She lifted her eyes and saw in the glass over the fireplace both Mr Hall and Louis Moore gazing at her gravely

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: If, she said, with a yielding smile    if a majority of the present company maintain that the De Walden Hall people have claims on my civility, I will subdue my inclinations to my duty. Let those who think I ought to go hold up their hands.

children.name: Paragraph_188

children.prevalue: Again consulting the mirror it reflected an unanimous vote against her

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: You must go, said Mr. Hall, and behave courteously too. You owe many duties to society. It is not permitted you to please only yourself.
children.prevalue: You must go said Mr Hall and behave courteously too You owe many duties to society It is not permitted you to please only yourself

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: Louis Moore assented with a low Hear, hear!
children.prevalue: Louis Moore assented with a low Hear hear

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: Caroline, approaching her, smoothed her wavy curls, gave to her attire a less artistic and more domestic grace, and Shirley was put out of the room, protesting still, by a pouting lip, against her dismissal.
children.prevalue: Caroline approaching her smoothed her wavy curls gave to her attire a less artistic and more domestic grace and Shirley was put out of the room protesting still by a pouting lip against her dismissal

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: There is a curious charm about her, observed Mr. Hall, when she was gone. And now, he added, I must away; for Sweeting is off to see his mother, and there are two funerals.
children.prevalue: There is a curious charm about her observed Mr Hall when she was gone And now he added I must away for Sweeting is off to see his mother and there are two funerals

children.name: Paragraph_193

children.value: A curious charm! repeated the pupil, when he and his master were left alone. True. Is she not a kind of white witch? he asked.

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: Of whom are you speaking, sir?
children.prevalue: Of whom are you speaking sir

children.name: Paragraph_196

children.prevalue: Of my cousin Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: No irrelevant questions; study in silence.
children.prevalue: No irrelevant questions study in silence

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: Mr. Moore looked and spoke sternly    sourly. Henry knew this mood. It was a rare one with his tutor; but when it came he had an awe of it. He obeyed.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore looked and spoke sternly sourly Henry knew this mood It was a rare one with his tutor but when it came he had an awe of it He obeyed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Miss Keeldar and her uncle had characters that would not harmonize, that never had harmonized. He was irritable, and she was spirited. He was despotic, and she liked freedom. He was worldly, and she, perhaps, romantic.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar and her uncle had characters that would not harmonize that never had harmonized He was irritable and she was spirited He was despotic and she liked freedom He was worldly and she perhaps romantic

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Not without purpose had he come down to Yorkshire. His mission was clear, and he intended to discharge it conscientiously. He anxiously desired to have his niece married, to make for her a suitable match, give her in charge to a proper husband, and wash his hands of her for ever.
children.prevalue: Not without purpose had he come down to Yorkshire His mission was clear and he intended to discharge it conscientiously He anxiously desired to have his niece married to make for her a suitable match give her in charge to a proper husband and wash his hands of her for ever

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The misfortune was, from infancy upwards, Shirley and he had disagreed on the meaning of the words suitable and proper. She never yet had accepted his definition; and it was doubtful whether, in the most important step of her life, she would consent to accept it.
children.prevalue: The misfortune was from infancy upwards Shirley and he had disagreed on the meaning of the words suitable and proper She never yet had accepted his definition and it was doubtful whether in the most important step of her life she would consent to accept it

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The trial soon came.
children.prevalue: The trial soon came

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Mr. Wynne proposed in form for his son, Samuel Fawthrop Wynne.
children.prevalue: Mr Wynne proposed in form for his son Samuel Fawthrop Wynne

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Decidedly suitable! most proper! pronounced Mr. Sympson. A fine unencumbered estate, real substance, good connections.   It must be done!
children.prevalue: Decidedly suitable most proper pronounced Mr Sympson A fine unencumbered estate real substance good connections It must be done

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: He sent for his niece to the oak parlour; he shut himself up there with her alone; he communicated the offer; he gave his opinion; he claimed her consent.
children.prevalue: He sent for his niece to the oak parlour he shut himself up there with her alone he communicated the offer he gave his opinion he claimed her consent

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It was withheld.
children.prevalue: It was withheld

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No; I shall not marry Samuel Fawthrop Wynne.
children.prevalue: No I shall not marry Samuel Fawthrop Wynne

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I ask why. I must have a reason. In all respects he is more than worthy of you.
children.prevalue: I ask why I must have a reason In all respects he is more than worthy of you

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: She stood on the hearth. She was pale as the white marble slab and cornice behind her; her eyes flashed large, dilated, unsmiling.
children.prevalue: She stood on the hearth She was pale as the white marble slab and cornice behind her her eyes flashed large dilated unsmiling

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And   I   ask in what sense that young man is worthy of   me  ?
children.prevalue: And I ask in what sense that young man is worthy of me

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He has twice your money, twice your common sense, equal connections, equal respectability.
children.prevalue: He has twice your money twice your common sense equal connections equal respectability

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Had he my money counted fivescore times I would take no vow to love him.
children.prevalue: Had he my money counted fivescore times I would take no vow to love him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Please to state your objections.
children.prevalue: Please to state your objections

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: He has run a course of despicable, commonplace profligacy. Accept that as the first reason why I spurn him.
children.prevalue: He has run a course of despicable commonplace profligacy Accept that as the first reason why I spurn him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Miss Keeldar, you shock me!
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar you shock me

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: That conduct alone sinks him in a gulf of immeasurable inferiority. His intellect reaches no standard I can esteem: there is a second stumbling  block. His views are narrow, his feelings are blunt, his tastes are coarse, his manners vulgar.
children.prevalue: That conduct alone sinks him in a gulf of immeasurable inferiority His intellect reaches no standard I can esteem there is a second stumbling block His views are narrow his feelings are blunt his tastes are coarse his manners vulgar

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The man is a respectable, wealthy man! To refuse him is presumption on your part.
children.prevalue: The man is a respectable wealthy man To refuse him is presumption on your part

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I refuse point  blank! Cease to annoy me with the subject; I forbid it!
children.prevalue: I refuse point blank Cease to annoy me with the subject I forbid it

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Is it your intention ever to marry; or do you prefer celibacy?
children.prevalue: Is it your intention ever to marry or do you prefer celibacy

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I deny your right to claim an answer to that question.
children.prevalue: I deny your right to claim an answer to that question

children.prevalue: May I ask if you expect some man of title some peer of the realm to demand your hand

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I doubt if the peer breathes on whom I would confer it.
children.prevalue: I doubt if the peer breathes on whom I would confer it

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Were there insanity in the family, I should believe you mad. Your eccentricity and conceit touch the verge of frenzy.
children.prevalue: Were there insanity in the family I should believe you mad Your eccentricity and conceit touch the verge of frenzy

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Perhaps, ere I have finished, you will see me over  leap it.
children.prevalue: Perhaps ere I have finished you will see me over leap it

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I anticipate no less. Frantic and impracticable girl! Take warning! I dare you to sully our name by a   msalliance  !
children.prevalue: I anticipate no less Frantic and impracticable girl Take warning I dare you to sully our name by a msalliance

children.value: Our   name! Am   I   called Sympson?
children.prevalue: Our name Am I called Sympson

children.prevalue: God be thanked that you are not But be on your guard I will not be trifled with

children.value: Take care! take care! warning her with voice and hand that trembled alike.
children.prevalue: Take care take care warning her with voice and hand that trembled alike

children.value: Take care, madam!
children.prevalue: Take care madam

children.prevalue: Scrupulous care I will take Mr Sympson Before I marry I am resolved to esteem to admire to love

children.value: Preposterous stuff! indecorous, unwomanly!
children.prevalue: Preposterous stuff indecorous unwomanly

children.prevalue: To love with my whole heart I know I speak in an unknown tongue but I feel indifferent whether I am comprehended or not

children.prevalue: And if this love of yours should fall on a beggar

children.prevalue: On a beggar it will never fall Mendicancy is not estimable

children.prevalue: On a low clerk a play actor a play writer or or

children.prevalue: Take courage Mr Sympson Or what

children.prevalue: To what will she come Why are not the laws more stringent that I might compel her to hear reason

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Console yourself, uncle. Were Britain a serfdom and you the Czar, you could not   compel   me to this step.   I   will write to Mr. Wynne. Give yourself no further trouble on the subject.
children.prevalue: Console yourself uncle Were Britain a serfdom and you the Czar you could not compel me to this step I will write to Mr Wynne Give yourself no further trouble on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Fortune is proverbially called changeful, yet her caprice often takes the form of repeating again and again a similar stroke of luck in the same quarter. It appeared that Miss Keeldar    or her fortune    had by this time made a sensation in the district, and produced an impression in quarters by her unthought of. No less than three offers followed Mr. Wynne's, all more or less eligible. All were in succession pressed on her by her uncle, and all in succession she refused. Yet amongst them was more than one gentleman of unexceptionable character as well as ample wealth. Many besides her uncle asked what she meant, and whom she expected to entrap, that she was so insolently fastidious.

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: At last the gossips thought they had found the key to her conduct, and her uncle was sure of it; and what is more, the discovery showed his niece to him in quite a new light, and he changed his whole deportment to her accordingly.
children.prevalue: At last the gossips thought they had found the key to her conduct and her uncle was sure of it and what is more the discovery showed his niece to him in quite a new light and he changed his whole deportment to her accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Fieldhead had of late been fast growing too hot to hold them both. The suave aunt could not reconcile them; the daughters froze at the view of their quarrels. Gertrude and Isabella whispered by the hour together in their dressing  room, and became chilled with decorous dread if they chanced to be left alone with their audacious cousin. But, as I have said, a change supervened. Mr. Sympson was appeased and his family tranquillized.

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The village of Nunnely has been alluded to    its old church, its forest, its monastic ruins. It had also its hall, called the priory    an older, a larger, a more lordly abode than any Briarfield or Whinbury owned; and what is more, it had its man of title    its baronet, which neither Briarfield nor Whinbury could boast. This possession    its proudest and most prized    had for years been nominal only. The present baronet, a young man hitherto resident in a distant province, was unknown on his Yorkshire estate.

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: During Miss Keeldar's stay at the fashionable watering  place of Cliffbridge, she and her friends had met with and been introduced to Sir Philip Nunnely. They encountered him again and again on the sands, the cliffs, in the various walks, sometimes at the public balls of the place. He seemed solitary. His manner was very unpretending    too simple to be termed affable; rather timid than proud. He did not   condescend   to their society; he seemed   glad   of it.
