children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I   am not  .
children.prevalue: I am not

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Did anything weigh on her mind? Had anything happened to affect her spirits?
children.prevalue: Did anything weigh on her mind Had anything happened to affect her spirits

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: She scornfully ridiculed the idea. What did they mean by spirits? She had no spirits, black or white, blue or gray, to affect.
children.prevalue: She scornfully ridiculed the idea What did they mean by spirits She had no spirits black or white blue or gray to affect

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Something must be the matter    she was so altered.
children.prevalue: Something must be the matter she was so altered

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: She supposed she had a right to alter at her ease. She knew she was plainer. If it suited her to grow ugly, why need others fret themselves on the subject?
children.prevalue: She supposed she had a right to alter at her ease She knew she was plainer If it suited her to grow ugly why need others fret themselves on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: There must be a cause for the change. What was it?
children.prevalue: There must be a cause for the change What was it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: She peremptorily requested to be let alone.
children.prevalue: She peremptorily requested to be let alone

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Then she would make every effort to appear quite gay, and she seemed indignant at herself that she could not perfectly succeed. Brief self  spurning epithets burst from her lips when alone. Fool! coward! she would term herself. Poltroon! she would say, if you must tremble, tremble in secret! Quail where no eye sees you!
children.prevalue: Then she would make every effort to appear quite gay and she seemed indignant at herself that she could not perfectly succeed Brief self spurning epithets burst from her lips when alone Fool coward she would term herself Poltroon she would say if you must tremble tremble in secret Quail where no eye sees you

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: How dare you, she would ask herself    how dare you show your weakness and betray your imbecile anxieties? Shake them off; rise above them. If you cannot do this, hide them.
children.prevalue: How dare you she would ask herself how dare you show your weakness and betray your imbecile anxieties Shake them off rise above them If you cannot do this hide them

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And to hide them she did her best. She once more became resolutely lively in company. When weary of effort and forced to relax, she sought solitude    not the solitude of her chamber (she refused to mope, shut up between four walls), but that wilder solitude which lies out of doors, and which she could chase, mounted on Zo, her mare. She took long rides of half a day. Her uncle disapproved, but he dared not remonstrate. It was never pleasant to face Shirley's anger, even when she was healthy and gay; but now that her face showed thin, and her large eye looked hollow, there was something in the darkening of that face and kindling of that eye which touched as well as alarmed.
children.prevalue: And to hide them she did her best She once more became resolutely lively in company When weary of effort and forced to relax she sought solitude not the solitude of her chamber she refused to mope shut up between four walls but that wilder solitude which lies out of doors and which she could chase mounted on Zo her mare She took long rides of half a day Her uncle disapproved but he dared not remonstrate It was never pleasant to face Shirley s anger even when she was healthy and gay but now that her face showed thin and her large eye looked hollow there was something in the darkening of that face and kindling of that eye which touched as well as alarmed

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: To all comparative strangers who, unconscious of the alterations in her spirits, commented on the alteration in her looks, she had one reply,
children.prevalue: To all comparative strangers who unconscious of the alterations in her spirits commented on the alteration in her looks she had one reply

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I am perfectly well; I have not an ailment.
children.prevalue: I am perfectly well I have not an ailment

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And health, indeed, she must have had, to be able to bear the exposure to the weather she now encountered. Wet or fair, calm or storm, she took her daily ride over Stilbro' Moor, Tartar keeping up at her side, with his wolf  like gallop, long and untiring.
children.prevalue: And health indeed she must have had to be able to bear the exposure to the weather she now encountered Wet or fair calm or storm she took her daily ride over Stilbro Moor Tartar keeping up at her side with his wolf like gallop long and untiring

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Twice, three times, the eyes of gossips    those eyes which are everywhere, in the closet and on the hill  top    noticed that instead of turning on Rushedge, the top ridge of Stilbro' Moor, she rode forwards all the way to the town. Scouts were not wanting to mark her destination there. It was ascertained that she alighted at the door of one Mr. Pearson Hall, a solicitor, related to the vicar of Nunnely. This gentleman and his ancestors had been the agents of the Keeldar family for generations back. Some people affirmed that Miss Keeldar was become involved in business speculations connected with Hollow's Mill    that she had lost money, and was constrained to mortgage her land. Others conjectured that she was going to be married, and that the settlements were preparing.

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Mr. Moore and Henry Sympson were together in the schoolroom. The tutor was waiting for a lesson which the pupil seemed busy in preparing.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore and Henry Sympson were together in the schoolroom The tutor was waiting for a lesson which the pupil seemed busy in preparing

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Henry, make haste. The afternoon is getting on.
children.prevalue: Henry make haste The afternoon is getting on

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Is it, sir?
children.prevalue: Is it sir

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Certainly. Are you nearly ready with that lesson?
children.prevalue: Certainly Are you nearly ready with that lesson

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Not   nearly   ready?
children.prevalue: Not nearly ready

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I have not construed a line.
children.prevalue: I have not construed a line

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Mr. Moore looked up. The boy's tone was rather peculiar.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore looked up The boy s tone was rather peculiar

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The task presents no difficulties, Henry; or, if it does, bring them to me. We will work together.
children.prevalue: The task presents no difficulties Henry or if it does bring them to me We will work together

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Mr. Moore, I can do no work.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore I can do no work

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: My boy, you are ill.
children.prevalue: My boy you are ill

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Sir, I am not worse in bodily health than usual, but my heart is full.
children.prevalue: Sir I am not worse in bodily health than usual but my heart is full

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Shut the book. Come hither, Harry. Come to the fireside.
children.prevalue: Shut the book Come hither Harry Come to the fireside

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Harry limped forward. His tutor placed him in a chair; his lips were quivering, his eyes brimming. He laid his crutch on the floor, bent down his head, and wept.
children.prevalue: Harry limped forward His tutor placed him in a chair his lips were quivering his eyes brimming He laid his crutch on the floor bent down his head and wept

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This distress is not occasioned by physical pain, you say, Harry? You have a grief; tell it me.
children.prevalue: This distress is not occasioned by physical pain you say Harry You have a grief tell it me

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Sir, I have such a grief as I never had before. I wish it could be relieved in some way; I can hardly bear it.
children.prevalue: Sir I have such a grief as I never had before I wish it could be relieved in some way I can hardly bear it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Who knows but, if we talk it over, we may relieve it? What is the cause? Whom does it concern?
children.prevalue: Who knows but if we talk it over we may relieve it What is the cause Whom does it concern

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The cause, sir, is Shirley; it concerns Shirley.
children.prevalue: The cause sir is Shirley it concerns Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Does it? You think her changed?
children.prevalue: Does it You think her changed

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: All who know her think her changed    you too, Mr. Moore.
children.prevalue: All who know her think her changed you too Mr Moore

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Not seriously    no. I see no alteration but such as a favourable turn might repair in a few weeks; besides, her own word must go for something: she says she is well.
children.prevalue: Not seriously no I see no alteration but such as a favourable turn might repair in a few weeks besides her own word must go for something she says she is well

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: There it is, sir. As long as she maintained she was well, I believed her. When I was sad out of her sight, I soon recovered spirits in her presence. Now
children.prevalue: There it is sir As long as she maintained she was well I believed her When I was sad out of her sight I soon recovered spirits in her presence Now

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Well, Harry, now. Has she said anything to you? You and she were together in the garden two hours this morning. I saw her talking, and you listening. Now, my dear Harry, if Miss Keeldar has said she is ill, and enjoined you to keep her secret, do not obey her. For her life's sake, avow everything. Speak, my boy.
children.prevalue: Well Harry now Has she said anything to you You and she were together in the garden two hours this morning I saw her talking and you listening Now my dear Harry if Miss Keeldar has said she is ill and enjoined you to keep her secret do not obey her For her life s sake avow everything Speak my boy

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: She   say she is ill! I believe, sir, if she were dying, she would smile, and aver, 'Nothing ails me.'
children.prevalue: She say she is ill I believe sir if she were dying she would smile and aver Nothing ails me

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: What have you learned then? What new circumstance?
children.prevalue: What have you learned then What new circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I have learned that she has just made her will.
children.prevalue: I have learned that she has just made her will

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Made her will?
children.prevalue: Made her will

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The tutor and pupil were silent.
children.prevalue: The tutor and pupil were silent

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: She told you that? asked Moore, when some minutes had elapsed.
children.prevalue: She told you that asked Moore when some minutes had elapsed

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: She told me quite cheerfully, not as an ominous circumstance, which I felt it to be. She said I was the only person besides her solicitor, Pearson Hall, and Mr. Helstone and Mr. Yorke, who knew anything about it; and to me, she intimated, she wished specially to explain its provisions.
children.prevalue: She told me quite cheerfully not as an ominous circumstance which I felt it to be She said I was the only person besides her solicitor Pearson Hall and Mr Helstone and Mr Yorke who knew anything about it and to me she intimated she wished specially to explain its provisions

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Go on, Harry.
children.prevalue: Go on Harry

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: 'Because,' she said, looking down on me with her beautiful eyes    oh! they   are   beautiful, Mr. Moore! I love them! I love her! She is my star! Heaven must not claim her! She is lovely in this world, and fitted for this world. Shirley is not an angel; she is a woman, and she shall live with men. Seraphs shall not have her! Mr. Moore, if one of the 'sons of God,' with wings wide and bright as the sky, blue and sounding as the sea, having seen that she was fair, descended to claim her, his claim should be withstood    withstood by me    boy and cripple as I am.
children.prevalue: Because she said looking down on me with her beautiful eyes oh they are beautiful Mr Moore I love them I love her She is my star Heaven must not claim her She is lovely in this world and fitted for this world Shirley is not an angel she is a woman and she shall live with men Seraphs shall not have her Mr Moore if one of the sons of God with wings wide and bright as the sky blue and sounding as the sea having seen that she was fair descended to claim her his claim should be withstood withstood by me boy and cripple as I am

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Henry Sympson, go on, when I tell you.
children.prevalue: Henry Sympson go on when I tell you

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Because,' she said, 'if I made no will, and died before you, Harry, all my property would go to you; and I do not intend that it should be so, though your father would like it. But you,' she said, 'will have his whole estate, which is large    larger than Fieldhead. Your sisters will have nothing; so I have left them some money, though I do not love them, both together, half so much as I love one lock of your fair hair.' She said these words, and she called me her 'darling,' and let me kiss her. She went on to tell me that she had left Caroline Helstone some money too; that this manor house, with its furniture and books, she had bequeathed to me, as she did not choose to take the old family place from her own blood; and that all the rest of her property, amounting to about twelve thousand pounds, exclusive of the legacies to my sisters and Miss Helstone, she had willed, not to me, seeing I was already rich, but to a good man, who would make the best use of it that any human being could do    a man, she said, that was both gentle and brave, strong and merciful    a man that might not profess to be pious, but she knew he had the secret of religion pure and undefiled before God. The spirit of love and peace was with him. He visited the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and kept himself unspotted from the world. Then she asked, 'Do you approve what I have done, Harry?' I could not answer. My tears choked me, as they do now.

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Mr. Moore allowed his pupil a moment to contend with and master his emotion. He then demanded, What else did she say?
children.prevalue: Mr Moore allowed his pupil a moment to contend with and master his emotion He then demanded What else did she say

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: When I had signified my full consent to the conditions of her will, she told me I was a generous boy, and she was proud of me. 'And now,' she added, 'in case anything should happen, you will know what to say to Malice when she comes whispering hard things in your ear, insinuating that Shirley has wronged you, that she did not love you. You will know that I   did   love you, Harry; that no sister could have loved you better    my own treasure.' Mr. Moore, sir, when I remember her voice, and recall her look, my heart beats as if it would break its strings. She   may   go to heaven before me    if God commands it, she   must  ; but the rest of my life    and my life will not be long, I am glad of that now    shall be a straight, quick, thoughtful journey in the path her step has pressed. I thought to enter the vault of the Keeldars before her. Should it be otherwise, lay my coffin by Shirley's side.

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Moore answered him with a weighty calm, that offered a strange contrast to the boy's perturbed enthusiasm.
children.prevalue: Moore answered him with a weighty calm that offered a strange contrast to the boy s perturbed enthusiasm

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: You are wrong, both of you    you harm each other. If youth once falls under the influence of a shadowy terror, it imagines there will never be full sunlight again; its first calamity it fancies will last a lifetime. What more did she say? Anything more?
children.prevalue: You are wrong both of you you harm each other If youth once falls under the influence of a shadowy terror it imagines there will never be full sunlight again its first calamity it fancies will last a lifetime What more did she say Anything more

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: We settled one or two family points between ourselves.
children.prevalue: We settled one or two family points between ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I should rather like to know what
children.prevalue: I should rather like to know what

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But, Mr. Moore, you smile.   I   could not smile to see Shirley in such a mood.
children.prevalue: But Mr Moore you smile I could not smile to see Shirley in such a mood

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: My boy, I am neither nervous, nor poetic, nor inexperienced. I see things as they are; you don't as yet. Tell me these family points.
children.prevalue: My boy I am neither nervous nor poetic nor inexperienced I see things as they are you don t as yet Tell me these family points

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Only, sir, she asked me whether I considered myself most of a Keeldar or a Sympson; and I answered I was Keeldar to the core of the heart and to the marrow of the bones. She said she was glad of it; for, besides her, I was the only Keeldar left in England. And then we agreed on some matters.
children.prevalue: Only sir she asked me whether I considered myself most of a Keeldar or a Sympson and I answered I was Keeldar to the core of the heart and to the marrow of the bones She said she was glad of it for besides her I was the only Keeldar left in England And then we agreed on some matters

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Well, sir, that if I lived to inherit my father's estate, and her house, I was to take the name of Keeldar, and to make Fieldhead my residence. Henry Shirley Keeldar I said I would be called; and I will. Her name and her manor house are ages old, and Sympson and Sympson Grove are of yesterday.
children.prevalue: Well sir that if I lived to inherit my father s estate and her house I was to take the name of Keeldar and to make Fieldhead my residence Henry Shirley Keeldar I said I would be called and I will Her name and her manor house are ages old and Sympson and Sympson Grove are of yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Come, you are neither of you going to heaven yet. I have the best hopes of you both, with your proud distinctions    a pair of half  fledged eaglets. Now, what is your inference from all you have told me? Put it into words.
children.prevalue: Come you are neither of you going to heaven yet I have the best hopes of you both with your proud distinctions a pair of half fledged eaglets Now what is your inference from all you have told me Put it into words

children.prevalue: That Shirley thinks she is going to die

children.value: She referred to her health?
children.prevalue: She referred to her health

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Not once; but I assure you she is wasting. Her hands are grown quite thin, and so is her cheek.
children.prevalue: Not once but I assure you she is wasting Her hands are grown quite thin and so is her cheek

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Does she ever complain to your mother or sisters?
children.prevalue: Does she ever complain to your mother or sisters

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Never. She laughs at them when they question her. Mr. Moore, she is a strange being, so fair and girlish    not a man  like woman at all, not an Amazon, and yet lifting her head above both help and sympathy.

children.prevalue: Do you know where she is now Henry Is she in the house or riding out

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Surely not out, sir. It rains fast.
children.prevalue: Surely not out sir It rains fast

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: True; which, however, is no guarantee that she is not at this moment cantering over Rushedge. Of late she has never permitted weather to be a hindrance to her rides.
children.prevalue: True which however is no guarantee that she is not at this moment cantering over Rushedge Of late she has never permitted weather to be a hindrance to her rides

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: You remember, Mr. Moore, how wet and stormy it was last Wednesday    so wild, indeed, that she would not permit Zo to be saddled? Yet the blast she thought too tempestuous for her mare she herself faced on foot; that afternoon she walked nearly as far as Nunnely. I asked her, when she came in, if she was not afraid of taking cold. 'Not I,' she said. 'It would be too much good luck for me. I don't know, Harry, but the best thing that could happen to me would be to take a good cold and fever, and so pass off like other Christians.' She is reckless, you see, sir.

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Reckless indeed! Go and find out where she is, and if you can get an opportunity of speaking to her without attracting attention, request her to come here a minute.
children.prevalue: Reckless indeed Go and find out where she is and if you can get an opportunity of speaking to her without attracting attention request her to come here a minute

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Yes, sir.
children.prevalue: Yes sir

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: He snatched his crutch, and started up to go.
children.prevalue: He snatched his crutch and started up to go

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Harry!
children.prevalue: Harry

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: He returned.
children.prevalue: He returned

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Do not deliver the message formally. Word it as, in former days, you would have worded an ordinary summons to the schoolroom.
children.prevalue: Do not deliver the message formally Word it as in former days you would have worded an ordinary summons to the schoolroom

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I see, sir. She will be more likely to obey.
children.prevalue: I see sir She will be more likely to obey

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: And, Harry
children.prevalue: And Harry

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Sir?
children.prevalue: Sir

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: I will call you when I want you. Till then, you are dispensed from lessons.
children.prevalue: I will call you when I want you Till then you are dispensed from lessons

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: He departed. Mr. Moore, left alone, rose from his desk.
children.prevalue: He departed Mr Moore left alone rose from his desk

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: I can be very cool and very supercilious with Henry, he said. I can seem to make light of his apprehensions, and look down   du haut de ma grandeur   on his youthful ardour. To   him   I can speak as if, in my eyes, they were both children. Let me see if I can keep up the same rle with her. I have known the moment when I seemed about to forget it, when Confusion and Submission seemed about to crush me with their soft tyranny, when my tongue faltered, and I have almost let the mantle drop, and stood in her presence, not master    no    but something else. I trust I shall never so play the fool. It is well for a Sir Philip Nunnely to redden when he meets her eye. He may permit himself the indulgence of submission. He may even, without disgrace, suffer his hand to tremble when it touches hers; but if one of her farmers were to show himself susceptible and sentimental, he would merely prove his need of a strait waistcoat. So far I have always done very well. She has sat near me, and I have not shaken    more than my desk. I have encountered her looks and smiles like    why, like a tutor, as I am. Her hand I never yet touched    never underwent that test. Her farmer or her footman I am not    no serf nor servant of hers have I ever been; but I am poor, and it behoves me to look to my self  respect    not to compromise an inch of it. What did she mean by that allusion to the cold people who petrify flesh to marble? It pleased me    I hardly know why; I would not permit myself to inquire. I never do indulge in scrutiny either of her language or countenance; for if I did, I should sometimes forget common sense and believe in romance. A strange, secret ecstasy steals through my veins at moments. I'll not encourage    I'll not remember it. I am resolved, as long as may be, to retain the right to say with Paul, 'I am not mad, but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.'

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: He paused, listening.
children.prevalue: He paused listening

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Will she come, or will she not come? he inquired. How will she take the message? Navely or disdainfully? Like a child or like a queen? Both characters are in her nature.
children.prevalue: Will she come or will she not come he inquired How will she take the message Navely or disdainfully Like a child or like a queen Both characters are in her nature

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: If she comes, what shall I say to her? How account, firstly, for the freedom of the request? Shall I apologize to her? I could in all humility; but would an apology tend to place us in the positions we ought relatively to occupy in this matter? I   must   keep up the professor, otherwise         I hear a door.
children.prevalue: If she comes what shall I say to her How account firstly for the freedom of the request Shall I apologize to her I could in all humility but would an apology tend to place us in the positions we ought relatively to occupy in this matter I must keep up the professor otherwise I hear a door

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: He waited. Many minutes passed.
children.prevalue: He waited Many minutes passed

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: She will refuse me. Henry is entreating her to come; she declines. My petition is presumption in her eyes. Let her   only   come, I can teach her to the contrary. I would rather she were a little perverse; it will steel me. I prefer her cuirassed in pride, armed with a taunt. Her scorn startles me from my dreams; I stand up myself. A sarcasm from her eyes or lips puts strength into every nerve and sinew I have. Some step approaches, and not Henry's.
children.prevalue: She will refuse me Henry is entreating her to come she declines My petition is presumption in her eyes Let her only come I can teach her to the contrary I would rather she were a little perverse it will steel me I prefer her cuirassed in pride armed with a taunt Her scorn startles me from my dreams I stand up myself A sarcasm from her eyes or lips puts strength into every nerve and sinew I have Some step approaches and not Henry s

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The door unclosed; Miss Keeldar came in. The message, it appeared, had found her at her needle; she brought her work in her hand. That day she had not been riding out; she had evidently passed it quietly. She wore her neat indoor dress and silk apron. This was no Thalestris from the fields, but a quiet domestic character from the fireside. Mr. Moore had her at advantage. He should have addressed her at once in solemn accents, and with rigid mien. Perhaps he would, had she looked saucy; but her air never showed less of   crnerie  . A soft kind of youthful shyness depressed her eyelid and mantled on her cheek. The tutor stood silent.
children.prevalue: The door unclosed Miss Keeldar came in The message it appeared had found her at her needle she brought her work in her hand That day she had not been riding out she had evidently passed it quietly She wore her neat indoor dress and silk apron This was no Thalestris from the fields but a quiet domestic character from the fireside Mr Moore had her at advantage He should have addressed her at once in solemn accents and with rigid mien Perhaps he would had she looked saucy but her air never showed less of crnerie A soft kind of youthful shyness depressed her eyelid and mantled on her cheek The tutor stood silent

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: She made a full stop between the door and his desk.
children.prevalue: She made a full stop between the door and his desk

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Did you want me, sir? she asked.
children.prevalue: Did you want me sir she asked

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I ventured, Miss Keeldar, to send for you    that is, to ask an interview of a few minutes.
children.prevalue: I ventured Miss Keeldar to send for you that is to ask an interview of a few minutes

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: She waited; she plied her needle.
children.prevalue: She waited she plied her needle

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Well, sir (not lifting her eyes), what about?
children.prevalue: Well sir not lifting her eyes what about

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Be seated first. The subject I would broach is one of some moment. Perhaps I have hardly a right to approach it. It is possible I ought to frame an apology; it is possible no apology can excuse me. The liberty I have taken arises from a conversation with Henry. The boy is unhappy about your health; all your friends are unhappy on that subject. It is of your health I would speak.
children.prevalue: Be seated first The subject I would broach is one of some moment Perhaps I have hardly a right to approach it It is possible I ought to frame an apology it is possible no apology can excuse me The liberty I have taken arises from a conversation with Henry The boy is unhappy about your health all your friends are unhappy on that subject It is of your health I would speak

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I am quite well, she said briefly.
children.prevalue: I am quite well she said briefly

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Yet changed.
children.prevalue: Yet changed

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: That matters to none but myself. We all change.
children.prevalue: That matters to none but myself We all change

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Will you sit down? Formerly, Miss Keeldar, I had some influence with you: have I any now? May I feel that what I am saying is not accounted positive presumption?
children.prevalue: Will you sit down Formerly Miss Keeldar I had some influence with you have I any now May I feel that what I am saying is not accounted positive presumption

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Let me read some French, Mr. Moore, or I will even take a spell at the Latin grammar, and let us proclaim a truce to all sanitary discussions.
children.prevalue: Let me read some French Mr Moore or I will even take a spell at the Latin grammar and let us proclaim a truce to all sanitary discussions

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: No, no. It is time there were discussions.
children.prevalue: No no It is time there were discussions

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Discuss away, then, but do not choose me for your text. I am a healthy subject.
children.prevalue: Discuss away then but do not choose me for your text I am a healthy subject

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Do you not think it wrong to affirm and reaffirm what is substantially untrue?
children.prevalue: Do you not think it wrong to affirm and reaffirm what is substantially untrue

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I say I am well. I have neither cough, pain, nor fever.
children.prevalue: I say I am well I have neither cough pain nor fever

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Is there no equivocation in that assertion? Is it the direct truth?
children.prevalue: Is there no equivocation in that assertion Is it the direct truth

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: The direct truth.
children.prevalue: The direct truth

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Louis Moore looked at her earnestly.
children.prevalue: Louis Moore looked at her earnestly

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I can myself, he said, trace no indications of actual disease. But why, then, are you altered?
children.prevalue: I can myself he said trace no indications of actual disease But why then are you altered

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Am   I altered?
children.prevalue: Am I altered

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: We will try. We will seek a proof.
children.prevalue: We will try We will seek a proof

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: How?
children.prevalue: How

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: I ask, in the first place, do you sleep as you used to?
children.prevalue: I ask in the first place do you sleep as you used to

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: I do not; but it is not because I am ill.
children.prevalue: I do not but it is not because I am ill

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Have you the appetite you once had?
children.prevalue: Have you the appetite you once had

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: No; but it is not because I am ill.
children.prevalue: No but it is not because I am ill

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: You remember this little ring fastened to my watch  chain? It was my mother's, and is too small to pass the joint of my little finger. You have many a time sportively purloined it. It fitted your fore  finger. Try now.
children.prevalue: You remember this little ring fastened to my watch chain It was my mother s and is too small to pass the joint of my little finger You have many a time sportively purloined it It fitted your fore finger Try now

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: She permitted the test. The ring dropped from the wasted little hand. Louis picked it up, and reattached it to the chain. An uneasy flush coloured his brow. Shirley again said, It is not because I am ill.
children.prevalue: She permitted the test The ring dropped from the wasted little hand Louis picked it up and reattached it to the chain An uneasy flush coloured his brow Shirley again said It is not because I am ill

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Not only have you lost sleep, appetite, and flesh, proceeded Moore, but your spirits are always at ebb. Besides, there is a nervous alarm in your eye, a nervous disquiet in your manner. These peculiarities were not formerly yours.
children.prevalue: Not only have you lost sleep appetite and flesh proceeded Moore but your spirits are always at ebb Besides there is a nervous alarm in your eye a nervous disquiet in your manner These peculiarities were not formerly yours

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Mr. Moore, we will pause here. You have exactly hit it. I am nervous. Now, talk of something else. What wet weather we have    steady, pouring rain!
children.prevalue: Mr Moore we will pause here You have exactly hit it I am nervous Now talk of something else What wet weather we have steady pouring rain

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: You   nervous? Yes; and if Miss Keeldar is nervous, it is not without a cause. Let me reach it. Let me look nearer. The ailment is not physical. I have suspected that. It came in one moment. I know the day. I noticed the change. Your pain is mental.
children.prevalue: You nervous Yes and if Miss Keeldar is nervous it is not without a cause Let me reach it Let me look nearer The ailment is not physical I have suspected that It came in one moment I know the day I noticed the change Your pain is mental

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Not at all. It is nothing so dignified    merely nervous. Oh! dismiss the topic.
children.prevalue: Not at all It is nothing so dignified merely nervous Oh dismiss the topic

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: When it is exhausted; not till then. Nervous alarms should always be communicated, that they may be dissipated. I wish I had the gift of persuasion, and could incline you to speak willingly. I believe confession, in your case, would be half equivalent to cure.
children.prevalue: When it is exhausted not till then Nervous alarms should always be communicated that they may be dissipated I wish I had the gift of persuasion and could incline you to speak willingly I believe confession in your case would be half equivalent to cure

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: No, said Shirley abruptly. I wish that were at all probable; but I am afraid it is not.
children.prevalue: No said Shirley abruptly I wish that were at all probable but I am afraid it is not

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: She suspended her work a moment. She was now seated. Resting her elbow on the table, she leaned her head on her hand. Mr. Moore looked as if he felt he had at last gained some footing in this difficult path. She was serious, and in her wish was implied an important admission; after that she could no longer affirm that   nothing   ailed her.
children.prevalue: She suspended her work a moment She was now seated Resting her elbow on the table she leaned her head on her hand Mr Moore looked as if he felt he had at last gained some footing in this difficult path She was serious and in her wish was implied an important admission after that she could no longer affirm that nothing ailed her

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: The tutor allowed her some minutes for repose and reflection ere he returned to the charge. Once his lips moved to speak, but he thought better of it, and prolonged the pause. Shirley lifted her eye to his. Had he betrayed injudicious emotion, perhaps obstinate persistence in silence would have been the result; but he looked calm, strong, trustworthy.
children.prevalue: The tutor allowed her some minutes for repose and reflection ere he returned to the charge Once his lips moved to speak but he thought better of it and prolonged the pause Shirley lifted her eye to his Had he betrayed injudicious emotion perhaps obstinate persistence in silence would have been the result but he looked calm strong trustworthy

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: I had better tell   you   than my aunt, she said, or than my cousins, or my uncle. They would all make such a bustle, and it is that very bustle I dread    the alarm, the flurry, the   clat  . In short, I never liked to be the centre of a small domestic whirlpool. You can bear a little shock    eh?
children.prevalue: I had better tell you than my aunt she said or than my cousins or my uncle They would all make such a bustle and it is that very bustle I dread the alarm the flurry the clat In short I never liked to be the centre of a small domestic whirlpool You can bear a little shock eh

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: A great one, if necessary.
children.prevalue: A great one if necessary

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Not a muscle of the man's frame moved, and yet his large heart beat fast in his deep chest. What was she going to tell him? Was irremediable mischief done?
children.prevalue: Not a muscle of the man s frame moved and yet his large heart beat fast in his deep chest What was she going to tell him Was irremediable mischief done

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Had I thought it right to go to you, I would never have made a secret of the matter one moment, she continued. I would have told you at once, and asked advice.
children.prevalue: Had I thought it right to go to you I would never have made a secret of the matter one moment she continued I would have told you at once and asked advice

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Why was it not right to come to me?
children.prevalue: Why was it not right to come to me

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: It might be   right      I do not mean that; but I could not do it. I seemed to have no title to trouble you. The mishap concerned me only. I wanted to keep it to myself, and people will not let me. I tell you, I hate to be an object of worrying attention, or a theme for village gossip. Besides, it may pass away without result    God knows!
children.prevalue: It might be right I do not mean that but I could not do it I seemed to have no title to trouble you The mishap concerned me only I wanted to keep it to myself and people will not let me I tell you I hate to be an object of worrying attention or a theme for village gossip Besides it may pass away without result God knows

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Moore, though tortured with suspense, did not demand a quick explanation. He suffered neither gesture, glance, nor word to betray impatience. His tranquillity tranquillized Shirley; his confidence reassured her.
children.prevalue: Moore though tortured with suspense did not demand a quick explanation He suffered neither gesture glance nor word to betray impatience His tranquillity tranquillized Shirley his confidence reassured her

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: Great effects may spring from trivial causes, she remarked, as she loosened a bracelet from her wrist. Then, unfastening her sleeve, and partially turning it up, Look here, Mr. Moore.
children.prevalue: Great effects may spring from trivial causes she remarked as she loosened a bracelet from her wrist Then unfastening her sleeve and partially turning it up Look here Mr Moore

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: She showed a mark in her white arm    rather a deep though healed  up indentation    something between a burn and a cut.
children.prevalue: She showed a mark in her white arm rather a deep though healed up indentation something between a burn and a cut

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: I would not show that to any one in Briarfield but you, because you can take it quietly.
children.prevalue: I would not show that to any one in Briarfield but you because you can take it quietly

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Certainly there is nothing in the little mark to shock. Its history will explain.
children.prevalue: Certainly there is nothing in the little mark to shock Its history will explain

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Small as it is, it has taken my sleep away, and made me nervous, thin, and foolish; because, on account of that little mark, I am obliged to look forward to a possibility that has its terrors.
children.prevalue: Small as it is it has taken my sleep away and made me nervous thin and foolish because on account of that little mark I am obliged to look forward to a possibility that has its terrors

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: The sleeve was readjusted, the bracelet replaced.
children.prevalue: The sleeve was readjusted the bracelet replaced

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Do you know that you try me? he said, smiling. I am a patient sort of man, but my pulse is quickening.
children.prevalue: Do you know that you try me he said smiling I am a patient sort of man but my pulse is quickening

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Whatever happens, you will befriend me, Mr. Moore? You will give me the benefit of your self  possession, and not leave me at the mercy of agitated cowards?
children.prevalue: Whatever happens you will befriend me Mr Moore You will give me the benefit of your self possession and not leave me at the mercy of agitated cowards

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: I make no promise now. Tell me the tale, and then exact what pledge you will.
children.prevalue: I make no promise now Tell me the tale and then exact what pledge you will

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: It is a very short tale. I took a walk with Isabella and Gertrude one day, about three weeks ago. They reached home before me; I stayed behind to speak to John. After leaving him, I pleased myself with lingering in the lane, where all was very still and shady. I was tired of chattering to the girls, and in no hurry to rejoin them. As I stood leaning against the gate  pillar, thinking some very happy thoughts about my future life    for that morning I imagined that events were beginning to turn as I had long wished them to turn
children.prevalue: It is a very short tale I took a walk with Isabella and Gertrude one day about three weeks ago They reached home before me I stayed behind to speak to John After leaving him I pleased myself with lingering in the lane where all was very still and shady I was tired of chattering to the girls and in no hurry to rejoin them As I stood leaning against the gate pillar thinking some very happy thoughts about my future life for that morning I imagined that events were beginning to turn as I had long wished them to turn

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Ah! Nunnely had been with her the evening before! thought Moore parenthetically.
children.prevalue: Ah Nunnely had been with her the evening before thought Moore parenthetically

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: I heard a panting sound; a dog came running up the lane. I know most of the dogs in this neighbourhood. It was Phbe, one of Mr. Sam Wynne's pointers. The poor creature ran with her head down, her tongue hanging out; she looked as if bruised and beaten all over. I called her. I meant to coax her into the house and give her some water and dinner. I felt sure she had been ill  used. Mr. Sam often flogs his pointers cruelly. She was too flurried to know me; and when I attempted to pat her head, she turned and snatched at my arm. She bit it so as to draw blood, then ran panting on. Directly after, Mr. Wynne's keeper came up, carrying a gun. He asked if I had seen a dog. I told him I had seen Phbe.

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: 'You had better chain up Tartar, ma'am,' he said, 'and tell your people to keep within the house. I am after Phbe to shoot her, and the groom is gone another way. She is raging mad.'
children.prevalue: You had better chain up Tartar ma am he said and tell your people to keep within the house I am after Phbe to shoot her and the groom is gone another way She is raging mad

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Mr. Moore leaned back in his chair and folded his arms across his chest. Miss Keeldar resumed her square of silk canvas, and continued the creation of a wreath of Parmese violets.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore leaned back in his chair and folded his arms across his chest Miss Keeldar resumed her square of silk canvas and continued the creation of a wreath of Parmese violets

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: And you told no one, sought no help, no cure? You would not come to me?
children.prevalue: And you told no one sought no help no cure You would not come to me

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: I got as far as the schoolroom door; there my courage failed. I preferred to cushion the matter.
children.prevalue: I got as far as the schoolroom door there my courage failed I preferred to cushion the matter

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: Why? What can I demand better in this world than to be of use to you?
children.prevalue: Why What can I demand better in this world than to be of use to you

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: I had no claim.
children.prevalue: I had no claim

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: Monstrous! And you did nothing?
children.prevalue: Monstrous And you did nothing

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: Yes. I walked straight into the laundry, where they are ironing most of the week, now that I have so many guests in the house. While the maid was busy crimping or starching, I took an Italian iron from the fire, and applied the light scarlet glowing tip to my arm. I bored it well in. It cauterized the little wound. Then I went upstairs.
