children.name: Paragraph_221
children.value: The intruder paused in her unconscious presence, and said, Miss Keeldar.
children.prevalue: The intruder paused in her unconscious presence and said Miss Keeldar

children.name: Paragraph_222
children.value: Perhaps his voice harmonized with some dream into which she was passing. It did not startle, it hardly roused her. Without opening her eyes, she but turned her head a little, so that her cheek and profile, before hidden by her arm, became visible. She looked rosy, happy, half smiling, but her eyelashes were wet. She had wept in slumber; or perhaps, before dropping asleep, a few natural tears had fallen after she had heard that epithet. No man    no woman    is always strong, always able to bear up against the unjust opinion, the vilifying word. Calumny, even from the mouth of a fool, will sometimes cut into unguarded feelings. Shirley looked like a child that had been naughty and punished, but was now forgiven and at rest.
children.prevalue: Perhaps his voice harmonized with some dream into which she was passing It did not startle it hardly roused her Without opening her eyes she but turned her head a little so that her cheek and profile before hidden by her arm became visible She looked rosy happy half smiling but her eyelashes were wet She had wept in slumber or perhaps before dropping asleep a few natural tears had fallen after she had heard that epithet No man no woman is always strong always able to bear up against the unjust opinion the vilifying word Calumny even from the mouth of a fool will sometimes cut into unguarded feelings Shirley looked like a child that had been naughty and punished but was now forgiven and at rest

children.name: Paragraph_223
children.value: Miss Keeldar, again said the voice. This time it woke her. She looked up, and saw at her side Louis Moore    not close at her side, but standing, with arrested step, two or three yards from her.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar again said the voice This time it woke her She looked up and saw at her side Louis Moore not close at her side but standing with arrested step two or three yards from her

children.name: Paragraph_224
children.value: O Mr. Moore! she said. I was afraid it was my uncle again: he and I have quarrelled.
children.prevalue: O Mr Moore she said I was afraid it was my uncle again he and I have quarrelled

children.name: Paragraph_225
children.value: Mr. Sympson should let you alone, was the reply. Can he not see that you are as yet far from strong?
children.prevalue: Mr Sympson should let you alone was the reply Can he not see that you are as yet far from strong

children.name: Paragraph_226
children.value: I assure you he did not find me weak. I did not cry when he was here.
children.prevalue: I assure you he did not find me weak I did not cry when he was here

children.name: Paragraph_227
children.value: He is about to evacuate Fieldhead    so he says. He is now giving orders to his family. He has been in the schoolroom issuing commands in a manner which, I suppose, was a continuation of that with which he has harassed you.
children.prevalue: He is about to evacuate Fieldhead so he says He is now giving orders to his family He has been in the schoolroom issuing commands in a manner which I suppose was a continuation of that with which he has harassed you

children.name: Paragraph_228
children.value: Are you and Henry to go?
children.prevalue: Are you and Henry to go

children.name: Paragraph_229
children.value: I believe, as far as Henry is concerned, that was the tenor of his scarcely intelligible directions; but he may change all to  morrow. He is just in that mood when you cannot depend on his consistency for two consecutive hours. I doubt whether he will leave you for weeks yet. To myself he addressed some words which will require a little attention and comment by  and  by, when I have time to bestow on them. At the moment he came in I was busied with a note I had got from Mr. Yorke    so fully busied that I cut short the interview with him somewhat abruptly. I left him raving. Here is the note. I wish you to see it. It refers to my brother Robert. And he looked at Shirley.
children.prevalue: I believe as far as Henry is concerned that was the tenor of his scarcely intelligible directions but he may change all to morrow He is just in that mood when you cannot depend on his consistency for two consecutive hours I doubt whether he will leave you for weeks yet To myself he addressed some words which will require a little attention and comment by and by when I have time to bestow on them At the moment he came in I was busied with a note I had got from Mr Yorke so fully busied that I cut short the interview with him somewhat abruptly I left him raving Here is the note I wish you to see it It refers to my brother Robert And he looked at Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_230
children.value: I shall be glad to hear news of him. Is he coming home?
children.prevalue: I shall be glad to hear news of him Is he coming home

children.name: Paragraph_231
children.value: He is come. He is in Yorkshire. Mr. Yorke went yesterday to Stilbro' to meet him.
children.prevalue: He is come He is in Yorkshire Mr Yorke went yesterday to Stilbro to meet him

children.name: Paragraph_232
children.value: Mr. Moore, something is wrong
children.prevalue: Mr Moore something is wrong

children.name: Paragraph_233
children.value: Did my voice tremble? He is now at Briarmains, and I am going to see him.
children.prevalue: Did my voice tremble He is now at Briarmains and I am going to see him

children.name: Paragraph_234
children.value: What has occurred?
children.prevalue: What has occurred

children.name: Paragraph_235
children.value: If you turn so pale I shall be sorry I have spoken. It might have been worse. Robert is not dead, but much hurt.
children.prevalue: If you turn so pale I shall be sorry I have spoken It might have been worse Robert is not dead but much hurt

children.name: Paragraph_236
children.value: O sir, it is you who are pale. Sit down near me.
children.prevalue: O sir it is you who are pale Sit down near me

children.name: Paragraph_237
children.value: Read the note. Let me open it.
children.prevalue: Read the note Let me open it

children.name: Paragraph_238
children.value: Miss Keeldar read the note. It briefly signified that last night Robert Moore had been shot at from behind the wall of Milldean plantation, at the foot of the Brow; that he was wounded severely, but it was hoped not fatally. Of the assassin, or assassins, nothing was known; they had escaped. No doubt, Mr. Yorke observed, it was done in revenge. It was a pity ill  will had ever been raised; but that could not be helped now.
children.prevalue: Miss Keeldar read the note It briefly signified that last night Robert Moore had been shot at from behind the wall of Milldean plantation at the foot of the Brow that he was wounded severely but it was hoped not fatally Of the assassin or assassins nothing was known they had escaped No doubt Mr Yorke observed it was done in revenge It was a pity ill will had ever been raised but that could not be helped now

children.name: Paragraph_239
children.value: He is my only brother, said Louis, as Shirley returned the note. I cannot hear unmoved that ruffians have laid in wait for him, and shot him down, like some wild beast from behind a wall.
children.prevalue: He is my only brother said Louis as Shirley returned the note I cannot hear unmoved that ruffians have laid in wait for him and shot him down like some wild beast from behind a wall

children.name: Paragraph_240
children.value: Be comforted; be hopeful. He will get better    I know he will.
children.prevalue: Be comforted be hopeful He will get better I know he will

children.name: Paragraph_241
children.value: Shirley, solicitous to soothe, held her hand over Mr. Moore's as it lay on the arm of the chair. She just touched it lightly, scarce palpably.
children.prevalue: Shirley solicitous to soothe held her hand over Mr Moore s as it lay on the arm of the chair She just touched it lightly scarce palpably

children.name: Paragraph_242
children.value: Well, give me your hand, he said. It will be for the first time; it is in a moment of calamity. Give it me.
children.prevalue: Well give me your hand he said It will be for the first time it is in a moment of calamity Give it me

children.name: Paragraph_243
children.value: Awaiting neither consent nor refusal, he took what he asked.
children.prevalue: Awaiting neither consent nor refusal he took what he asked

children.name: Paragraph_244
children.value: I am going to Briarmains now, he went on. I want you to step over to the rectory and tell Caroline Helstone what has happened. Will you do this? She will hear it best from you.
children.prevalue: I am going to Briarmains now he went on I want you to step over to the rectory and tell Caroline Helstone what has happened Will you do this She will hear it best from you

children.name: Paragraph_245
children.value: Immediately, said Shirley, with docile promptitude. Ought I to say that there is no danger?
children.prevalue: Immediately said Shirley with docile promptitude Ought I to say that there is no danger

children.name: Paragraph_246
children.value: Say so.
children.prevalue: Say so

children.name: Paragraph_247
children.value: You will come back soon, and let me know more?
children.prevalue: You will come back soon and let me know more

children.name: Paragraph_248
children.value: I will either come or write.
children.prevalue: I will either come or write

children.name: Paragraph_249
children.value: Trust me for watching over Caroline. I will communicate with your sister too; but doubtless she is already with Robert?
children.prevalue: Trust me for watching over Caroline I will communicate with your sister too but doubtless she is already with Robert

children.name: Paragraph_250
children.value: Doubtless, or will be soon. Good  morning now.
children.prevalue: Doubtless or will be soon Good morning now

children.name: Paragraph_251
children.value: You will bear up, come what may.
children.prevalue: You will bear up come what may

children.name: Paragraph_252
children.value: We shall see that.
children.prevalue: We shall see that

children.name: Paragraph_253
children.value: Shirley's fingers were obliged to withdraw from the tutor's. Louis was obliged to relinquish that hand folded, clasped, hidden in his own.
children.prevalue: Shirley s fingers were obliged to withdraw from the tutor s Louis was obliged to relinquish that hand folded clasped hidden in his own

children.name: Paragraph_254
children.value: I thought I should have had to support her, he said, as he walked towards Briarmains, and it is she who has made me strong. That look of pity, that gentle touch! No down was ever softer, no elixir more potent! It lay like a snowflake; it thrilled like lightning. A thousand times I have longed to possess that hand    to have it in mine. I   have   possessed it; for five minutes I held it. Her fingers and mine can never be strangers more. Having met once they must meet again.
children.prevalue: I thought I should have had to support her he said as he walked towards Briarmains and it is she who has made me strong That look of pity that gentle touch No down was ever softer no elixir more potent It lay like a snowflake it thrilled like lightning A thousand times I have longed to possess that hand to have it in mine I have possessed it for five minutes I held it Her fingers and mine can never be strangers more Having met once they must meet again

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Briarmains being nearer than the Hollow, Mr. Yorke had conveyed his young comrade there. He had seen him laid in the best bed of the house, as carefully as if he had been one of his own sons. The sight of his blood, welling from the treacherously inflicted wound, made him indeed the son of the Yorkshire gentleman's heart. The spectacle of the sudden event, of the tall, straight shape prostrated in its pride across the road, of the fine southern head laid low in the dust, of that youth in prime flung at once before him pallid, lifeless, helpless    this was the very combination of circumstances to win for the victim Mr. Yorke's liveliest interest.
children.prevalue: Briarmains being nearer than the Hollow Mr Yorke had conveyed his young comrade there He had seen him laid in the best bed of the house as carefully as if he had been one of his own sons The sight of his blood welling from the treacherously inflicted wound made him indeed the son of the Yorkshire gentleman s heart The spectacle of the sudden event of the tall straight shape prostrated in its pride across the road of the fine southern head laid low in the dust of that youth in prime flung at once before him pallid lifeless helpless this was the very combination of circumstances to win for the victim Mr Yorke s liveliest interest

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: No other hand was there to raise    to aid, no other voice to question kindly, no other brain to concert measures; he had to do it all himself. This utter dependence of the speechless, bleeding youth (as a youth he regarded him) on his benevolence secured that benevolence most effectually. Well did Mr. Yorke like to have power, and to use it. He had now between his hands power over a fellow  creature's life. It suited him.
children.prevalue: No other hand was there to raise to aid no other voice to question kindly no other brain to concert measures he had to do it all himself This utter dependence of the speechless bleeding youth as a youth he regarded him on his benevolence secured that benevolence most effectually Well did Mr Yorke like to have power and to use it He had now between his hands power over a fellow creature s life It suited him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: No less perfectly did it suit his saturnine better half. The incident was quite in her way and to her taste. Some women would have been terror  struck to see a gory man brought in over their threshold, and laid down in their hall in the howe of the night. There, you would suppose, was subject  matter for hysterics. No. Mrs. Yorke went into hysterics when Jessie would not leave the garden to come to her knitting, or when Martin proposed starting for Australia, with a view to realize freedom and escape the tyranny of Matthew; but an attempted murder near her door    a half  murdered man in her best bed    set her straight, cheered her spirits, gave her cap the dash of a turban.
children.prevalue: No less perfectly did it suit his saturnine better half The incident was quite in her way and to her taste Some women would have been terror struck to see a gory man brought in over their threshold and laid down in their hall in the howe of the night There you would suppose was subject matter for hysterics No Mrs Yorke went into hysterics when Jessie would not leave the garden to come to her knitting or when Martin proposed starting for Australia with a view to realize freedom and escape the tyranny of Matthew but an attempted murder near her door a half murdered man in her best bed set her straight cheered her spirits gave her cap the dash of a turban

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Mrs. Yorke was just the woman who, while rendering miserable the drudging life of a simple maid  servant, would nurse like a heroine a hospital full of plague patients. She almost loved Moore. Her tough heart almost yearned towards him when she found him committed to her charge    left in her arms, as dependent on her as her youngest  born in the cradle. Had she seen a domestic or one of her daughters give him a draught of water or smooth his pillow, she would have boxed the intruder's ears. She chased Jessie and Rose from the upper realm of the house; she forbade the housemaids to set their foot in it.
children.prevalue: Mrs Yorke was just the woman who while rendering miserable the drudging life of a simple maid servant would nurse like a heroine a hospital full of plague patients She almost loved Moore Her tough heart almost yearned towards him when she found him committed to her charge left in her arms as dependent on her as her youngest born in the cradle Had she seen a domestic or one of her daughters give him a draught of water or smooth his pillow she would have boxed the intruder s ears She chased Jessie and Rose from the upper realm of the house she forbade the housemaids to set their foot in it

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Now, if the accident had happened at the rectory gates, and old Helstone had taken in the martyr, neither Yorke nor his wife would have pitied him. They would have adjudged him right served for his tyranny and meddling. As it was, he became, for the present, the apple of their eye.
children.prevalue: Now if the accident had happened at the rectory gates and old Helstone had taken in the martyr neither Yorke nor his wife would have pitied him They would have adjudged him right served for his tyranny and meddling As it was he became for the present the apple of their eye

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Strange! Louis Moore was permitted to come    to sit down on the edge of the bed and lean over the pillow; to hold his brother's hand, and press his pale forehead with his fraternal lips; and Mrs. Yorke bore it well. She suffered him to stay half the day there; she once suffered him to sit up all night in the chamber; she rose herself at five o'clock of a wet November morning, and with her own hands lit the kitchen fire, and made the brothers a breakfast, and served it to them herself. Majestically arrayed in a boundless flannel wrapper, a shawl, and her nightcap, she sat and watched them eat, as complacently as a hen beholds her chickens feed. Yet she gave the cook warning that day for venturing to make and carry up to Mr. Moore a basin of sago  gruel; and the housemaid lost her favour because, when Mr. Louis was departing, she brought him his surtout aired from the kitchen, and, like a forward piece as she was, helped him on with it, and accepted in return a smile, a Thank you, my girl, and a shilling. Two ladies called one day, pale and anxious, and begged earnestly, humbly, to be allowed to see Mr. Moore one instant. Mrs. Yorke hardened her heart, and sent them packing    not without opprobrium.
children.prevalue: Strange Louis Moore was permitted to come to sit down on the edge of the bed and lean over the pillow to hold his brother s hand and press his pale forehead with his fraternal lips and Mrs Yorke bore it well She suffered him to stay half the day there she once suffered him to sit up all night in the chamber she rose herself at five o clock of a wet November morning and with her own hands lit the kitchen fire and made the brothers a breakfast and served it to them herself Majestically arrayed in a boundless flannel wrapper a shawl and her nightcap she sat and watched them eat as complacently as a hen beholds her chickens feed Yet she gave the cook warning that day for venturing to make and carry up to Mr Moore a basin of sago gruel and the housemaid lost her favour because when Mr Louis was departing she brought him his surtout aired from the kitchen and like a forward piece as she was helped him on with it and accepted in return a smile a Thank you my girl and a shilling Two ladies called one day pale and anxious and begged earnestly humbly to be allowed to see Mr Moore one instant Mrs Yorke hardened her heart and sent them packing not without opprobrium

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But how was it when Hortense Moore came? Not so bad as might have been expected. The whole family of the Moores really seemed to suit Mrs. Yorke so as no other family had ever suited her. Hortense and she possessed an exhaustless mutual theme of conversation in the corrupt propensities of servants. Their views of this class were similar; they watched them with the same suspicion, and judged them with the same severity. Hortense, too, from the very first showed no manner of jealousy of Mrs. Yorke's attentions to Robert    she let her keep the post of nurse with little interference; and, for herself, found ceaseless occupation in fidgeting about the house, holding the kitchen under surveillance, reporting what passed there, and, in short, making herself generally useful. Visitors they both of them agreed in excluding sedulously from the sickroom. They held the young mill  owner captive, and hardly let the air breathe or the sun shine on him.
children.prevalue: But how was it when Hortense Moore came Not so bad as might have been expected The whole family of the Moores really seemed to suit Mrs Yorke so as no other family had ever suited her Hortense and she possessed an exhaustless mutual theme of conversation in the corrupt propensities of servants Their views of this class were similar they watched them with the same suspicion and judged them with the same severity Hortense too from the very first showed no manner of jealousy of Mrs Yorke s attentions to Robert she let her keep the post of nurse with little interference and for herself found ceaseless occupation in fidgeting about the house holding the kitchen under surveillance reporting what passed there and in short making herself generally useful Visitors they both of them agreed in excluding sedulously from the sickroom They held the young mill owner captive and hardly let the air breathe or the sun shine on him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mr. MacTurk, the surgeon to whom Moore's case had been committed, pronounced his wound of a dangerous, but, he trusted, not of a hopeless character. At first he wished to place with him a nurse of his own selection; but this neither Mrs. Yorke nor Hortense would hear of. They promised faithful observance of directions. He was left, therefore, for the present in their hands.
children.prevalue: Mr MacTurk the surgeon to whom Moore s case had been committed pronounced his wound of a dangerous but he trusted not of a hopeless character At first he wished to place with him a nurse of his own selection but this neither Mrs Yorke nor Hortense would hear of They promised faithful observance of directions He was left therefore for the present in their hands

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Doubtless they executed the trust to the best of their ability; but something got wrong. The bandages were displaced or tampered with; great loss of blood followed. MacTurk, being summoned, came with steed afoam. He was one of those surgeons whom it is dangerous to vex    abrupt in his best moods, in his worst savage. On seeing Moore's state he relieved his feelings by a little flowery language, with which it is not necessary to strew the present page. A bouquet or two of the choicest blossoms fell on the unperturbed head of one Mr. Graves, a stony young assistant he usually carried about with him; with a second nosegay he gifted another young gentleman in his train    an interesting fac  simile of himself, being indeed his own son; but the full   corbeille   of blushing bloom fell to the lot of meddling womankind,   en masse  .
children.prevalue: Doubtless they executed the trust to the best of their ability but something got wrong The bandages were displaced or tampered with great loss of blood followed MacTurk being summoned came with steed afoam He was one of those surgeons whom it is dangerous to vex abrupt in his best moods in his worst savage On seeing Moore s state he relieved his feelings by a little flowery language with which it is not necessary to strew the present page A bouquet or two of the choicest blossoms fell on the unperturbed head of one Mr Graves a stony young assistant he usually carried about with him with a second nosegay he gifted another young gentleman in his train an interesting fac simile of himself being indeed his own son but the full corbeille of blushing bloom fell to the lot of meddling womankind en masse

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: For the best part of one winter night himself and satellites were busied about Moore. There at his bedside, shut up alone with him in his chamber, they wrought and wrangled over his exhausted frame. They three were on one side of the bed, and Death on the other. The conflict was sharp; it lasted till day broke, when the balance between the belligerents seemed so equal that both parties might have claimed the victory.
children.prevalue: For the best part of one winter night himself and satellites were busied about Moore There at his bedside shut up alone with him in his chamber they wrought and wrangled over his exhausted frame They three were on one side of the bed and Death on the other The conflict was sharp it lasted till day broke when the balance between the belligerents seemed so equal that both parties might have claimed the victory

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: At dawn Graves and young MacTurk were left in charge of the patient, while the senior went himself in search of additional strength, and secured it in the person of Mrs. Horsfall, the best nurse on his staff. To this woman he gave Moore in charge, with the sternest injunctions respecting the responsibility laid on her shoulders. She took this responsibility stolidly, as she did also the easy  chair at the bedhead. That moment she began her reign.
children.prevalue: At dawn Graves and young MacTurk were left in charge of the patient while the senior went himself in search of additional strength and secured it in the person of Mrs Horsfall the best nurse on his staff To this woman he gave Moore in charge with the sternest injunctions respecting the responsibility laid on her shoulders She took this responsibility stolidly as she did also the easy chair at the bedhead That moment she began her reign

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Mrs. Horsfall had one virtue    orders received from MacTurk she obeyed to the letter. The ten commandments were less binding in her eyes than her surgeon's dictum. In other respects she was no woman, but a dragon. Hortense Moore fell effaced before her; Mrs. Yorke withdrew    crushed; yet both these women were personages of some dignity in their own estimation, and of some bulk in the estimation of others. Perfectly cowed by the breadth, the height, the bone, and the brawn of Mrs. Horsfall, they retreated to the back parlour. She, for her part, sat upstairs when she liked, and downstairs when she preferred it. She took her dram three times a day, and her pipe of tobacco four times.
children.prevalue: Mrs Horsfall had one virtue orders received from MacTurk she obeyed to the letter The ten commandments were less binding in her eyes than her surgeon s dictum In other respects she was no woman but a dragon Hortense Moore fell effaced before her Mrs Yorke withdrew crushed yet both these women were personages of some dignity in their own estimation and of some bulk in the estimation of others Perfectly cowed by the breadth the height the bone and the brawn of Mrs Horsfall they retreated to the back parlour She for her part sat upstairs when she liked and downstairs when she preferred it She took her dram three times a day and her pipe of tobacco four times

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: As to Moore, no one now ventured to inquire about him. Mrs. Horsfall had him at dry  nurse. It was she who was to do for him, and the general conjecture now ran that she did for him accordingly.
children.prevalue: As to Moore no one now ventured to inquire about him Mrs Horsfall had him at dry nurse It was she who was to do for him and the general conjecture now ran that she did for him accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Morning and evening MacTurk came to see him. His case, thus complicated by a new mischance, was become one of interest in the surgeon's eyes. He regarded him as a damaged piece of clockwork, which it would be creditable to his skill to set agoing again. Graves and young MacTurk    Moore's sole other visitors    contemplated him in the light in which they were wont to contemplate the occupant for the time being of the dissecting  room at Stilbro' Infirmary.
children.prevalue: Morning and evening MacTurk came to see him His case thus complicated by a new mischance was become one of interest in the surgeon s eyes He regarded him as a damaged piece of clockwork which it would be creditable to his skill to set agoing again Graves and young MacTurk Moore s sole other visitors contemplated him in the light in which they were wont to contemplate the occupant for the time being of the dissecting room at Stilbro Infirmary

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Robert Moore had a pleasant time of it    in pain, in danger, too weak to move, almost too weak to speak, a sort of giantess his keeper, the three surgeons his sole society. Thus he lay through the diminishing days and lengthening nights of the whole drear month of November.
children.prevalue: Robert Moore had a pleasant time of it in pain in danger too weak to move almost too weak to speak a sort of giantess his keeper the three surgeons his sole society Thus he lay through the diminishing days and lengthening nights of the whole drear month of November

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: In the commencement of his captivity Moore used feebly to resist Mrs. Horsfall. He hated the sight of her rough bulk, and dreaded the contact of her hard hands; but she taught him docility in a trice. She made no account whatever of his six feet, his manly thews and sinews; she turned him in his bed as another woman would have turned a babe in its cradle. When he was good she addressed him as my dear and honey, and when he was bad she sometimes shook him. Did he attempt to speak when MacTurk was there, she lifted her hand and bade him Hush! like a nurse checking a forward child. If she had not smoked, if she had not taken gin, it would have been better, he thought; but she did both. Once, in her absence, he intimated to MacTurk that that woman was a dram  drinker.
children.prevalue: In the commencement of his captivity Moore used feebly to resist Mrs Horsfall He hated the sight of her rough bulk and dreaded the contact of her hard hands but she taught him docility in a trice She made no account whatever of his six feet his manly thews and sinews she turned him in his bed as another woman would have turned a babe in its cradle When he was good she addressed him as my dear and honey and when he was bad she sometimes shook him Did he attempt to speak when MacTurk was there she lifted her hand and bade him Hush like a nurse checking a forward child If she had not smoked if she had not taken gin it would have been better he thought but she did both Once in her absence he intimated to MacTurk that that woman was a dram drinker

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Pooh! my dear sir, they are all so, was the reply he got for his pains. But Horsfall has this virtue, added the surgeon    drunk or sober, she always remembers to obey   me  .
children.prevalue: Pooh my dear sir they are all so was the reply he got for his pains But Horsfall has this virtue added the surgeon drunk or sober she always remembers to obey me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: At length the latter autumn passed; its fogs, its rains withdrew from England their mourning and their tears; its winds swept on to sigh over lands far away. Behind November came deep winter    clearness, stillness, frost accompanying.
children.prevalue: At length the latter autumn passed its fogs its rains withdrew from England their mourning and their tears its winds swept on to sigh over lands far away Behind November came deep winter clearness stillness frost accompanying

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A calm day had settled into a crystalline evening. The world wore a North Pole colouring; all its lights and tints looked like the   reflets  [A] of white, or violet, or pale green gems. The hills wore a lilac blue; the setting sun had purple in its red; the sky was ice, all silvered azure; when the stars rose, they were of white crystal, not gold; gray, or cerulean, or faint emerald hues    cool, pure, and transparent    tinged the mass of the landscape.
children.prevalue: A calm day had settled into a crystalline evening The world wore a North Pole colouring all its lights and tints looked like the reflets A of white or violet or pale green gems The hills wore a lilac blue the setting sun had purple in its red the sky was ice all silvered azure when the stars rose they were of white crystal not gold gray or cerulean or faint emerald hues cool pure and transparent tinged the mass of the landscape

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: [A] Find me an English word as good, reader, and I will gladly         dispense with the French word. Reflections won't do.
children.prevalue: A Find me an English word as good reader and I will gladly dispense with the French word Reflections won t do

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What is this by itself in a wood no longer green, no longer even russet, a wood neutral tint    this dark blue moving object? Why, it is a schoolboy    a Briarfield grammar  school boy    who has left his companions, now trudging home by the highroad, and is seeking a certain tree, with a certain mossy mound at its root, convenient as a seat. Why is he lingering here? The air is cold and the time wears late. He sits down. What is he thinking about? Does he feel the chaste charm Nature wears to  night? A pearl  white moon smiles through the gray trees; does he care for her smile?
children.prevalue: What is this by itself in a wood no longer green no longer even russet a wood neutral tint this dark blue moving object Why it is a schoolboy a Briarfield grammar school boy who has left his companions now trudging home by the highroad and is seeking a certain tree with a certain mossy mound at its root convenient as a seat Why is he lingering here The air is cold and the time wears late He sits down What is he thinking about Does he feel the chaste charm Nature wears to night A pearl white moon smiles through the gray trees does he care for her smile

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Impossible to say; for he is silent, and his countenance does not speak. As yet it is no mirror to reflect sensation, but rather a mask to conceal it. This boy is a stripling of fifteen    slight, and tall of his years. In his face there is as little of amenity as of servility, his eye seems prepared to note any incipient attempt to control or overreach him, and the rest of his features indicate faculties alert for resistance. Wise ushers avoid unnecessary interference with that lad. To break him in by severity would be a useless attempt; to win him by flattery would be an effort worse than useless. He is best let alone. Time will educate and experience train him.
children.prevalue: Impossible to say for he is silent and his countenance does not speak As yet it is no mirror to reflect sensation but rather a mask to conceal it This boy is a stripling of fifteen slight and tall of his years In his face there is as little of amenity as of servility his eye seems prepared to note any incipient attempt to control or overreach him and the rest of his features indicate faculties alert for resistance Wise ushers avoid unnecessary interference with that lad To break him in by severity would be a useless attempt to win him by flattery would be an effort worse than useless He is best let alone Time will educate and experience train him

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Professedly Martin Yorke (it is a young Yorke, of course) tramples on the name of poetry. Talk sentiment to him, and you would be answered by sarcasm. Here he is, wandering alone, waiting duteously on Nature, while she unfolds a page of stern, of silent, and of solemn poetry beneath his attentive gaze.
children.prevalue: Professedly Martin Yorke it is a young Yorke of course tramples on the name of poetry Talk sentiment to him and you would be answered by sarcasm Here he is wandering alone waiting duteously on Nature while she unfolds a page of stern of silent and of solemn poetry beneath his attentive gaze

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Being seated, he takes from his satchel a book    not the Latin grammar, but a contraband volume of fairy tales. There will be light enough yet for an hour to serve his keen young vision. Besides, the moon waits on him; her beam, dim and vague as yet, fills the glade where he sits.
children.prevalue: Being seated he takes from his satchel a book not the Latin grammar but a contraband volume of fairy tales There will be light enough yet for an hour to serve his keen young vision Besides the moon waits on him her beam dim and vague as yet fills the glade where he sits

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: He reads. He is led into a solitary mountain region; all round him is rude and desolate, shapeless, and almost colourless. He hears bells tinkle on the wind. Forth  riding from the formless folds of the mist dawns on him the brightest vision    a green  robed lady, on a snow  white palfrey. He sees her dress, her gems, and her steed. She arrests him with some mysterious question. He is spell  bound, and must follow her into fairyland.
children.prevalue: He reads He is led into a solitary mountain region all round him is rude and desolate shapeless and almost colourless He hears bells tinkle on the wind Forth riding from the formless folds of the mist dawns on him the brightest vision a green robed lady on a snow white palfrey He sees her dress her gems and her steed She arrests him with some mysterious question He is spell bound and must follow her into fairyland

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A second legend bears him to the sea  shore. There tumbles in a strong tide, boiling at the base of dizzy cliffs. It rains and blows. A reef of rocks, black and rough, stretches far into the sea. All along, and among, and above these crags dash and flash, sweep and leap, swells, wreaths, drifts of snowy spray. Some lone wanderer is out on these rocks, treading with cautious step the wet, wild seaweed; glancing down into hollows where the brine lies fathoms deep and emerald clear, and seeing there wilder and stranger and huger vegetation than is found on land, with treasure of shells    some green, some purple, some pearly    clustered in the curls of the snaky plants. He hears a cry. Looking up and forward, he sees, at the bleak point of the reef, a tall, pale thing    shaped like man, but made of spray    transparent, tremulous, awful. It stands not alone. They are all human figures that wanton in the rocks    a crowd of foam  women    a band of white, evanescent Nereids.
children.prevalue: A second legend bears him to the sea shore There tumbles in a strong tide boiling at the base of dizzy cliffs It rains and blows A reef of rocks black and rough stretches far into the sea All along and among and above these crags dash and flash sweep and leap swells wreaths drifts of snowy spray Some lone wanderer is out on these rocks treading with cautious step the wet wild seaweed glancing down into hollows where the brine lies fathoms deep and emerald clear and seeing there wilder and stranger and huger vegetation than is found on land with treasure of shells some green some purple some pearly clustered in the curls of the snaky plants He hears a cry Looking up and forward he sees at the bleak point of the reef a tall pale thing shaped like man but made of spray transparent tremulous awful It stands not alone They are all human figures that wanton in the rocks a crowd of foam women a band of white evanescent Nereids

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Hush! Shut the book; hide it in the satchel. Martin hears a tread. He listens. No    yes. Once more the dead leaves, lightly crushed, rustle on the wood path. Martin watches; the trees part, and a woman issues forth.
children.prevalue: Hush Shut the book hide it in the satchel Martin hears a tread He listens No yes Once more the dead leaves lightly crushed rustle on the wood path Martin watches the trees part and a woman issues forth

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: She is a lady dressed in dark silk, a veil covering her face. Martin never met a lady in this wood before    nor any female, save, now and then, a village girl come to gather nuts. To  night the apparition does not displease him. He observes, as she approaches, that she is neither old nor plain, but, on the contrary, very youthful; and, but that he now recognizes her for one whom he has often wilfully pronounced ugly, he would deem that he discovered traits of beauty behind the thin gauze of that veil.
children.prevalue: She is a lady dressed in dark silk a veil covering her face Martin never met a lady in this wood before nor any female save now and then a village girl come to gather nuts To night the apparition does not displease him He observes as she approaches that she is neither old nor plain but on the contrary very youthful and but that he now recognizes her for one whom he has often wilfully pronounced ugly he would deem that he discovered traits of beauty behind the thin gauze of that veil

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: She passes him and says nothing. He knew she would. All women are proud monkeys, and he knows no more conceited doll than that Caroline Helstone. The thought is hardly hatched in his mind when the lady retraces those two steps she had got beyond him, and raising her veil, reposes her glance on his face, while she softly asks, Are you one of Mr. Yorke's sons?
children.prevalue: She passes him and says nothing He knew she would All women are proud monkeys and he knows no more conceited doll than that Caroline Helstone The thought is hardly hatched in his mind when the lady retraces those two steps she had got beyond him and raising her veil reposes her glance on his face while she softly asks Are you one of Mr Yorke s sons

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: No human evidence would ever have been able to persuade Martin Yorke that he blushed when thus addressed; yet blush he did, to the ears.
children.prevalue: No human evidence would ever have been able to persuade Martin Yorke that he blushed when thus addressed yet blush he did to the ears

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I am, he said bluntly, and encouraged himself to wonder, superciliously, what would come next.
children.prevalue: I am he said bluntly and encouraged himself to wonder superciliously what would come next

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You are Martin, I think? was the observation that followed.
children.prevalue: You are Martin I think was the observation that followed

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It could not have been more felicitous. It was a simple sentence    very artlessly, a little timidly, pronounced; but it chimed in harmony to the youth's nature. It stilled him like a note of music.
children.prevalue: It could not have been more felicitous It was a simple sentence very artlessly a little timidly pronounced but it chimed in harmony to the youth s nature It stilled him like a note of music

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Martin had a keen sense of his personality; he felt it right and sensible that the girl should discriminate him from his brothers. Like his father, he hated ceremony. It was acceptable to hear a lady address him as Martin, and not Mr. Martin or Master Martin, which form would have lost her his good graces for ever. Worse, if possible, than ceremony was the other extreme of slipshod familiarity. The slight tone of bashfulness, the scarcely perceptible hesitation, was considered perfectly in place.
children.prevalue: Martin had a keen sense of his personality he felt it right and sensible that the girl should discriminate him from his brothers Like his father he hated ceremony It was acceptable to hear a lady address him as Martin and not Mr Martin or Master Martin which form would have lost her his good graces for ever Worse if possible than ceremony was the other extreme of slipshod familiarity The slight tone of bashfulness the scarcely perceptible hesitation was considered perfectly in place

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I am Martin, he said.
children.prevalue: I am Martin he said

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Are your father and mother well? (it was lucky she did not say   papa   and   mamma  ; that would have undone all); and Rose and Jessie?
children.prevalue: Are your father and mother well it was lucky she did not say papa and mamma that would have undone all and Rose and Jessie

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I suppose so.
children.prevalue: I suppose so

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: My cousin Hortense is still at Briarmains?
children.prevalue: My cousin Hortense is still at Briarmains

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Oh yes.
children.prevalue: Oh yes

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Martin gave a comic half  smile and demi  groan. The half  smile was responded to by the lady, who could guess in what sort of odour Hortense was likely to be held by the young Yorkes.
children.prevalue: Martin gave a comic half smile and demi groan The half smile was responded to by the lady who could guess in what sort of odour Hortense was likely to be held by the young Yorkes

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Does your mother like her?
children.prevalue: Does your mother like her

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: They suit so well about the servants they can't help liking each other.
children.prevalue: They suit so well about the servants they can t help liking each other

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: It is cold to  night.
children.prevalue: It is cold to night

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Why are you out so late?
children.prevalue: Why are you out so late

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I lost my way in this wood.
children.prevalue: I lost my way in this wood

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Now, indeed, Martin allowed himself a refreshing laugh of scorn.
children.prevalue: Now indeed Martin allowed himself a refreshing laugh of scorn

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Lost your way in the mighty forest of Briarmains! You deserve never more to find it.
children.prevalue: Lost your way in the mighty forest of Briarmains You deserve never more to find it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I never was here before, and I believe I am trespassing now. You might inform against me if you chose, Martin, and have me fined. It is your father's wood.
children.prevalue: I never was here before and I believe I am trespassing now You might inform against me if you chose Martin and have me fined It is your father s wood

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I should think I knew that. But since you are so simple as to lose your way, I will guide you out.
children.prevalue: I should think I knew that But since you are so simple as to lose your way I will guide you out

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You need not. I have got into the track now. I shall be right. Martin (a little quickly), how is Mr. Moore?
children.prevalue: You need not I have got into the track now I shall be right Martin a little quickly how is Mr Moore

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Martin had heard certain rumours; it struck him that it might be amusing to make an experiment.
children.prevalue: Martin had heard certain rumours it struck him that it might be amusing to make an experiment

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Going to die. Nothing can save him. All hope flung overboard!
children.prevalue: Going to die Nothing can save him All hope flung overboard

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: She put her veil aside. She looked into his eyes, and said, To die!
children.prevalue: She put her veil aside She looked into his eyes and said To die

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: To die. All along of the women, my mother and the rest. They did something about his bandages that finished everything. He would have got better but for them. I am sure they should be arrested, cribbed, tried, and brought in for Botany Bay, at the very least.
children.prevalue: To die All along of the women my mother and the rest They did something about his bandages that finished everything He would have got better but for them I am sure they should be arrested cribbed tried and brought in for Botany Bay at the very least

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The questioner, perhaps, did nor hear this judgment. She stood motionless. In two minutes, without another word, she moved forwards; no good  night, no further inquiry. This was not amusing, nor what Martin had calculated on. He expected something dramatic and demonstrative. It was hardly worth while to frighten the girl if she would not entertain him in return. He called, Miss Helstone!
children.prevalue: The questioner perhaps did nor hear this judgment She stood motionless In two minutes without another word she moved forwards no good night no further inquiry This was not amusing nor what Martin had calculated on He expected something dramatic and demonstrative It was hardly worth while to frighten the girl if she would not entertain him in return He called Miss Helstone

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: She did not hear or turn. He hastened after and overtook her.
children.prevalue: She did not hear or turn He hastened after and overtook her

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Come; are you uneasy about what I said?
children.prevalue: Come are you uneasy about what I said

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: You know nothing about death, Martin; you are too young for me to talk to concerning such a thing.
children.prevalue: You know nothing about death Martin you are too young for me to talk to concerning such a thing

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Did you believe me? It's all flummery! Moore eats like three men. They are always making sago or tapioca or something good for him. I never go into the kitchen but there is a saucepan on the fire, cooking him some dainty. I think I will play the old soldier, and be fed on the fat of the land like him.

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Martin! Martin! Here her voice trembled, and she stopped.
children.prevalue: Martin Martin Here her voice trembled and she stopped

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: It is exceedingly wrong of you, Martin. You have almost killed me.
children.prevalue: It is exceedingly wrong of you Martin You have almost killed me

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Again she stopped. She leaned against a tree, trembling, shuddering, and as pale as death.
children.prevalue: Again she stopped She leaned against a tree trembling shuddering and as pale as death

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Martin contemplated her with inexpressible curiosity. In one sense it was, as he would have expressed it, nuts to him to see this. It told him so much, and he was beginning to have a great relish for discovering secrets. In another sense it reminded him of what he had once felt when he had heard a blackbird lamenting for her nestlings, which Matthew had crushed with a stone, and that was not a pleasant feeling. Unable to find anything very appropriate to   say   in order to comfort her, he began to cast about in his mind what he could   do  . He smiled. The lad's smile gave wondrous transparency to his physiognomy.

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Eureka! he cried. I'll set all straight by  and  by. You are better now, Miss Caroline. Walk forward, he urged.
children.prevalue: Eureka he cried I ll set all straight by and by You are better now Miss Caroline Walk forward he urged

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Not reflecting that it would be more difficult for Miss Helstone than for himself to climb a wall or penetrate a hedge, he piloted her by a short cut which led to no gate. The consequence was he had to help her over some formidable obstacles, and while he railed at her for helplessness, he perfectly liked to feel himself of use.
children.prevalue: Not reflecting that it would be more difficult for Miss Helstone than for himself to climb a wall or penetrate a hedge he piloted her by a short cut which led to no gate The consequence was he had to help her over some formidable obstacles and while he railed at her for helplessness he perfectly liked to feel himself of use

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Martin, before we separate, assure me seriously, and on your word of honour, that Mr. Moore is better.
children.prevalue: Martin before we separate assure me seriously and on your word of honour that Mr Moore is better

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: How very much you think of that Moore!
children.prevalue: How very much you think of that Moore

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: No    but    many of his friends may ask me, and I wish to be able to give an authentic answer.
children.prevalue: No but many of his friends may ask me and I wish to be able to give an authentic answer

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You may tell them he is well enough, only idle. You may tell them that he takes mutton chops for dinner, and the best of arrowroot for supper. I intercepted a basin myself one night on its way upstairs, and ate half of it.
children.prevalue: You may tell them he is well enough only idle You may tell them that he takes mutton chops for dinner and the best of arrowroot for supper I intercepted a basin myself one night on its way upstairs and ate half of it

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And who waits on him, Martin? who nurses him?
children.prevalue: And who waits on him Martin who nurses him

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Nurses him? The great baby! Why, a woman as round and big as our largest water  butt    a rough, hard  favoured old girl. I make no doubt she leads him a rich life. Nobody else is let near him. He is chiefly in the dark. It is my belief she knocks him about terribly in that chamber. I listen at the wall sometimes when I am in bed, and I think I hear her thumping him. You should see her fist. She could hold half a dozen hands like yours in her one palm. After all, notwithstanding the chops and jellies he gets, I would not be in his shoes. In fact, it is my private opinion that she eats most of what goes up on the tray to Mr. Moore. I wish she may not be starving him.

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Profound silence and meditation on Caroline's part, and a sly watchfulness on Martin's.
children.prevalue: Profound silence and meditation on Caroline s part and a sly watchfulness on Martin s

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You never see him, I suppose, Martin?
children.prevalue: You never see him I suppose Martin

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I? No. I don't care to see him, for my own part.
children.prevalue: I No I don t care to see him for my own part

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Silence again.
children.prevalue: Silence again

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Did not you come to our house once with Mrs. Pryor, about five weeks since, to ask after him? again inquired Martin.
children.prevalue: Did not you come to our house once with Mrs Pryor about five weeks since to ask after him again inquired Martin

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I dare say you wished to be shown upstairs?
children.prevalue: I dare say you wished to be shown upstairs

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: We   did   wish it. We entreated it; but your mother declined.
children.prevalue: We did wish it We entreated it but your mother declined

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Ay! she declined. I heard it all. She treated you as it is her pleasure to treat visitors now and then. She behaved to you rudely and harshly.
children.prevalue: Ay she declined I heard it all She treated you as it is her pleasure to treat visitors now and then She behaved to you rudely and harshly

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: She was not kind; for you know, Martin, we are relations, and it is natural we should take an interest in Mr. Moore. But here we must part; we are at your father's gate.
children.prevalue: She was not kind for you know Martin we are relations and it is natural we should take an interest in Mr Moore But here we must part we are at your father s gate

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Very well, what of that? I shall walk home with you.
children.prevalue: Very well what of that I shall walk home with you

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: They will miss you, and wonder where you are.
children.prevalue: They will miss you and wonder where you are

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Let them. I can take care of myself, I suppose.
children.prevalue: Let them I can take care of myself I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Martin knew that he had already incurred the penalty of a lecture, and dry bread for his tea. No matter; the evening had furnished him with an adventure. It was better than muffins and toast.
children.prevalue: Martin knew that he had already incurred the penalty of a lecture and dry bread for his tea No matter the evening had furnished him with an adventure It was better than muffins and toast

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: He walked home with Caroline. On the way he promised to see Mr. Moore, in spite of the dragon who guarded his chamber, and appointed an hour on the next day when Caroline was to come to Briarmains Wood and get tidings of him. He would meet her at a certain tree. The scheme led to nothing; still he liked it.

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Having reached home, the dry bread and the lecture were duly administered to him, and he was dismissed to bed at an early hour. He accepted his punishment with the toughest stoicism.
children.prevalue: Having reached home the dry bread and the lecture were duly administered to him and he was dismissed to bed at an early hour He accepted his punishment with the toughest stoicism

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Ere ascending to his chamber he paid a secret visit to the dining  room, a still, cold, stately apartment, seldom used, for the family customarily dined in the back parlour. He stood before the mantelpiece, and lifted his candle to two pictures hung above    female heads: one, a type of serene beauty, happy and innocent; the other, more lovely, but forlorn and desperate.

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: She looked like   that  , he said, gazing on the latter sketch, when she sobbed, turned white, and leaned against the tree.
children.prevalue: She looked like that he said gazing on the latter sketch when she sobbed turned white and leaned against the tree

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I suppose, he pursued, when he was in his room, and seated on the edge of his pallet  bed    I suppose she is what they call '  in love  '    yes,   in love   with that long thing in the next chamber. Whisht! is that Horsfall clattering him? I wonder he does not yell out. It really sounds as if she had fallen on him tooth and nail; but I suppose she is making the bed. I saw her at it once. She hit into the mattresses as if she was boxing. It is queer, Zillah (they call her Zillah)    Zillah Horsfall is a woman, and Caroline Helstone is a woman; they are two individuals of the same species    not much alike though. Is she a pretty girl, that Caroline? I suspect she is; very nice to look at    something so clear in her face, so soft in her eyes. I approve of her looking at me; it does me good. She has long eyelashes. Their shadow seems to rest where she gazes, and to instil peace and thought. If she behaves well, and continues to suit me as she has suited me to  day, I may do her a good turn. I rather relish the notion of circumventing my mother and that ogress old Horsfall. Not that I like humouring Moore; but whatever I do I'll be paid for, and in coin of my own choosing. I know what reward I will claim    one displeasing to Moore, and agreeable to myself.
