children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: He turned into bed.
children.prevalue: He turned into bed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was necessary to the arrangement of Martin's plan that he should stay at home that day. Accordingly, he found no appetite for breakfast, and just about school  time took a severe pain about his heart, which rendered it advisable that, instead of setting out to the grammar school with Mark, he should succeed to his father's arm  chair by the fireside, and also to his morning paper. This point being satisfactorily settled, and Mark being gone to Mr. Summer's class, and Matthew and Mr. Yorke withdrawn to the counting  house, three other exploits    nay, four    remained to be achieved.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to the arrangement of Martin s plan that he should stay at home that day Accordingly he found no appetite for breakfast and just about school time took a severe pain about his heart which rendered it advisable that instead of setting out to the grammar school with Mark he should succeed to his father s arm chair by the fireside and also to his morning paper This point being satisfactorily settled and Mark being gone to Mr Summer s class and Matthew and Mr Yorke withdrawn to the counting house three other exploits nay four remained to be achieved

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The first of these was to realize the breakfast he had not yet tasted, and with which his appetite of fifteen could ill afford to dispense; the second, third, fourth, to get his mother, Miss Moore, and Mrs. Horsfall successfully out of the way before four o'clock that afternoon.
children.prevalue: The first of these was to realize the breakfast he had not yet tasted and with which his appetite of fifteen could ill afford to dispense the second third fourth to get his mother Miss Moore and Mrs Horsfall successfully out of the way before four o clock that afternoon

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The first was, for the present, the most pressing, since the work before him demanded an amount of energy which the present empty condition of his youthful stomach did not seem likely to supply.
children.prevalue: The first was for the present the most pressing since the work before him demanded an amount of energy which the present empty condition of his youthful stomach did not seem likely to supply

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Martin knew the way to the larder, and knowing this way he took it. The servants were in the kitchen, breakfasting solemnly with closed doors; his mother and Miss Moore were airing themselves on the lawn, and discussing the closed doors aforesaid. Martin, safe in the larder, made fastidious selection from its stores. His breakfast had been delayed; he was determined it should be   recherch  . It appeared to him that a variety on his usual somewhat insipid fare of bread and milk was both desirable and advisable; the savoury and the salutary he thought might be combined. There was store of rosy apples laid in straw upon a shelf; he picked out three. There was pastry upon a dish; he selected an apricot puff and a damson tart. On the plain household bread his eye did not dwell; but he surveyed with favour some currant tea  cakes, and condescended to make choice of one. Thanks to his clasp  knife, he was able to appropriate a wing of fowl and a slice of ham; a cantlet of cold custard  pudding he thought would harmonize with these articles; and having made this final addition to his booty, he at length sallied forth into the hall.
children.prevalue: Martin knew the way to the larder and knowing this way he took it The servants were in the kitchen breakfasting solemnly with closed doors his mother and Miss Moore were airing themselves on the lawn and discussing the closed doors aforesaid Martin safe in the larder made fastidious selection from its stores His breakfast had been delayed he was determined it should be recherch It appeared to him that a variety on his usual somewhat insipid fare of bread and milk was both desirable and advisable the savoury and the salutary he thought might be combined There was store of rosy apples laid in straw upon a shelf he picked out three There was pastry upon a dish he selected an apricot puff and a damson tart On the plain household bread his eye did not dwell but he surveyed with favour some currant tea cakes and condescended to make choice of one Thanks to his clasp knife he was able to appropriate a wing of fowl and a slice of ham a cantlet of cold custard pudding he thought would harmonize with these articles and having made this final addition to his booty he at length sallied forth into the hall

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He was already half  way across    three steps more would have anchored him in the harbour of the back parlour    when the front door opened, and there stood Matthew. Better far had it been the Old Gentleman, in full equipage of horns, hoofs, and tail.
children.prevalue: He was already half way across three steps more would have anchored him in the harbour of the back parlour when the front door opened and there stood Matthew Better far had it been the Old Gentleman in full equipage of horns hoofs and tail

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Matthew, sceptic and scoffer, had already failed to subscribe a prompt belief in that pain about the heart. He had muttered some words, amongst which the phrase shamming Abraham had been very distinctly audible, and the succession to the armchair and newspaper had appeared to affect him with mental spasms. The spectacle now before him    the apples, the tarts, the tea  cakes, the fowl, ham, and pudding    offered evidence but too well calculated to inflate his opinion of his own sagacity.
children.prevalue: Matthew sceptic and scoffer had already failed to subscribe a prompt belief in that pain about the heart He had muttered some words amongst which the phrase shamming Abraham had been very distinctly audible and the succession to the armchair and newspaper had appeared to affect him with mental spasms The spectacle now before him the apples the tarts the tea cakes the fowl ham and pudding offered evidence but too well calculated to inflate his opinion of his own sagacity

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Martin paused   interdit   one minute, one instant; the next he knew his ground, and pronounced all well. With the true perspicacity   des mes lites  , he at once saw how this at first sight untoward event might be turned to excellent account. He saw how it might be so handled as to secure the accomplishment of his second task    namely, the disposal of his mother. He knew that a collision between him and Matthew always suggested to Mrs. Yorke the propriety of a fit of hysterics. He further knew that, on the principle of calm succeeding to storm, after a morning of hysterics his mother was sure to indulge in an afternoon of bed. This would accommodate him perfectly.
children.prevalue: Martin paused interdit one minute one instant the next he knew his ground and pronounced all well With the true perspicacity des mes lites he at once saw how this at first sight untoward event might be turned to excellent account He saw how it might be so handled as to secure the accomplishment of his second task namely the disposal of his mother He knew that a collision between him and Matthew always suggested to Mrs Yorke the propriety of a fit of hysterics He further knew that on the principle of calm succeeding to storm after a morning of hysterics his mother was sure to indulge in an afternoon of bed This would accommodate him perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The collision duly took place in the hall. A dry laugh, an insulting sneer, a contemptuous taunt, met by a nonchalant but most cutting reply, were the signals. They rushed at it. Martin, who usually made little noise on these occasions, made a great deal now. In flew the servants, Mrs. Yorke, Miss Moore. No female hand could separate them. Mr. Yorke was summoned.
children.prevalue: The collision duly took place in the hall A dry laugh an insulting sneer a contemptuous taunt met by a nonchalant but most cutting reply were the signals They rushed at it Martin who usually made little noise on these occasions made a great deal now In flew the servants Mrs Yorke Miss Moore No female hand could separate them Mr Yorke was summoned

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Sons, said he, one of you must leave my roof if this occurs again. I will have no Cain and Abel strife here.
children.prevalue: Sons said he one of you must leave my roof if this occurs again I will have no Cain and Abel strife here

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Martin now allowed himself to be taken off. He had been hurt; he was the youngest and slightest. He was quite cool, in no passion; he even smiled, content that the most difficult part of the labour he had set himself was over.
children.prevalue: Martin now allowed himself to be taken off He had been hurt he was the youngest and slightest He was quite cool in no passion he even smiled content that the most difficult part of the labour he had set himself was over

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Once he seemed to flag in the course of the morning.
children.prevalue: Once he seemed to flag in the course of the morning

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: It is not worth while to bother myself for that Caroline, he remarked. But a quarter of an hour afterwards he was again in the dining  room, looking at the head with dishevelled tresses, and eyes turbid with despair.
children.prevalue: It is not worth while to bother myself for that Caroline he remarked But a quarter of an hour afterwards he was again in the dining room looking at the head with dishevelled tresses and eyes turbid with despair

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, he said, I made her sob, shudder, almost faint. I'll see her smile before I've done with her; besides, I want to outwit all these womenites.
children.prevalue: Yes he said I made her sob shudder almost faint I ll see her smile before I ve done with her besides I want to outwit all these womenites

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Directly after dinner Mrs. Yorke fulfilled her son's calculation by withdrawing to her chamber. Now for Hortense.
children.prevalue: Directly after dinner Mrs Yorke fulfilled her son s calculation by withdrawing to her chamber Now for Hortense

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: That lady was just comfortably settled to stocking  mending in the back parlour, when Martin    laying down a book which, stretched on the sofa (he was still indisposed, according to his own account), he had been perusing in all the voluptuous ease of a yet callow pacha    lazily introduced some discourse about Sarah, the maid at the Hollow. In the course of much verbal meandering he insinuated information that this damsel was said to have three suitors    Frederic Murgatroyd, Jeremiah Pighills, and John  of  Mally's  of  Hannah's  of  Deb's; and that Miss Mann had affirmed she knew for a fact that, now the girl was left in sole charge of the cottage, she often had her swains to meals, and entertained them with the best the house afforded.
children.prevalue: That lady was just comfortably settled to stocking mending in the back parlour when Martin laying down a book which stretched on the sofa he was still indisposed according to his own account he had been perusing in all the voluptuous ease of a yet callow pacha lazily introduced some discourse about Sarah the maid at the Hollow In the course of much verbal meandering he insinuated information that this damsel was said to have three suitors Frederic Murgatroyd Jeremiah Pighills and John of Mally s of Hannah s of Deb s and that Miss Mann had affirmed she knew for a fact that now the girl was left in sole charge of the cottage she often had her swains to meals and entertained them with the best the house afforded

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It needed no more. Hortense could not have lived another hour without betaking herself to the scene of these nefarious transactions, and inspecting the state of matters in person. Mrs. Horsfall remained.
children.prevalue: It needed no more Hortense could not have lived another hour without betaking herself to the scene of these nefarious transactions and inspecting the state of matters in person Mrs Horsfall remained

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Martin, master of the field now, extracted from his mother's work  basket a bunch of keys; with these he opened the sideboard cupboard, produced thence a black bottle and a small glass, placed them on the table, nimbly mounted the stairs, made for Mr. Moore's door, tapped; the nurse opened.
children.prevalue: Martin master of the field now extracted from his mother s work basket a bunch of keys with these he opened the sideboard cupboard produced thence a black bottle and a small glass placed them on the table nimbly mounted the stairs made for Mr Moore s door tapped the nurse opened

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: If you please, ma'am, you are invited to step into the back parlour and take some refreshment. You will not be disturbed; the family are out.
children.prevalue: If you please ma am you are invited to step into the back parlour and take some refreshment You will not be disturbed the family are out

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He watched her down; he watched her in; himself shut the door. He knew she was safe.
children.prevalue: He watched her down he watched her in himself shut the door He knew she was safe

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The hard work was done; now for the pleasure. He snatched his cap, and away for the wood.
children.prevalue: The hard work was done now for the pleasure He snatched his cap and away for the wood

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It was yet but half  past three. It had been a fine morning, but the sky looked dark now. It was beginning to snow; the wind blew cold; the wood looked dismal, the old tree grim. Yet Martin approved the shadow on his path. He found a charm in the spectral aspect of the doddered oak.
children.prevalue: It was yet but half past three It had been a fine morning but the sky looked dark now It was beginning to snow the wind blew cold the wood looked dismal the old tree grim Yet Martin approved the shadow on his path He found a charm in the spectral aspect of the doddered oak

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: He had to wait. To and fro he walked, while the flakes fell faster; and the wind, which at first had but moaned, pitifully howled.
children.prevalue: He had to wait To and fro he walked while the flakes fell faster and the wind which at first had but moaned pitifully howled

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: She is long in coming, he muttered, as he glanced along the narrow track. I wonder, he subjoined, what I wish to see her so much for? She is not coming for me. But I have power over her, and I want her to come that I may use that power.
children.prevalue: She is long in coming he muttered as he glanced along the narrow track I wonder he subjoined what I wish to see her so much for She is not coming for me But I have power over her and I want her to come that I may use that power

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: He continued his walk.
children.prevalue: He continued his walk

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Now, he resumed, when a further period had elapsed, if she fails to come, I shall hate and scorn her.
children.prevalue: Now he resumed when a further period had elapsed if she fails to come I shall hate and scorn her

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It struck four. He heard the church clock far away. A step so quick, so light, that, but for the rustling of leaves, it would scarcely have sounded on the wood  walk, checked his impatience. The wind blew fiercely now, and the thickening white storm waxed bewildering; but on she came, and not dismayed.
children.prevalue: It struck four He heard the church clock far away A step so quick so light that but for the rustling of leaves it would scarcely have sounded on the wood walk checked his impatience The wind blew fiercely now and the thickening white storm waxed bewildering but on she came and not dismayed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, Martin, she said eagerly, how is he?
children.prevalue: Well Martin she said eagerly how is he

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It is queer how she thinks of   him  , reflected Martin. The blinding snow and bitter cold are nothing to her, I believe; yet she is but a 'chitty  faced creature,' as my mother would say. I could find in my heart to wish I had a cloak to wrap her in.
children.prevalue: It is queer how she thinks of him reflected Martin The blinding snow and bitter cold are nothing to her I believe yet she is but a chitty faced creature as my mother would say I could find in my heart to wish I had a cloak to wrap her in

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Thus meditating to himself, he neglected to answer Miss Helstone.
children.prevalue: Thus meditating to himself he neglected to answer Miss Helstone

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You have seen him?
children.prevalue: You have seen him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh! you promised you would.
children.prevalue: Oh you promised you would

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I mean to do better by you than that. Didn't I say   I   don't care to see him?
children.prevalue: I mean to do better by you than that Didn t I say I don t care to see him

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: But now it will be so long before I get to know any thing certain about him, and I am sick of waiting. Martin,   do   see him, and give him Caroline Helstone's regards, and say she wished to know how he was, and if anything could be done for his comfort.
children.prevalue: But now it will be so long before I get to know any thing certain about him and I am sick of waiting Martin do see him and give him Caroline Helstone s regards and say she wished to know how he was and if anything could be done for his comfort

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I won't.
children.prevalue: I won t

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You are changed. You were so friendly last night.
children.prevalue: You are changed You were so friendly last night

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Come, we must not stand in this wood; it is too cold.
children.prevalue: Come we must not stand in this wood it is too cold

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But before I go promise me to come again to  morrow with news.
children.prevalue: But before I go promise me to come again to morrow with news

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No such thing. I am much too delicate to make and keep such appointments in the winter season. If you knew what a pain I had in my chest this morning, and how I went without breakfast, and was knocked down besides, you'd feel the impropriety of bringing me here in the snow. Come, I say.
children.prevalue: No such thing I am much too delicate to make and keep such appointments in the winter season If you knew what a pain I had in my chest this morning and how I went without breakfast and was knocked down besides you d feel the impropriety of bringing me here in the snow Come I say

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Are you really delicate, Martin?
children.prevalue: Are you really delicate Martin

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Don't I look so?
children.prevalue: Don t I look so

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You have rosy cheeks.
children.prevalue: You have rosy cheeks

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: That's hectic. Will you come    or you won't?
children.prevalue: That s hectic Will you come or you won t

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Where?
children.prevalue: Where

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: With me. I was a fool not to bring a cloak. I would have made you cosy.
children.prevalue: With me I was a fool not to bring a cloak I would have made you cosy

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You are going home; my nearest road lies in the opposite direction.
children.prevalue: You are going home my nearest road lies in the opposite direction

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Put your arm through mine; I'll take care of you.
children.prevalue: Put your arm through mine I ll take care of you

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But the wall    the hedge    it is such hard work climbing, and you are too slender and young to help me without hurting yourself.
children.prevalue: But the wall the hedge it is such hard work climbing and you are too slender and young to help me without hurting yourself

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You shall go through the gate.
children.prevalue: You shall go through the gate

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But
children.prevalue: But

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: But, but    will you trust me or not?
children.prevalue: But but will you trust me or not

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: She looked into his face.
children.prevalue: She looked into his face

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I think I will. Anything rather than return as anxious as I came.
children.prevalue: I think I will Anything rather than return as anxious as I came

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I can't answer for that. This, however, I promise you: be ruled by me, and you shall see Moore yourself.
children.prevalue: I can t answer for that This however I promise you be ruled by me and you shall see Moore yourself

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: See him myself?
children.prevalue: See him myself

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yourself.
children.prevalue: Yourself

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But, dear Martin, does he know?
children.prevalue: But dear Martin does he know

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ah! I'm dear now. No, he doesn't know.
children.prevalue: Ah I m dear now No he doesn t know

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And your mother and the others?
children.prevalue: And your mother and the others

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: All is right.
children.prevalue: All is right

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Caroline fell into a long, silent fit of musing, but still she walked on with her guide. They came in sight of Briarmains.
children.prevalue: Caroline fell into a long silent fit of musing but still she walked on with her guide They came in sight of Briarmains

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Have you made up your mind? he asked.
children.prevalue: Have you made up your mind he asked

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: She was silent.
children.prevalue: She was silent

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Decide; we are just on the spot. I   won't   see him    that I tell you    except to announce your arrival.
children.prevalue: Decide we are just on the spot I won t see him that I tell you except to announce your arrival

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Martin, you are a strange boy, and this is a strange step; but all I feel   is   and   has   been, for a long time, strange. I will see him.
children.prevalue: Martin you are a strange boy and this is a strange step but all I feel is and has been for a long time strange I will see him

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Having said that, you will neither hesitate nor retract?
children.prevalue: Having said that you will neither hesitate nor retract

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Here we are, then. Do not be afraid of passing the parlour window; no one will see you. My father and Matthew are at the mill, Mark is at school, the servants are in the back kitchen, Miss Moore is at the cottage, my mother in her bed, and Mrs. Horsfall in paradise. Observe    I need not ring. I open the door; the hall is empty, the staircase quiet; so is the gallery. The whole house and all its inhabitants are under a spell, which I will not break till you are gone.
children.prevalue: Here we are then Do not be afraid of passing the parlour window no one will see you My father and Matthew are at the mill Mark is at school the servants are in the back kitchen Miss Moore is at the cottage my mother in her bed and Mrs Horsfall in paradise Observe I need not ring I open the door the hall is empty the staircase quiet so is the gallery The whole house and all its inhabitants are under a spell which I will not break till you are gone

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Martin, I trust you.
children.prevalue: Martin I trust you

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You never said a better word. Let me take your shawl. I will shake off the snow and dry it for you. You are cold and wet. Never mind; there is a fire upstairs. Are you ready?
children.prevalue: You never said a better word Let me take your shawl I will shake off the snow and dry it for you You are cold and wet Never mind there is a fire upstairs Are you ready

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Follow me.
children.prevalue: Follow me

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: He left his shoes on the mat, mounted the stair unshod. Caroline stole after, with noiseless step. There was a gallery, and there was a passage; at the end of that passage Martin paused before a door and tapped. He had to tap twice    thrice. A voice, known to one listener, at last said, Come in.
children.prevalue: He left his shoes on the mat mounted the stair unshod Caroline stole after with noiseless step There was a gallery and there was a passage at the end of that passage Martin paused before a door and tapped He had to tap twice thrice A voice known to one listener at last said Come in

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The boy entered briskly.
children.prevalue: The boy entered briskly

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Mr. Moore, a lady called to inquire after you. None of the women were about. It is washing  day, and the maids are over the crown of the head in soap  suds in the back kitchen, so I asked her to step up.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore a lady called to inquire after you None of the women were about It is washing day and the maids are over the crown of the head in soap suds in the back kitchen so I asked her to step up

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Up here, sir?
children.prevalue: Up here sir

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Up here, sir; but if you object, she shall go down again.
children.prevalue: Up here sir but if you object she shall go down again

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Is this a place or am I a person to bring a lady to, you absurd lad?
children.prevalue: Is this a place or am I a person to bring a lady to you absurd lad

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: No; so I'll take her off.
children.prevalue: No so I ll take her off

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Martin, you will stay here. Who is she?
children.prevalue: Martin you will stay here Who is she

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Your grandmother from that chteau on the Scheldt Miss Moore talks about.
children.prevalue: Your grandmother from that chteau on the Scheldt Miss Moore talks about

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Martin, said the softest whisper at the door, don't be foolish.
children.prevalue: Martin said the softest whisper at the door don t be foolish

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Is she there? inquired Moore hastily. He had caught an imperfect sound.
children.prevalue: Is she there inquired Moore hastily He had caught an imperfect sound

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: She is there, fit to faint. She is standing on the mat, shocked at your want of filial affection.
children.prevalue: She is there fit to faint She is standing on the mat shocked at your want of filial affection

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Martin, you are an evil cross between an imp and a page. What is she like?
children.prevalue: Martin you are an evil cross between an imp and a page What is she like

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: More like me than you; for she is young and beautiful.
children.prevalue: More like me than you for she is young and beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: You are to show her forward. Do you hear?
children.prevalue: You are to show her forward Do you hear

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Come, Miss Caroline.
children.prevalue: Come Miss Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Miss Caroline! repeated Moore.
children.prevalue: Miss Caroline repeated Moore

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And when Miss Caroline entered she was encountered in the middle of the chamber by a tall, thin, wasted figure, who took both her hands.
children.prevalue: And when Miss Caroline entered she was encountered in the middle of the chamber by a tall thin wasted figure who took both her hands

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I give you a quarter of an hour, said Martin, as he withdrew, no more. Say what you have to say in that time. Till it is past I will wait in the gallery; nothing shall approach; I'll see you safe away. Should you persist in staying longer, I leave you to your fate.
children.prevalue: I give you a quarter of an hour said Martin as he withdrew no more Say what you have to say in that time Till it is past I will wait in the gallery nothing shall approach I ll see you safe away Should you persist in staying longer I leave you to your fate

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: He shut the door. In the gallery he was as elate as a king. He had never been engaged in an adventure he liked so well, for no adventure had ever invested him with so much importance or inspired him with so much interest.
children.prevalue: He shut the door In the gallery he was as elate as a king He had never been engaged in an adventure he liked so well for no adventure had ever invested him with so much importance or inspired him with so much interest

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You are come at last, said the meagre man, gazing on his visitress with hollow eyes.
children.prevalue: You are come at last said the meagre man gazing on his visitress with hollow eyes

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Did you expect me before?
children.prevalue: Did you expect me before

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: For a month, near two months, we have been very near; and I have been in sad pain, and danger, and misery, Cary.
children.prevalue: For a month near two months we have been very near and I have been in sad pain and danger and misery Cary

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I could not come.
children.prevalue: I could not come

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Couldn't you? But the rectory and Briarmains are very near    not two miles apart.
children.prevalue: Couldn t you But the rectory and Briarmains are very near not two miles apart

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: There was pain and there was pleasure in the girl's face as she listened to these implied reproaches. It was sweet, it was bitter to defend herself.
children.prevalue: There was pain and there was pleasure in the girl s face as she listened to these implied reproaches It was sweet it was bitter to defend herself

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: When I say I could not come, I mean I could not see you; for I came with mamma the very day we heard what had happened. Mr. MacTurk then told us it was impossible to admit any stranger.
children.prevalue: When I say I could not come I mean I could not see you for I came with mamma the very day we heard what had happened Mr MacTurk then told us it was impossible to admit any stranger

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: But afterwards    every fine afternoon these many weeks past I have waited and listened. Something here, Cary    laying his hand on his breast    told me it was impossible but that you should think of me. Not that I merit thought; but we are old acquaintance    we are cousins.
children.prevalue: But afterwards every fine afternoon these many weeks past I have waited and listened Something here Cary laying his hand on his breast told me it was impossible but that you should think of me Not that I merit thought but we are old acquaintance we are cousins

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: I came again, Robert; mamma and I came again.
children.prevalue: I came again Robert mamma and I came again

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Did you? Come, that is worth hearing. Since you came again, we will sit down and talk about it.
children.prevalue: Did you Come that is worth hearing Since you came again we will sit down and talk about it

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: They sat down. Caroline drew her chair up to his. The air was now dark with snow; an Iceland blast was driving it wildly. This pair neither heard the long wuthering rush, nor saw the white burden it drifted. Each seemed conscious but of one thing    the presence of the other.
children.prevalue: They sat down Caroline drew her chair up to his The air was now dark with snow an Iceland blast was driving it wildly This pair neither heard the long wuthering rush nor saw the white burden it drifted Each seemed conscious but of one thing the presence of the other

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: So mamma and you came again?
children.prevalue: So mamma and you came again

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: And Mrs. Yorke did treat us strangely. We asked to see you. 'No,' said she, 'not in my house. I am at present responsible for his life; it shall not be forfeited for half an hour's idle gossip.' But I must not tell you all she said; it was very disagreeable. However, we came yet again    mamma, Miss Keeldar, and I. This time we thought we should conquer, as we were three against one, and Shirley was on our side. But Mrs. Yorke opened such a battery.
children.prevalue: And Mrs Yorke did treat us strangely We asked to see you No said she not in my house I am at present responsible for his life it shall not be forfeited for half an hour s idle gossip But I must not tell you all she said it was very disagreeable However we came yet again mamma Miss Keeldar and I This time we thought we should conquer as we were three against one and Shirley was on our side But Mrs Yorke opened such a battery

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Moore smiled. What did she say?
children.prevalue: Moore smiled What did she say

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Things that astonished us. Shirley laughed at last; I cried; mamma was seriously annoyed. We were all three driven from the field. Since that time I have only walked once a day past the house, just for the satisfaction of looking up at your window, which I could distinguish by the drawn curtains. I really dared not come in.
children.prevalue: Things that astonished us Shirley laughed at last I cried mamma was seriously annoyed We were all three driven from the field Since that time I have only walked once a day past the house just for the satisfaction of looking up at your window which I could distinguish by the drawn curtains I really dared not come in

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I   have   wished for you, Caroline.
children.prevalue: I have wished for you Caroline

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I did not know that; I never dreamt one instant that you thought of me. If I had but most distantly imagined such a possibility
children.prevalue: I did not know that I never dreamt one instant that you thought of me If I had but most distantly imagined such a possibility

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Mrs. Yorke would still have beaten you.
children.prevalue: Mrs Yorke would still have beaten you

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: She would not. Stratagem should have been tried, if persuasion failed. I would have come to the kitchen door; the servants should have let me in, and I would have walked straight upstairs. In fact, it was far more the fear of intrusion    the fear of yourself    that baffled me than the fear of Mrs. Yorke.
children.prevalue: She would not Stratagem should have been tried if persuasion failed I would have come to the kitchen door the servants should have let me in and I would have walked straight upstairs In fact it was far more the fear of intrusion the fear of yourself that baffled me than the fear of Mrs Yorke

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Only last night I despaired of ever seeing you again. Weakness has wrought terrible depression in me    terrible depression.
children.prevalue: Only last night I despaired of ever seeing you again Weakness has wrought terrible depression in me terrible depression

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: And you sit alone?
children.prevalue: And you sit alone

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Worse than alone.
children.prevalue: Worse than alone

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: But you must be getting better, since you can leave your bed?
children.prevalue: But you must be getting better since you can leave your bed

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I doubt whether I shall live. I see nothing for it, after such exhaustion, but decline.
children.prevalue: I doubt whether I shall live I see nothing for it after such exhaustion but decline

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: You    you shall go home to the Hollow.
children.prevalue: You you shall go home to the Hollow

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Dreariness would accompany, nothing cheerful come near me.
children.prevalue: Dreariness would accompany nothing cheerful come near me

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: I   will   alter this. This   shall   be altered, were there ten Mrs. Yorkes to do battle with.
children.prevalue: I will alter this This shall be altered were there ten Mrs Yorkes to do battle with

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Cary, you make me smile.
children.prevalue: Cary you make me smile

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Do smile; smile again. Shall I tell you what I should like?
children.prevalue: Do smile smile again Shall I tell you what I should like

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Tell me anything    only keep talking. I am Saul; but for music I should perish.
children.prevalue: Tell me anything only keep talking I am Saul but for music I should perish

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I should like you to be brought to the rectory, and given to me and mamma.
children.prevalue: I should like you to be brought to the rectory and given to me and mamma

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: A precious gift! I have not laughed since they shot me till now.
children.prevalue: A precious gift I have not laughed since they shot me till now

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Do you suffer pain, Robert?
children.prevalue: Do you suffer pain Robert

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Not so much pain now; but I am hopelessly weak, and the state of my mind is inexpressible    dark, barren, impotent. Do you not read it all in my face? I look a mere ghost.
children.prevalue: Not so much pain now but I am hopelessly weak and the state of my mind is inexpressible dark barren impotent Do you not read it all in my face I look a mere ghost

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Altered; yet I should have known you anywhere. But I understand your feelings; I experienced something like it. Since we met, I too have been very ill.
children.prevalue: Altered yet I should have known you anywhere But I understand your feelings I experienced something like it Since we met I too have been very ill

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Very   ill?
children.prevalue: Very ill

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: I thought I should die. The tale of my life seemed told. Every night, just at midnight, I used to wake from awful dreams; and the book lay open before me at the last page, where was written 'Finis.' I had strange feelings.
children.prevalue: I thought I should die The tale of my life seemed told Every night just at midnight I used to wake from awful dreams and the book lay open before me at the last page where was written Finis I had strange feelings

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: You speak my experience.
children.prevalue: You speak my experience

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: I believed I should never see you again; and I grew so thin    as thin as you are now. I could do nothing for myself    neither rise nor lie down; and I could not eat. Yet you see I am better.
children.prevalue: I believed I should never see you again and I grew so thin as thin as you are now I could do nothing for myself neither rise nor lie down and I could not eat Yet you see I am better

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Comforter    sad as sweet. I am too feeble to say what I feel; but while you speak I   do   feel.
children.prevalue: Comforter sad as sweet I am too feeble to say what I feel but while you speak I do feel

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Here I am at your side, where I thought never more to be. Here I speak to you. I see you listen to me willingly    look at me kindly. Did I count on that? I despaired.
children.prevalue: Here I am at your side where I thought never more to be Here I speak to you I see you listen to me willingly look at me kindly Did I count on that I despaired

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Moore sighed    a sigh so deep it was nearly a groan. He covered his eyes with his hand.
children.prevalue: Moore sighed a sigh so deep it was nearly a groan He covered his eyes with his hand

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: May I be spared to make some atonement.
children.prevalue: May I be spared to make some atonement

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Such was his prayer.
children.prevalue: Such was his prayer

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: And for what?
children.prevalue: And for what

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: We will not touch on it now, Cary; unmanned as I am, I have not the power to cope with such a topic. Was Mrs. Pryor with you during your illness?
children.prevalue: We will not touch on it now Cary unmanned as I am I have not the power to cope with such a topic Was Mrs Pryor with you during your illness

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Yes    Caroline smiled brightly    you know she is mamma?
children.prevalue: Yes Caroline smiled brightly you know she is mamma

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: I have heard    Hortense told me; but that tale too I will receive from yourself. Does she add to your happiness?
children.prevalue: I have heard Hortense told me but that tale too I will receive from yourself Does she add to your happiness

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: What! mamma? She is   dear   to me;   how   dear I cannot say. I was altogether weary, and she held me up.
children.prevalue: What mamma She is dear to me how dear I cannot say I was altogether weary and she held me up

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: I deserve to hear that in a moment when I can scarce lift my hand to my head. I deserve it.
children.prevalue: I deserve to hear that in a moment when I can scarce lift my hand to my head I deserve it

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: It is no reproach against you.
children.prevalue: It is no reproach against you

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: It is a coal of fire heaped on my head; and so is every word you address to me, and every look that lights your sweet face. Come still nearer, Lina; and give me your hand    if my thin fingers do not scare you.
children.prevalue: It is a coal of fire heaped on my head and so is every word you address to me and every look that lights your sweet face Come still nearer Lina and give me your hand if my thin fingers do not scare you

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: She took those thin fingers between her two little hands; she bent her head   et les effleura de ses lvres  . (I put that in French because the word   effleurer   is an exquisite word.) Moore was much moved. A large tear or two coursed down his hollow cheek.
children.prevalue: She took those thin fingers between her two little hands she bent her head et les effleura de ses lvres I put that in French because the word effleurer is an exquisite word Moore was much moved A large tear or two coursed down his hollow cheek

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: I'll keep these things in my heart, Cary; that kiss I will put by, and you shall hear of it again one day.
children.prevalue: I ll keep these things in my heart Cary that kiss I will put by and you shall hear of it again one day

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Come out! cried Martin, opening the door    come away; you have had twenty minutes instead of a quarter of an hour.
children.prevalue: Come out cried Martin opening the door come away you have had twenty minutes instead of a quarter of an hour

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: She will not stir yet, you hempseed.
children.prevalue: She will not stir yet you hempseed

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: I dare not stay longer, Robert.
children.prevalue: I dare not stay longer Robert

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Can you promise to return?
children.prevalue: Can you promise to return

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: No, she can't, responded Martin. The thing mustn't become customary. I can't be troubled. It's very well for once; I'll not have it repeated.
children.prevalue: No she can t responded Martin The thing mustn t become customary I can t be troubled It s very well for once I ll not have it repeated

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: You  'll not have it repeated.
children.prevalue: You ll not have it repeated

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Hush! don't vex him; we could not have met to  day but for him. But I will come again, if it is your wish that I should come.
children.prevalue: Hush don t vex him we could not have met to day but for him But I will come again if it is your wish that I should come

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: It   is   my wish    my   one   wish    almost the only wish I can feel.
children.prevalue: It is my wish my one wish almost the only wish I can feel

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Come this minute. My mother has coughed, got up, set her feet on the floor. Let her only catch you on the stairs, Miss Caroline. You're not to bid him good  bye    stepping between her and Moore    you are to march.
children.prevalue: Come this minute My mother has coughed got up set her feet on the floor Let her only catch you on the stairs Miss Caroline You re not to bid him good bye stepping between her and Moore you are to march

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: My shawl, Martin.
children.prevalue: My shawl Martin

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: I have it. I'll put it on for you when you are in the hall.
children.prevalue: I have it I ll put it on for you when you are in the hall

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: He made them part. He would suffer no farewell but what could be expressed in looks. He half carried Caroline down the stairs. In the hall he wrapped her shawl round her, and, but that his mother's tread then creaked in the gallery, and but that a sentiment of diffidence    the proper, natural, therefore the noble impulse of his boy's heart    held him back, he would have claimed his reward; he would have said, Now, Miss Caroline, for all this give me one kiss. But ere the words had passed his lips she was across the snowy road, rather skimming than wading the drifts.
children.prevalue: He made them part He would suffer no farewell but what could be expressed in looks He half carried Caroline down the stairs In the hall he wrapped her shawl round her and but that his mother s tread then creaked in the gallery and but that a sentiment of diffidence the proper natural therefore the noble impulse of his boy s heart held him back he would have claimed his reward he would have said Now Miss Caroline for all this give me one kiss But ere the words had passed his lips she was across the snowy road rather skimming than wading the drifts

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: She is my debtor, and I   will   be paid.
children.prevalue: She is my debtor and I will be paid

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: He flattered himself that it was opportunity, not audacity, which had failed him. He misjudged the quality of his own nature, and held it for something lower than it was.
children.prevalue: He flattered himself that it was opportunity not audacity which had failed him He misjudged the quality of his own nature and held it for something lower than it was

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Martin, having known the taste of excitement, wanted a second draught; having felt the dignity of power, he loathed to relinquish it. Miss Helstone    that girl he had always called ugly, and whose face was now perpetually before his eyes, by day and by night, in dark and in sunshine    had once come within his sphere. It fretted him to think the visit might never be repeated.
children.prevalue: Martin having known the taste of excitement wanted a second draught having felt the dignity of power he loathed to relinquish it Miss Helstone that girl he had always called ugly and whose face was now perpetually before his eyes by day and by night in dark and in sunshine had once come within his sphere It fretted him to think the visit might never be repeated

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Though a schoolboy he was no ordinary schoolboy; he was destined to grow up an original. At a few years' later date he took great pains to pare and polish himself down to the pattern of the rest of the world, but he never succeeded; an unique stamp marked him always. He now sat idle at his desk in the grammar school, casting about in his mind for the means of adding another chapter to his commenced romance. He did not yet know how many commenced life  romances are doomed never to get beyond the first, or at most the second chapter. His Saturday half  holiday he spent in the wood with his book of fairy legends, and that other unwritten book of his imagination.
children.prevalue: Though a schoolboy he was no ordinary schoolboy he was destined to grow up an original At a few years later date he took great pains to pare and polish himself down to the pattern of the rest of the world but he never succeeded an unique stamp marked him always He now sat idle at his desk in the grammar school casting about in his mind for the means of adding another chapter to his commenced romance He did not yet know how many commenced life romances are doomed never to get beyond the first or at most the second chapter His Saturday half holiday he spent in the wood with his book of fairy legends and that other unwritten book of his imagination

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Martin harboured an irreligious reluctance to see the approach of Sunday. His father and mother, while disclaiming community with the Establishment, failed not duly, once on the sacred day, to fill their large pew in Briarfield Church with the whole of their blooming family. Theoretically, Mr. Yorke placed all sects and churches on a level. Mrs. Yorke awarded the palm to Moravians and Quakers, on account of that crown of humility by these worthies worn. Neither of them were ever known, however, to set foot in a conventicle.
children.prevalue: Martin harboured an irreligious reluctance to see the approach of Sunday His father and mother while disclaiming community with the Establishment failed not duly once on the sacred day to fill their large pew in Briarfield Church with the whole of their blooming family Theoretically Mr Yorke placed all sects and churches on a level Mrs Yorke awarded the palm to Moravians and Quakers on account of that crown of humility by these worthies worn Neither of them were ever known however to set foot in a conventicle

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Martin, I say, disliked Sunday, because the morning service was long, and the sermon usually little to his taste. This Saturday afternoon, however, his woodland musings disclosed to him a new  found charm in the coming day.
children.prevalue: Martin I say disliked Sunday because the morning service was long and the sermon usually little to his taste This Saturday afternoon however his woodland musings disclosed to him a new found charm in the coming day

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It proved a day of deep snow    so deep that Mrs. Yorke during breakfast announced her conviction that the children, both boys and girls, would be better at home; and her decision that, instead of going to church, they should sit silent for two hours in the back parlour, while Rose and Martin alternately read a succession of sermons    John Wesley's Sermons. John Wesley, being a reformer and an agitator, had a place both in her own and her husband's favour.
children.prevalue: It proved a day of deep snow so deep that Mrs Yorke during breakfast announced her conviction that the children both boys and girls would be better at home and her decision that instead of going to church they should sit silent for two hours in the back parlour while Rose and Martin alternately read a succession of sermons John Wesley s Sermons John Wesley being a reformer and an agitator had a place both in her own and her husband s favour

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Rose will do as she pleases, said Martin, not looking up from the book which, according to his custom then and in after  life, he was studying over his bread and milk.
children.prevalue: Rose will do as she pleases said Martin not looking up from the book which according to his custom then and in after life he was studying over his bread and milk

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Rose will do as she is told, and Martin too, observed the mother.
children.prevalue: Rose will do as she is told and Martin too observed the mother

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I am going to church.
children.prevalue: I am going to church

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So her son replied, with the ineffable quietude of a true Yorke, who knows his will and means to have it, and who, if pushed to the wall, will let himself be crushed to death, provided no way of escape can be found, but will never capitulate.
children.prevalue: So her son replied with the ineffable quietude of a true Yorke who knows his will and means to have it and who if pushed to the wall will let himself be crushed to death provided no way of escape can be found but will never capitulate

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It is not fit weather, said the father.
children.prevalue: It is not fit weather said the father

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No answer. The youth read studiously; he slowly broke his bread and sipped his milk.
children.prevalue: No answer The youth read studiously he slowly broke his bread and sipped his milk

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Martin hates to go to church, but he hates still more to obey, said Mrs. Yorke.
children.prevalue: Martin hates to go to church but he hates still more to obey said Mrs Yorke

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I suppose I am influenced by pure perverseness?
children.prevalue: I suppose I am influenced by pure perverseness

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, you are.
children.prevalue: Yes you are

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Mother,   I am not  .
children.prevalue: Mother I am not

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: By what, then, are you influenced?
children.prevalue: By what then are you influenced

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: By a complication of motives, the intricacies of which I should as soon think of explaining to you as I should of turning myself inside out to exhibit the internal machinery of my frame.
children.prevalue: By a complication of motives the intricacies of which I should as soon think of explaining to you as I should of turning myself inside out to exhibit the internal machinery of my frame

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Hear Martin! hear him! cried Mr. Yorke. I must see and have this lad of mine brought up to the bar. Nature meant him to live by his tongue. Hesther, your third son must certainly be a lawyer; he has the stock  in  trade    brass, self  conceit, and words    words    words.
children.prevalue: Hear Martin hear him cried Mr Yorke I must see and have this lad of mine brought up to the bar Nature meant him to live by his tongue Hesther your third son must certainly be a lawyer he has the stock in trade brass self conceit and words words words

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Some bread, Rose, if you please, requested Martin, with intense gravity, serenity, phlegm. The boy had naturally a low, plaintive voice, which in his dour moods rose scarcely above a lady's whisper. The more inflexibly stubborn the humour, the softer, the sadder the tone. He rang the bell, and gently asked for his walking  shoes.
children.prevalue: Some bread Rose if you please requested Martin with intense gravity serenity phlegm The boy had naturally a low plaintive voice which in his dour moods rose scarcely above a lady s whisper The more inflexibly stubborn the humour the softer the sadder the tone He rang the bell and gently asked for his walking shoes

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: But, Martin, urged his sire, there is drift all the way; a man could hardly wade through it. However, lad, he continued, seeing that the boy rose as the church bell began to toll, this is a case wherein I would by no means balk the obdurate chap of his will. Go to church by all means. There is a pitiless wind, and a sharp, frozen sleet, besides the depth under foot. Go out into it, since thou prefers it to a warm fireside.
children.prevalue: But Martin urged his sire there is drift all the way a man could hardly wade through it However lad he continued seeing that the boy rose as the church bell began to toll this is a case wherein I would by no means balk the obdurate chap of his will Go to church by all means There is a pitiless wind and a sharp frozen sleet besides the depth under foot Go out into it since thou prefers it to a warm fireside

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Martin quietly assumed his cloak, comforter, and cap, and deliberately went out.
children.prevalue: Martin quietly assumed his cloak comforter and cap and deliberately went out

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: My father has more sense than my mother, he pronounced. How women miss it! They drive the nail into the flesh, thinking they are hammering away at insensate stone.
children.prevalue: My father has more sense than my mother he pronounced How women miss it They drive the nail into the flesh thinking they are hammering away at insensate stone

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: He reached church early.
children.prevalue: He reached church early

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Now, if the weather frightens her (and it is a real December tempest), or if that Mrs. Pryor objects to her going out, and I should miss her after all, it will vex me; but, tempest or tornado, hail or ice, she   ought   to come, and if she has a mind worthy of her eyes and features she   will   come. She will be here for the chance of seeing me, as I am here for the chance of seeing her. She will want to get a word respecting her confounded sweetheart, as I want to get another flavour of what I think the essence of life    a taste of existence, with the spirit preserved in it, and not evaporated. Adventure is to stagnation what champagne is to flat porter.
children.prevalue: Now if the weather frightens her and it is a real December tempest or if that Mrs Pryor objects to her going out and I should miss her after all it will vex me but tempest or tornado hail or ice she ought to come and if she has a mind worthy of her eyes and features she will come She will be here for the chance of seeing me as I am here for the chance of seeing her She will want to get a word respecting her confounded sweetheart as I want to get another flavour of what I think the essence of life a taste of existence with the spirit preserved in it and not evaporated Adventure is to stagnation what champagne is to flat porter

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: He looked round. The church was cold, silent, empty, but for one old woman. As the chimes subsided and the single bell tolled slowly, another and another elderly parishioner came dropping in, and took a humble station in the free sittings. It is always the frailest, the oldest, and the poorest that brave the worst weather, to prove and maintain their constancy to dear old mother church. This wild morning not one affluent family attended, not one carriage party appeared    all the lined and cushioned pews were empty; only on the bare oaken seats sat ranged the gray  haired elders and feeble paupers.
children.prevalue: He looked round The church was cold silent empty but for one old woman As the chimes subsided and the single bell tolled slowly another and another elderly parishioner came dropping in and took a humble station in the free sittings It is always the frailest the oldest and the poorest that brave the worst weather to prove and maintain their constancy to dear old mother church This wild morning not one affluent family attended not one carriage party appeared all the lined and cushioned pews were empty only on the bare oaken seats sat ranged the gray haired elders and feeble paupers

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I'll scorn her if she doesn't come, muttered Martin, shortly and savagely, to himself. The rector's shovel  hat had passed the porch. Mr. Helstone and his clerk were in the vestry.
children.prevalue: I ll scorn her if she doesn t come muttered Martin shortly and savagely to himself The rector s shovel hat had passed the porch Mr Helstone and his clerk were in the vestry

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The bells ceased    the reading  desk was filled    the doors were closed    the service commenced. Void stood the rectory pew    she was not there. Martin scorned her.
children.prevalue: The bells ceased the reading desk was filled the doors were closed the service commenced Void stood the rectory pew she was not there Martin scorned her

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Worthless thing! vapid thing! commonplace humbug! Like all other girls    weakly, selfish, shallow!
children.prevalue: Worthless thing vapid thing commonplace humbug Like all other girls weakly selfish shallow

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Such was Martin's liturgy.
children.prevalue: Such was Martin s liturgy

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: She is not like our picture. Her eyes are not large and expressive; her nose is not straight, delicate, Hellenic; her mouth has not that charm I thought it had, which I imagined could beguile me of sullenness in my worst moods. What is she? A thread  paper, a doll, a toy, a   girl  , in short.
children.prevalue: She is not like our picture Her eyes are not large and expressive her nose is not straight delicate Hellenic her mouth has not that charm I thought it had which I imagined could beguile me of sullenness in my worst moods What is she A thread paper a doll a toy a girl in short

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: So absorbed was the young cynic he forgot to rise from his knees at the proper place, and was still in an exemplary attitude of devotion when, the litany over, the first hymn was given out. To be so caught did not contribute to soothe him. He started up red (for he was as sensitive to ridicule as any girl). To make the matter worse, the church door had reopened, and the aisles were filling: patter, patter, patter, a hundred little feet trotted in. It was the Sunday scholars. According to Briarfield winter custom, these children had till now been kept where there was a warm stove, and only led into church just before the communion and sermon.
children.prevalue: So absorbed was the young cynic he forgot to rise from his knees at the proper place and was still in an exemplary attitude of devotion when the litany over the first hymn was given out To be so caught did not contribute to soothe him He started up red for he was as sensitive to ridicule as any girl To make the matter worse the church door had reopened and the aisles were filling patter patter patter a hundred little feet trotted in It was the Sunday scholars According to Briarfield winter custom these children had till now been kept where there was a warm stove and only led into church just before the communion and sermon

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The little ones were settled first, and at last, when the boys and the younger girls were all arranged    when the organ was swelling high, and the choir and congregation were rising to uplift a spiritual song    a tall class of young women came quietly in, closing the procession. Their teacher, having seen them seated, passed into the rectory pew. The French  gray cloak and small beaver bonnet were known to Martin; it was the very costume his eyes had ached to catch. Miss Helstone had not suffered the storm to prove an impediment. After all, she was come to church. Martin probably whispered his satisfaction to his hymn book; at any rate, he therewith hid his face two minutes.

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Satisfied or not, he had time to get very angry with her again before the sermon was over. She had never once looked his way; at least he had not been so lucky as to encounter a glance.
children.prevalue: Satisfied or not he had time to get very angry with her again before the sermon was over She had never once looked his way at least he had not been so lucky as to encounter a glance

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: If, he said    if she takes no notice of me, if she shows I am not in her thoughts, I shall have a worse, a meaner opinion of her than ever. Most despicable would it be to come for the sake of those sheep  faced Sunday scholars, and not for my sake or that long skeleton Moore's.

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The sermon found an end; the benediction was pronounced; the congregation dispersed. She had not been near him.
children.prevalue: The sermon found an end the benediction was pronounced the congregation dispersed She had not been near him

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Now, indeed, as Martin set his face homeward, he felt that the sleet was sharp and the east wind cold.
children.prevalue: Now indeed as Martin set his face homeward he felt that the sleet was sharp and the east wind cold

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: His nearest way lay through some fields. It was a dangerous, because an untrodden way. He did not care; he would take it. Near the second stile rose a clump of trees. Was that an umbrella waiting there? Yes, an umbrella, held with evident difficulty against the blast; behind it fluttered a French  gray cloak. Martin grinned as he toiled up the steep, encumbered field, difficult to the foot as a slope in the upper realms of Etna. There was an inimitable look in his face when, having gained the stile, he seated himself coolly thereupon, and thus opened a conference which, for his own part, he was willing to prolong indefinitely.

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I think you had better strike a bargain. Exchange me for Mrs. Pryor.
children.prevalue: I think you had better strike a bargain Exchange me for Mrs Pryor

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I was not sure whether you would come this way, Martin, but I thought I would run the chance. There is no such thing as getting a quiet word spoken in the church or churchyard.
children.prevalue: I was not sure whether you would come this way Martin but I thought I would run the chance There is no such thing as getting a quiet word spoken in the church or churchyard

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Will you agree?    make over Mrs. Pryor to my mother, and put me in her skirts?
children.prevalue: Will you agree make over Mrs Pryor to my mother and put me in her skirts

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: As if I could understand you! What puts Mrs. Pryor into your head?
children.prevalue: As if I could understand you What puts Mrs Pryor into your head

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You call her 'mamma,' don't you?
children.prevalue: You call her mamma don t you

children.value: She   is   my mamma.
children.prevalue: She is my mamma

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Not possible    or so inefficient, so careless a mamma; I should make a five times better one. You   may   laugh. I have no objection to see you laugh. Your teeth    I hate ugly teeth; but yours are as pretty as a pearl necklace, and a necklace of which the pearls are very fair, even, and well matched too.

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Martin, what now? I thought the Yorkes never paid compliments?
children.prevalue: Martin what now I thought the Yorkes never paid compliments

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: They have not done till this generation; but I feel as if it were my vocation to turn out a new variety of the Yorke species. I am rather tired of my own ancestors. We have traditions going back for four ages    tales of Hiram, which was the son of Hiram, which was the son of Samuel, which was the son of John, which was the son of Zerubbabel Yorke. All, from Zerubbabel down to the last Hiram, were such as you see my father. Before that there was a Godfrey. We have his picture; it hangs in Moore's bedroom; it is like me. Of his character we know nothing; but I am sure it was different to his descendants. He has long, curling dark hair; he is carefully and cavalierly dressed. Having said that he is like me, I need not add that he is handsome.

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You are not handsome, Martin.
children.prevalue: You are not handsome Martin

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: No; but wait awhile    just let me take my time. I mean to begin from this day to cultivate, to polish, and we shall see.
children.prevalue: No but wait awhile just let me take my time I mean to begin from this day to cultivate to polish and we shall see

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You are a very strange, a very unaccountable boy, Martin. But don't imagine you ever will be handsome; you cannot.
children.prevalue: You are a very strange a very unaccountable boy Martin But don t imagine you ever will be handsome you cannot

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I mean to try. But we were talking about Mrs. Pryor. She must be the most unnatural mamma in existence, coolly to let her daughter come out in this weather. Mine was in such a rage because I would go to church; she was fit to fling the kitchen brush after me.
children.prevalue: I mean to try But we were talking about Mrs Pryor She must be the most unnatural mamma in existence coolly to let her daughter come out in this weather Mine was in such a rage because I would go to church she was fit to fling the kitchen brush after me

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Mamma was very much concerned about me; but I am afraid I was obstinate. I   would   go.
children.prevalue: Mamma was very much concerned about me but I am afraid I was obstinate I would go

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: To see me?
children.prevalue: To see me

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Exactly; I thought of nothing else. I greatly feared the snow would hinder you from coming. You don't know how pleased I was to see you all by yourself in the pew.
children.prevalue: Exactly I thought of nothing else I greatly feared the snow would hinder you from coming You don t know how pleased I was to see you all by yourself in the pew

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I   came to fulfil my duty, and set the parish a good example. And so you were obstinate, were you? I should like to see you obstinate, I should. Wouldn't I have you in good discipline if I owned you? Let me take the umbrella.
children.prevalue: I came to fulfil my duty and set the parish a good example And so you were obstinate were you I should like to see you obstinate I should Wouldn t I have you in good discipline if I owned you Let me take the umbrella

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I can't stay two minutes; our dinner will be ready.
children.prevalue: I can t stay two minutes our dinner will be ready

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And so will ours; and we have always a hot dinner on Sundays. Roast goose to  day, with apple  pie and rice  pudding. I always contrive to know the bill of fare. Well, I like these things uncommonly; but I'll make the sacrifice, if you will.
children.prevalue: And so will ours and we have always a hot dinner on Sundays Roast goose to day with apple pie and rice pudding I always contrive to know the bill of fare Well I like these things uncommonly but I ll make the sacrifice if you will

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: We have a cold dinner. My uncle will allow no unnecessary cooking on the Sabbath. But I must return; the house would be in commotion if I failed to appear.
children.prevalue: We have a cold dinner My uncle will allow no unnecessary cooking on the Sabbath But I must return the house would be in commotion if I failed to appear

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: So will Briarmains, bless you! I think I hear my father sending out the overlooker and five of the dyers, to look in six directions for the body of his prodigal son in the snow; and my mother repenting her of her many misdeeds towards me, now I am gone.
children.prevalue: So will Briarmains bless you I think I hear my father sending out the overlooker and five of the dyers to look in six directions for the body of his prodigal son in the snow and my mother repenting her of her many misdeeds towards me now I am gone

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Martin, how is Mr. Moore?
children.prevalue: Martin how is Mr Moore

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: That   is what you came for, just to say that word.
children.prevalue: That is what you came for just to say that word

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Come, tell me quickly.
children.prevalue: Come tell me quickly

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Hang him! he is no worse; but as ill  used as ever    mewed up, kept in solitary confinement. They mean to make either an idiot or a maniac of him, and take out a commission of lunacy. Horsfall starves him; you saw how thin he was.
children.prevalue: Hang him he is no worse but as ill used as ever mewed up kept in solitary confinement They mean to make either an idiot or a maniac of him and take out a commission of lunacy Horsfall starves him you saw how thin he was

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You were very good the other day, Martin.
children.prevalue: You were very good the other day Martin

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What day? I am always good    a model.
children.prevalue: What day I am always good a model

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: When will you be so good again?
children.prevalue: When will you be so good again

children.value: I see what you are after; but you'll not wheedle me    I am no cat's  paw.
children.prevalue: I see what you are after but you ll not wheedle me I am no cat s paw

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But it must be done. It is quite a right thing, and a necessary thing.
children.prevalue: But it must be done It is quite a right thing and a necessary thing

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: How you encroach! Remember, I managed the matter of my own free will before.
children.prevalue: How you encroach Remember I managed the matter of my own free will before

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: And you will again.
children.prevalue: And you will again
