children.prevalue: I won t The business gave me far too much trouble I like my ease

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Mr. Moore wishes to see me, Martin, and I wish to see him.
children.prevalue: Mr Moore wishes to see me Martin and I wish to see him

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I dare say (coolly).
children.prevalue: I dare say coolly

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: It is too bad of your mother to exclude his friends.
children.prevalue: It is too bad of your mother to exclude his friends

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Tell her so.
children.prevalue: Tell her so

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: His own relations.
children.prevalue: His own relations

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Come and blow her up.
children.prevalue: Come and blow her up

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You know that would advance nothing. Well, I shall stick to my point. See him I will. If you won't help me, I'll manage without help.
children.prevalue: You know that would advance nothing Well I shall stick to my point See him I will If you won t help me I ll manage without help

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Do; there is nothing like self  reliance, self  dependence.
children.prevalue: Do there is nothing like self reliance self dependence

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I have no time to reason with you now; but I consider you provoking. Good  morning.
children.prevalue: I have no time to reason with you now but I consider you provoking Good morning

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Away she went, the umbrella shut, for she could not carry it against the wind.
children.prevalue: Away she went the umbrella shut for she could not carry it against the wind

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: She is not vapid; she is not shallow, said Martin. I shall like to watch, and mark how she will work her way without help. If the storm were not of snow, but of fire    such as came refreshingly down on the cities of the plain    she would go through it to procure five minutes' speech of that Moore. Now, I consider I have had a pleasant morning. The disappointments got time on; the fears and fits of anger only made that short discourse pleasanter, when it came at last. She expected to coax me at once. She'll not manage that in one effort. She shall come again, again, and yet again. It would please me to put her in a passion    to make her cry. I want to discover how far she will go    what she will do and dare    to get her will. It seems strange and new to find one human being thinking so much about another as she thinks about Moore. But it is time to go home; my appetite tells me the hour. Won't I walk into that goose? and we'll try whether Matthew or I shall get the largest cut of the apple  pie to  day.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Martin had planned well. He had laid out a dexterously concerted scheme for his private amusement. But older and wiser schemers than he are often doomed to see their finest  spun projects swept to annihilation by the sudden broom of Fate, that fell housewife whose red arm none can control. In the present instance this broom was manufactured out of the tough fibres of Moore's own stubborn purpose, bound tight with his will. He was now resuming his strength, and making strange head against Mrs. Horsfall. Each morning he amazed that matron with a fresh astonishment. First he discharged her from her valet duties; he would dress himself. Then he refused the coffee she brought him; he would breakfast with the family. Lastly, he forbade her his chamber. On the same day, amidst the outcries of all the women in the place, he put his head out of doors. The morning after, he followed Mr. Yorke to his counting  house, and requested an envoy to fetch a chaise from the Red House Inn. He was resolved, he said, to return home to the Hollow that very afternoon. Mr. Yorke, instead of opposing, aided and abetted him. The chaise was sent for, though Mrs. Yorke declared the step would be his death. It came. Moore, little disposed to speak, made his purse do duty for his tongue. He expressed his gratitude to the servants and to Mrs. Horsfall by the chink of his coin. The latter personage approved and understood this language perfectly; it made amends for all previous contumacy. She and her patient parted the best friends in the world.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The kitchen visited and soothed, Moore betook himself to the parlour. He had Mrs. Yorke to appease; not quite so easy a task as the pacification of her housemaids. There she sat plunged in sullen dudgeon, the gloomiest speculations on the depths of man's ingratitude absorbing her thoughts. He drew near and bent over her; she was obliged to look up, if it were only to bid him avaunt. There was beauty still in his pale, wasted features; there was earnestness and a sort of sweetness    for he was smiling    in his hollow eyes.
children.prevalue: The kitchen visited and soothed Moore betook himself to the parlour He had Mrs Yorke to appease not quite so easy a task as the pacification of her housemaids There she sat plunged in sullen dudgeon the gloomiest speculations on the depths of man s ingratitude absorbing her thoughts He drew near and bent over her she was obliged to look up if it were only to bid him avaunt There was beauty still in his pale wasted features there was earnestness and a sort of sweetness for he was smiling in his hollow eyes

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Good  bye! he said, and as he spoke the smile glittered and melted. He had no iron mastery of his sensations now; a trifling emotion made itself apparent in his present weak state.
children.prevalue: Good bye he said and as he spoke the smile glittered and melted He had no iron mastery of his sensations now a trifling emotion made itself apparent in his present weak state

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: And what are you going to leave us for? she asked. We will keep you, and do anything in the world for you, if you will only stay till you are stronger.
children.prevalue: And what are you going to leave us for she asked We will keep you and do anything in the world for you if you will only stay till you are stronger

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Good  bye! he again said; and added, You have been a mother to me; give your wilful son one embrace.
children.prevalue: Good bye he again said and added You have been a mother to me give your wilful son one embrace

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Like a foreigner, as he was, he offered her first one cheek, then the other. She kissed him.
children.prevalue: Like a foreigner as he was he offered her first one cheek then the other She kissed him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What a trouble    what a burden I have been to you! he muttered.
children.prevalue: What a trouble what a burden I have been to you he muttered

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You are the worst trouble now, headstrong youth! was the answer. I wonder who is to nurse you at Hollow's Cottage? Your sister Hortense knows no more about such matters than a child.
children.prevalue: You are the worst trouble now headstrong youth was the answer I wonder who is to nurse you at Hollow s Cottage Your sister Hortense knows no more about such matters than a child

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Thank God! for I have had nursing enough to last me my life.
children.prevalue: Thank God for I have had nursing enough to last me my life

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Here the little girls came in    Jessie crying, Rose quiet but grave. Moore took them out into the hall to soothe, pet, and kiss them. He knew it was not in their mother's nature to bear to see any living thing caressed but herself. She would have felt annoyed had he fondled a kitten in her presence.
children.prevalue: Here the little girls came in Jessie crying Rose quiet but grave Moore took them out into the hall to soothe pet and kiss them He knew it was not in their mother s nature to bear to see any living thing caressed but herself She would have felt annoyed had he fondled a kitten in her presence

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The boys were standing about the chaise as Moore entered it; but for them he had no farewell. To Mr. Yorke he only said, You have a good riddance of me. That was an unlucky shot for you, Yorke; it turned Briarmains into an hospital. Come and see me at the cottage soon.
children.prevalue: The boys were standing about the chaise as Moore entered it but for them he had no farewell To Mr Yorke he only said You have a good riddance of me That was an unlucky shot for you Yorke it turned Briarmains into an hospital Come and see me at the cottage soon

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He drew up the glass; the chaise rolled away. In half an hour he alighted at his own garden wicket. Having paid the driver and dismissed the vehicle, he leaned on that wicket an instant, at once to rest and to muse.
children.prevalue: He drew up the glass the chaise rolled away In half an hour he alighted at his own garden wicket Having paid the driver and dismissed the vehicle he leaned on that wicket an instant at once to rest and to muse

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Six months ago I passed out at this gate, said he, a proud, angry, disappointed man. I come back sadder and wiser; weakly enough, but not worried. A cold, gray, yet quiet world lies round    a world where, if I hope little, I fear nothing. All slavish terrors of embarrassment have left me. Let the worst come, I can work, as Joe Scott does, for an honourable living; in such doom I yet see some hardship but no degradation. Formerly, pecuniary ruin was equivalent in my eyes to personal dishonour. It is not so now; I know the difference. Ruin   is   an evil, but one for which I am prepared; the day of whose coming I know, for I have calculated. I can yet put it off six months    not an hour longer. If things by that time alter, which is not probable; if fetters, which now seem indissoluble, should be loosened from our trade (of all things the most unlikely to happen), I might conquer in this long struggle yet    I might    good God! what might I not do? But the thought is a brief madness; let me see things with sane eyes. Ruin will come, lay her axe to my fortune's roots, and hew them down. I shall snatch a sapling, I shall cross the sea, and plant it in American woods. Louis will go with me. Will none but Louis go? I cannot tell    I have no right to ask.

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He entered the house.
children.prevalue: He entered the house

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It was afternoon, twilight yet out of doors    starless and moonless twilight; for though keenly freezing with a dry, black frost, heaven wore a mask of clouds congealed and fast locked. The mill  dam too was frozen. The Hollow was very still. Indoors it was already dark. Sarah had lit a good fire in the parlour; she was preparing tea in the kitchen.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Hortense, said Moore, as his sister bustled up to help him off with his cloak, I am pleased to come home.
children.prevalue: Hortense said Moore as his sister bustled up to help him off with his cloak I am pleased to come home

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Hortense did not feel the peculiar novelty of this expression coming from her brother, who had never before called the cottage his home, and to whom its narrow limits had always heretofore seemed rather restrictive than protective. Still, whatever contributed to his happiness pleased her, and she expressed herself to that effect.
children.prevalue: Hortense did not feel the peculiar novelty of this expression coming from her brother who had never before called the cottage his home and to whom its narrow limits had always heretofore seemed rather restrictive than protective Still whatever contributed to his happiness pleased her and she expressed herself to that effect

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: He sat down, but soon rose again. He went to the window; he came back to the fire.
children.prevalue: He sat down but soon rose again He went to the window he came back to the fire

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Hortense!
children.prevalue: Hortense

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Mon frre?
children.prevalue: Mon frre

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: This little parlour looks very clean and pleasant    unusually bright, somehow.
children.prevalue: This little parlour looks very clean and pleasant unusually bright somehow

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It is true, brother; I have had the whole house thoroughly and scrupulously cleaned in your absence.
children.prevalue: It is true brother I have had the whole house thoroughly and scrupulously cleaned in your absence

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Sister, I think on this first day of your return home you ought to have a friend or so to tea, if it were only to see how fresh and spruce you have made the little place.
children.prevalue: Sister I think on this first day of your return home you ought to have a friend or so to tea if it were only to see how fresh and spruce you have made the little place

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: True, brother. If it were not late I might send for Miss Mann.
children.prevalue: True brother If it were not late I might send for Miss Mann

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: So you might; but it really is too late to disturb that good lady, and the evening is much too cold for her to come out.

children.value: How thoughtful in you, dear Grard! We must put it off till another day.
children.prevalue: How thoughtful in you dear Grard We must put it off till another day

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I want some one to  day, dear sister    some quiet guest, who would tire neither of us.
children.prevalue: I want some one to day dear sister some quiet guest who would tire neither of us

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Miss Ainley?
children.prevalue: Miss Ainley

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: An excellent person, they say; but she lives too far off. Tell Harry Scott to step up to the rectory with a request from you that Caroline Helstone should come and spend the evening with you.
children.prevalue: An excellent person they say but she lives too far off Tell Harry Scott to step up to the rectory with a request from you that Caroline Helstone should come and spend the evening with you

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Would it not be better to  morrow, dear brother?
children.prevalue: Would it not be better to morrow dear brother

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I should like her to see the place as it is just now; its brilliant cleanliness and perfect neatness are so much to your credit.
children.prevalue: I should like her to see the place as it is just now its brilliant cleanliness and perfect neatness are so much to your credit

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: It might benefit her in the way of example.
children.prevalue: It might benefit her in the way of example

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It might and must; she ought to come.
children.prevalue: It might and must she ought to come

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: He went into the kitchen.
children.prevalue: He went into the kitchen

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Sarah, delay tea half an hour. He then commissioned her to dispatch Harry Scott to the rectory, giving her a twisted note hastily scribbled in pencil by himself, and addressed Miss Helstone.
children.prevalue: Sarah delay tea half an hour He then commissioned her to dispatch Harry Scott to the rectory giving her a twisted note hastily scribbled in pencil by himself and addressed Miss Helstone

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Scarcely had Sarah time to get impatient under the fear of damage to her toast already prepared when the messenger returned, and with him the invited guest.
children.prevalue: Scarcely had Sarah time to get impatient under the fear of damage to her toast already prepared when the messenger returned and with him the invited guest

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: She entered through the kitchen, quietly tripped up Sarah's stairs to take off her bonnet and furs, and came down as quietly, with her beautiful curls nicely smoothed, her graceful merino dress and delicate collar all trim and spotless, her gay little work  bag in her hand. She lingered to exchange a few kindly words with Sarah, and to look at the new tortoise  shell kitten basking on the kitchen hearth, and to speak to the canary  bird, which a sudden blaze from the fire had startled on its perch; and then she betook herself to the parlour.
children.prevalue: She entered through the kitchen quietly tripped up Sarah s stairs to take off her bonnet and furs and came down as quietly with her beautiful curls nicely smoothed her graceful merino dress and delicate collar all trim and spotless her gay little work bag in her hand She lingered to exchange a few kindly words with Sarah and to look at the new tortoise shell kitten basking on the kitchen hearth and to speak to the canary bird which a sudden blaze from the fire had startled on its perch and then she betook herself to the parlour

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The gentle salutation, the friendly welcome, were interchanged in such tranquil sort as befitted cousins meeting; a sense of pleasure, subtle and quiet as a perfume, diffused itself through the room; the newly  kindled lamp burnt up bright; the tray and the singing urn were brought in.
children.prevalue: The gentle salutation the friendly welcome were interchanged in such tranquil sort as befitted cousins meeting a sense of pleasure subtle and quiet as a perfume diffused itself through the room the newly kindled lamp burnt up bright the tray and the singing urn were brought in

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I am pleased to come home, repeated Mr. Moore.
children.prevalue: I am pleased to come home repeated Mr Moore

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: They assembled round the table. Hortense chiefly talked. She congratulated Caroline on the evident improvement in her health. Her colour and her plump cheeks were returning, she remarked. It was true. There was an obvious change in Miss Helstone. All about her seemed elastic; depression, fear, forlornness, were withdrawn. No longer crushed, and saddened, and slow, and drooping, she looked like one who had tasted the cordial of heart's ease, and been lifted on the wing of hope.
children.prevalue: They assembled round the table Hortense chiefly talked She congratulated Caroline on the evident improvement in her health Her colour and her plump cheeks were returning she remarked It was true There was an obvious change in Miss Helstone All about her seemed elastic depression fear forlornness were withdrawn No longer crushed and saddened and slow and drooping she looked like one who had tasted the cordial of heart s ease and been lifted on the wing of hope

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: After tea Hortense went upstairs. She had not rummaged her drawers for a month past, and the impulse to perform that operation was now become resistless. During her absence the talk passed into Caroline's hands. She took it up with ease; she fell into her best tone of conversation. A pleasing facility and elegance of language gave fresh charm to familiar topics; a new music in the always soft voice gently surprised and pleasingly captivated the listener; unwonted shades and lights of expression elevated the young countenance with character, and kindled it with animation.
children.prevalue: After tea Hortense went upstairs She had not rummaged her drawers for a month past and the impulse to perform that operation was now become resistless During her absence the talk passed into Caroline s hands She took it up with ease she fell into her best tone of conversation A pleasing facility and elegance of language gave fresh charm to familiar topics a new music in the always soft voice gently surprised and pleasingly captivated the listener unwonted shades and lights of expression elevated the young countenance with character and kindled it with animation

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Caroline, you look as if you had heard good tidings, said Moore, after earnestly gazing at her for some minutes.
children.prevalue: Caroline you look as if you had heard good tidings said Moore after earnestly gazing at her for some minutes

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Do I?
children.prevalue: Do I

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I sent for you this evening that I might be cheered; but you cheer me more than I had calculated.
children.prevalue: I sent for you this evening that I might be cheered but you cheer me more than I had calculated

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I am glad of that. And I   really   cheer you?
children.prevalue: I am glad of that And I really cheer you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You look brightly, move buoyantly, speak musically.
children.prevalue: You look brightly move buoyantly speak musically

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is pleasant to be here again.
children.prevalue: It is pleasant to be here again

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Truly it is pleasant; I feel it so. And to see health on your cheek and hope in your eye is pleasant, Cary; but what is this hope, and what is the source of this sunshine I perceive about you?
children.prevalue: Truly it is pleasant I feel it so And to see health on your cheek and hope in your eye is pleasant Cary but what is this hope and what is the source of this sunshine I perceive about you

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: For one thing, I am happy in mamma. I love her so much, and she loves me. Long and tenderly she nursed me. Now, when her care has made me well, I can occupy myself for and with her all the day. I say it is my turn to attend to her; and I   do   attend to her. I am her waiting  woman as well as her child. I like    you would laugh if you knew what pleasure I have in making dresses and sewing for her. She looks so nice now, Robert; I will not let her be old  fashioned. And then, she is charming to talk to    full of wisdom, ripe in judgment, rich in information, exhaustless in stores her observant faculties have quietly amassed. Every day that I live with her I like her better, I esteem her more highly, I love her more tenderly.
children.prevalue: For one thing I am happy in mamma I love her so much and she loves me Long and tenderly she nursed me Now when her care has made me well I can occupy myself for and with her all the day I say it is my turn to attend to her and I do attend to her I am her waiting woman as well as her child I like you would laugh if you knew what pleasure I have in making dresses and sewing for her She looks so nice now Robert I will not let her be old fashioned And then she is charming to talk to full of wisdom ripe in judgment rich in information exhaustless in stores her observant faculties have quietly amassed Every day that I live with her I like her better I esteem her more highly I love her more tenderly

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That   for one thing, then, Cary. You talk in such a way about 'mamma' it is enough to make one jealous of the old lady.
children.prevalue: That for one thing then Cary You talk in such a way about mamma it is enough to make one jealous of the old lady

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: She is not old, Robert.
children.prevalue: She is not old Robert

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Of the young lady, then.
children.prevalue: Of the young lady then

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: She does not pretend to be young.
children.prevalue: She does not pretend to be young

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well, of the matron. But you said 'mamma's' affection was   one   thing that made you happy; now for the other thing.
children.prevalue: Well of the matron But you said mamma s affection was one thing that made you happy now for the other thing

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I am glad you are better.
children.prevalue: I am glad you are better

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: What besides?
children.prevalue: What besides

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I am glad we are friends.
children.prevalue: I am glad we are friends

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: You and I?
children.prevalue: You and I

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Yes. I once thought we never should be.
children.prevalue: Yes I once thought we never should be

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Cary, some day I mean to tell you a thing about myself that is not to my credit, and consequently will not please you.
children.prevalue: Cary some day I mean to tell you a thing about myself that is not to my credit and consequently will not please you

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Ah, don't! I cannot bear to think ill of you.
children.prevalue: Ah don t I cannot bear to think ill of you

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And I cannot bear that you should think better of me than I deserve.
children.prevalue: And I cannot bear that you should think better of me than I deserve

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Well, but I half know your 'thing;' indeed, I believe I know all about it.
children.prevalue: Well but I half know your thing indeed I believe I know all about it

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You do not.
children.prevalue: You do not

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I believe I do.
children.prevalue: I believe I do

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Whom does it concern besides me?
children.prevalue: Whom does it concern besides me

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: She coloured; she hesitated; she was silent.
children.prevalue: She coloured she hesitated she was silent

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Speak, Cary! Whom does it concern?
children.prevalue: Speak Cary Whom does it concern

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: She tried to utter a name, and could not.
children.prevalue: She tried to utter a name and could not

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Tell me; there is none present but ourselves. Be frank.
children.prevalue: Tell me there is none present but ourselves Be frank

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But if I guess wrong?
children.prevalue: But if I guess wrong

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I will forgive. Whisper, Cary.
children.prevalue: I will forgive Whisper Cary

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: He bent his ear to her lips. Still she would not, or could not, speak clearly to the point. Seeing that Moore waited and was resolved to hear something, she at last said, Miss Keeldar spent a day at the rectory about a week since. The evening came on very wintry, and we persuaded her to stay all night.

children.name: Paragraph_74

children.prevalue: And you and she curled your hair together

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: How do you know that?
children.prevalue: How do you know that

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: And then you chattered, and she told you
children.prevalue: And then you chattered and she told you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: It was not at curling  hair time, so you are not as wise as you think; and, besides, she didn't tell me.
children.prevalue: It was not at curling hair time so you are not as wise as you think and besides she didn t tell me

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You slept together afterwards?
children.prevalue: You slept together afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: We occupied the same room and bed. We did not sleep much; we talked the whole night through.
children.prevalue: We occupied the same room and bed We did not sleep much we talked the whole night through

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I'll be sworn you did! And then it all came out      tant pis  . I would rather you had heard it from myself.
children.prevalue: I ll be sworn you did And then it all came out tant pis I would rather you had heard it from myself

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You are quite wrong. She did not tell me what you suspect    she is not the person to proclaim such things; but yet I inferred something from parts of her discourse. I gathered more from rumour, and I made out the rest by instinct.
children.prevalue: You are quite wrong She did not tell me what you suspect she is not the person to proclaim such things but yet I inferred something from parts of her discourse I gathered more from rumour and I made out the rest by instinct

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: But if she did not tell you that I wanted to marry her for the sake of her money, and that she refused me indignantly and scornfully (you need neither start nor blush; nor yet need you prick your trembling fingers with your needle. That is the plain truth, whether you like it or not)    if such was not the subject of her august confidences, on what point did they turn? You say you talked the whole night through; what about?
children.prevalue: But if she did not tell you that I wanted to marry her for the sake of her money and that she refused me indignantly and scornfully you need neither start nor blush nor yet need you prick your trembling fingers with your needle That is the plain truth whether you like it or not if such was not the subject of her august confidences on what point did they turn You say you talked the whole night through what about

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: About things we never thoroughly discussed before, intimate friends as we have been; but you hardly expect I should tell you?
children.prevalue: About things we never thoroughly discussed before intimate friends as we have been but you hardly expect I should tell you

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, yes, Cary; you will tell me. You said we were friends, and friends should always confide in each other.
children.prevalue: Yes yes Cary you will tell me You said we were friends and friends should always confide in each other

children.prevalue: But you are sure you won t repeat it

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Quite sure.
children.prevalue: Quite sure

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Not to Louis?
children.prevalue: Not to Louis

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Not even to Louis. What does Louis care for young ladies' secrets?
children.prevalue: Not even to Louis What does Louis care for young ladies secrets

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Robert, Shirley is a curious, magnanimous being.
children.prevalue: Robert Shirley is a curious magnanimous being

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I dare say. I can imagine there are both odd points and grand points about her.
children.prevalue: I dare say I can imagine there are both odd points and grand points about her

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I have found her chary in showing her feelings; but when they rush out, river  like, and pass full and powerful before you    almost without leave from her    you gaze, wonder; you admire, and    I think    love her.
children.prevalue: I have found her chary in showing her feelings but when they rush out river like and pass full and powerful before you almost without leave from her you gaze wonder you admire and I think love her

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: You saw this spectacle?
children.prevalue: You saw this spectacle

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Yes; at dead of night, when all the house was silent, and starlight and the cold reflection from the snow glimmered in our chamber, then I saw Shirley's heart.
children.prevalue: Yes at dead of night when all the house was silent and starlight and the cold reflection from the snow glimmered in our chamber then I saw Shirley s heart

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Her heart's core? Do you think she showed you that?
children.prevalue: Her heart s core Do you think she showed you that

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Her heart's core.
children.prevalue: Her heart s core

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: And how was it?
children.prevalue: And how was it

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Like a shrine, for it was holy; like snow, for it was pure; like flame, for it was warm; like death, for it was strong.
children.prevalue: Like a shrine for it was holy like snow for it was pure like flame for it was warm like death for it was strong

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Can she love? tell me that.
children.prevalue: Can she love tell me that

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: What think you?
children.prevalue: What think you

children.value: She has loved none that have loved her yet.
children.prevalue: She has loved none that have loved her yet

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Who are those that have loved her?
children.prevalue: Who are those that have loved her

children.value: He named a list of gentlemen, closing with Sir Philip Nunnely.
children.prevalue: He named a list of gentlemen closing with Sir Philip Nunnely

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: She has loved none of these.
children.prevalue: She has loved none of these

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Yet some of them were worthy of a woman's affection.
children.prevalue: Yet some of them were worthy of a woman s affection

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Of some women's, but not of Shirley's.
children.prevalue: Of some women s but not of Shirley s

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Is she better than others of her sex?
children.prevalue: Is she better than others of her sex

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: She is peculiar, and more dangerous to take as a wife    rashly.
children.prevalue: She is peculiar and more dangerous to take as a wife rashly

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I can imagine that.
children.prevalue: I can imagine that

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: She spoke of you
children.prevalue: She spoke of you

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Oh, she did! I thought you denied it.
children.prevalue: Oh she did I thought you denied it

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: She did not speak in the way you fancy; but I asked her, and I would make her tell me what she thought of you, or rather how she felt towards you. I wanted to know; I had long wanted to know.
children.prevalue: She did not speak in the way you fancy but I asked her and I would make her tell me what she thought of you or rather how she felt towards you I wanted to know I had long wanted to know

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: So had I; but let us hear. She thinks meanly, she feels contemptuously, doubtless?
children.prevalue: So had I but let us hear She thinks meanly she feels contemptuously doubtless

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: She thinks of you almost as highly as a woman can think of a man. You know she can be eloquent. I yet feel in fancy the glow of the language in which her opinion was conveyed.
children.prevalue: She thinks of you almost as highly as a woman can think of a man You know she can be eloquent I yet feel in fancy the glow of the language in which her opinion was conveyed

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: But how does she feel?
children.prevalue: But how does she feel

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Till you shocked her (she said you had shocked her, but she would not tell me how) she felt as a sister feels towards a brother of whom she is at once fond and proud.
children.prevalue: Till you shocked her she said you had shocked her but she would not tell me how she felt as a sister feels towards a brother of whom she is at once fond and proud

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I'll shock her no more, Cary, for the shock rebounded on myself till I staggered again. But that comparison about sister and brother is all nonsense. She is too rich and proud to entertain fraternal sentiments for me.
children.prevalue: I ll shock her no more Cary for the shock rebounded on myself till I staggered again But that comparison about sister and brother is all nonsense She is too rich and proud to entertain fraternal sentiments for me

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: You don't know her, Robert; and, somehow, I fancy now (I had other ideas formerly) that you cannot know her. You and she are not so constructed as to be able thoroughly to understand each other.
children.prevalue: You don t know her Robert and somehow I fancy now I had other ideas formerly that you cannot know her You and she are not so constructed as to be able thoroughly to understand each other

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: It may be so. I esteem her, I admire her; and yet my impressions concerning her are harsh    perhaps uncharitable. I believe, for instance, that she is incapable of love
children.prevalue: It may be so I esteem her I admire her and yet my impressions concerning her are harsh perhaps uncharitable I believe for instance that she is incapable of love

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Shirley incapable of love!
children.prevalue: Shirley incapable of love

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: That she will never marry. I imagine her jealous of compromising her pride, of relinquishing her power, of sharing her property.
children.prevalue: That she will never marry I imagine her jealous of compromising her pride of relinquishing her power of sharing her property

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Shirley has hurt your   amour propre  .
children.prevalue: Shirley has hurt your amour propre

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: She did hurt it; though I had not an emotion of tenderness, nor a spark of passion for her.
children.prevalue: She did hurt it though I had not an emotion of tenderness nor a spark of passion for her

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Then, Robert, it was very wicked in you to want to marry her.
children.prevalue: Then Robert it was very wicked in you to want to marry her

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: And very mean, my little pastor, my pretty priestess. I never wanted to kiss Miss Keeldar in my life, though she has fine lips, scarlet and round as ripe cherries; or, if I did wish it, it was the mere desire of the eye.
children.prevalue: And very mean my little pastor my pretty priestess I never wanted to kiss Miss Keeldar in my life though she has fine lips scarlet and round as ripe cherries or if I did wish it it was the mere desire of the eye

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: I doubt, now, whether you are speaking the truth. The grapes or the cherries are sour    'hung too high.'
children.prevalue: I doubt now whether you are speaking the truth The grapes or the cherries are sour hung too high

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: She has a pretty figure, a pretty face, beautiful hair. I acknowledge all her charms and feel none of them, or only feel them in a way she would disdain. I suppose I was truly tempted by the mere gilding of the bait. Caroline, what a noble fellow your Robert is    great, good, disinterested, and then so pure!
children.prevalue: She has a pretty figure a pretty face beautiful hair I acknowledge all her charms and feel none of them or only feel them in a way she would disdain I suppose I was truly tempted by the mere gilding of the bait Caroline what a noble fellow your Robert is great good disinterested and then so pure

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: But not perfect. He made a great blunder once, and we will hear no more about it.
children.prevalue: But not perfect He made a great blunder once and we will hear no more about it

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: And shall we think no more about it, Cary? Shall we not despise him in our heart    gentle but just, compassionate but upright?
children.prevalue: And shall we think no more about it Cary Shall we not despise him in our heart gentle but just compassionate but upright

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Never! We will remember that with what measure we mete it shall be measured unto us, and so we will give no scorn, only affection.
children.prevalue: Never We will remember that with what measure we mete it shall be measured unto us and so we will give no scorn only affection

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Which won't satisfy, I warn you of that. Something besides affection    something far stronger, sweeter, warmer    will be demanded one day. Is it there to give?
children.prevalue: Which won t satisfy I warn you of that Something besides affection something far stronger sweeter warmer will be demanded one day Is it there to give

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Caroline was moved, much moved.
children.prevalue: Caroline was moved much moved

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Be calm, Lina, said Moore soothingly. I have no intention, because I have no right, to perturb your mind now, nor for months to come. Don't look as if you would leave me. We will make no more agitating allusions; we will resume our gossip. Do not tremble; look me in the face. See what a poor, pale, grim phantom I am    more pitiable than formidable.
children.prevalue: Be calm Lina said Moore soothingly I have no intention because I have no right to perturb your mind now nor for months to come Don t look as if you would leave me We will make no more agitating allusions we will resume our gossip Do not tremble look me in the face See what a poor pale grim phantom I am more pitiable than formidable

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: She looked shyly. There is something formidable still, pale as you are, she said, as her eye fell under his.
children.prevalue: She looked shyly There is something formidable still pale as you are she said as her eye fell under his

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: To return to Shirley, pursued Moore: is it your opinion that she is ever likely to marry?
children.prevalue: To return to Shirley pursued Moore is it your opinion that she is ever likely to marry

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: She loves.
children.prevalue: She loves

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Platonically    theoretically    all humbug!
children.prevalue: Platonically theoretically all humbug

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: She loves what I call sincerely.
children.prevalue: She loves what I call sincerely

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Did she say so?
children.prevalue: Did she say so

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: I cannot affirm that she said so. No such confession as 'I love this man or that' passed her lips.
children.prevalue: I cannot affirm that she said so No such confession as I love this man or that passed her lips

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: I thought not.
children.prevalue: I thought not

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: But the feeling made its way in spite of her, and I saw it. She spoke of one man in a strain not to be misunderstood. Her voice alone was sufficient testimony. Having wrung from her an opinion on your character, I demanded a second opinion of    another person about whom I had my conjectures, though they were the most tangled and puzzled conjectures in the world. I would   make   her speak. I shook her, I chid her, I pinched her fingers when she tried to put me off with gibes and jests in her queer provoking way, and at last out it came. The voice, I say, was enough; hardly raised above a whisper, and yet such a soft vehemence in its tones. There was no confession, no confidence, in the matter. To these things she cannot condescend; but I am sure that man's happiness is dear to her as her own life.
children.prevalue: But the feeling made its way in spite of her and I saw it She spoke of one man in a strain not to be misunderstood Her voice alone was sufficient testimony Having wrung from her an opinion on your character I demanded a second opinion of another person about whom I had my conjectures though they were the most tangled and puzzled conjectures in the world I would make her speak I shook her I chid her I pinched her fingers when she tried to put me off with gibes and jests in her queer provoking way and at last out it came The voice I say was enough hardly raised above a whisper and yet such a soft vehemence in its tones There was no confession no confidence in the matter To these things she cannot condescend but I am sure that man s happiness is dear to her as her own life

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Louis Moore's doubts respecting the immediate evacuation of Fieldhead by Mr. Sympson turned out to be perfectly well founded. The very next day after the grand quarrel about Sir Philip Nunnely a sort of reconciliation was patched up between uncle and niece. Shirley, who could never find it in her heart to be or to seem inhospitable (except in the single instance of Mr. Donne), begged the whole party to stay a little longer. She begged in such earnest it was evident she wished it for some reason. They took her at her word. Indeed, the uncle could not bring himself to leave her quite unwatched    at full liberty to marry Robert Moore as soon as that gentleman should be able (Mr. Sympson piously prayed this might never be the case) to reassert his supposed pretensions to her hand. They all stayed.
children.prevalue: Louis Moore s doubts respecting the immediate evacuation of Fieldhead by Mr Sympson turned out to be perfectly well founded The very next day after the grand quarrel about Sir Philip Nunnely a sort of reconciliation was patched up between uncle and niece Shirley who could never find it in her heart to be or to seem inhospitable except in the single instance of Mr Donne begged the whole party to stay a little longer She begged in such earnest it was evident she wished it for some reason They took her at her word Indeed the uncle could not bring himself to leave her quite unwatched at full liberty to marry Robert Moore as soon as that gentleman should be able Mr Sympson piously prayed this might never be the case to reassert his supposed pretensions to her hand They all stayed

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: In his first rage against all the house of Moore, Mr. Sympson had so conducted himself towards Mr. Louis that that gentleman    patient of labour or suffering, but intolerant of coarse insolence    had promptly resigned his post, and could now be induced to resume and retain it only till such time as the family should quit Yorkshire. Mrs. Sympson's entreaties prevailed with him thus far; his own attachment to his pupil constituted an additional motive for concession; and probably he had a third motive, stronger than either of the other two. Probably he would have found it very hard indeed to leave Fieldhead just now.
children.prevalue: In his first rage against all the house of Moore Mr Sympson had so conducted himself towards Mr Louis that that gentleman patient of labour or suffering but intolerant of coarse insolence had promptly resigned his post and could now be induced to resume and retain it only till such time as the family should quit Yorkshire Mrs Sympson s entreaties prevailed with him thus far his own attachment to his pupil constituted an additional motive for concession and probably he had a third motive stronger than either of the other two Probably he would have found it very hard indeed to leave Fieldhead just now

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Things went on for some time pretty smoothly. Miss Keeldar's health was re  established; her spirits resumed their flow. Moore had found means to relieve her from every nervous apprehension; and, indeed, from the moment of giving him her confidence, every fear seemed to have taken wing. Her heart became as lightsome, her manner as careless, as those of a little child, that, thoughtless of its own life or death, trusts all responsibility to its parents. He and William Farren    through whose medium he made inquiries concerning the state of Phbe    agreed in asserting that the dog was not mad, that it was only ill  usage which had driven her from home; for it was proved that her master was in the frequent habit of chastising her violently. Their assertion might or might not be true. The groom and gamekeeper affirmed to the contrary    both asserting that, if hers was not a clear case of hydrophobia, there was no such disease. But to this evidence Louis Moore turned an incredulous ear. He reported to Shirley only what was encouraging. She believed him; and, right or wrong, it is certain that in her case the bite proved innocuous.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: November passed; December came. The Sympsons were now really departing. It was incumbent on them to be at home by Christmas. Their packages were preparing; they were to leave in a few days. One winter evening, during the last week of their stay, Louis Moore again took out his little blank book, and discoursed with it as follows:

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: She is lovelier than ever. Since that little cloud was dispelled all the temporary waste and wanness have vanished. It was marvellous to see how soon the magical energy of youth raised her elastic and revived her blooming.
children.prevalue: She is lovelier than ever Since that little cloud was dispelled all the temporary waste and wanness have vanished It was marvellous to see how soon the magical energy of youth raised her elastic and revived her blooming

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: After breakfast this morning, when I had seen her, and listened to her, and, so to speak, felt her, in every sentient atom of my frame, I passed from her sunny presence into the chill drawing  room. Taking up a little gilt volume, I found it to contain a selection of lyrics. I read a poem or two; whether the spell was in me or in the verse I know not, but my heart filled genially, my pulse rose. I glowed, notwithstanding the frost air. I, too, am young as yet. Though she said she never considered me young, I am barely thirty. There are moments when life, for no other reason than my own youth, beams with sweet hues upon me.

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It was time to go to the schoolroom. I went. That same schoolroom is rather pleasant in a morning. The sun then shines through the low lattice; the books are in order; there are no papers strewn about; the fire is clear and clean; no cinders have fallen, no ashes accumulated. I found Henry there, and he had brought with him Miss Keeldar. They were together.
children.prevalue: It was time to go to the schoolroom I went That same schoolroom is rather pleasant in a morning The sun then shines through the low lattice the books are in order there are no papers strewn about the fire is clear and clean no cinders have fallen no ashes accumulated I found Henry there and he had brought with him Miss Keeldar They were together

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I said she was lovelier than ever. She is. A fine rose, not deep but delicate, opens on her cheek. Her eye, always dark, clear, and speaking, utters now a language I cannot render; it is the utterance, seen not heard, through which angels must have communed when there was 'silence in heaven.' Her hair was always dusk as night and fine as silk, her neck was always fair, flexible, polished; but both have now a new charm. The tresses are soft as shadow, the shoulders they fall on wear a goddess grace. Once I only   saw   her beauty, now I   feel   it.
children.prevalue: I said she was lovelier than ever She is A fine rose not deep but delicate opens on her cheek Her eye always dark clear and speaking utters now a language I cannot render it is the utterance seen not heard through which angels must have communed when there was silence in heaven Her hair was always dusk as night and fine as silk her neck was always fair flexible polished but both have now a new charm The tresses are soft as shadow the shoulders they fall on wear a goddess grace Once I only saw her beauty now I feel it

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Henry was repeating his lesson to her before bringing it to me. One of her hands was occupied with the book; he held the other. That boy gets more than his share of privileges; he dares caress and is caressed. What indulgence and compassion she shows him! Too much. If this went on, Henry in a few years, when his soul was formed, would offer it on her altar, as I have offered mine.
children.prevalue: Henry was repeating his lesson to her before bringing it to me One of her hands was occupied with the book he held the other That boy gets more than his share of privileges he dares caress and is caressed What indulgence and compassion she shows him Too much If this went on Henry in a few years when his soul was formed would offer it on her altar as I have offered mine

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I saw her eyelid flitter when I came in, but she did not look up;   now   she hardly ever gives me a glance. She seems to grow silent too; to   me   she rarely speaks, and when I am present, she says little to others. In my gloomy moments I attribute this change to indifference, aversion, what not? In my sunny intervals I give it another meaning. I say, were I her equal, I could find in this shyness coyness, and in that coyness love. As it is, dare I look for it? What could I do with it if found?
children.prevalue: I saw her eyelid flitter when I came in but she did not look up now she hardly ever gives me a glance She seems to grow silent too to me she rarely speaks and when I am present she says little to others In my gloomy moments I attribute this change to indifference aversion what not In my sunny intervals I give it another meaning I say were I her equal I could find in this shyness coyness and in that coyness love As it is dare I look for it What could I do with it if found

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: This morning I dared at least contrive an hour's communion for her and me; I dared not only   wish   but   will   an interview with her. I dared summon solitude to guard us. Very decidedly I called Henry to the door. Without hesitation I said, 'Go where you will, my boy; but, till I call you, return not here.'
children.prevalue: This morning I dared at least contrive an hour s communion for her and me I dared not only wish but will an interview with her I dared summon solitude to guard us Very decidedly I called Henry to the door Without hesitation I said Go where you will my boy but till I call you return not here

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Henry, I could see, did not like his dismissal. That boy is young, but a thinker; his meditative eye shines on me strangely sometimes. He half feels what links me to Shirley; he half guesses that there is a dearer delight in the reserve with which I am treated than in all the endearments he is allowed. The young, lame, half  grown lion would growl at me now and then, because I have tamed his lioness and am her keeper, did not the habit of discipline and the instinct of affection hold him subdued. Go, Henry; you must learn to take your share of the bitter of life with all of Adam's race that have gone before or will come after you. Your destiny can be no exception to the common lot; be grateful that your love is overlooked thus early, before it can claim any affinity to passion. An hour's fret, a pang of envy, suffice to express what you feel. Jealousy hot as the sun above the line, rage destructive as the tropic storm, the clime of your sensations ignores    as yet.
children.prevalue: Henry I could see did not like his dismissal That boy is young but a thinker his meditative eye shines on me strangely sometimes He half feels what links me to Shirley he half guesses that there is a dearer delight in the reserve with which I am treated than in all the endearments he is allowed The young lame half grown lion would growl at me now and then because I have tamed his lioness and am her keeper did not the habit of discipline and the instinct of affection hold him subdued Go Henry you must learn to take your share of the bitter of life with all of Adam s race that have gone before or will come after you Your destiny can be no exception to the common lot be grateful that your love is overlooked thus early before it can claim any affinity to passion An hour s fret a pang of envy suffice to express what you feel Jealousy hot as the sun above the line rage destructive as the tropic storm the clime of your sensations ignores as yet

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I took my usual seat at the desk, quite in my usual way. I am blessed in that power to cover all inward ebullition with outward calm. No one who looks at my slow face can guess the vortex sometimes whirling in my heart, and engulfing thought and wrecking prudence. Pleasant is it to have the gift to proceed peacefully and powerfully in your course without alarming by one eccentric movement. It was not my present intention to utter one word of love to her, or to reveal one glimpse of the fire in which I wasted. Presumptuous I never have been; presumptuous I never will be. Rather than even   seem   selfish and interested, I would resolutely rise, gird my loins, part and leave her, and seek, on the other side of the globe, a new life, cold and barren as the rock the salt tide daily washes. My design this morning was to take of her a near scrutiny    to read a line in the page of her heart. Before I left I determined to know   what   I was leaving.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I had some quills to make into pens. Most men's hands would have trembled when their hearts were so stirred; mine went to work steadily, and my voice, when I called it into exercise, was firm.
children.prevalue: I had some quills to make into pens Most men s hands would have trembled when their hearts were so stirred mine went to work steadily and my voice when I called it into exercise was firm

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'This day week you will be alone at Fieldhead, Miss Keeldar.'
children.prevalue: This day week you will be alone at Fieldhead Miss Keeldar

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Yes: I rather think my uncle's intention to go is a settled one now.'
children.prevalue: Yes I rather think my uncle s intention to go is a settled one now

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'He leaves you dissatisfied.'
children.prevalue: He leaves you dissatisfied

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'He is not pleased with me.'
children.prevalue: He is not pleased with me

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'He departs as he came    no better for his journey. This is mortifying.'
children.prevalue: He departs as he came no better for his journey This is mortifying

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'I trust the failure of his plans will take from him all inclination to lay new ones.'
children.prevalue: I trust the failure of his plans will take from him all inclination to lay new ones

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'In his way Mr. Sympson honestly wished you well. All he has done or intended to do he believed to be for the best.'
children.prevalue: In his way Mr Sympson honestly wished you well All he has done or intended to do he believed to be for the best

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: 'You are kind to undertake the defence of a man who has permitted himself to treat you with so much insolence.'
children.prevalue: You are kind to undertake the defence of a man who has permitted himself to treat you with so much insolence

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: 'I never feel shocked at, or bear malice for, what is spoken in character; and most perfectly in character was that vulgar and violent onset against me, when he had quitted you worsted.'
children.prevalue: I never feel shocked at or bear malice for what is spoken in character and most perfectly in character was that vulgar and violent onset against me when he had quitted you worsted

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'You cease now to be Henry's tutor?'
children.prevalue: You cease now to be Henry s tutor

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: 'I shall be parted from Henry for a while (if he and I live we shall meet again somehow, for we love each other) and be ousted from the bosom of the Sympson family for ever. Happily this change does not leave me stranded; it but hurries into premature execution designs long formed.'
children.prevalue: I shall be parted from Henry for a while if he and I live we shall meet again somehow for we love each other and be ousted from the bosom of the Sympson family for ever Happily this change does not leave me stranded it but hurries into premature execution designs long formed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'No change finds you off your guard. I was sure, in your calm way, you would be prepared for sudden mutation. I always think you stand in the world like a solitary but watchful, thoughtful archer in a wood. And the quiver on your shoulder holds more arrows than one; your bow is provided with a second string. Such too is your brother's wont. You two might go forth homeless hunters to the loneliest western wilds; all would be well with you. The hewn tree would make you a hut, the cleared forest yield you fields from its stripped bosom, the buffalo would feel your rifle  shot, and with lowered horns and hump pay homage at your feet.'
children.prevalue: No change finds you off your guard I was sure in your calm way you would be prepared for sudden mutation I always think you stand in the world like a solitary but watchful thoughtful archer in a wood And the quiver on your shoulder holds more arrows than one your bow is provided with a second string Such too is your brother s wont You two might go forth homeless hunters to the loneliest western wilds all would be well with you The hewn tree would make you a hut the cleared forest yield you fields from its stripped bosom the buffalo would feel your rifle shot and with lowered horns and hump pay homage at your feet

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'And any Indian tribe of Blackfeet or Flatheads would afford us a bride, perhaps?'
children.prevalue: And any Indian tribe of Blackfeet or Flatheads would afford us a bride perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'No' (hesitating), 'I think not. The savage is sordid. I think    that is, I   hope      you would neither of you share your hearth with that to which you could not give your heart.'
children.prevalue: No hesitating I think not The savage is sordid I think that is I hope you would neither of you share your hearth with that to which you could not give your heart

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: 'What suggested the wild West to your mind, Miss Keeldar? Have you been with me in spirit when I did not see you? Have you entered into my day  dreams, and beheld my brain labouring at its scheme of a future?'
children.prevalue: What suggested the wild West to your mind Miss Keeldar Have you been with me in spirit when I did not see you Have you entered into my day dreams and beheld my brain labouring at its scheme of a future

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: She had separated a slip of paper for lighting tapers    a spill, as it is called    into fragments. She threw morsel by morsel into the fire, and stood pensively watching them consume. She did not speak.
children.prevalue: She had separated a slip of paper for lighting tapers a spill as it is called into fragments She threw morsel by morsel into the fire and stood pensively watching them consume She did not speak

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'How did you learn what you seem to know about my intentions?'
children.prevalue: How did you learn what you seem to know about my intentions

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: 'I know nothing. I am only discovering them now. I spoke at hazard.'
children.prevalue: I know nothing I am only discovering them now I spoke at hazard

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Your hazard sounds like divination. A tutor I will never be again; never take a pupil after Henry and yourself; not again will I sit habitually at another man's table    no more be the appendage of a family. I am now a man of thirty; I have never been free since I was a boy of ten. I have such a thirst for freedom, such a deep passion to know her and call her mine, such a day  desire and night  longing to win her and possess her, I will not refuse to cross the Atlantic for her sake; her I will follow deep into virgin woods. Mine it shall not be to accept a savage girl as a slave    she could not be a wife. I know no white woman whom I love that would accompany me; but I am certain Liberty will await me, sitting under a pine. When I call her she will come to my loghouse, and she shall fill my arms.'

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: She could not hear me speak so unmoved, and she   was   moved. It was right    I meant to move her. She could not answer me, nor could she look at me. I should have been sorry if she could have done either. Her cheek glowed as if a crimson flower through whose petals the sun shone had cast its light upon it. On the white lid and dark lashes of her downcast eye trembled all that is graceful in the sense of half  painful, half  pleasing shame.
children.prevalue: She could not hear me speak so unmoved and she was moved It was right I meant to move her She could not answer me nor could she look at me I should have been sorry if she could have done either Her cheek glowed as if a crimson flower through whose petals the sun shone had cast its light upon it On the white lid and dark lashes of her downcast eye trembled all that is graceful in the sense of half painful half pleasing shame

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Soon she controlled her emotion, and took all her feelings under command. I saw she had felt insurrection, and was waking to empire. She sat down. There was that in her face which I could read. It said, I see the line which is my limit; nothing shall make me pass it. I feel    I know how far I may reveal my feelings, and when I must clasp the volume. I have advanced to a certain distance, as far as the true and sovereign and undegraded nature of my kind permits; now here I stand rooted. My heart may break if it is baffled; let it break. It shall never dishonour me; it shall never dishonour my sisterhood in me. Suffering before degradation! death before treachery!
children.prevalue: Soon she controlled her emotion and took all her feelings under command I saw she had felt insurrection and was waking to empire She sat down There was that in her face which I could read It said I see the line which is my limit nothing shall make me pass it I feel I know how far I may reveal my feelings and when I must clasp the volume I have advanced to a certain distance as far as the true and sovereign and undegraded nature of my kind permits now here I stand rooted My heart may break if it is baffled let it break It shall never dishonour me it shall never dishonour my sisterhood in me Suffering before degradation death before treachery

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I, for my part, said, 'If she were poor, I would be at her feet; if she were lowly, I would take her in my arms. Her gold and her station are two griffins that guard her on each side. Love looks and longs, and dares not; Passion hovers round, and is kept at bay; Truth and Devotion are scared. There is nothing to lose in winning her, no sacrifice to make. It is all clear gain, and therefore unimaginably difficult.'
children.prevalue: I for my part said If she were poor I would be at her feet if she were lowly I would take her in my arms Her gold and her station are two griffins that guard her on each side Love looks and longs and dares not Passion hovers round and is kept at bay Truth and Devotion are scared There is nothing to lose in winning her no sacrifice to make It is all clear gain and therefore unimaginably difficult

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Difficult or not, something must be done, something must be said. I could not, and would not, sit silent with all that beauty modestly mute in my presence. I spoke thus, and still I spoke with calm. Quiet as my words were, I could hear they fell in a tone distinct, round, and deep.
children.prevalue: Difficult or not something must be done something must be said I could not and would not sit silent with all that beauty modestly mute in my presence I spoke thus and still I spoke with calm Quiet as my words were I could hear they fell in a tone distinct round and deep

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: 'Still, I know I shall be strangely placed with that mountain nymph Liberty. She is, I suspect, akin to that Solitude which I once wooed, and from which I now seek a divorce. These Oreads are peculiar. They come upon you with an unearthly charm, like some starlight evening; they inspire a wild but not warm delight; their beauty is the beauty of spirits; their grace is not the grace of life, but of seasons or scenes in nature. Theirs is the dewy bloom of morning, the languid flush of evening, the peace of the moon, the changefulness of clouds. I want and will have something different. This elfish splendour looks chill to my vision, and feels frozen to my touch. I am not a poet; I cannot live with abstractions. You, Miss Keeldar, have sometimes, in your laughing satire, called me a material philosopher, and implied that I live sufficiently for the substantial. Certainly I feel material from head to foot; and glorious as Nature is, and deeply as I worship her with the solid powers of a solid heart, I would rather behold her through the soft human eyes of a loved and lovely wife than through the wild orbs of the highest goddess of Olympus.'
children.prevalue: Still I know I shall be strangely placed with that mountain nymph Liberty She is I suspect akin to that Solitude which I once wooed and from which I now seek a divorce These Oreads are peculiar They come upon you with an unearthly charm like some starlight evening they inspire a wild but not warm delight their beauty is the beauty of spirits their grace is not the grace of life but of seasons or scenes in nature Theirs is the dewy bloom of morning the languid flush of evening the peace of the moon the changefulness of clouds I want and will have something different This elfish splendour looks chill to my vision and feels frozen to my touch I am not a poet I cannot live with abstractions You Miss Keeldar have sometimes in your laughing satire called me a material philosopher and implied that I live sufficiently for the substantial Certainly I feel material from head to foot and glorious as Nature is and deeply as I worship her with the solid powers of a solid heart I would rather behold her through the soft human eyes of a loved and lovely wife than through the wild orbs of the highest goddess of Olympus

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'Juno could not cook a buffalo steak as you like it,' said she.
children.prevalue: Juno could not cook a buffalo steak as you like it said she

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: 'She could not; but I will tell you who could    some young, penniless, friendless orphan girl. I wish I could find such a one    pretty enough for me to love, with something of the mind and heart suited to my taste; not uneducated    honest and modest. I care nothing for attainments, but I would fain have the germ of those sweet natural powers which nothing acquired can rival; any temper Fate wills    I can manage the hottest. To such a creature as this I should like to be first tutor and then husband. I would teach her my language, my habits and my principles, and then I would reward her with my love.'

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: '  Reward   her, lord of the creation      reward   her!' ejaculated she, with a curled lip.
children.prevalue: Reward her lord of the creation reward her ejaculated she with a curled lip

children.name: Paragraph_43

children.prevalue: And be repaid a thousandfold

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: 'If she willed it, monseigneur.'
children.prevalue: If she willed it monseigneur

children.value: 'And she   should   will it.'
children.prevalue: And she should will it

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: 'You have stipulated for any temper Fate wills. Compulsion is flint and a blow to the metal of some souls.'
children.prevalue: You have stipulated for any temper Fate wills Compulsion is flint and a blow to the metal of some souls

children.name: Paragraph_47

children.prevalue: And love the spark it elicits

children.name: Paragraph_48

children.prevalue: Who cares for the love that is but a spark seen flown upward and gone

children.prevalue: I must find my orphan girl Tell me how Miss Keeldar

children.prevalue: Advertise and be sure you add when you describe the qualifications she must be a good plain cook

children.prevalue: Not you and her voice took a sudden accent of peculiar scorn

children.name: Paragraph_53

children.name: Paragraph_54

children.prevalue: Why doubt it

children.value: '  You   marry!'
children.prevalue: You marry

children.name: Paragraph_56

children.prevalue: Yes of course nothing more evident than that I can and shall

children.name: Paragraph_57

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: She charmed me in this mood    waxing disdainful, half insulting; pride, temper, derision, blent in her large fine eye, that had just now the look of a merlin's.
children.prevalue: She charmed me in this mood waxing disdainful half insulting pride temper derision blent in her large fine eye that had just now the look of a merlin s

children.prevalue: Favour me with your reasons for such an opinion Miss Keeldar

children.prevalue: How what

children.value: I now felt, and looked, and spoke eagerly. I was unwise to quit my sheet  anchor of calm even for an instant; it deprived me of an advantage and transferred it to her. The little spark of temper dissolved in sarcasm, and eddied over her countenance in the ripples of a mocking smile.

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: 'Only show me where.'

children.value: 'Any stout widow that has had a few husbands already, and can manage these things.'
children.prevalue: Any stout widow that has had a few husbands already and can manage these things

children.prevalue: Never would you have gathered the produce of the gold bearing garden You have not courage to confront the sleepless dragon you have not craft to borrow the aid of Atlas

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'You look hot and haughty.'

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: 'And you far haughtier. Yours is the monstrous pride which counterfeits humility.'
children.prevalue: And you far haughtier Yours is the monstrous pride which counterfeits humility

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: 'I am a dependant; I know my place.'
children.prevalue: I am a dependant I know my place

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: 'I am a woman; I know mine.'
children.prevalue: I am a woman I know mine

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: 'I am poor; I must be proud.'
children.prevalue: I am poor I must be proud

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: 'I have received ordinances, and own obligations stringent as yours.'
children.prevalue: I have received ordinances and own obligations stringent as yours

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: We had reached a critical point now, and we halted and looked at each other.   She   would not give in, I felt. Beyond this I neither felt nor saw. A few moments yet were mine. The end was coming    I heard its rush    but not come. I would dally, wait, talk, and when impulse urged I would act. I am never in a hurry; I never was in a hurry in my whole life. Hasty people drink the nectar of existence scalding hot; I taste it cool as dew. I proceeded: 'Apparently, Miss Keeldar, you are as little likely to marry as myself. I know you have refused three    nay, four    advantageous offers, and, I believe, a fifth. Have you rejected Sir Philip Nunnely?'

children.prevalue: I put this question suddenly and promptly

children.name: Paragraph_80

children.prevalue: Did you think I should take him

children.value: 'On what grounds, may I ask?'
children.prevalue: On what grounds may I ask

children.value: 'Conformity of rank, age, pleasing contrast of temper    for   he   is mild and amiable    harmony of intellectual tastes.'

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: 'A beautiful sentence! Let us take it to pieces. Conformity of rank. He is quite above me. Compare my grange with his palace, if you please. I am disdained by his kith and kin. Suitability of age. We were born in the same year; consequently he is still a boy, while I am a woman    ten years his senior to all intents and purposes. Contrast of temper. Mild and amiable, is he; I    what? Tell me.'

children.value: 'Leading and improving! teaching and tutoring! bearing and forbearing! Pah! my husband is not to be my baby. But it is like a tutor to talk of the satisfaction of teaching. I suppose   you   think it the finest employment in the world. I don't. I reject it. Improving a husband! No. I shall insist upon my husband improving me, or else we part.'
